LEAD: President Bush announced that the troops sent for the invasion of Panama last month would be brought back to the United States ''well before the end of February.''

Seoul Officials See Accord on U.S. Troop Cut
LEAD: Senior Government officials said today that they ''fully expect'' to reach an agreement with the United States this year for the largest withdrawal of American military personnel from South Korea since the end of the Vietnam War.

Northrop Sale Of Properties
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell two office buildings, one of which houses its corporate headquarters, and another 53-acre site.
The price of the sales is more than $250 million.


English Ballet Dismisses Its Director
LEAD: Peter Schaufuss, the Danish artistic director of the English National Ballet, was dismissed Tuesday because of ''irreconcilable differences'' between him and the company's board.


Stop Destroying Files, Poland Says to Police
LEAD: The Government ordered police and security officers today to halt any destruction of files and other official records.


Defense Seems to Admit Gotti Role as Mob Boss
LEAD: Trying to chip away at vital prosecution evidence, John Gotti's chief counsel appeared yesterday to concede tacitly that Mr.
Gotti was heard on tapes directing affairs for the Gambino organization, reputed to be the largest crime family in the nation.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Sunday about skaters at the Wollman rink in Manhattan misstated the location of the buildings at the rear.
They were on Central Park South, not Central Park West.

Atlanta Trial Focusing on Color-Bias Charge
LEAD: A light-skinned black woman who contends she was dismissed as a clerk-typist because of her color said her darker-skinned supervisor told her that her life was too easy, the plaintiff's lawyer said in opening arguments Tuesday in the woman's discrimination suit in Federal District Court.


Hollinger Stake In Paper Chain
LEAD: The chief executive of Hollinger Inc. said Tuesday that the Canadian newspaper chain wanted to continue raising its stake in United Newspapers P.L.C. but was not planning a hostile takeover bid for the giant British publisher.
The chief executive, David


Ex-Navajo Leader Is Facing 3 Criminal Trials
LEAD: A Navajo tribal judge today ordered Peter MacDonald Sr., the suspended Navajo chairman, to face three criminal trials instead of a single trial on 107 criminal counts.


Alexander Schiff, 90; Was Ringside Doctor
LEAD: Dr.
Alexander Schiff, a longtime physician for the New York State Athletic Commission and president of the Actors' Temple, died Monday at the White Plains Hospital.
He was 90 years old.


Cloth Diapers, Brought to Your Door
LEAD: ''THE past year has been a boon for diaper services,'' said John A. Shiffert, the executive director of the National Association of Diaper Services, a trade group based in Philadelphia.
Why? ''Because disposable diapers are a symbol of the solid-waste crisis,'' Mr.
Shiffert said. ''Cotton diapers are the original curbside recyclables.


Georgia Gulf To Get NL Bid
LEAD: NL Industries, the Houston-based commodity chemical maker that has been seeking to maximize the value of its investment in the Georgia Gulf Corporation, announced today that it intends to make a $45-a-share cash tender offer for the Atlanta-based chemical company by next Wednesday.


Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   Bulgaria Opposition Rebuffs Communists On Sharing Power
LEAD: Bulgaria's opposition today rejected a Communist offer to share power before the first free elections in more than four decades.


Abortion Foes Gain in Wisconsin Assembly Vote
LEAD: One chamber of Wisconsin's Legislature approved a bill early today requiring minors to get parental consent before having abortions and defeated an effort to repeal a law that penalizes doctors who perform abortions.


Milton Gordon, 82, An Early Producer Of Television Shows
LEAD: Milton A. Gordon, a financier and early producer of television features and series, died of a heart attack yesterday at New York Hospital.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Reviews/Television;   '27 Wagons Full of Cotton,' Tennessee Williams Drama
LEAD: The Arts &amp; Entertainment Network seems a bit nervous about ''27 Wagons Full of Cotton,'' the Tennessee Williams play that concludes (tonight at 9) the first batch of monthly one-acters being presented on the new ''American Playwrights Theater.'' Although the first to be produced for the series, this play is the last of four to be shown.


Take Some Junk, Let It Rust, Then Bring It Home
LEAD: THE age of the anti-antique is here.


Treasury Prices Move Up Again
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher for the second straight session yesterday, as bargain-hunters bought securities that had been battered over the last six weeks.
Gains of as much as a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, were recorded.


Unisys Products For Sending Data
LEAD: Timeplex Inc., a subsidiary of the Unisys Corporation, announced new products to connect computers that it said were vastly quicker at transferring data than existing systems were.
Timeplex said its computer networking products could speed the time of transferring complex computer data - for example, a three-dimensional representation of a product would take 30 seconds, compared with the current 12 to 15 minutes.


F. W. Winterbotham, British Code Expert, 92
LEAD: Group Capt.
F.
W.
Winterbotham, who played a key role in exploiting broken German codes in World War II and wrote the best-selling memoir ''The Ultra Secret,'' died on Sunday, British news reports said today.
He was 92 years old.


An Apparent Test for Cancer Relapse
LEAD: A protein secreted by tumor cells can indicate whether women will have a recurrence of breast cancer, researchers report.


Ohio Mattress To Leo Burnett
LEAD: The Ohio Mattress Company, the Cleveland-based manufacturer and marketer of Sealy bedding products, gave its $5 million-plus advertising account to Leo Burnett in Chicago.

LEAD: David Wolper, the executive producer of ''Murder in Mississippi,'' a new television movie that NBC will broadcast on Monday at 9 P.M., insists that his film is ''completely different'' from ''Mississippi Burning,'' the 1988 film about the murder of three civil rights workers 26 years ago. '' 'Mississippi Burning' begins where our story ends,'' Mr.


Dallas Jury Convicts Woman For Counterfeit Coupon Plot
LEAD: A woman with a passion for clipping coupons and proof-of-purchase seals has been convicted of dealing in counterfeit coupons in a $2 million scheme.


M.T.A. Appealing U.S. Judge's Ruling On Subway Begging
LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday sought to restore its rule against panhandling in the subways, appealing a Federal Judge's ruling that the ban was unconstitutional.


Bridge
LEAD: One of America's leading players, Nancy Gruver of Ellicott, City, Md., died on Sunday at the age of 78.
In a distinguished career, she won 14 national titles and came close to world titles three times.


Trees That Droop, Ever So Sculpturally
LEAD: THE 150-year-old weeping Camperdown elm in Prospect Park in Brooklyn stands a mere 12 feet high, but its intricate pattern of branches etches a 25-foot circle.


Philip Morris's Profit Jumps On Sale of Rothmans Stake
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer products company, said yesterday that its earnings more than doubled in the fourth quarter, partly because of a large gain from the sale of its stake in a British company.


Home Improvement
LEAD: WHEN a circuit breaker governing a household electrical circuit trips or a fuse blows, power to the circuit is immediately shut off to reduce the chance of fire and injury from electric shock.
Restoring power by resetting the breaker or replacing the fuse is usually simple.
But care must be taken to proceed safely, and only after the cause of the circuit's malfunction has been corrected.


Thomas Blakeman, 80, Metropolitan Planner
LEAD: Thomas Ledyard Blakeman, one of the early metropolitan regional planners in this country, died of lung cancer on Wednesday at his home in Cataumet, Mass.
He was 80 years old.


Police Officer Is Attacked and Stabbed in Brooklyn
LEAD: A police officer was slashed and stabbed last night as he left the 84th Precinct station house in downtown Brooklyn to get a sandwich for dinner, a police spokesman said.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Avon Products Inc. said it had begun a joint venture with a Chinese partner, Guangzhou Cosmetics Factory, to make and sell its products in China.


College Panel at Work
LEAD: With an ambitous agenda aimed at curbing the excesses of prominent college athletic programs, the Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics held its first meeting here today.


Test Substances Halt Growth of AIDS Virus
LEAD: Scientists say they have created what appear to be the most potent substances yet studied for stopping the AIDS virus from reproducing, based on test tube results.


Acted to Protect His Son, 3, Says Man in Subway Killing
LEAD: Surrounded by his lawyers, a plumber accused of fatally beating a homeless man on a subway platform after the man attacked him said yesterday that he regretted the man's death but that he had acted to protect his 3-year-old son, who was with him at the time.


Federated Considers Taking Bloomingdale's Off the Block
LEAD: For the first time since it put Bloomingdale's up for sale in September, Federated Stores Inc. said yesterday that it might not sell the 17-store chain.


Market Place;   Can RJR Nabisco Keep Its Promise?
LEAD: WHEN RJR Nabisco Inc. was acquired in the largest leveraged buyout ever, the buyers were betting on more than the health of the food and cigarette businesses.
They were betting billions on the continued health of the ''junk bond'' market.


Bank in Northeast Sells Leasing Unit
LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation, scrambling for cash because of large losses from bad real estate loans, announced it had completed the sale of a vehicle-leasing business for $350 million.
The bank sold the United States portion of McCullagh Leasing to GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company.


Prices Paid To Farmers Increase 2.7%
LEAD: Prices that farmers get for raw products rose 2.7 percent from December to January, leaving the monthly average 2.7 percent above the level a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

Arnaud d'Usseau, 73, Playwright, Screenplay Writer and Instructor
LEAD: Arnaud d'Usseau, a playwright and screenplay writer, died of complications after surgery for stomach cancer on Monday at his Manhattan home.
He was 73 years old.


RICO Racket in the Senate
LEAD: The Senate Judiciary Committee's vote on a bill masquerading as a ''reform'' of RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, could provide the year's first indication of Congressional seriousness about ethics and public justice.
The bill would remove or weaken the strong civil remedies now available to victims of commercial fraud perpetrated either by mobsters or white-collar professionals who behave like mobsters.


Hornets Release Harter as Coach
LEAD: The Charlotte Hornets dismissed Coach Dick Harter yesterday and named the assistant coach, Gene Littles, as interim coach.

Record Industry Bargaining With the Musicians' Union
LEAD: The musicians' union and representatives of the North American record industry are negotiating the contract that will govern payments to the union on commercial recordings.
The current contract, which dates from 1986, expired yesterday and covers recording of all kinds, from opera to rock-and-roll.


Environmental Groups Told They Are Racists in Hiring
LEAD: Several members of civil rights and minority groups have written to eight major national environmental organizations charging them with racism in their hiring practices.


Samuel C. Phillips, Who Directed Apollo Lunar Landing, Dies at 68
LEAD: Samuel Cochran Phillips, an Air Force lieutenant general who directed the Apollo space program through the lunar landing in 1969, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif.
He was 68 years old.


Cosmetics Executive To Run Cartier in U.S.
LEAD: Simon J. Critchell, a cosmetics executive for the last decade, yesterday was named president and chief executive of Cartier Inc., the American subsidiary of the Cartier International Group, the Paris luxury jewelry and cosmetics company.

LEAD: Directors of the Aristech Chemical Corporation accepted a sweetened offer today of $27 a share, or about $877 million, from a group led by the company's management and financed by the giant Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan.


Man Faces New Trial in Molest Case
LEAD: Two weeks after a jury acquitted him of most charges of child molesting in the longest criminal trial in American history, Raymond Buckey learned today that he had to stand trial again.


Where Money Talks, New Columbia Heads Are Fairly Shouting
LEAD: In their first months as co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures Entertainment, Peter Guber and Jon Peters have raised the ante in one of Hollywood's biggest poker games - the betting of millions of dollars today on scripts that may or may not be tomorrow's hit movies.

LEAD: From poet to peasant, Rumanians who want to vent disappointment with the way things are going these days are turning increasingly to Romania Libera, the only major newspaper to take an adversarial role against the ruling Council of National Salvation.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: SIR GEORG SOLTI has commissioned four new works for his 22d, and final, season with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which will also be the orchestra's 100th.


A Portraitist's Romp Through Art History
LEAD: The woman of a thousand faces was pouring mint tea from a gilded Chinese teapot and talking about invisibility. ''I feel I'm anonymous in my work,'' Cindy Sherman was saying. ''When I look at the pictures, I never see myself; they aren't self-portraits.
Sometimes I disappear.'' Ms.
Sherman was talking about the photographs in her new show at Metro Pictures, 150 Greene Street in SoHo.


Group Drops Bid For Stride Rite
LEAD: A group of investors scrapped a $900 million takeover bid for the Stride Rite Corporation but refused to rule out another offer for the shoe company. ''We are meeting to discuss all options,'' said Stephen Walsh, managing partner of Walsh, Greenwood &amp; Company, the Greenwich, Conn., investment concern that led the takeover effort.


A Deserter, Returning, Is Arrested
LEAD: An American soldier who fled to East Germany in 1959, fearing that an accident in which he was involved would land him in the stockade, saw his family on Tuesday for the first time in three decades and was then taken away as an Army deserter.


Wells Fargo Official Is New First Bank Chief
LEAD: After a four-month search, John F. Grundhofer has been named chairman, president and chief executive of the troubled First Bank System Inc. of Minneapolis.
Mr.
Grundhofer, 51, had been a vice chairman of the Wells Fargo Bank.


Policy Shift On Bailouts Is Explored
LEAD: The chairman of the agency created to manage the bailout of the savings industry said today that the number of ailing institutions had soared to such an extent that the Government should consider keeping some of them open rather than taking them over.


Mirza Abdul Beg, 55, A Professor of Physics
LEAD: Mirza Abdul Baqi Beg, a professor of physics at Rockefeller University who helped verify that elementary particles like protons and neutrons are made up of smaller entities known as quarks, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 55 years old.


Charges Seen For Developer
LEAD: The General Development Corporation, a real estate developer based in Miami, disclosed today that the company, its mortgage banking subsidiary and members of its senior management are facing possible criminal indictments.


Leading Indicators Climb 0.8%
LEAD: The Government's most widely followed economic forecasting gauge rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, the biggest gain since April, the Commerce Department reported today.


Fighting Rages Between Lebanese Christian Forces
LEAD: Fierce street battles raged in most areas of the Christian enclave north of here today as thousands of troops loyal to Gen.
Michel Aoun moved to suppress and disarm the Lebanese Forces, a rival Christian militia.

LEAD: Deputy Prime Minister Frantisek Pitra, the last of the old guard Communist leaders left in power after Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution, resigned today as leader of the Czech republic, the official press agency said.

He is Paul Marer.

Immigration Policy Sends Blacks Back to South
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Computer Model Suggests Gravity Shaped the Universe
LEAD: In the largest computer simulation of the cosmos ever attempted, scientists at Princeton University have addressed the most perplexing question of the moment in cosmology: How did the universe evolve from an initially smooth state to the dense clusters of galaxies that stretch across the heavens today?

LEAD: While New Yorkers have become accustomed to beggars, if not accepting of them, visitors to the city may be surprised when panhandlers approach.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recognition that pressure is growing for German reunification was seized upon in West Germany today as the lifting of the last major obstacle to unity.


Profits Fall At 2 Steel Companies
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, and Armco Inc. the fifth-largest, reported lower earnings yesterday, reflecting softer demand for steel products and higher operating costs, the companies said.

LEAD: Connoisseurs of fast food and human behavior were doubly satiated today as anxious crowds of Soviet customers engaged in traditional pushing and shoving to place ''Beeg Mek'' orders at the nation's first McDonald's restaurant, only to be calmed by uniformed compatriots dictating that they have a nice day.


Gerald N. Lanier, 52, Entomologist, Is Dead
LEAD: Dr.
Gerald N. Lanier, an entomologist who specialized in controlling the bark beetles that cause Dutch elm disease and threaten forests, died of pancreatic cancer on Sunday at Community General Hospital in Syracuse.
He was 52 years old and lived in Syracuse.

Stakeout for News Gluttons
LEAD: Detectives staked out a newspaper box and arrested three people for taking more copies than they paid for, the authorities said today.
The stakeout on Tuesday was requested by The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette because of an increase in complaints of thefts.
Each of the three people arrested was offered a choice of being charged with retail theft or enrolling in a $50 course on the evils of shoplifting.

LEAD: Three ethnic Albanians were reported killed today in Kosovo, bringing the total to at least 16 since riots began last week in the poor southern province adjacent to Albania.


Washington Post Stock
LEAD: The Washington Post Company switched the listing of its class B common stock today from the American Stock Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange.
About 7,000 shares of the stock were traded on its first day on the Big Board, and it rose to $270.75 a share, up $2.25 from its close Tuesday on the Amex.


Hungary Can Take No Pride in Nazi Past;   Servetus Was Spanish
LEAD: To the Editor:


Generic Drugs Recalled After Questions on Data
LEAD: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company, a generic drug maker, announced today that it was recalling its version of a drug widely used to treat high blood pressure.
The company had been resisting the action for months.


Cuomo Vetoes Cable TV Bill
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo yesterday vetoed a bill aimed at forcing cable television companies to compensate subscribers for major changes in programming.
The measure was prompted last year when Cablevision, a company based in Woodbury, L.I., failed to provide viewers with sports coverage they had been led to expect.


Harlem Troupe's Dancers Being Laid Off Over Deficit
LEAD: Dance Theater of Harlem announced yesterday that it would lay off its dancers, technical staff and some of its administrators as of March 25, the closing date of its winter season at Kennedy Center.
The company has canceled a two-week spring season at City Center and will not conduct the annual summer session at its school in Harlem.

LEAD: ''Black Rain'' was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival.
Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 26.
The film, which is in Japanese with English subtitles, opens today at the Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets.

But no, not in India in 1990.

Baker May Meet on Israel-Palestinian Talks
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is close to opening negotiations with the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Israel that could pave the way for direct talks between Israel and a Palestinian delegation, Administration officials said today.


Taking the Opportunity To Play Hide-and-Seek
LEAD: For the White House, the State of the Union Message was just another golden opportunity to play hide-and-seek.


First Aid for a U.S. Agency
LEAD: Every American ought to be outraged about what is happening to one of our great public assets - the National Institutes of Health.


Apple's Chief Details Plans
LEAD: The chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc. said today that the company would develop new products and get them on the market faster in an effort to increase slow sales in the United States.


No Big Oil Walkout, but Maybe Small Ones
LEAD: Leaders of unionized workers at oil refineries and petrochemical plants decided against a nationwide strike yesterday but threatened to halt work at selected companies as a way to increase pressure on management.


Anti-Abortion Group To Close Headquarters
LEAD: The founder of the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue said today that the group would close its headquarters because of debt but that its affiliates nationwide would continue their activities.


2 Ex-Mexican Aides Charged in Slaying Of U.S. Drug Agent
LEAD: The Justice Department announced today that for the first time the United States had charged former high-ranking officials in Mexico with the 1985 kidnapping, torture and killing of a Drug Enforcement Administration agent.


In Oakland, Spaces Tailored To Life and Art
LEAD: WHEN Bruce Beasley moved to Lewis Street here in 1963, there were no sidewalks, no street lights and no trees.
But like any resourceful pioneer, he rallied his neighbors and soon persuaded the city to supply those amenities.


Bush's Plans for Troop Cuts Are Praised on Capitol Hill
LEAD: President Bush's proposal for further troop reductions in Europe won bipartisan praise on Capitol Hill tonight, kindling new hope among even his harshest Democratic critics for deeper cuts in the military budget.


Local School Districts Will Resist Fernandez on Vetoing Job Offers
LEAD: Local school boards in New York City will resist any attempt by Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez to veto candidates for local superintendent, a spokesman for the boards said yesterday, even as the Chancellor issued guidelines for the selection process.

LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that profits fell nearly 33 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 but rose almost 4 percent for the year, a third consecutive record.

Mr. Bush's Piggy Bank
LEAD: President Bush's budget dramatizes the sorry rate of savings in America.
With admirable candor, he concedes that the Federal deficit is responsible for most of the slack.
But he has no real remedy -only another year of nibbling at spending, and a pallid package of tax breaks for savers.


Reviews/Television;   How Alzheimer's Affects A Patient's Family, Too
LEAD: Tonight's affecting episode of ''48 Hours'' confirms that the sufferers from Alzheimer's disease include not only those whom it strikes but, very directly, their wives, husbands and children as well.
Some four million Americans now have the disease, which, as Dan Rather says, has ''no known cause, no known cure,'' and the number may go up to 14 million in the next 50 years.


Metro Matters;   From Rohatyn, Unlikely Praise For New Mayor
LEAD: David N. Dinkins was Felix G. Rohatyn's second, maybe third, choice last year to be mayor of New York City.
Now Mr.
Rohatyn pays Mayor Dinkins what appears to be the ultimate compliment.

LEAD: In his first State of the Union address, President Bush tonight proposed sharp new reductions in the number of Soviet and United States troops in Europe.
He said the cuts had been made feasible by the rapid collapse of the Soviet empire.

PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: The aromas of freshly baked bread, the air after a spring rain or a rose by any other name are lost to millions of Americans who have a muted or absent sense of smell.


Knicks' Cold Streak In Boston Continues
LEAD: Larry Bird and Robert Parish would not allow the Knicks' Boston Garden losing streak to end tonight.
Bird helped extend the streak to 23 games, 17 in regular-season play, by scoring the final 6 points in the Celtics' 97-91 victory.


Threat of 455 Layoffs in Westchester
LEAD: The Westchester County Executive said today that layoff notices would go out to 455 county employees starting on Thursday.
But county officials said that it was uncertain how many would eventually be forced from their jobs to balance the county's budget, or which programs and services would be cut.


Yankee Rumor Denied
LEAD: George Steinbrenner yesterday blunted rumors that he was preparing to hire Dick Williams as a special adviser with the Yankees, in part because the team's principal owner does not want to put pressure on his current manager, Bucky Dent.

Review/Film;   Liberal Old vs. Conservative Young in 'Flashback'
LEAD: About 30 minutes before it's over, ''Flashback'' begins to go to pieces, like someone who has overdosed on carrot juice and organic marzipan.
The movie becomes woozy and sort of distraught.
Until then, it's an engaging comedy about the confrontation of a superannuated flower child of the 1960's and a 26-year-old representative of the clean-shaven, cholesterol-conscious, fiercely conservative 1980's.

NEW TEST DETECTS A GENETIC DEFECT
LEAD: A new test can detect three-quarters of all adults who risk having children with cystic fibrosis, researchers said today, and more accurate versions should soon allow routine screening of every American for this genetic defect.


Smaller Weapons Industry Proposed
LEAD: For the first time since President Lyndon B. Johnson closed six reactors and six weapons production plants in the 1960's, the White House has proposed steps to make the nuclear weapons industry smaller.

Corrections Town and Gown Clash Over Zoning
LEAD: An article on Feb. 2 about a zoning conflict between Princeton, N.J., and Princeton University referred incorrectly to the university's objections to the borough's zoning procedures.
The university does not oppose submitting its plans to a public hearing and a vote by the Regional Planning Board of Princeton.
LEAD: The people of Murray Place are fond of their neighbor Princeton University, with its fine buildings and its feeling of quiet intellectual excitement.

The President's Two Worlds
LEAD: George Bush gave two State of the Union addresses Wednesday.
The first was a lofty speech about domestic needs, full of oratory and lacking substance.
This was the old George Bush, offering bright shining goals - cities without drugs, schools where everyone graduates, a nation bathed in civic virtue - but few new programs, and little new money, for reaching them.

Corrections
LEAD: Four recent articles in Business Day about the bankruptcy filing of Federated Stores Inc. - one on Jan. 20, one on Jan. 23 and two on Tuesday - misidentified the United States trustee who is overseeing the proceedings.
He is Conrad Morgenstern.


UAL Up on Rumor
LEAD: A rumor that the UAL Corporation's unions had met with bankers and were planning a $180-a-share bid for the airline sent the stock sharply higher yesterday.
The shares of UAL, parent of United Airlines, rose $8.75 each, to $129.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Bankers' unwillingness to support a buyout of the carrier contributed to the collapse of a $300-a-share offer last October.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Marketing Campaign By Airborne Express
LEAD: Airborne Express, which has refrained from active participation in the advertising wars fought by its rivals the United Parcel Service and the Federal Express Corporation, is joining the fray, with Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley as its new marketing partner.
The $15 million San Francisco agency would not disclose billings for the account.


Pinnacle West Debt Restructuring
LEAD: One day after Federal regulators seized its savings and loan subsidiary, the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation said today that it had completed a debt restructuring that would allow it to avoid bankruptcy proceedings.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: The former Surgeon General of the United States, DR.
C.
EVERETT KOOP, will receive this year's Harry S. Truman Award for Public Service.
The award is presented by Independence, Mo., the hometown of the former President, to an American with the qualities personified by Truman.


Rio Restoring Christ Statue
LEAD: Restoration of the Christ the Redeemer statue, cracked and chipped by years of wear on its perch above Rio de Janeiro, began this week, a city spokeswoman said today.
Some $2 million will be spent to restore the 125-foot-high monument, which attracts hundreds of visitors every day.
The work should be finished by October, in time for the 59th anniversary of the opening of the statue, the spokeswoman, Estela Elliot, said, .

Revamping Racketeering Law
LEAD: Brushing aside complaints from consumer groups, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved plans today to cut damages that can be awarded in civil fraud cases under the nation's major anti-racketeering law.


Post for Nigel Lawson
LEAD: Nigel Lawson, who resigned abruptly as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer in October, has been named a director of Barclays Bank P.L.C., the bank said today.
Mr.
Lawson, 57 years old, will continue as a Conservative Party Member of Parliament and also serve as a part-time adviser to the bank.
Barclays declined to disclose how much he would be paid.


Congressman in Sex Case Bitterly Attacks Critics
LEAD: In a bitter speech on the House floor, an Illinois Congressman declared today that the House ethics committee had decided not to take any disciplinary action against him after investigating charges of sexual improprieties.


East Germans' Dream Vacations Can Now Become a Reality


3 Outsiders Appointed To First Fidelity Posts
LEAD: Anthony P. Terracciano , who was named chairman of the First Fidelity Bancorporation in mid-January, wasted no time in asserting his control.
Yesterday, in his first day in office, Mr.
Terracciano appointed three outside executives to top positions in the company, the 21st-largest banking company in the country.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Officer at BSB
LEAD: Hoping to add creative flair to an agency that many advertising executives say has grown a bit stale, Backer Spielvogel Bates has apparently lured Peter Murphy from his post as executive creative director of Hal Riney &amp; Partners in San Francisco, advertising executives say.
In a novel twist, Mr.
Murphy, who left Marschalk/New York in 1986 to take the West Coast creative position, will take the title of executive vice presi-dent/copywriter at BSB.


5 Arrests in Ghana Plot
LEAD: Five men, including three military officers, were arrested after trying to destroy evidence linking them to a reported attempt to assassinate Flight Lieut.
Jerry Rawlings, the Ghananian leader, the Ministry of Defense said today.
The action followed the arrest of seven officers in November on charges of planning to kill Lieutenant Rawlings.


Stand on Police Killings Could Shape Lee Brown's Future
LEAD: Less than two weeks after being sworn in as New York City Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown is facing a test that could shape his relationship for years to come with both officers on the beat and communities alarmed by police brutality.


Judges Can't Agree About Illegal Evidence
LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the Yale football coach, Carmen L. Cozza, misidentified the college team that has played the most games.
The University of Pennsylvania has played the most, 1,105; Yale, with 1,052, is second.


Strickland Fumes As Knicks Prevail
LEAD: The Knicks played as poorly last night as they did in losing six of their previous seven games.
Fortunately for them, the opposition was the Sacramento Kings.


Allen Barke, Ex-Ford Executive, 86
LEAD: Allen Barke, former chief executive of the British subsidiary of Ford, died on Monday.
He was 86 years old.
The cause of his death was not given.
Mr.
Barke became director of Ford's product division in 1959 when the company's plants were being increasingly hit by wildcat strikes.
In 1965 he contracted hepatitis, and soon after his health forced him to resign.


Purchasers Index Posts 9th Decrease in a Row
LEAD: The nation's purchasing managers said yesterday that the economy declined sharply in January for the ninth consecutive month, despite strength in orders for exports.

Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current.
Aurora
** (Aug. 4, 1989), 60 East 49th Street (692-9292) - Aurora is a comfortable, and quiet restaurant appropriate for business meals.


Panama Crime Wave Shakes Faith in Police
LEAD: A growing crime wave in and around the capital in recent weeks, some of it the work of men carrying assault rifles, has stirred widespread worry about how soon Panama's new police force will be ready to take over law-enforcement duties from American troops.


N.C.A.A. Clears Ware
LEAD: Andre Ware's weekend trip to the Super Bowl as a guest of the Houston Oiler quarterback Warren Moon did not violate National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, nor did the Heisman Trophy winner's attendance at a party given by Moon's agent, the N.C.A.A. has ruled.


Gold Makes Quick Rebound From Wednesday's Plunge
LEAD: Gold prices roared back today after falling sharply on Wednesday when it was reported that the Treasury had asked the International Monetary Fund to sell at least a million ounces of gold to offset late payments by 11 countries.

Dennis McIntyre, Dramatist, 47; Wrote of Ills in American Society
LEAD: Dennis McIntyre, a playwright whose work examined the ills of American society, died of stomach cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 47 years old.
Mr.
McIntyre's latest play, ''Established Price,'' was staged at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven last month by Arvin Brown with a cast that included Jason Robards.

The Bush Style
LEAD: ''Style,'' said the Comte de Leclerc Buffon upon admission to the French Academy in 1753, ''is the man himself.'' He held that style was not an outer garment or mask, but was essence - that the way you organized and expressed your thoughts was the mark of the kind of person you were.


Europe Welcomes Troops Proposal
LEAD: Western European officials said today that President Bush's proposal to cut the number of Soviet and American troops in Europe was a positive move but also inevitable, given the political changes in Eastern Europe.


Mendelssohn Cycle
LEAD: Anthony Newman will play the complete organ works of Felix Mendelssohn at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 316 East 88th Street, on Sunday afternoon at 5.
Mendelssohn's organ canon includes six sonatas, composed in 1844 and 1845, as well as fantasias, fugues, chorale settings and individual movements.


Creditors' Committees Set
LEAD: Two committees representing the unsecured creditors of Federated Stores Inc. were formed yesterday by Conrad Morgenstern, the United States Trustee overseeing the bankruptcy proceedings.

Nicholls Shoots but Doesn't Score
LEAD: Bernie Nicholls's debut in Madison Square Garden had all the ingredients for a Hollywood ending except that the Rangers' flamboyant center failed at the fadeout.

Where Classics Are King And Theaters Their Court
LEAD: MOSS HART once wrote that the best way to get even with a producer is to talk him into doing an Ibsen revival.


AZERBAIJAN TALKS STARTING IN LATVIA
LEAD: With an air of low-budget pomp and protocol, political insurgents from four Soviet republics converged on this Baltic capital today to begin peace talks aimed at resolving the Armenian-Azerbaijani civil conflict.


Two Moves to Pluralism
LEAD: The Rumanian and Bulgarian rulers agreed to give up one-party control.
A 30-party coalition is planned in Bucharest, and the Communists in Sofia said they would seek a broad-based Cabinet.
Page A13.


North Stars Consider A Change of Scenery
LEAD: On the ice, the Minnesota North Stars' power play ranks seventh in a 21-team league.
In the front office, their current power play ranks among the most threatening in professional sports.


Market Place;   Ship Companies 'Born to Die'
LEAD: IN the late 1970's, after spending much of his career in real estate, Michael S. Hudner turned his attention to shipping, an industry that had suffered several protracted downturns but that he believed was due for a recovery.
In an attempt to persuade skeptical investors, he constructed a new investment vehicle, whose management would not be allowed to invest in new ships or other ventures once it had spent the original amount raised in a public offering.


Peru Rebels Kill 2 Officials
LEAD: Maoist guerrillas shot to death the deputy mayors of two Andean villages who were members of the Democratic Front, the opposition coalition of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, the police said.
The Shining Path rebels left notes on both bodies that said: ''This is how the new starvers of the people die,'' the police said.


Ottawa Orchestra
LEAD: Gabriel Chumra is to conduct the National Arts Center Orchestra of Ottawa in the New York premiere of Michael Colgrass's ''Schubert Birds,'' Haydn's Symphony No. 85 in B flat (''La Reine''), Schubert's Fifth Symphony and the Nielsen Clarinet Concerto at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M.
Richard Stoltzman is to be the soloist in the Nielsen.


New Name and New Age (Is There a New Party?)
LEAD: A cartoon in The Guardian recently depicted two women reading a sign that said, ''Communist Party of Great Britain - General Secretary Nina Temple.''


Univision Misses Payment
LEAD: Univision Holdings Inc., the New York-based company that operates the country's largest Spanish-language television network and owns nine television stations, said last night that it had failed to make interest payments due yesterday of about $3 million to its bank lenders and about $7 million to holders of subordinated debentures.


More Filers Settle
LEAD: Larry Andersen and the Houston Astros agreed to a two-year $1.95 million contract yesterday, and six other players who had filed for arbitration settled on one-year contracts.


Cherishing A Black Past
LEAD: ''IN the past 20 to 25 years, there has been a spectacular growth in the number of institutions that concentrate on one or another aspect of African-American culture,'' said Dr.
Mary Schmidt Campbell, New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs and the former director of the Studio Museum in Harlem.


Hungary Has Another Round Of Steep Increases in Prices
LEAD: Hungarians faced steep price increases for housing, transportion, phones, water and sewage today in the second wave of increases this year aimed at satisfying austerity demands by the International Monetary Fund.


Economic Effect of Cutting Troops in Europe Assessed
LEAD: Troop reductions of the type proposed by President Bush would temporarily disrupt the local economy in parts of West Germany, but would have negligible effects on the civilian economy of the United States, experts said today.


New Jersey Court Calls Breathalyzer Test Valid
LEAD: Breathalyzer results may continue to be accepted as valid evidence in drunken driving trials in New Jersey, the State Supreme Court has ruled.

Weapon in Drug War: Imagination
LEAD: A police radio crackled, ''Go!
Go!
Go!'' and two police cars converged on a man in a white hat in one of the city's highest-crime areas.
He started to run, saw the other car and froze.


Eye Care Chief Named U.S. Shoe's President
LEAD: The United States Shoe Corporation thinks Bannus B. Hudson did a terrific job developing its eye care business and has rewarded the effort: It named him president and chief operating officer.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Effort for Barbasol
LEAD: A television commercial for Barbasol breaks today, the Pfizer Inc. product's first new spot in five years.
Back then, Ally &amp; Gargano's ads for the inexpensive shaving cream won an Effie.
In Ally's new spots, for Barbasol's shaving gel, a wealthy young man sends his butler for shaving gel, and gets Barbasol plus change.


Review/Art;   Bob Thompson's Figures and Abstractions, Religion and Myth
LEAD: The painter Bob Thompson died in 1966 at the age of 28, having spent less than a decade getting all he could out of the New York art scene and the great museums of Italy and France, and putting it to immediate use.
It's hard to say if he reached absolute maturity as an artist; the exhibition of his work from the early 1960's at the Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery is often uneven.


SmithKline Price On Drug to Be Cut
LEAD: Under pressure from members of Congress to lower the price of Dyazide, its drug for treating high blood pressure, the SmithKline Beecham Corporation said it was cutting the wholesale price by 11 percent.
The new price will be 25.75 cents per capsule, the usual daily dose.
The company, based in Philadelphia, said the estimated price to consumers would drop to about 32 cents from 36 cents.


Chrysler Closing Set In St. Louis
LEAD: In a surprise move that will reduce its car-making capacity by about 20 percent, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it would permanently close its suburban St.
Louis car assembly plant, laying off about 3,700 workers.

Pop/Jazz;   B.B. King: Making the Most of a Lifetime of Experience
LEAD: In 1945, when B. B. King wandered into Memphis and began his career at the age of 20, American music was mutating and proliferating as at no other time since the turn of the century.
Radio and records were easily available, and since the big bands were dying out as commercial entities, audiences hungered for the new, as long as it kept the pleasures of the old to remind them how far they'd come.

Soviet Aide Welcomes Bush's Troop Proposal
LEAD: A Soviet spokesman today welcomed President Bush's proposals to reduce American and Soviet troop levels in Central Europe and said Moscow was ready to discuss them.


Cuban Heads U.N. Council
LEAD: Cuba's delegate to the United Nations, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, took over the presidency of the Security Council today, the first time a Cuban has held the post since 1957.
Cuba was elected by the General Assembly late last year to a two-year Council term that began on Jan. 1, the first time it has obtained a seat on the 15-nation body since before Fidel Castro came to power in 1959.

Review/Music;   Rockabilly, Dangerously
LEAD: In the mid-1950's, rockabilly must have sounded noisy and frantic and sloppy and dangerous - just the way the Flat Duo Jets sounded Tuesday night when they performed at the Lone Star Roadhouse.
In the three-man band from Raleigh, N.C., Dexter Romweber sings old rockabilly sentiments - about girls who drive him insane, about loving them all night long - with the baritone drawl and chesty vibrato of Elvis Presley.

Corrections
LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday misstated the manner in which the 286 microprocessor handles data.
The chip, used in many personal computers, processes data in bundles of 16 characters, or 16 bytes.


Budget for the Space Agency Sets a Broader Course in Exploration
LEAD: The proposed 24 percent increase in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget, which would be the biggest increase for any major agency, represents a critical step in expanding the nation's civilian space program, opening the way finally to building an orbiting space station, initiating two ambitious efforts in Earth and planetary exploration, and setting the agenda for space flight well into the next century.

LEAD: Asserting that New York City faces ''very painful consequences'' and sacrifices that could grow even more severe, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday presented a $27.8 billion spending plan that calls for tax increases and deep cuts in services to close a budget gap of more than $1 billion.

LEAD: The preliminary budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed yesterday is based in part on the city's ability to come up with $172 million in ''productivity'' gains in the next 18 months, including $40 million that still has to be identified.


'Tough Call' for Police on When to Fire
LEAD: In the adrenaline-charged moment before a police officer fires at a suspect, the officer must decide, often without solid information, whether the suspect is armed and presents an ''immediate threat'' to others, according to New York City Police Department guidelines and law-enforcement experts.


Review/Opera;   Second Round of 'Traviata'
LEAD: Verdi's ''Traviata'' has been performed 526 times at the Metropolitan Opera.
It is unlikely that many of the first 525 were as emotionally and vocally empty as the performance that tumbled through Franco Zeffirelli's overstuffed staging on Monday evening.
Even Alfredo Kraus, one of the company's principal assets these days, was powerless to raise the performance to a level of passable mediocrity.

Money Fund Assets Rise
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 493 money market mutual funds increased by $1.54 billion, to $384.60 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 149 institutional funds decreased by $708.5 million, to $91.71 billion.
The assets of the 243 general-purpose funds were up by $1.77 billion, to $129.78 billion.

41 Pathe Theaters Are Sold in Europe
LEAD: The Pathe Communications Corporation said it had sold 41 movie theaters in Britain and the Netherlands for about $233 million.
The buyer, Cinema 5 Europe N.V., a company owned by Fininvest International Ltd., will lease the theaters back to Pathe. French Love For Animals: Too Fervent?
LEAD: There are twice as many of them as there are children in France.
They consume more meat than all Spaniards put together.
They can be found in 55 percent of France's households: one dog to every three French families and one cat to every four.

Rumania's Rulers Agree to Share Power
LEAD: Bowing to pressure from opposition forces, the ruling Council of National Salvation agreed today to give up its monopoly on power and join with 29 other political parties in a coalition that is to rule the country until elections in May.


LEGISLATION EASES LIMITS ON ALIENS
LEAD: In yet another sign of diminishing world tensions, the Senate this week gave final Congressional approval to repealing a provision of a McCarthy-era law that bars foreigners from visiting the United States because of their political beliefs.


Britain Will Expel 9 Iranians Because of National Security
LEAD: The British Government today ordered nine Iranians, including the London bureau chief for Iranian Television, to leave the country by Feb. 9 for reasons of national security.


Review/Photography;   Photos by Peter Hujar, A Mapplethorpe Precursor
LEAD: Even before his death in 1987, Peter Hujar was known as an overlooked and underappreciated photographer.
His mostly underground reputation was based on his portraits of artists and writers and on his frank chronicle of the hip homosexual scene of the 1970's.
Because of his subject matter and his preference for square, black-and-white prints, Hujar is viewed by his most ardent admirers as a precursor of Robert Mapplethorpe.


Gillette Is Planning to Open A Plant in the Soviet Union
LEAD: In a bid to become the Soviet Union's major Western supplier of razor blades, the Gillette Company said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to build a $50 million factory capable of making 800 million blades a year, or 80 percent of the total exported annually to the Soviet Union.


Kingdom Hoping to Be 'Sharp' at Garden
LEAD: The indoor track season is half over, and Roger Kingdom has not run a race all winter.
Set back by the flu, he has been spending as much time at awards banquets as in training.
Tonight, he will make his season debut, in a meet in which he has finished second twice, third and sixth, but never first.

But he also gained a share of $1.7 million in proceeds from those operations, which are now frozen in Swiss banks.

Diphtheria Inoculations Set
LEAD: Health officials are preparing to vaccinate up to 20,000 Dade County preschool children after a 2-year-old boy died of a rare case of highly infectious diphtheria.
Diphtheria, which is marked by a serious sore throat, a thick gray-yellow coating at the back of the throat and a low-grade fever, is treated with a strong antibiotic, and a vaccine in use since 1928 is considered highly effective.

Economic Scene;   Four Pathways Japan Might Take

LEAD: Mono-unsaturated fats like olive oil may benefit the heart not only by lowering cholesterol but also by reducing blood pressure and blood sugar, a study in Italy has suggested.

LEAD: Henry Baker, a New York real-estate broker for more than 75 years and believed to be the oldest active broker in the field in the United States, died of pneumonia yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 99 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Experimental as Always, P.S. 122 Completes a Decade
LEAD: Performance Space 122 is calling its annual benefit ''Dress Up'' this year.
But the audience is not expected to arrive in tuxedos and tails or evening dresses for the four-day festival of new music and dance and performance art, which opened yesterday and runs through Sunday.
Instead, audience members are likely to sport anything from the latest in East Village fashions to blue jeans and work shirts.

Cup Winners Ready to Run Again
LEAD: A shift in racing from early retirement to longer careers on the track is becoming clearer than ever this year.
For the first time since the inception of the Breeders' Cup in 1984, all seven of the cup race winners are back in training.
Most of them, in fact, are just about ready to race.


Yugoslavia Sends Troops to Province as 6 Are Slain in Strife
LEAD: Yugoslavia deployed troops, tanks and warplanes today in Kosovo province, where six more ethnic Albanians were killed in fierce clashes verging on civil war.

At 15th St. Condo, an English Touch
LEAD: A new 23-story condominium called the Grosvenor House, at 22 West 15th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, may not have all the English embellishments of the London hotel of the same name.
But it apparently has enough to help it sell fairly well in a generally slow market.
In nine months, well over 50 percent of the units, 77 of 134, have been sold.


Diplomats Report China's Premier Will Visit Soviet Union in April
LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng of China is scheduled to visit the Soviet Union in April, in an effort to improve relations between the two nations, foreign diplomats in Beijing say.


Net Off 38.6% At Grumman
LEAD: The Grumman Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings dropped sharply for both the fourth quarter of 1989 and the full year, in part because of lower sales in its aerospace and electronics sectors.

Review/Film;   Tawdriness Is Emphasized in 'Mack the Knife'
LEAD: When the gangster MacHeath (Raul Julia) is saved from hanging by the theatrically happy ending of the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill ''Threepenny Opera,'' the film adaptation ''Mack the Knife'' emphasizes the change of mood by shifting its setting to the Queen Victoria Theater in London.
There, a well-dressed, well-heeled audience is seen enjoying this show more wholeheartedly than any prosperous-looking crowd ever should.


Foodbusters
LEAD: The American Heart Association is awarding its seal of approval to foods it deems beneficially low in cholesterol, salt and fat.
The Food and Drug Administration, stung by the trespass on its turf, has told the association to desist.
The unfitting shootout between these two custodians of public fitness at least draws attention to the deepening confusion over food health claims.


Top U.S. Drug Agent in New York Resigns
LEAD: Robert M. Stutman, the outspoken top Federal drug agent in New York, said yesterday that he would leave office at the end of the month and hinted that when he did he would criticize Federal drug policy.


Herbert Whyman, 76, A Real-Estate Lawyer
LEAD: Herbert Whyman, a Manhattan lawyer for more than half a century, died of bladder cancer on Wednesday at his home in Roslyn Heights, L.I.
He was 76 years old.


Bass-Owned California Unit Has Big Profit
LEAD: The once-troubled American Savings Bank today reported a large profit for 1989.
The California savings and loan institution was acquired by the Robert M. Bass Group just over a year ago in one of the Government's biggest bailout deals.


Chronicle
LEAD: Another addition at Harvard Law is $1 million donated by WALTER H. ANNENBERG, the communications magnate and former Ambassador, to supplement salaries of students and recent alumni entering public service.
The fellowships are $10,000 each.
The endowment was made in honor of JUDGE IRVING R. KAUFMAN of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, who has spent 40 years on the Federal bench.

Troubled Jet Lands Safely
LEAD: A Northwest Airlines DC-10 bound for Minneapolis with 108 people on board returned safely to Los Angeles International Airport today after the control tower reported flames coming from one of its three engines on takeoff.
The crew dumped the plane's fuel.
A spokesman for Northwest Airlines said a preliminary examination of the faulty engine indicated that a compressor may have stopped working.

The Editorial Notebook;   Mass Transit, en Masse
LEAD: Transit workers are often lonely.
The work of motormen, track walkers, change agents and many managers keeps them apart.
That makes all the more valuable the ''transit school'' conducted each year by David Gunn, president of the New York City Transit Authority.
He has just done it again, for the last time before leaving office at the end of this month, achieving the usual beneficial boost for managers and riders.

Michigan Star Idled
LEAD: After starting all of Michigan's 19 games this season and averaging 16 points a game, Sean Higgins will be sidelined three to four weeks with a stress fracture in his left foot.
The 6-foot-9-inch forward was injured in a 91-73 loss to Purdue Wednesday.


New Jersey Symphony To Perform in Ireland
LEAD: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has been invited to become the resident ensemble of a new two-week music festival this summer in Adare, County Limerick, Ireland.
Hugh Wolff, the orchestra's music director, will conduct the festival's opening concerts on July 13 and 14.
The program is to include Beethoven's Ninth Symphony and excerpts from his ''Creatures of Prometheus.

South Africa's New Era;   After 30 Years of Suppression, an Unquiet Black Voice Is Legal
LEAD: The unbanning of the African National Congress yesterday technically restored the organization to the status it had in the 1950's, when it was legal and led by many of the same people who still lead it today.


Review/Pop;   Modern Soukous of Zaire By Three of Four Etoiles
LEAD: Only three of the four Zairian stars who founded Les Quatre Etoiles -the singers Wuta Mayi and Nyboma and the guitarist Syran Mbenza -were on hand when the group performed on Friday night at Kilimanjaro; in the seven-man group, an Angolan bassist, Miguel, deputized for Bopol.
There were other letdowns, too, as the first set started typically late and was atypically short, less than an hour.

Jackson Asked Help for Donor, U.S. Aides Say
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson repeatedly sought meetings with Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp last year on behalf of an important Jackson fund-raiser and housing financier whose company has become the subject of an investigation by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, agency officials said today.


Chrysler Workers Skeptical On Detroit Plant's Last Day
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation shut the doors of its crumbling downtown Jefferson Avenue assembly plant for the last time today, amid an atmosphere of uncertainty among laid-off auto workers.
The 3,500 workers are awaiting completion of a factory less than a mile from the old one, and many hope to get jobs there.


Review/Pop;   Salute to Indian Film Music And a Mix of Styles on Loan
LEAD: Among the world's musical melting pots, the one that bubbles most merrily may be the Indian film industry, which turns out nearly a thousand movies a year, virtually all of them including song-and-dance numbers.
Composers of sound-track songs, or filmi, draw on Indian and Western classical music as well as any pop style that strikes their ears.

A Reward Fit for a King
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky has paid off handsomely for Bruce McNall, and the Los Angeles Kings' owner is going to return the favor to the National Hockey League's career scoring leader.


Chronicle
LEAD: A group of skaters, led by the Olympic champion KEN SHELLEY, have taken over Sky Rink, Manhattan's only full-sized indoor skating rink, and will continue to operate it as a nonprofit training center for figure skaters and hockey players, as well as for recreational use.
Sky Rink, which was built in 1967 near Madison Square Garden by the Skating Club of New York, went bankrupt in 1979, and the trustee who has run it has sought a group to operate it.


O'Rourke Seeks Westchester Budget Change
LEAD: The Westchester County Executive today proposed changes to the current $1.008 billion budget that would prevent the layoff of hundreds of county employees and save the Westchester County Medical Center's Psychiatric Institute, previously threatened with closing.


Prego's Potential Earnings Put at $30 Million
LEAD: An economist testified yesterday that Dr.
Veronica Prego could have earned more than $30 million in a normal career as a doctor if she had not been stricken with AIDS.


Corrections
LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday, and a correction in this space yesterday referring to it, misstated the measurement by which the 286 computer chip processes data.
It does so in bundles of 16 bits, not bytes or characters.
A bit is the smallest unit of information; eight bits equal one byte, the minimum necessary in a computer to define a character (like a letter or a number).

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
U.S. Takes 2-0 Davis Cup Lead
Brad Gilbert defeated Leonardo Lavalle in straight sets yesterday to complete a United States sweep of the two opening singles matches in first-round Davis Cup World Group play against Mexico.
Gilbert won, 6-3, 6-1, 7-6.
The United States is within one victory of winning the three-of-five-match event.

Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Question in Bucharest: Who's in What Party?
LEAD: To start a political party in Rumania these days, all you need is 251 members, about $1,100 in the bank, an address, a platform and a set of bylaws.
Those who met those requirements by Feb. 1 are today part of the interim government that will rule the country until the elections in May.

Bridge
LEAD: Perhaps the most confusing auction of the world team championships held in September in Perth, Australia, occurred on the diagramed deal in a match between Colombia and Egypt.
East-West bid and raised spades.

Review/Dance;   Debuts in All-Balanchine Program
LEAD: Major debuts studded the New York City Ballet's all-Balanchine program Thursday night at the New York State Theater, where several works were new to the repertory season.
Rather than spread many ballets out within a week and throughout the season, the company nowadays tends to cluster the same ballets in a short period, picking up with others later.

Woman Admits Role In the Fatal Beating Of Her Daughter, 5
LEAD: Abigail Cortez, the mother of a 5-year-old girl whose beating death in 1988 drew attention to failures in New York City's child-protection system, pleaded guilty on Thursday to manslaughter in the case, and a judge said she would sentence Mrs.
Cortez to 5 to 15 years in prison.


Going on 90, Joseph Fuchs Goes On Making Music
LEAD: ''Look at these hands,'' said the 89-year-old violinist Joseph Fuchs, demonstrating the flexibility of his fingers. ''These are not the hands of an old man.
I'd like to go on playing for a while.
I don't have any difficulties.
When I do, I'll quit, simple as that.
It's a matter of pushing against time, and I must say, time has been good to me.

That Clatterin' Town
LEAD: Peter Cohen, 43, was ''a model of the 1980's breed of bold young leaders of Wall Street,'' according to The New York Times.

Ohio Bank Buys Unit In Texas
LEAD: The Bright Banc Savings Association, one of the largest troubled savings institutions controlled by Federal regulators, was acquired today by the Banc One Corporation of Ohio, regulators announced late today.
The deal is expected to cost the Government $1.4 billion.


Jets' Walker and Giants' Anderson Among Free Agents
LEAD: As anticipated, Pat Ryan and Wesley Walker, a quarterback and a wide receiver with a combined total of 23 years' experience with the Jets, were among 22 players who were left unprotected today by the team and thus became Plan B free agents.
But Freeman McNeil, the 30-year-old running back whose salary is $965,000, and Marty Lyons, a 33-year-old defensive lineman, were protected.

Eveready Battery
LEAD: Eveready Canada Inc. introduced a low-mercury battery this week.
Eveready's plans to sell similar low-mercury batteries in the United States have not been completed, said Patrick Farrell, an Eveready spokesman.
Eveready said its new alkaline battery has a mercury content less than 0.025 percent by weight.

Besides being an actress, Miss Ross is herself a well-regarded concert pianist.
Impersonating the Venezuelan-born virtuoso, who was nicknamed the Empress of the Keyboard, she devotes half the evening to playing romantic war horses by Chopin, Grieg, Liszt, Schumann and others on a grand piano placed center stage at the Intar

Prices of Treasury Bonds Tumble
LEAD: Treasury bond prices tumbled yesterday, while notes and bills posted smaller losses.
Dealers said the market was on the defensive from the start of trading, largely because of mixed interpretations of the Government's employment report for January, which was released before trading began.

Armstrong said assertions of anti-Semitism had figured in the discussions - assertions they dismissed.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   A Slice for Each Guest
LEAD:
No wedding reception is complete without a cake.
Spring and summer weddings are being planned now, and the cake is worth researching.
Pastry shops quote prices according to the number of servings and the elaborateness of the decorations.
Catering halls and hotels usually charge a flat per-person price for a wedding cake, often including it as part of a package.

LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has disclosed that an employee of a long-delayed nuclear power plant southeast of here was dismissed suddenly three months ago after trying to report safety problems to Federal officials.

LEAD: Factory orders posted a second consecutive increase in December, rising 1.9 percent because of a surge in orders for civilian aircraft, the Commerce Department said today.

Instantly, two transformations took place.
The obvious one was that we had officially taken office.
The less-apparent one was that, in the perception of the public, we changed from ''us'' to ''them.

LEWIS MUMFORD: PREACHER, PROPHET, ROMANTIC
LEAD: ''One of our giant redwoods has fallen, and left a space we cannot fill by any quick plantation of lesser trees,'' Lewis Mumford wrote of Frank Lloyd Wright after Wright's death in 1959, and today we might use these words to speak of Lewis Mumford himself.
His death a few days ago at the age of 94 brings to a close a life of extraordinary breadth, sweep, ambition and passion.


All About/Cable Television Programming;   Fighting for Visibility in a Proliferating Industry
LEAD: Only a decade ago, there were so few cable services that marketing merely meant telling the American public that cable existed.
Today there are 54 advertiser-supported networks, which get their revenues both from commercials and from fees paid by cable operators.
ESPN, the sports network, and CNN, the Cable News Network, are by far the largest, seen in virtually all 55 million cable households.

LYNN HILL, CLIFFHANGER
LEAD: I was born in Ellenville, N.Y., in the shadow of the Shawangunk Mountains.
This is the first time I've ever heard them referred to as the ''Gunks.'' Yuppies must have coined the phrase without ever having listened to the proper pronunciation, which is SHON-gum, not Sha-wan-GUNK.
Don't ask me why, but they're our mountains, and that's what we call 'em.

LEAD: New Jersey should continue to ban self-service at the gasoline stations because in the dozen or more states where I have visited the gasoline price has not gone down.

She later learned that young Appalachian women crocheted such bracelets during the 1930's, raiding their grandmothers' sewing boxes to create Depression-era jewels.

Where Neon Art Comes of Age
LEAD: THE smile on the Mona Lisa at 704 Traction Avenue is all lit up.
Two delicate bands of neon - a squiggle for the upper lip and a small curve for the lower - are like brush strokes of light.
This Mona Lisa, with a dramatic yellow zig-zag above the left eyebrow, a chin outlined in uranium blue and strands of hot pink, yellow and blue hair cascading in a fireworks finish, positively glows.

Review/Music;   Taped Lecture by Schoenberg Is Concert Prelude
LEAD: This year's Focus series at the Juilliard School has been exploring the world of Arnold Schoenberg through his own works and works by composers who influenced him or who were influenced by him.
In the fifth installment, on Thursday evening at the Juilliard Theater, the student musicians offered a group of harmonically and dramatically edgy works that Schoenberg composed between 1941 and 1950, as well as gentler scores by Luigi Dallapiccola and Earl Kim.

Richard Wilson, 55, Tribal Head In Occupation of Wounded Knee
LEAD: Richard Wilson, the Oglala Sioux tribal president who was a principal target of dissident Indians who occupied Wounded Knee, S.D., for 71 days in 1973, died of complications from an enlarged heart and kidney failure Thursday at a hospital in Rapid City.
He was 55 years old.
The occupation of Wounded Knee, the historic village within the Pine Ridge Reservation, resulted in gunfights between the dissidents and Federal forces, with dozens of injuries and two Indians' deaths.

IT CURES WHAT AILS
LEAD: CHICKEN SOUP SEEMS TO BELONG to New York.
It is a curative, a panacea, a culinary medium.
Its aroma rushes from the doors of Jewish delis and waves like steamy ribbons behind the bicycles that deliver Chinese food throughout the city.
The scent of chicken soup lingers over kitchen stoops in the Italian section of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and above the homes of Greek families in Astoria, Queens.

Dried Porcini Enters Some New Waters
LEAD: WHEN a friend presented me with a giant bag of dried porcini mushrooms he had bought at the Rome airport, duty free, I thought it would be years before I got around to finishing them.
But soon I found myself using them more and more often, in a variety of different ways.
These powerful mushrooms have a strong meaty flavor that is wonderful in sauces, stews and impromptu pasta dishes.

The Effect of Balloons On the Environment
LEAD: Except for scientific or educational purposes, balloons should be eliminated from use outdoors.
Of course there is a sense of excitement (as noted by Erwin Lewis, in his letter to the New Jersey editor on Dec. 17) felt by each of us when they float overhead.
However, if only one bird or animal (including human) is injured through strangulation on the things, their use must be stopped.

Building a Bathtub Framework
LEAD: ENCLOSING a bathtub to give it the appearance of being set into a raised platform can transform a drab bathroom into a lavish one.
The project involves building a framework around the tub by using ordinary 2-by-4 or 2-by-6 lumber, sheathing it with plywood and applying finish material like wood paneling or ceramic tile.

MY JOSEPHINE BAKER
LEAD: There have been more than a dozen books written about Josephine Baker.
She herself wrote five autobiographies, a novel and a collection of fairy tales that expressed her vision of universal brotherhood.

An era of daring and deal-making at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. undoubtedly ended Tuesday night with the resignation of Peter A. Cohen as chairman and chief executive.
His replacement, Howard L. Clark Jr., has been chief financial officer at the American Express Company, Shearson's corporate parent.

Africa's Claim to Egypt's History Grows More Insistent
LEAD: THE poster that hung in a Washington classroom, ''Great Kings and Queens of Africa,'' was a work of pride.
All the figures were in heroic poses and all were black.
Like Queen Nandi of the Zulus, the Egyptian pharaoh Akhenaton and even Cleopatra had the broad features and dark skin tints indicating origins in Central Africa.

Richard A. Duszynski of Denver, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs.
Heinn Frederic Tomfohrde 3d of Smoke Rise, N.J.
A May wedding is planned.


Queen Closes the Games
LEAD: Queen Elizabeth II brought the curtain down on the 14th Commonwealth Games today and the 11-day, 57-nation event closed in controversy as one of the world's best-known runners, John Walker, made a sad and angry exit in front of his home public.


We Can't Take More of This 'Reagan Boom'
LEAD: To the Editor:


At Yale, the Return of the Carrillon
LEAD: ABOVE High Street on the Yale campus, Harkness Tower soars in neo-Gothic grandeur, as if seeking divine inspiration for a community of scholars.
After six months of silence, the tower's bells have rung again with the music of Mozart, Handel and Bach.


Reviews/Music;   A Collection of Rarities Conducted by Leinsdorf
LEAD: Erich Leinsdorf - now in town for concerts with the New York Philharmonic - has reversed the usual career cycle of wandering youth followed by sedentary maturity.
With a long history of music directorships behind him, Mr.
Leinsdorf has forsaken permanence for guest conducting.


AFGHANS: Now They Blame America
LEAD: AT FIRST, IT WAS A JUST A morbid whistling overhead, the sound of an antipersonnel rocket in the dying moments of flight.
Then it exploded in a shattering burst of smoke and dust.

LEAD: Mr and Mrs.
F.
Bosley Crowther 3d of Troy, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Miller Crowther, to Clinton V. Marziali, the son of Mrs.
Frank D. Brown of Herndon, Va., and Enrico Marziali of Washington.
An April wedding is planned.
Miss Crowther, who is employed by the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Va., graduated from Fluvanna County High School in Palmyra, Va., and the Woodrow Wilson Center in Fishersville, Va.


We Can't Take More of This 'Reagan Boom';   If Things Are So Good
LEAD: To the Editor:


SCHEDULE SHIFTED FOR THE SHUTTLES
LEAD: A delay of almost four weeks in the scheduled launching of the Hubble Space Telescope has forced the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to shuffle its 1990 space shuttle timetable, shifting one science mission from June to November and deferring a military flight until 1992.


U.S. Aid Just Dribbles In to Nicaragua Opposition, but the Sandinistas Profit
LEAD: A $9 million program to assist the opposition in Nicaragua's presidential election has encountered so many delays and bureaucratic obstacles that a Nicaraguan Government agency has received more money than the coalition of opposition parties supported by the United States, American officials say.

Toll in Timisoara Disputed
LEAD: A Government report said today that just 71 people died in Timisoara, where the December uprising against President Nicolae Ceausescu began, in contrast to initial estimates that put the number in the thousands.
Students at the western city's Polytechnic Institute said they did not believe the official count and would conduct a house-to-house canvass to interview relatives of the victims.


Some Suggestions For Better Health
LEAD: Robert Figlerski's essay (''Encouraging a Healthy Life Style,'' Jan. 14) advocates group calisthenics as a way of lowering medical insturance expenditures.

For New Health Chief, More Problems Ahead
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S new health commissioner will not get the usual honeymoon period.
Instead, the tenure of Dr.
Woodrow A. Myers Jr. is going to be something akin to instant marriage counseling as he seeks reconciliation with the advocates for AIDS services who are bitterly divided over his selection.


About Men;   What Do You Call An Aging Hoopster?
LEAD: EXCUSE ME, SIR, would you like to play a game with us?''


The Classic Conglomerate Wades Into the 90's
LEAD: It has a reputation for business aplomb, but Textron Inc., the Providence, R.I., conglomerate, is also a company that's found itself on the crest of trends.
Back in the early 1950's, when single-mindedness was American corporate gospel, Textron's founder, Royal Little, decided he needed a strategy to protect his cyclical textile business, so he invented the modern conglomerate.


Tentative Pact for Oil Workers
LEAD: The oil workers' union has reached a tentative agreement with the Amoco Corporation that is expected to set a pattern for negotiations with the oil industry nationwide.

New Orleans Mayor Is Easy Victor in Bid for a Second Term
LEAD: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won a second term in a primary today, capturing well over the 50 percent of votes he needed to avoid a runoff against his challenger, Donald Mintz.


Pastimes;   Bridge
LEAD: Tournament bridge is in general a democratic game with almost everyone permitted to play subject to occasional restrictions based on gender, age or, more frequently, past performance measured by some standard such as master points.


Currency;   Taking Mr. Greenspan in Stride
LEAD: The yen lost its punch this week, falling back to its level of 145 against the dollar.
As for the West German mark, it continued strong, but the dollar only moved down a little against it.
Suggestions from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that there was less chance of a recession seemed to have little impact.


Base Closings Seen as Opportunity Inside Problem
LEAD: Instead of just single-mindedly fighting the proposed closing of five Bay Area naval bases, local officials here are also considering how to acccomplish the historic task of converting to a peacetime economy with the least immediate pain and the most long-range promise.


The Debate On Self-Service Gas
LEAD: I find it comical, if not ludicrous, to read that safety is one of the factors in prohibiting self-service gas stations in New Jersey (''Debate on Self-Service Gas Lives On,'' Dec. 31).


LYNN HILL, CLIFFHANGER
LEAD: Congratulations on a superb article; Trip Gabriel's ''Cliffhanger'' (Dec. 31) just makes it for the end of a decade.
What fun to have the experience of climbing with Lynn Hill.
Her arrival in New Paltz marks a definite upswing for women climbers.
It's wonderful to be older and to have a younger woman as a role model.


On Great South Bay, Spring Comes in Its Own Sweet Time
LEAD: IT is a morning deep in February and the village dock on the Great South Bay is deserted except for seagulls.
Children are in school; adults are working.
The few baymen left are far out on the icy water.
They stand in flat wooden boats clawing at the bottom ooze with long, heavy tongs.
Silhouetted against the pale gray of sky and bay, their shoulders rock back and forth, back and forth, like men davening at the Western

Deadly Force
LEAD: Spend a night cruising the streets of the city in a patrol car, eyeing the crackheads and the hustlers, stopping for domestic disputes and suspicious characters, and by the time the sun comes up, there'll be one clear thought in your head: I'm glad I don't have this job.


New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: Two years ago Paul Hecht and his wife, Lynn Vogt, built a log cabin in the Muskoka Lake region north of Toronto.
Theoretically, that is.
Actually, Ms.
Vogt built it with the help of her father.


VENTURERS
LEAD: YOUNG MAN started his career as a makeup artist at a cosmetics company.
He worked his way up and, with $80,000 from the sale of his house, moved to California to invent his own line.
He ordered $500,000 worth of makeup and other products from an Italian concern that supplies the leading cosmetics companies, but when they arrived, the lipstick cases were smashed and the foundation bottles were shattered.

Chatham Association's Dues Structure
LEAD: The well-written article on the Chatham Fish and Game Protective Association (''From a Fish and Game Agency to a Friendly Social Center,'' Jan. 7) captured much of the flavor of the club, its past and present.

John's, a third consecutive Big East Conference loss was now the least of their problems.

POSTINGS: Park Slope South?;   20-Unit Condo for Brooklyn
LEAD: Even the most conscientious cartographers could not find Park Slope South on any map of Brooklyn.
But it exists in the minds of real estate brokers, according to William J. Kane, a Brooklyn developer, and who knows, it may catch on as the new more-marketable name for the area west of Greenwood Cemetery and east of Gowanus Bay that up to now has been called Sunset Park.
