At the Crash Scene, Disbelief, Disarray, Then Cooperation
LEAD: EMERGENCY teams in fire departments, hospitals and other agencies spend many hours every year reviewing disaster plans, but when Avianca Flight 52 crashed Jan. 25 in Cove Neck, with 158 passengers and crew members aboard, the same people who had drilled repeatedly and prepared continually for disasters were in disbelief that a catastrophe of that magnitude had actually occurred.


CAMBODIA FACTIONS SAID TO LINK ARMIES
LEAD: A memorandum prepared by the Cambodian Defense Ministry says the two non-Communist factions opposing the Phnom Penh Government are increasingly cooperating on the battlefield with their dominant ally, the Communist Khmer Rouge.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:
CROOKED HEARTS, by Robert Boswell. (Laurel/Dell, $9.95.) For the members of the Warren family of Yuma, Ariz., disappointment is such an expected part of life that they throw parties to celebrate their latest failures.
This novel is ''rich and vivid, an intriguingly busy view of the human adventure, the impossible family of man,'' Sharon Sheehe Stark said here in 1987.


World Markets
LEAD: While the Frankfurt Bund has been the focus of this year's excitement over investing in the future of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Bourse has quietly crept higher and higher, setting nine new record highs.
And this after 1989, a year it outperformed every other major market.


Two Sides in Angola Claim Rebel Stronghold
LEAD: The fate of an Angolan rebel stronghold remained unclear today, with both sides in the 15-year civil war claiming that they held the town.


Mr. Bush, You Must Raise Taxes
LEAD: At the end of 1989, as chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, I issued a report that concluded our top economic policy priority in 1990 should be eliminating the Federal budget deficit.
Unfortunately, the budget proposed by President Bush last week breaks no new ground in dealing with the deficit.


Question Of the Week;   Should N.F.L. Drug Testing Be Revised?
LEAD: In reference to your call for opinions on National Football League drug testing policies: the men playing the games today are big boys.
They all know the risks and dangers of using and abusing drugs.
I think the league should butt out and leave the individual teams to decide their own policies.
Those teams with weak policies will end up out of the game because of weak, debilitated and jailed players.


Outside Distractions Affect U.S. Performance on Field And Leave Coach Angry
LEAD: Bob Gansler, the coach of the United States national soccer team, made it clear today that he was losing patience with players who have allowed peripheral issues, like contract disputes, to affect their preparation for the World Cup finals four months from now in Italy.


PARTNERS CHANGE, ALONG WITH ATTITUDES
LEAD: Dance, the most sheerly physical of all the performing arts, has long seemed to offer an inherent though changeable commentary on gender and sexuality.
With its wordless metaphoric power, dance is capable of suggesting as much if not more than the relationship of two people sharing a stage in an aria or as characters who talk of their love.

Lifestyle;   A Satellite of Mars Mixes Cultures In the Red-Light Zone of Bangkok
LEAD: With the requisite amount of hype and hoopla, the principals of Mars in New York, the club with the ''Bladerunner'' look at Tenth Avenue and 13th Street, have opened a branch along Bangkok's street of shame, Patpong, and it is the most wholesome establishment in the neighborhood.


Editors' Note
LEAD: The Times today adopts the country name Romania, spelled with an o, in place of Rumania.
The o form is preferred by many Romanians as a reflection of their Roman origins and has been favored in recent years by most English-language publications.


'The Diary of H. L. Mencken'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Dried Porcini Enters Some New Waters
LEAD: WHEN a friend presented me with a giant bag of dried porcini mushrooms he had bought at the Rome airport, duty free, I thought it would be years before I got around to finishing them.
But soon I found myself using them more and more often, in a variety of different ways.
These powerful mushrooms have a strong meaty flavor that is wonderful in sauces, stews and impromptu pasta dishes.


Corrections
LEAD: A credit line in the Arts and Leisure section on Jan. 21 with a picture of Dylan Thomas misidentified the photographer, and a correction today on page 32 of the section refers to her incorrectly.
She is Rollie McKenna.

Translation Problems
LEAD: To the Editor:


Mendelssohn's Prophet Triumphs Anew
LEAD: If Handel's ''Messiah'' heralded the dawn of oratorio worship in England, and to a great degree in Victorian America, Felix Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' struck high noon with its premiere at the Birmingham Festival in 1846.
Even in these more secular times, ''Elijah'' appeals, because its beauty and dramatic vitality ring true.

The Executive Computer;   'I'm Sorry; My Machine Doesn't Like Your Work'
LEAD: Managers at most companies are required to give performance evaluations to their workers on a regular basis, usually at least once a year.
While some executives say they enjoy the opportunity to provide thoughtful, constructive feedback that will help the worker meet clearly defined performance objectives, others - the majority, perhaps - would rather go to the dentist.


A Protest Was in Order
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday on the right to bear arms misstated the annual number of murders in the United States.
In recent years there have been just over 20,000.

LEAD: Yes. It should be downgraded to a tropical storm.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: A surgeon at a hospital here has implanted in a human an experimental device made of a slender, hollow bundle of fibers that works like a lung in supplying oxygen to the body.

LEAD: Ethnic Albanian emigrants from the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo say that contrary to official reports, the conflict in the area is not religious or ethnic but a struggle for freedom and democracy.

Consumers: Battleground Emerges'']  continues to distort the truth about Cablevision.
Mr.
Carey replies that on a cost-per-channel basis, we are paying less in 1989 than we did in 1986.

Troubled Jet Is Brought In
LEAD: An American Airlines 727-200 jetliner with 63 people aboard landed safely at O'Hare International Airport on Friday after the pilot reported steering problems.
The flight originated in Omaha.
The pilot brought the airliner in with a back-up hydraulic system.
No one was hurt.

Review/Theater;   'Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread'
LEAD: A bakery is alive and atonal in David Ives's ''Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread'' as two women, Philip Glass and a baker rap their way through a devastating send-up of this idiosyncratic composer.
The play is the first of four in the Manhattan Punch Line's sixth annual festival of one-act comedies.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Sam Oolie of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janis Lisbeth Oolie to Peter Marshall Berk, a son of Mr. and Mrs.

Ships of Mauritius: Models of Fine Craft
LEAD: EVEN as travelers streak from place to place in jets, many are drawn back to the days of journeys by sailing ship, of crashing storms and even mutinies.
On the island of Mauritius, about 530 miles east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean, this fascination is created and sated by the island's popular craft of building model ships.


Lawyers' Objection Follows a Pattern
LEAD: I would like to thank the editor who brought us the funny story about the lawyers objecting to mandatory continuing education.
These are the same people who object to ''pro bono'' legal assistance in offices or courts.
These are the same people who have made it a requirement for other professionals to have continuing education so they can better serve the public.


GIRLS GROWING UP
LEAD: Thank you for the article on Carol Gilligan's work with adolescent girls.
I understand that it is a moral study, but I am surprised that there is no mention of the fierce female biological change that takes place at about 12 years of age.


TALKING: Landings;   Decorating Shared Areas
LEAD: IN many of New York City's prime residential co-operatives there is a semiprivate elevator landing on each floor - a miniature common area, often no larger than a walk-in closet, shared by only two apartments whose tenant-shareholders are normally given the right to furnish and decorate the landing.

Review/Music;   Laderman Pieces For Flute
LEAD: The composer Ezra Laderman celebrated his 65th birthday in June, but he is still collecting presents.
The latest was a concert of his flute music, presented by the New York Flute Club last Sunday at Cami Hall.
Mr.
Laderman is an amateur flutist and has written a good deal of solo and chamber music for the instrument.


McEnroe: Victim or Villain?
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


The Rush to One Germany Starts to Blur Europe's Map of Alliances
LEAD: IT had long been the common wisdom that East Germany could have no separate identity if stripped of Communism.
What nobody seemed to realize until recently, however, was just how true this was - how rapidly the ''first state of workers and peasants on German soil'' would disintegrate once freed of the Muscovite mold, how swiftly its citizens would reach out to the other Germany.


Campus Life: Berkeley;   'Squat or Rot': Students Fight Eviction Effort
LEAD: When the University Students Cooperative Association voted to close Barrington Hall last November, the 166 University of California students who lived there were given until Jan. 20 to move out.
The residence has a history of drug-dealing, poor maintenance and bad community relations, officials say.


On the Edge of the Universe With Hard Butter on Cold Toast
LEAD: THERE I was, trying to spread an intractable pat of butter across a rapidly disintegrating slice of toast when my wife suddenly asked across the breakfast table: ''Does the universe go on forever?'' Just like that, no warning, no preparation - metaphysics at 8:15 in the morning, and I hadn't even had my juice yet.


Seeking a Suitable Way To Approach the Issue of AIDS
LEAD: ''How do you deal with AIDS in pictures?'' asks Marvin Heiferman. ''Do you show those suffering from the disease, depress everyone, and let the audience gawk at a bunch of sick people?
Or do you try to raise issues and hopes, even though that may seem too politically correct?''


THE INTRIGUING POTENTIAL OF MOLECULAR SWITCHES
LEAD: In the annals of biochemistry it would be hard to find a more enigmatic and intriguing substance than the neurotransmitting chemical called serotonin.


When Murder Is on the Daily Agenda
LEAD: MURDER is a crime and thou shalt not commit it.
Everyone knows that.
Everyone who reads a newspaper also knows that people murder other people.


Surhoff Gets Contract
LEAD: The Milwaukee Brewers announced yesterday that they had reached a contract agreement with their catcher, B. J. Surhoff, and thereby averted an arbitration hearing scheduled for tomorrow.
The contract is for one year, but no other details were announced.

An Epic and Jazz: 2 Views of Black History
LEAD: CONNECTICUT has pulled out more stops than usual for Black History Month; in Hartford alone, half a dozen or more shows are scheduled.

Building a Bathtub Framework
LEAD: ENCLOSING a bathtub to give it the appearance of being set into a raised platform can transform a drab bathroom into a lavish one.
The project involves building a framework around the tub by using ordinary 2-by-4 or 2-by-6 lumber, sheathing it with plywood and applying finish material like wood paneling or ceramic tile.


15 Million or So More Chinese
LEAD: China's population increased by 15.77 million people last year, bringing the total population to 1.112 billion, according to the State Statistical Bureau.
The bureau's figures, reported today by People's Daily, said the natural population increase for the year was 14.33 per 1,000 people, up slightly from 14.2 per 1,000 in 1988.

Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows.
When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill.
This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem.
Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night.

On Two-Wheels in Italian Traffic
LEAD: THE beginning of love stays in memory, a vivid freeze-frame amid the flux of the past.

Confronted by the huge presence of a long-familiar icon, I gaped like a Visigoth fresh from the boondocks.

Building a Bathtub Framework
LEAD: ENCLOSING a bathtub to give it the appearance of being set into a raised platform can transform a drab bathroom into a lavish one.
The project involves building a framework around the tub by using ordinary 2-by-4 or 2-by-6 lumber, sheathing it with plywood and applying finish material like wood paneling or ceramic tile.

Ms.
Schwarzkopf was the high priestess of the lieder recital from sometime around the early 1950's, when her collaboration with her husband and record producer Walter Legge entered its most fruitful phase, until her gradual retirement in the later 1970's.

Sex, Drugs and Rock-and-Roll - Updated
LEAD: Eric Bogosian, the monologuist, writer, actor, is at a crossroads.

For Mr.
Bogosian, the show is a culmination, the final synthesis of the characters, attitude and energy he has created that has made him one of the shooting stars of the downtown performance art world.


Review/Dance;   Fagan's 'Easter Freeway'
LEAD: Garth Fagan's ''Easter Freeway Processional'' may well become a modern-dance classic.
The dance, created in 1983, offers a clear and vibrant look into Mr.
Fagan's unusual choreographic style and uses Philip Glass's music in an equally fresh way.
Mysterious emotion bubbles through its fairly formalistic surface.

FICTION
LEAD:
THREE-LEGGED HORSE.
By Ann Hood. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) Between the tuna casseroles, the women's magazines of yesteryear served up heart- and hearth-warming fiction.
The spirit of that fiction, nicely adapted to the changing social patterns of the 1980's, suffuses ''Three-Legged Horse,'' Ann Hood's third novel, in which Abby Nash comes belatedly of age, shedding her immaturity in the person of her footloose husband, Zach, for whom the summer of 1969 will never end.

Not All the Drama Is on the Stage
LEAD: BARCELONA is a city of innate theatricality.
It is a theatricality that springs, in large part, from the vivid contrasts that make Barcelona so engaging.
Laundry hangs from lines draped across apartment houses on some of the most cosmospolitan of streets.
A city plaza that bursts with Saturday night street-fair festivities, complete with the skulking ladrones and murmuring gitanos - petty thieves and gypsies - that tourists are warned about, is taken over by elderly men selling stamps and antique postcards on the sunny Sunday morning that follows.

LEAD: I was raised in a traditional 1950's home, where I was taught that to be feminine was to be caring . . . as well as to be coy, deferring and, frankly, dishonest.
Women had to get by in life by being seductive or subtly manipulative.
Too seductive, however, and you were ''loose,'' too manipulative and you were a nag.

The red-brick, Romanesque building, which opened as Public School 135 in 1892, then became the first home of the United Nations School in the 1940's, is now a shelter for homeless women.

LEAD: The Sumitomo conglomerate of Japan entered the Parisian silk scarf business with the purchase of a small stake in Hermes, the family-controlled group said last week.
Hermes, the former saddle maker that grew into a global seller of scarves and luxury leather goods, announced that Sumitomo had acquired a 1.2 percent stake in the company.


Market Place;   Who's in No Pain When the Flu Hits
LEAD: NOW that the Centers for Disease Control have labeled the flu outbreak a full-fledged epidemic in 35 states, it should come as no great surprise that drugstores almost everywhere are experiencing a rush for dozens of remedies to fight coughs and colds.


Headaches in China for Investors
LEAD: When officials of the Shanghai Center told the Chinese customs bureau that the complex planned to import 50 to 60 cars, they received a strange notice: for each model of a Japanese car it imported, it would have to bring in two extra samples.
These would be turned over to authorities for ''test driving.

LEAD: A listing in the Social Events column yesterday gave an incorrect time for a dinner and dance tonight at the Plaza Hotel sponsored by the Children's Hearing Institute of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital.

Father of Clay Pigeon
LEAD: To the Editor:


BAKER TO PROPOSE NEW AFGHAN DEAL DURING SOVIET TRIP
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is expected to propose to the Soviets this week an approach for ending the Afghan conflict that would allow President Najibullah to remain in power in Kabul for a transitional period before having to step down, Administration officials said today.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
THE ECONOMY
Many health insurers have quietly blacklisted dozens of types of small businesses and professions.
While some insurance companies have been accused of denying coverage to people in cities and occupations where the insurers contend the AIDS virus is most prevalent, the exclusions extend well beyond these groups.


Chronicle
LEAD: DR.
THOMAS Q. MORRIS has resigned quietly as president of the Presbyterian Hospital, New York City's largest hospital.
The hospital's acting president is HARRY J. BOLWELL, who is 64 years old.
A search is under way for a successor to Dr.
Morris.


FACTIONS CONTINUE TO FIGHT IN BEIRUT
LEAD: The battle for control of the 300-square-mile Christian enclave in Lebanon went into its sixth day today, as artillery duels between rival Christian forces killed at least 20 more people and wounded scores.


Carroll V. Newsom, 85, President Of N.Y.U. Who First Taught at 14
LEAD: Carroll Vincent Newsom, the president of New York University from 1956 to 1961 and a leader in educational television, died Saturday at his home in Dublin, Ohio.
He was 85 years old.

No Weddings On This Pier, Signs Declare
LEAD: The New York City government, which has signs banning everything from U-turns on streets to smoking in buildings, now has a sign banning weddings.


Nets Smothered By Lakers, 121-105
LEAD: Magic Johnson had 22 points and 13 assists and Byron Scott scored 22 points as the Los Angeles Lakers beat New Jersey, 121-105, tonight and extended the Nets' losing streak to nine.


A New Look For Softballs
LEAD: Softballs for amateur play will have a new look this spring.
Spalding Sports Worldwide, an athletic equipment manufacturer based in Chicopee, Mass., has started to market a fluorescent yellow ball.


Adrift, Angry, Hurt, Alone: Stories of 7 'Throwaway' Youths
LEAD: In midsummer, 21 young people at six youth shelters in five states talked with reporter about how they came to be there.
Counselors in the shelters either veirified the accounts or said they were consistent with the lives and personalities of the young people.
The stories of seven of the young people from four states are summarized here, and recent checks determined what had happened to them since the interviews.


South Africa's New Era;   Wife Sees Obstacles to Mandela Release
LEAD: The wife of Nelson Mandela today repeated that obstacles remained to her husband's release, despite President F. W. de Klerk's assertion on Friday that it was imminent.
But Mr.
Mandela's wife, Winnie, would not say what the obstacles were.


New York Post Hires Kirshenbaum &amp; Bond
LEAD: The New York Post has enlisted Kirshenbaum &amp; Bond to help it fight the New York City tabloid war.
The paper's previous agency, Ammirati &amp; Puris, resigned the account in September.


Sound Becomes the New Frontier for TV Ads
LEAD: A new Coca-Cola commercial probably has some television viewers thinking they are hearing things.
At one point during the spot, chirping birds seemingly can be heard flying overhead while the wind whistles through the living room.


The Editorial Notebook; Lessons of Nuclear Winter;   Impassioned Experts Blow Hot and Cold
LEAD: The horrors of nuclear war are hard to exaggerate.
That hasn't stopped proponents of the ''nuclear winter'' theory, who announced in 1983 that the soot from a large nuclear war would blot out sunlight and create weeks of icy darkness.
The result could be ''global environmental changes sufficient to cause the extinction of a major fraction of the plant and animal species on the Earth,'' wrote a group of eminent biologists in Science magazine.


8 Killed and 17 Wounded in Raid On Bus of Israeli Tourists in Egypt
LEAD: Assailants armed with rifles and grenades attacked a tour bus carrying a group of Israeli academics and their wives on a main highway east of Cairo today, killing 8 Israelis and wounding 17 others, Israeli and Egyptian officials said.


Harold G. Warner, Retired G.M. Director, 81
LEAD: Harold G. Warner, who rose from a job installing parts at the General Motors Corporation to become a member of the automaker's board, died of cancer Friday.
He was 81 years old.


Japanese Bid Seen in Brazil
LEAD: A group of Japanese businessmen has offered to buy Brazil's $115 billion in foreign debt in exchange for mining rights for gold deposits in the Amazon, the Brazilian newspaper O Globo said today.


Reporter's Notebook;   For Gotti Jurors, Long Isolation Under Guards' Watchful Eyes
LEAD: Today when summations are completed at John Gotti's trial in Manhattan, everyone will go home except the jury.
For three weeks the freedom of 12 jurors and four alternates has been severely restricted as the evidence unfolded against Mr.
Gotti.

LEAD: The Rev.
George A. Stallings Jr., who formed an independent African-American Catholic church last summer, said today that his congregation would encourage the ordination of women and allow birth control and abortion.


Rentals Give Skiers Variety And Room to Maneuver
LEAD: SKIERS are renting equipment in greater numbers than ever before.
This increase has been caused partly because rental skis, boots and bindings have been improved in quality and performance, but also because more people are trying the sport for the first time.
In addition, many skiers test different ski models before buying; others find it more convenient to rent equipment than to bring their own for ski vacations.

LEAD: Dance Theater of Harlem arrived in San Diego in mid-January to find itself suddenly without work because the local sponsors had run out of money.

Question Box
LEAD:
Boggs Bogged Down
Q.
Generally, if a minor league player has a decent season, he gets a shot at the major leagues.
Wade Boggs played six years in the minors and hit over .300 five times before joining the Boston Red Sox.
Why the delay?
A.
Blame it mostly on his glove and the bats ahead of him, as well as Boston's success with both during Boggs's minor league days.

Curtiss E. Frank, 85; Was Yonkers Mayor And Company Head
LEAD: Curtiss E. Frank, a lawyer who was a mayor of Yonkers, a publishing executive and the president of Dun &amp; Bradstreet, died of Alzheimer's disease on Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla.
He was 85 years old.
Mr.
Frank was elected to the City Council of Yonkers in 1942, and became mayor in 1944.
He resigned in 1949.

LEAD: The Mexican Government and its foreign bank creditors signed a historic agreement today that will cut Mexico's foreign debt burden by as much as 20 percent.

Mortgage Rates Rise
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.17 percent, up from 10.05 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.45 percent this week, up from 8.41 percent the week before.

LEAD: Kate Simon, a writer of popular, literate and vivid travel guides and two memoirs that were hailed by reviewers as lucid, lively and humorous, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 77 years old.

LEAD: A new study of domestic violence has failed to find any patterns or indicators to help the police anticipate which of thousands of violent incidents reported annually are most likely to result in a killing.

LEAD: A 6-year-old boy who was one of 36 children injured in a school bus accident last week died of severe head injuries today.
The boy, Joseph Ribaudo of Monroe, was pronounced brain dead at 2:55 P.M., said Barry Bowman, director of public relations at the Westchester County Medical Center here.
Joseph is the only child to die from the accident on Tuesday in the Orange County town of Monroe.

TENNIS
Italy Eliminates Sweden From Cup
Paolo Cane defeated Mats Wilander in the fifth set of a 4-hour-37-minute marathon completed yesterday in Cagliari on the Italian island of Sardinia, and as a result, Italy knocked Sweden out of Davis Cup competition.
Cane won, 6-4, 3-6, 4-6, 7-5, 7-5, in a match suspended because of darkness Sunday with the players tied at two sets each.

Dream Song
The Life of John Berryman
By Paul Mariani
Illustrated. 519 pages. William Morrow &amp; Company. $29.95.
I consider a song will be as humming-bird
swift, down-light, missile-metal-hard, &amp; strange
as the world of anti-matter
where they are wondering: does time run backward -
which the poet thought was true; Scarlatti-supple;
but can Henry write it?

Tailored city shorts, cuffed or uncuffed and ending an inch or two above the knees, have caught the fancy of women across the country.
An alternate to either a short, slim skirt or regular pants, they are sportier than the skirt and kickier than the pants.

Honda Asked To Sell Jeeps To Japanese
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company said today that the Chrysler Corporation had asked it to sell Jeep recreational vehicles in Japan, and some Honda officials hinted that they were likely to strike an agreement soon.


Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   What They Don't Know
LEAD: To the Editor:


Taxes May Increase, Trenton Warns
LEAD: The Florio administration said today that the state faces a $550 million deficit this fiscal year and that the Governor is contemplating tax increases despite his pledge as a candidate last year that none were needed.


Radio Deal in Honolulu
LEAD: The Bedford Broadcasting Company announced Friday that it had agreed to buy the Honolulu radio stations KSSK-AM and KSSK-FM from the Heftel Broadcasting Company of Hawaii.
Terms of the sale, which must be approved by the Federal Communications Commission, were not disclosed.
Bedford also owns four newspapers in Southern California and a company in San Francisco that publishes books on the arts.


Moscow and Pretoria News Lifts Precious Metals Prices
LEAD: Precious metals prices continued to rise yesterday in reaction to developments in South Africa and the Soviet Union.
Dealers said a further decline in the dollar against the yen and the West German mark also bolstered the gold market.


A $15 Million Penalty for Laundering
LEAD: In the first case involving laundering drug money brought by the United States against a large bank, a Federal judge in Tampa today ordered two subsidiaries of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International to forfeit $15 million, the largest penalty ever assessed against a bank.

Chronicle
LEAD: Two prospective governors declared their candidacies yesterday.
If elected, one would be the first woman to serve as Governor of California and the other the first black to be Governor of Georgia.


Strawberry's Case Delayed
LEAD: One of Darryl Strawberry's problems was eased yesterday when the city attorney's office in Los Angeles indefinitely delayed a scheduled hearing into the police report on Strawberry's arrest following a fight with his wife on Jan. 26.


Daimler Ends Talks on Sale
LEAD: Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that it had broken off talks with a consortium about the sale of its navy and missile technology lines.


Probert Finishes Term
LEAD: After serving a three-month prison term on a cocaine smuggling charge, Bob Probert of the Detroit Red Wings yesterday was released from a Federal prison hospital in Rochester, Minn.
He will spend another three months in a halfway house, according to his lawyer, Harold Fried.


The Sandinista Machine vs. Avid Opponents
LEAD: Less than three weeks before national elections here, diplomats say the campaign has become a showdown between the organizational skills of the Sandinista Front and the disorganized but energetic rallies of Government opponents.


Visitors to U.S. Expected To Increase 75% in Decade
LEAD: The number of visitors to the United States will increase more than 75 percent by the end of the decade from last year's 38 million visitors, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: The Government showed the Czechoslovak public one of its proudest achievements today.
It was a massive building that takes up most of a city block, and it was totally deserted.

Correction
LEAD: An obituary on Thursday about Samuel C. Phillips, a former director of the Apollo space program, misstated his last rank and military assignment.
When he retired in 1975, he was a four-star general and commander of the Air Force Systems Command.

On Horse Racing;   Aiming at Rebuilding A Trainer's Spirit
LEAD: rrShug McGaughey left Gulfstream Park on Nov. 6 with two Breeders' Cup victories and a broken spirit.
Two days earlier, the trainer for the Phipps Stable had come within a neck of the greatest afternoon of training in American racing history.
After sending out Dancing Spree to win the $1 million Sprint and Rhythm to win the $1 million Juvenile, McGaughey was odds-on to add the $3 million Classic with Easy Goer.

A prominent physician involved in drug control said use of the drug was allowed sometimes in training, but never in competition.

G.M. Class E Dividend Up
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation today increased its class E stock dividend by 17 percent and split the stock, 2 for 1, because of growth in non-G.M. computer business at the auto maker's Electronic Data Systems Corporation subsidiary.


Showdown for Democracy in the House
LEAD: Imagine an American Presidential election where about half the eligible voters stayed home.
That actually happened in 1988.
The trend in non-Presidential years is even more lamentable.
In 1986, the last midterm election, non-voters outnumbered voters by about 40 million.
One fundamental problem is that fully one-third of all eligible voters aren't even registered.


Baseball Owners and Players at Impasse Over Almost Everything
LEAD: They met for five hours and could report agreement only on a labor-management committee that will meet three times a year and discuss labor relations issues.
That's after they have a new collective-bargaining agreement.

Cooper Acquires 6.26% of Anacomp
LEAD: The Cooper Companies. a Palo Alto, Calif., contact lens concern, acquired a 6.26 percent stake in Anacomp Inc. and said it would like to discuss a business combination with the management of the Indianapolis-based software and data processing concern.
Anacomp reacted strongly against Cooper's suggestion, which was included in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.


Ease Comes at Expense of Speed
LEAD: MICROPHONE II version 3.0, an updated communication software package for Apple Macintosh computers, is a lot like the Stealth bomber.
It was designed to be extremely powerful and practically invisible.
The user can press a single button to put the software on automatic pilot, turning it loose to perform a variety of defined tasks.


TURKEY SENSITIVE ABOUT ITS IDENTITY
LEAD: Enveloped in smog and, for Turks, in familiarity, too, the slogan that spreads across the highway here on a kind of ceremonial arch proclaims: ''What joy to say I am a Turk.''


Chess
LEAD: The former world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman are supposed to be getting set for their final candidates' match in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, starting on March 7, but lately neither has been in good form.


Bomber Crashes Off England
LEAD: An American Air Force F-111 bomber with a crew of two crashed into the sea today off east England during a routine training mission.
The British Defense Ministry said one body was recovered and a search was under way for the second crew member.

Infant Deaths Linked To Mothers' Smoking
LEAD: TWO doctors in Sweden say they have found a strong link between smoking and sudden infant death syndrome.
They attributed more than one-fourth of the deaths in a three-year study to smoking by mothers during pregnancy.

A Ranger Continues To Deny Racial Slur
LEAD: Kris King, upset by the ugly promise of the next day's headlines, did not sleep very well Saturday night.
His Sunday afternoon, the headlines having been read and cringed at, was no better.


Dow Up 19.82, to 2,622.52, on Lower Volume
LEAD: Stocks registered another strong gain yesterday but on sharply lower volume.


Senate Votes Death Penalty Despite Cuomo's Veto Stand
LEAD: In what has become an annual legislative ritual, the State Senate approved the death penalty today, but one Senator's absence left proponents wondering whether they had enough votes to override a gubernatorial veto.


Vehicle Sales Gained 3.2% In January
LEAD: Helped by fat rebates that enticed buyers back to showrooms they had avoided for several weeks, sales of cars and light trucks rose 3.2 percent in January, despite a relatively poor showing in the last 10 days of the month.


West Europeans Vote To Widen Eastern Aid
LEAD: A governing body of the European Community voted today to signal its willingness to extend to East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and Yugoslavia the aid programs of the major industrialized countries already under way in Poland and Hungary.


Review/Television;   Soviet Bathing Beauties on Parade
LEAD: It was only a matter of time before the Soviet Union got a nationwide beauty contest.
As tonight's ''Miss U.S.S.R.'' reports, the event beat McDonald's to Moscow; the finals of ''the first all-Union beauty contest'' were held last May near Red Square at the big Rossiya Hotel, where men in the audience followed the proceedings with the help of binoculars.

Rig Count Drops Again
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States continued to decline last week, dropping by six, to a total of 931, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
But the number was higher than the 780 posted for the corresponding week last year.
In the two previous weeks, the count plunged by a total of 82 rigs.


Ralph Anderson, 67, Architect in Southwest
LEAD: Ralph Alexander Anderson Jr., a leading architect in the Southwest for 40 years, died Saturday at his home in Houston.
He was 67 years old.


First Black Elected to Head Harvard's Law Review
LEAD: The Harvard Law Review, generally considered the most prestigious in the country, elected the first black president in its 104-year history today.
The job is considered the highest student position at Harvard Law School.


Notre Dame Breaks Ranks on TV Football Rights
LEAD: Breaking ranks with other major universities, the University of Notre Dame announced yesterday that it had signed a five-year contract giving NBC the exclusive right to broadcast all its home football games, starting in 1991.


Mandela Set No Conditions For Release, an Aide Insists
LEAD: A senior official of the African National Congress said today that the organization's jailed leader, Nelson Mandela, had set no conditions for his release and that, as far as Mr.
Mandela was concerned, ''he should have come out a long time ago.''


Review/Opera;   'The Tender Land,' a Rarity by Copland
LEAD: Aaron Copland's second opera, ''The Tender Land'' (1954), has elements that ought to have made it an American classic.
Its melodies are charming and folksy, in the tradition of Mr.
Copland's most popular works.
Its setting is deep in the American heartland, on a farm in the Midwest during the Depression.


Archibald Ross Lewis, Historian, Dies at 75
LEAD: Dr.
Archibald Ross Lewis, an author, educator and historian, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Tucson, Ariz.
He was 75 years old and had homes in Amherst, Mass., and Marblehead, Mass.

LEAD: Budget decisions by the Bush Administration to reduce the operations of the Export-Import Bank have drawn loud protests from business supporters of the Administration, as well as from some lawmakers.


S.E.C. Said to Review Trading by Simmons

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev's speech to the Central Committee calling for the surrender of the party's monopoly on power signals the onset of a two-month period that promises to be the most significant in Soviet political history since Stalin completed his seizure of power in 1929.

Major Harris Eyes Pros
LEAD: Major Harris, the West Virginia quarterback who after his junior year is already the Mountaineers' career leader in total offense with 7,334 yards, is ready to sign with an agent and turn professional, the Thomson Newspapers reported.(AP)


Savings Bond Curb Planned
LEAD: The Treasury Department said today that beginning on Oct. 1, it will not issue $50 and $75 Series EE savings bonds through payroll savings plans, making $100 bonds the minimum denomination for plan participants.


Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   Dialogue Takes Two
LEAD: To the Editor:


Truck Deaths Linked to Alcohol or Drugs
LEAD: One of every three truck drivers whose bodies were examined after they died in highway accidents had recently used drugs or alcohol, according to a study issued today by the National Transportation Safety Board.


Hunt for Aliens in Space: The Next Generation
LEAD: AFTER decades of dreaming, and sometimes scheming, a small band of earthlings has received Federal money to embark on a $100 million, 10-year project to find aliens in space.


Multiparty Voting: Back To the Future for Soviets
LEAD: The move for multiparty elections in the Soviet Union, which has been dominated by its Communist Party since 1918, recalls a brief period in early Soviet history when multiparty political activity loomed large - only to be followed by years of monolithic Communist rule.

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Howard Beach racial attack case said yesterday that he would prosecute three young white men again on riot charges stemming from the 1986 attack.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Premier at Thompson
LEAD: Premier Cruise Lines Ltd., a subsidiary of the Greyhound Corporation that specializes in family vacation-packages to the Bahamas and Disney World, awarded its advertising account yesterday to J. Walter Thompson in Chicago, a unit of the WPP Group.
The account, previously at CAK, Miami, has billings of $10 million.


Review/Architecture;   Frank Lloyd Wright Is Lauded in Phoenix With His Own Work
LEAD: Two things are remarkable about ''Frank Lloyd Wright Drawings: Masterworks From the Frank Lloyd Wright Archives,'' the sweeping exhibition of the master architect's work that has just opened at the Phoenix Art Museum.


Lebanon Faction Claims Attack on Israeli Group
LEAD: An Islamic fundamentalist movement based in Lebanon took responsibility today for the assault on a tour bus carrying Israelis in Egypt, the worst terrorist attack here in years.
The group, part of the coalition of extremist factions known as Islamic Holy War, said the killings on Sunday were meant to show opposition to Mideast peace efforts and to the tide of Soviet Jews entering Israel.

Review/Television;   'Elvis,' ABC Series on You-Know-Who
LEAD: Groan, groan, groan.
That was more or less how I felt on hearing that ABC had a new series called ''Elvis.'' About the only thing left to explore about Elvis Presley, it would seem, are those bizarre tabloid stories regularly marketed under the heading ''Elvis Lives!'' Spare me, oh ye desperate network programmers.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Paramount to Ogilvy
LEAD: Graham Phillips called one of his senior executives over the weekend to exult: ''We're back in show business!'' The chief executive of Ogilvy &amp; Mather Worldwide was reveling because his Los Angeles office had just won the media planning and buying account of the Paramount Pictures Corporation.
The account, which is worth $60 million to $70 million in annual billings, was pulled four weeks ago from D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles's Los Angeles office after less than two years there.

LEAD: THE common practice of hospitalizing women bearing twins to prevent premature labor and other complications late in pregnancy is ineffective, a new study in Australia has found.

RCA Is Fined $2.5 Million
LEAD: The General Electric Company's RCA unit pleaded guilty today to obtaining classified Pentagon planning documents illegally, and it agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle charges in an investigation of contractors' trading military secrets.


Peninsular-Laing
LEAD: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company offered today to pay $:441 million (about $745 million) for the 78.2 percent of Laing Properties P.L.C. it does not already own.
Laing rejected the offer, saying it significantly undervalued Laing's assets and longer-term growth potential.
P.&amp;O., which has interests in passenger and cargo shipping, said its offer for Laing, a property investment and development company, amounted to 650 pence, or $10.99, a share.


BankAmerica Names Successor to Clausen
LEAD: Richard M. Rosenberg, whose aggressive marketing tactics fueled the BankAmerica Corporation's resurgence in California banking, yesterday was named the next chairman and chief executive of the nation's third-largest banking company.


Big Christian Battle Taking Shape Along Highway North From Beirut
LEAD: Civilians in Christian East Beirut who spent six days and nights sheltering from fighting between warring Christians took advantage of a lull today to look for food or flee to safer ground.

LEAD: Adm.
Eugenio Henke, who led the Italian secret service in the late 1960's when its agents were linked to right-wing terrorism and coup plots, died of a heart attack on Sunday.
He was 81 years old.

LEAD: The Bush Administration reacted to the rapidly unfolding events in the Soviet Union today with a caution that reflected both uncertainty over the outcome and the Administration's efforts to fight off proposals for more sweeping cuts in the United States military budget.

LEAD: The savings and loan bailout agency approved ethics rules today for deciding which private consultants and managers get a piece of what is being called the biggest real estate sale since the Oklahoma land rush.

Jean Bissell, 53, Dies; Federal Appeals Judge
LEAD: Jean Galloway Bissell, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, died of cancer Sunday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington.
She was 53 years old and lived in Washington.


Ouster of Priest Is Explained
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington said today that the Rev.
George A. Stallings Jr. had excommunicated himself from the faith by declaring over the weekend that the African-American congregation he organized here last year was ''independent'' of Rome and would permit abortion, birth control, divorce and the ordination of women and married men.


Going to the Hoop To Redirect Lives
LEAD: There are some 110 gangs in this city.
They control drug traffic in the public-housing developments and have names like the Vice Lords and the Disciples.
The Chicago Housing Authority is trying to convert some members of the gangs into basketball players on teams with names like the Bulls and the Lakers.

TESTIMONY BEGINS IN OIL SPILL TRIAL
LEAD: Joseph J. Hazelwood was in a bar for seven hours, ordering glasses of vodka, a short time before before his tanker tanker left port on a voyage that would result in the nation's worst oil spill, a prosecutor said today.


Vanguard of the Revolution: The Soviet Party
LEAD:
1883: The first Russian Marxist group, ''Emancipation of Labor,'' is founded in Geneva, with G. V. Plekhanov at its head.
1898: The Russian Social Democratic Labor Party, a Marxist organization, is founded in Minsk; it is soon broken up by the police and and forced to meet in European exile.
1903: There is a split in the Russian Social Democratic Labor Party; the Bolsheviks, led by Lenin, organize as one wing of the party and pick a name meaning the party of the majority although they gained their majority at a congress by virtue of a protest walkout by others.


MEETS HARD-LINE OPPOSITION
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called on the Communist Party today to forswear its constitutional monopoly on power and to accept the prospect of rival political parties.


Saving the Landfills
LEAD: Crab scraps are being converted into high-quality compost in an effort to solve an expensive waste disposal problem.
The pilot project in Perry, Fla., uses cypress sawdust, yard waste and bark to convert the smelly crab scraps into marketable compost.


St. Anthony Wins Metro Classic
LEAD: Since withdrawing from the Hudson County League before the start of last season, St.
Anthony of Jersey City now plays for the national spotlight, and tonight the school turned the lights up a little higher by defeating St.
Nicholas of Tolentine, 65-63, in the championship of the first Metro Classic.

Westchester Board Approves Plant to Treat Sewage Sludge
LEAD: The Westchester Board of Legislators cleared the way today for construction of an $18.9 million sewage treatment plant in Yonkers.
The plant would remove the water from sewage sludge, allowing the county to meet a Federal deadline banning ocean dumping of sludge by the end of next year.

Seoul Is Planning to Convert Its Raucous Politics Into Gray Japanese Model
LEAD: Two years into South Korea's first experiment with a freely elected democracy, the country's strife-weary leaders say they are planning to transform the government into a system that, at least on the surface, will strikingly resemble Japan's: parliamentary-style rule dominated by a single, conservative party powerful enough to drown out opposition voices.


Panthers Get Virus Similar To AIDS
LEAD: The discovery of an AIDS-like virus in Florida panthers has surprised and worried scientists, but they say there is no indication that the infection is fatal to the endangered cats.
An estimated 30 to 50 of the panthers live in South Florida. ''It's just another problem that we need to be aware of,'' said Dr.


Home Buyers Fall Behind
LEAD: Home buyers waited longer to buy in 1989 because prices rose faster than their incomes, an annual study has found.
Last year was the 14th straight year that the gap between home prices and income has widened, The Chicago Title and Trust Company said its annual survey of home buyers in 18 urban areas showed that the majority of 1989 home buyers were two-income couples who had saved for an average of 2.9 years -the longest period in the survey's 14-year history - to obtain enough for a down payment.

Bridge
LEAD: When Horace Walpole coined the word ''serendipity'' from the activities of the Three Princes of Serendip, who regularly made fortunate discoveries by complete accident, he did not have bridge players in mind.
But in some remote part of the world it is likely that somebody at a card table benefited from serendipity on the diagramed deal.


New Aggressiveness at Siemens
LEAD: Siemens A.G., Western Europe's largest electronics concern, is at last breaking out of its traditional mold as the prototype of a West German industrial group: conservative, cash-laden and about as exciting as yesterday's sauerkraut.


Pupil Waits 2 Nights in a Bus
LEAD: A kindergarten pupil who fell asleep on a school bus was hospitalized with frostbite after spending nearly two nights in the bus waiting for help, the authorities said.
The child, Angela Terrell, boarded the Mayflower school bus on Friday for Ashland Elementary School in midtown Kansas City, the police said.


A Role for South Africa
LEAD: It was almost exactly 30 years ago that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain made his ''wind of change'' speech here.
It signaled Britain's sweeping acceptance of decolonization, the dismantling of empires almost everywhere that has so changed the world.


Less Sulfur Found From Marine Organisms
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have found evidence buried within the Greenland ice cap that although human activity is pouring sulfur into the atmosphere at a prodigious rate, sulfur emitted by marine organisms into the air has begun to decline sharply.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Thin Blood
Q.Does blood thicken in winter?
A.No, said Dr.
Joan Uehlinger, associate director of clinical services for the New York Blood Center. ''In fact, it might tend to be thicker in summer, when the body loses water through sweating, and people need to drink more to remain hydrated,'' she said.

LEAD: Dick Colman, the head football coach at Princeton from 1957-68, was among four figures elected to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame.

LEAD: It's the height of ambition for a 27-year old actor to try remaking a star's masterpiece.
But Kenneth Branagh's new film of ''Henry V'' soars with invention, eclipsing even Sir Laurence Olivier's celebrated version.
The two films, 44 years apart, attest to Mr.
Branagh's skills as actor and director, and the progress in the film maker's art.

LEAD: Genentech Inc.'s stock fell after analysts concluded that a proposed merger with Roche Holding Ltd. was less favorable to investors than it first seemed. LEAD: An internal State Department review has concluded that the agency has not taken its role in the drug war seriously because it is hampered by the complexity of its mission, limited resources and a lack of interest among senior agency officials.

LEAD: A woman crossing Times Square was struck by a hit-and-run driver yesterday morning and then robbed of her purse as she lay dying on the pavement, the police said.

LEAD: A man armed with a gun killed his two adult sons and a girlfriend of one of them and stabbed his wife before taking his own life this morning as the police tried to negotiate with him by telephone, the authorities said.

LEAD: A judge dismissed a legal challenge today by McDonald's restaurants and others to a ban on food containers made of polystyrene foam in Portland.

Circuit Judge Douglas R. Spencer ruled today that the city was within its authority in enacting the ban.

Maxwell Venture Fund
LEAD: The British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell said Monday that he would set up a $1 billion investment fund to finance joint ventures in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Mr.
Maxwell, who heads the Maxwell Communication Corporation, said at the annual World Economic Forum that the fund would be established by his London &amp; Bishopsgate Investment Management P.L.C.


Joel Fluellen, 81, A Longtime Actor In Films and TV
LEAD: Joel Fluellen, a veteran film and television actor who was also noted for his efforts to end stereotyping of blacks in Hollywood films, was found dead at his home in Los Angeles on Friday.
He was 81 years old.

Timeout for Webster
LEAD: Coach Tom Webster of the Los Angeles Kings, former coach of the Rangers, has been ordered to take off two weeks because of an inner-ear problem.
He will be replaced by two assistants, Cap Raeder and Rick Wilson.

Appeals Court Nominee Is Questioned on Rights
LEAD: Some members of the Senate Judiciary Committee today closely questioned Clarence Thomas, an outspoken conservative, about his approach to civil rights, but committee aides and others said there seemed to be no significant obstacle raised to his being confirmed to a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

LEAD: Dr.
Edward Massie, a St.
Louis cardiologist for 50 years, died Monday at a convalescent hospital in St.
Louis County, Mo.
He was 79 years old and lived in Clayton, Mo.

Upheaval in the East: The Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV GAINS SUPPORT IN RAUCOUS DEBATE ON ROLE OF PARTY, DELEGATES REPORT
LEAD: Communist Party leaders went through a raucous day of debate over their future today, with delegates at the closed-door session reporting a strong majority favoring the end of the party's power monopoly and pointing to the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe as the ultimate object lesson.

Genentech Matchmaker Calls Roche Ideal Partner
LEAD: The investment banker behind Genentech Inc.'s plan to sell a 60 percent interest to Roche Holdings Ltd. for $2.1 billion is Frederick Frank, who brought the management of the two companies together and shepherded the deal through.

LEAD: Take my agency. Please.


Attack on Israelis Upsets Palestinians in Egypt
LEAD: The Egyptian authorities said today that the men they suspected of killing nine Israelis in a rifle and grenade attack on a tour bus near here on Sunday were Palestinians.
That has come as no comfort to a dwindling minority of 40,000 Palestinians whose roots here, once firm, have weakened with time.

Tanker's Captain Seemed Sober, Pilot Tells Court
LEAD: Except for a trace of liquor on his breath, Capt.
Joseph J. Hazelwood appeared sober and in control of the Exxon Valdez an hour before the tanker struck a reef in Prince William Sound last March and began spewing almost 11 million gallons of crude oil, a marine pilot testified today.


Harold S. Spielman, Professor, 75
LEAD: Harold S. Spielman, professor emeritus of education at City College, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Friday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital.
He was 75 years old and lived in Yonkers.

More Sallie Mae Floating Rates Set
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering its second floating rate issue for the week.


British Air Link With Argentina
LEAD: The chairman of British Airways P.L.C., Lord King, said his airline might take a stake in the Argentine flag carrier Aerolineas Argentinas when it is sold to private investors later this year.
Speaking to reporters after an interview with President Carlos Saul Menem, Lord King said: ''We are looking at it as we look at any offer - to see if there is anything in it for us.


William I. Walsh, 67, Ex-Official of A.&amp;P.
LEAD: William I. Walsh, who rose from stock boy to executive vice president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company before he left the grocery chain in 1980, died of liver cancer on Monday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J.
He was 67 years old and lived in River Vale, N.J.


Ronald Reagan, Still Hiding
LEAD: ''The buck stops here with me,'' John Poindexter told Congress in 1987, protecting his President on the Iran-contra arms deal.
That was incredible but also loyal, permitting Ronald Reagan to hide behind a claim of ignorance of what his White House was doing secretly to help the rebels in Nicaragua.


Whitestar Head Named Leader of Bell &amp; Howell
LEAD: The Bell &amp; Howell Company yesterday named William J. White chairman, president and chief executive.
He replaces Nils Johansson, the company's chief financial officer, who had been acting as interim chief executive since September, when Gerald E. Schultz resigned.


Doctor Says Prego Knew of Serious Infection in '85
LEAD: A physician who examined Dr.
Veronica Prego in 1985 testified yesterday that he told her she had a serious infection but that he did not know with any certainty at the time that she would get AIDS.


Canadian Channel Bans Rap Group
LEAD: The rap group Public Enemy has been banned from Canada's music-videos station because the lyrics of its latest record are considered anti-Semitic.

U.N. TEAM REPORTS ON NICARAGUA VOTE
LEAD: A United Nations observer mission led by Elliot L. Richardson said today that the election campaign in Nicaragua was generally fair, but it found that some opposition candidates had been intimidated by members of the governing Sandinista party.

Reviews/Music;   Mateos's Populist Rock, With Lyrics in Spanish
LEAD: Miguel Mateos Zas and his band were the image of late-1980's rock when they performed Sunday night at the Beacon Theater.
Mr.
Mateos swung his shoulder-length chestnut hair and romped cheerfully across the stage; his band, in a smoke-machine mist, wore pouts or grins, leather pants and mousse-abused hairdos.


Upheaval in the East: The Pentagon;   Discount Soviet Peril to Iran, Cheney Tells His Strategists
LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has issued a new guide for military planning that instructs the services to drop the mission of defending Iran in the event of a Soviet attack and calls on the United States' Asian allies to take on more of the burden for their own defense, Pentagon officals said today.

Greece and Bulgaria Plan Anti-Turkey Strategies
LEAD: Greece and Bulgaria, both Orthodox Christian nations with significant Turkish Muslim minorities, are developing common strategies toward Turkey that include military cooperation.


No Pan Am Pact
LEAD: The board of the Pan Am Corporation ended a meeting yesterday without making an announcement, amid speculation about a possible deal with Northwest Airlines.
That halted a two-day rally in Pan Am's stock.
The stock rose to a peak of $4 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning; at the close of trading Friday it was $3 a share.

Bush Calls For Some Regulation
LEAD: In the most thorough presentation of his economic views since he took office, President Bush today embraced the mainstream Republican philosophy of reliance on private initiatives and market forces.
But his first Economic Report to Congress did not have the ideological edge of those submitted by Ronald Reagan.


Joseph J. Nazzaro, 76, An Air Force General
LEAD: Joseph James Nazzaro, a retired four-star general of the Air Force, died of cancer Monday at the Tucson Medical Center in Arizona.
He was 76 years old and lived in Tucson.

Will Federated's Chief Have Time?
LEAD: At the helm of Bullock's five years ago, Allen I. Questrom ordered the West Coast department store chain to pull out of a data exchange through which competing chains tracked short-term shifts in market share.
He warned his merchandisers and buyers to think of the long term because short-term gains mean little in the life of any business.


Early Retirements Taken at U S West
LEAD: U S West Inc., a telecommunications holding company based in Englewood, Colo., said that its early retirement offer had been accepted by some 3,850 managers.
The company's president, Richard D. McCormick, said he expected the final tally of participants in the company's cost-cutting program to be 4,000.


Tax Raffles in Argentina
LEAD: Argentina plans to hold weekly and monthly raffles to encourage people to pay the 13 percent value-added tax introduced earlier this month.
Numbered sales receipts, distributed by the Federal Tax Bureau, will be used as raffle tickets, the Public Revenues Secretary, Raul Cuello, said Monday night.


G.I.'s Who Fought in Panama Are Counseled to Ease Stress
LEAD: The Army, which has long denied that going into combat can cause long-term psychological stress for some soldiers, is providing counseling to try to avert such problems for troops who recently returned from Panama.


Sometimes an Advance Goes Too Far
LEAD: Interactive displays, in which a customer uses a keypad and a graphic screen to ask questions about a product, have become an important feature in modern merchandising.
But every once in a while they backfire.

LEAD: YOKO ONO won her day in court.
JUDGE CAROL H. ARBER of the New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan granted Ms.
Ono's motion to stop MARILYN GOLDBERG, an art dealer, from selling works by John Lennon.
The prohibition remains in effect until a trial, expected later this year.

LEAD: On a day when he hailed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for proposing an end to the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on power in the Soviet Union, President Bush stood on a bleak Mojave Desert ridge today to watch American soldiers fight ''Soviet'' tanks in a mock World War III battle.

LEAD: The shelves of the Adamant Co-op are tidy and well-stocked, giving the place an aura of modest prosperity, the boxes of prunes arranged neatly next to the canned vegetables, the coolers full of cheese, soda, eggs from local farms and, of course, beer.

Large Losses Are Reported By Texas Air
LEAD: The Texas Air Corporation, citing heavy losses at its Eastern Airlines subsidiary, said yesterday that it lost $362.8 million in the fourth quarter, up from a loss of $224.4 million a year earlier.
For the year, the company had a loss of $885.6 million, an industry record, compared with a loss of $718.6 million in 1988.

Wildfires in Central Florida
LEAD: Drought and a December freeze that dried vegetation have combined to cause central Florida's worst spell of wildfires in five years, officals say.
In Polk, Hillsborough and Pinellas counties, which include Tampa and St.
Petersburg, 122 brush fires have been reported since Jan. 1, almost triple last year's rate.

That should keep world prices above $18 a barrel this year, the head of OPEC said today.

LEAD: American Airlines announced an expansion plan for its hub at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport.

The airline, which is owned by the AMR Corporation, now schedules more than 400 flights a day out of the airport, the nation's fourth-largest.

Economic Scene;   Social Security: Paying the Piper
LEAD: FOR most of Washington's movers and shakers, the big question about Social Security is whether there will be enough cash to honor the pension promises made to the giant baby boom generation.
For Stephen J. Entin, a Reagan Administration Treasury official now at the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation, the big question is whether the promises should have been made in the first place.

LEAD: Dr.
Norton Nelson, a leader in establishing environmental medicine and a former director of the New York University Institute of Environmental Medicine, died of pneumonia on Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y.
He was 80 years old and lived in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

LEAD: Nelson Mandela is pressing the Government for further concessions before he gains his freedom but he is not staging a prison sit-in, a visitor to his prison bungalow said today.

LEAD: The Rev.

LEAD: Since the program presented by the Fine Arts Quartet at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening included only two substantial works, one expected the players to revel in each to its full extent.
But in Mozart's expansive Quintet for Clarinet and Strings in A (K. 581), with the clarinetist David Shifrin taking part, they skipped the opening exposition repeat.


A.T.&amp;T. Wins a Rate Increase
LEAD: The State Public Service Commission approved an A.T.&amp;T. rate plan today that will increase the cost of evening long-distance calls by an average of 9 percent.
The approval lets the company raise its rates this year but prohibits it from filing for another increase for two years.

Boston College fell to 7-14 and 1-10.

Grand Central Brought to Halt By Cable Fire
LEAD: A huge machine that levels the tracks leading into Grand Central Terminal snagged a 600-volt electrical cable in a tunnel beneath Park Avenue yesterday, sending up a shower of sparks and flames that injured 11 railroad workers and 2 firefighters.
Train service was halted for hours, and thousands of commuters were delayed.

Pogorelich Postpones
LEAD: The pianist Ivo Pogorelich has postponed his Feb. 21 Carnegie Hall recital and his Feb. 25 Avery Fisher Hall recital because of illness.
He is now scheduled to play at Carnegie Hall on May 7 at 8 P.M., and at Fisher Hall on May 13 at 8:30 P.M.
Original tickets may be used.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the election of Barack Obama as president of the Harvard Law Review misidentified the United States court on which Patricia M. Wald is Chief Judge.

Review/Music;   A Tippett Oratorio By Way Of Spirituals
LEAD: Sir Michael Tippett's oratorio ''A Child of Our Time'' is seldom performed in the United States, and it is difficult to fathom why.
The subjects, to be sure, are war, persecution and misery, and the mood is predominantly desolate.
The ''child of our time,'' it turns out, is ''the scapegoat.'' Yet the work's ultimate message is consolatory, and the composer's incorporation of

Reviews/Music;   Haiti's Compas Rhythms From 2 New York Groups
LEAD: Compas, Haiti's pop music, is a mass of rhythmic complication, in which syncopations are accented and pass for downbeats, and rhythms interlock and repeat, all for the benefit of dancers.
Two of the best Haitian groups, Skah Shah and Les Superstars, both based in New York, came to S.O.B.'s on Saturday night, and both jammed the dance floor.


Milwaukee Plans a College Guarantee for Pupils
LEAD: This city is pledging to guarantee a spot in college, with financial aid, if needed, for any student in the city who graduates from high school with at least a C-plus average.


Bridge
LEAD: The New York bridge scene loses two of its most popular figures today, when Tom and Sue Snow go Down Under.
Tom Snow recently resigned after 10 years as manager of the Cavendish Club, and the couple will live in Sydney.
Sue Snow's return to her native Australia, just in time for maternity, will allow her once again to vie for international honors.

LEAD: In an effort to support the last non-Arab presence on the Red Sea, Israel has increased its diplomatic and military links with the embattled Marxist-Leninist Government here, diplomats say.

Imperial Cleared For Texaco Deal
LEAD: Imperial Oil Ltd., which is controlled by the Exxon Corporation, received final Government approval for its $5 billion (Canadian) takeover of Texaco Canada.

Imperial, based in Toronto, is 70 percent owned by Exxon.

Corrections
LEAD: A diagram in Science Times yesterday about an effort to find evidence of aliens in space mislabeled the orientation of the microwave frequencies to be monitored on the electromagnetic spectrum.
Although stated correctly as 1 to 10 gigahertz, the range should have been reversed, with 10 gigahertz closer than 1 gigahertz to the visible spectrum.


Kemp Tightens Control of 3,300 Housing Agencies
LEAD: Responding to findings of financial abuses at a New Jersey public housing authority, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp has ended a program that gave 600 local housing agencies relative independence in their management practices.

November Savings Outflow Is $4.9 Billion, 4-Month Low
LEAD: Savings and loan customers withdrew $4.9 billion more than they deposited in November as the industry continued to shrink in response to tougher financial standards enacted last summer, the Government said today.

LEAD: Riots broke out between rival political parties today, and 22 people were hurt, the police and hospital personnel said.

Metropolitan Diary
LEAD: THE scene was one of the theaters in the Loew's Sixplex on Broadway at West 84th Street.
The time, a recent Friday night.
Cast of characters: Manette R. Berlinger and the rest of the audience waiting for Woody Allen's ''Crimes and Misdemeanors'' to begin.

LEAD: Slowly but inexorably, Ronald Reagan is being drawn into the Iran-contra affair after years of conflicting statements and an unwillingness to give a public account of his actions.


Super No More
LEAD: We can now mothball the word ''superpower.'' The Soviet Union, which used to be one, is unraveling, and the United States, which still talks like one, is becoming irrelevant.

The 'Half Free' Are 'Half Enslaved'
LEAD: The poem was a simple, dramatic dessert to a long dinner around a table laden with delicacies rarely seen during a Soviet winter: plates full of beef and fish and a pyramid of fresh oranges.


Upheaval in the East: Poland;   World Bank Approves Its First Loans to Warsaw, in Support of Economic Reforms
LEAD: The World Bank today approved its first two loans to Poland, totaling $360 million, part of a package of more than $2.5 billion that it is preparing over the next three years to help break economic bottlenecks and support reforms of the Solidarity-led Government.


C.D.'s, Bank Funds Mixed
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as banks showed signs of pulling back on yields.


Jury Starts Deliberations in Gotti Case
LEAD: After being told by a judge to ''apply your common sense'' and not to ''turn the jury room into the twilight zone,'' 12 jurors began deliberating yesterday in the John Gotti assault and conspiracy trial.


Kingdom Captures Owens Award Trophy
LEAD: Roger Kingdom, the 1984 and 1988 Olympic 110-meter hurdles champion for the United States, who set the world record of 12.92 seconds in the event last year, was chosen yesterday as the winner of the 1990 Jesse Owens International Trophy Award.


Appeals Court Says Mississippi Colleges Remain Segregated
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Mississippi's state-supported universities are insufficiently desegregated, saying that racial imbalances have continued since 1962 when the University of Mississippi was ordered to admit its first black student.

LEAD: Ruth Hall Bleecker, a consultant on planning weddings and parties and founder of the Long Island Junior Dances, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at a nursing home in Woodbury, L.I.

LEAD: The Communist Party leader in the Siberian city of Sverdlovsk has resigned in a growing wave of discontent over regional and local party practices, the newspaper Trud reported today.
The resignation of the official, Leonid F. Bobykin, was announced on Monday at a regional meeting of party activists, the newspaper said.

LEAD: The enduring musical legacy of Irving Berlin was honored yesterday at the Music Box Theater in a memorial tribute to the songwriter, who died in September at the age of 101.


Selma, Ala., Reinstates Black Schools Chief
LEAD: After racial turmoil forced the closing of two public schools, the Selma Board of Education today reinstated the city's first black school superintendent, whom the board dismissed only last week.

LEAD: A commission has been established to investigate complaints against security forces that put down the violent ethnic unrest in Kosovo province, the police chief said today.


Kodak Has Loss, Polaroid a Profit
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported a larger-than-expected charge in the fourth quarter from selling operations and laying off employees, resulting in a loss of $60 million.
In the fourth quarter of 1988, Kodak had profits of $312 million, or 96 cents a share.

House Backs Easy Voter Registration
LEAD: Over the objections of President Bush and some other leading Republicans, the House of Representatives today approved legislation that proponents say would dramatically increase the number of Americans who are registered to vote.
The vote was 289 to 132.
The legislation would establish national voter registration procedures that all states would have to follow, replacing the current patchwork of different procedures from state to state.

Reviews/Music;   A Factorylike Emptiness
LEAD: Frank Zappa was perhaps the most intriguing name on Sunday's program by the Aspen Wind Quintet at the 92d Street Y, even if the music he provided was not.
In the midst of this all-20th-century afternoon was Mr.
Zappa's ''Times Beach,'' at least its new fifth movement.
The previous four were first heard in 1985.


GTE Profits Up 20.2%; United Telecom Down
LEAD: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that its 1989 fourth-quarter earnings rose 20.2 percent because of strong performances by its telephone and telecommunications units.
United Telecommunications Inc. said its profit declined sharply in the fourth quarter although revenue jumped 15 percent, reflecting continued growth by U S Sprint.


Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   Hungary to Recognize Vatican
LEAD: Hungary removed 40-year-old restrictions on the Roman Catholic Church today, and the Vatican announced that it was re-establishing diplomatic relations with Budapest.


Arthur J. Barry, 80, Chemical Researcher
LEAD: Arthur J. Barry, a chemical researcher who had an important role in the development of silicon products, died of heart disease on Saturday.
He was 80 years old and lived in Tucson.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher announced today that they would travel to Moscow this weekend to reassure Soviet leaders about the accelerating course of German reunification and its effect on the military balance.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Jan. 26 about automobile safety gave an incomplete list of the Japanese cars equipped with air bags as standard equipment.
Besides Toyota's Lexus, Nissan's Infiniti and Honda's Acura Legend, the 1990 Toyota Supra and Celica models have air bags as standard equipment.

Mr.

LEAD: New York City yesterday accused the Exxon Corporation of filing reports for years that falsely indicated that the company's leak-detection system in the Arthur Kill was in good working order.


John Merivale, Actor, 72
LEAD: John Merivale, an actor who appeared in such movies as ''A Night to Remember,'' ''King Rat'' and ''Arabesque'' in the 1950's and 60's, died on Tuesday in London.
He was 72 years old.


U.S. Is Given More Time on Noriega Evidence
LEAD: A Federal magistrate today rejected a motion by a lawyer for Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega that would have compelled Government prosecutors to provide ''forthwith,'' instead of in the next week or so, a complete inventory of evidence seized by American troops at homes and offices of the deposed Panamanian military leader.


John A. Reuling, Church Executive, 83
LEAD: John A. Reuling, a retired missionary and executive with the overseas mission of the United Church of Christ, died of complications from Alzheimer's disease on Monday at a nursing home in Port Huron, Mich.
He was 83 years old and had lived in Tenafly, N.J.

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani is sending strong signals that he will not be a Republican candidate for governor this year, even though he has started a traditional campaign warm-up: a series of speaking engagements throughout New York State.


SOVIET LEADERS AGREE TO SURRENDER COMMUNIST PARTY MONOPOLY ON POWER
LEAD: The Communist Party leadership agreed today to surrender its historic monopoly of power in the Soviet Union and accept a program that recommends the creation of a Western-style presidency and Cabinet system of government.


3 Airlines in Pact On Reservations
LEAD: Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Trans World Airlines said they had completed their agreement to form a new company that will own and market a computer reservation system.
T.W.A. and Northwest will contribute their Pars system to the joint venture, while Delta will contribute its Datas II system.


How Steele's Garden Visions Grew
LEAD: For 60 years, Fletcher Steele, one of America's premier landscape architects, created more than 700 gardens.
About 100 photographs and drawings of his work continue to be on view through March 30 at the Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street, in Manhattan.

LEAD: In business, it is good to have strong financial backing.
And that is what John S. Thorbeck has in his unlikely bid to take an old shoe company and put it on a new footing.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section yesterday about research on the healing potential of foods misidentified the component involved in products developed by Paul Stitt, a biochemist who owns Natural Ovens in Manitowoc, Wis.
He uses flaxseed mash and holds the patent for stabilizing the mash, not flaxseed oil.

Judge Nullifies Law Mandating Use of English
LEAD: A Federal district judge in Phoenix has declared that the state's constitutional amendment making English the language ''of all government functions and actions'' in Arizona is a violation of federally protected free speech rights.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Offices Closing
LEAD: The Television Bureau of Advertising said yesterday that it would close its offices in Dallas and Atlanta and consolidate its operations in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.
A spokesman for the bureau said it would develop a regional sales development team, modeled on its national sales development team, to try to draw more advertising to broadcast television.

LEAD: It's hard to overstate the significance of yesterday's epochal votes in Moscow.
This is truly a third Russian Revolution.
The first overthrew the Czar in February 1917.
Nine months later, Lenin's Bolsheviks ousted an interim democratic regime and imposed a dictatorship of the Communist Party.
Now, heeding a bold appeal by an embattled Mikhail Gorbachev, the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist

LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company will lay off more than 10 percent of its employees by Feb. 23 because of reduced military spending by the Government, the company's president, William P. Brown, announced.

The Wheelchair-Friendly Apartment
LEAD: RONNIE EISENBERG, who has multiple sclerosis, lived in an apartment on East 72d Street that was an obstacle course.
The arches to the living room and the door to the kitchen were too narrow for her wheelchair.
Each time she took a shower, she had to be carried over the lip.

LEAD: It has been a shivery winter, and the fireplace has been burning more than usual.
The once-gleaming brass tools that provide rich accents in a room - shovel, tongs, andirons, poker, brass-trimmed screen - are covered with soot and badly stained by smoke, fire gases and resinous secretions.
As one fireplace expert put it, ''It's time for open-hearth surgery.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: DURING the first trimester of my wife's pregnancy with our son, her weight stayed the same and I put on 10 pounds.
Other fathers have described weeks of morning sickness, food cravings, moodiness or chronic fatigue - symptoms of pregnancy they had expected to see in their wives, not in themselves.

LEAD: After years as a symbol of hard-line resistance to the Sandinista Government, the commander of the American-supported contra army has been removed from his post by younger officers, rebel radio reports and American diplomats said today.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: REPAINTING can be a simple way to brighten a room.
But to minimize the potential for creating a mess instead, it is important to choose appropriate materials, tools and equipment and to work in an orderly fashion.
Latex-based paint is the most popular and the easiest to use.
Because the paint is soluble in water, drying takes only about an hour and cleanup can be done with soap and water.
