A Freudian Dream Come True
LEAD: A square in Pribor that once honored Stalin is to be renamed after the Czechoslovak town's most famous son, Sigmund Freud.
The state press agency said an opinion poll in the north Moravian town showed most of its inhabitants wanted Stalin Square to be named after the founder of psychoanalysis.
Freud, born in Pribor in 1856, moved to Vienna where he pioneered analysis of the subconscious mind.

LEAD:
N.B.A.
Warriors End 76ers' Streak
A last-second rebound basket by Mitch Richmond ended the Philadelphia 76ers' league-best winning streak at 12 games last night and gave Golden State a 113-112 triumph, the Warriors' first victory at the Spectrum in 11 years.
Richmond scored with three-tenths of a second left after rebounding a miss by Winston Garland.

Covenant House, Beyond Father Ritter
LEAD: The Rev.
Bruce Ritter and Covenant House are virtually synonymous.
Father Ritter founded this remarkable home for runaway children in 1968.
More than 200,000 kids have gone in and out of its doors.
What started in two abandoned tenements in New York City's East Village has become a string of houses and shelters across the country.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the downgrading of debt ratings on three Japanese banks misstated their size rankings.
The Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation is the world's 19th-largest banking company; the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company is the 21st-largest, and the Mitsui Trust and Banking Company is the 23d-largest.

LEAD: A line of glass tableware imported from Italy is being recalled because it has dangerous concentrations of lead, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

Review/Dance;   The Trocks Are Back, Playing With Conventions
LEAD: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo arrived at City Center on Tuesday night after a seven-year absence from New York, and it was a triumphant return for the all-male dance company.
If there had been a laugh meter anywhere in the theater, it would have gone into orbit at this opening-night benefit for the Gay Men's Health Crisis.


Times Books Appoints An Editorial Director
LEAD: Steve Wasserman, executive editor of Doubleday, was named editorial director of Times Books yesterday, effective on Monday.
Mr.
Wasserman is to replace Derek Johns, who recently decided to return to Britain.
Mr.
Wasserman was previously publisher of Hill &amp; Wang and Noonday Press, divisions of Farrar, Straus &amp;


Hewlett-Oki Deal
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Oki Electric Industry Company of Tokyo agreed to build and operate jointly a printed circuit board manufacturing plant in Aguadilla, P.R.
The partners will jointly invest $40 million in building the plant, 50 percent of which will be owned by each company.
Hewlett-Packard will use its portion of the boards in computer products made in Puerto Rico, while Oki will sell its portion on the open market.

Swedish Electricity Plan
LEAD: Sweden will have to pay up to $670 million a year in extra costs if it scraps two nuclear power reactors as scheduled in 1995 and 1996, the state electricity board said last week.
In addition, companies that consume large amounts of electricity would face higher charges and some might go out of business, the board said in a report.

LEAD: JOHN BRYAN of Pownal, Me., calls himself an artist in wood.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet's program on Tuesday night was the equivalent of a fine meal.
George Balanchine's light ''Donizetti Variations'' was the appetizer while the meaty entree consisted of his paired Stravinsky ballets ''Monumentum pro Gesualdo'' and ''Movements for Piano and Orchestra.''

LEAD: Acutely embarrassed officials at the Bank of Japan and the Ministry of Finance acknowledged today that Japan's vaults hold at least $71 million in gold coins that no one - not even the central bank that minted the originals - had recognized as counterfeit until recently.

SmithKline Lags On Cosmetics Sale
LEAD: The sale of the cosmetics operations units of the British-American pharmaceutical company SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. ''is not going as well as we wished,'' Robert Bauman, chief executive of the company, said in Tokyo, where it is starting a Japanese unit.
There are fewer buyers than expected, partly because of the overall softness of the market, and some of the prices will probably be lower than original estimates, he said.

Romania's AIDS Babies: A Legacy of Neglect
LEAD: The babies, about 60 of them, are on the third floor of the drab gray hospital, the only AIDS clinic in Romania.
In some rooms, there are two babies to a crib.

LEAD: A Delaware court on Tuesday upheld DeSoto Inc.'s ''poison pill'' takeover defense but chided the company's directors for failing to seek the best value for shareholders.

LEAD: The playwright HAROLD PINTER delivered a speech by the novelist SALMAN RUSHDIE at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London Tuesday night.
Mr.
Pinter explained that Mr.
Rushdie had considered showing up, but reconsidered on the advice of the British Government detectives who have protected him since he went into hiding nearly a year ago.


Oregon Governor Won't Run
LEAD: Gov.
Neil Goldschmidt announced today that he would not run this year for a second term.
The Governor, a 49-year-old Democrat, said that he and his wife of 25 years, Margie, had agreed to separate and that as a result, ''it's certainly no time to be running for governor.'' The Goldschmidts have two children.

LEAD: Arab nations are planning a major diplomatic campaign to warn the world that the expected arrival of hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews in Israel over the next few years threatens to increase tension in the Middle East and reduce the chances of peace.

LEAD: Wall Street dealers and investors are bracing nervously for the sale by Federal regulators of large amounts of ''junk bonds.'' With the seizure of the Centrust Savings Bank in Miami last week, the Federal agency responsible for selling the assets of ailing savings institutions now controls a portfolio of high-yield, high-risk junk bonds worth almost $2 billion, analysts estimate.


NATO Chief Says He Accepted Cuts On Bush's Urging
LEAD: The commander of NATO forces in Europe told Congress today that he had recommended against President Bush's proposal to cut American and Soviet troops in central Europe to 195,000, but had been later persuaded that such a cut was acceptable.

Reviews/Theater;   A Cool Medea Lashes Back At the Man Who Jilted Her
LEAD: Among the classic Greek tragedies, Euripides' ''Medea'' probably strikes the brightest sparks in contemporary imaginations.
Its story of a woman who lashes back at the man who betrayed her after she had saved his life and engineered his ascent to power is one of the most potent revenge fantasies of all time.

Bridge
LEAD: In a simple bidding style, a player whose partner opens one no-trump tends to settle in three no-trump if he can see values for game and can rule out a major-suit fit.
This leads to an occasional disaster when there is extreme weakness in a major suit and the right contract is game in a minor.
It is seldom right to play three no-trump when the partnership has a two-two, or worse, fit in a major.

Desert Raid: A Rare Effect
LEAD: When gunmen killed nine Israelis on a bus in the desert east of Cairo three days ago, their assault revived one of this region's cruelest realities: In the lexicon of extremism, talk of peace between Arab and Jew translates almost automatically into violence and terror by its adversaries.


CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: I HAVE read the warnings and I do what I'm told.
My keys are in the pocket of my coat; my wallet is in the pocket of my dress, and only my cosmetics, checkbook, pen, handkerchief and change purse are in my bag.
That way, smart money says, I cut my losses.
That I will be mugged someday, smart money says, is an inevitability.

Good Design, Good Prices Uptown
LEAD: THEY look like 21 individual brick houses along Manhattan Avenue and 104th and 105th Streets, but they are actually a single building of 74 condominium apartments.
The building, Manhattan Valley Townhouses, was finished last year.
It was intended for families of moderate income, defined as those with about $30,000 gross income for a family of four.

Campeau Trustee Forms Creditors' Panels
LEAD: Committees representing bondholders that hold much of the debt of the retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation were appointed yesterday by the United States Trustee overseeing the stores' bankruptcy proceedings.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Jan. 12 about the authorship of an article that appeared in the quarterly Daedalus under the pseudonym Z referred incorrectly to Marx's essay ''The 18th Brumaire of Louis Napoleon Bonaparte.'' The title of the essay is the date in the French Revolutionary calendar on which Napoleon seized power in France in 1799, not the date in 1851 when his nephew Louis Napoleon Bonaparte overthrew the Second French Republic.

Irish Leader to Visit Bush
LEAD: Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, current president of the European Community, will fly to Washington for talks with President Bush on Feb. 27, a Government spokesman said today.
Ireland currently holds the rotating presidency of the 12-nation European Community, and Prime Minister Haughey says his country can play an important role in European-American relations.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Cracks in Concrete Floor
Q.
My basement floor has hairline cracks in the concrete, and these cracks seem to become more numerous and more noticeable as time goes on.
I am concerned about water seeping up through the cracks in a heavy rain.
How can I fix them?
A.
The cracks can be repaired by filling in with hydraulic cement, following the directions on the package.


Costs Can Go Downhill If Skiers Are Flexible
LEAD: rrAt the start of each ski season, skiers are greeted with the news that lift-ticket prices have gone up.
Usually the amount of the increases is only a dollar or two, but over the years this has brought some single-day weekend tickets to $35 and $37 at Eastern ski areas.

LEAD: Steffi Graf, the 1990 Australian Open champion and the world's top-ranked women's tennis player for the last three years, suffered a thumb injury Wednesday when she fell while cross-country skiing in St.
Moritz, Switzerland.
She will be sidelined for 10 to 12 weeks.

LEAD: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company, a large generic drug company that last week recalled its best-selling product, has temporarily suspended shipment of all its prescription drugs while it negotiates with the Food and Drug Administration on auditing more of its operations, an agency official said today.

Obscenities, Hang-Ups and Technology
LEAD: When the telephone rings, some people, curious, still leap to answer.
Others don't, wary of an annoying sales pitch or indecent proposition.
Now phone companies are able to remove the mystery and perhaps some of the anxiety.
With a $50 attachment and for a monthly fee of $6 or $7, a customer can see the caller's number on a screen while the phone is ringing, and decide whether to answer.

The Editorial Notebook;   Flags! Horns! Costa Rica!
LEAD: To people in the U.S., Central America seems a region of unrelieved violence and insecurity, dominated by extremists and peopled by death squads, drug lords, shadowy agents and assorted pistoleros.
To the visitor, Costa Rica thus comes as not just a pleasant surprise but a genuine shock.
Wedged between Panama and Nicaragua, this little nation, no bigger than Vermont and New Hampshire, seems literally to revel in democracy.


Havens for the Heart in a Hard-Boiled City
LEAD: ROMANTIC, in the traditional sense of the word, is not how one expects a casual observer to describe New York City circa 1990.
Our steely, impetuous metropolis plays hard to get with new suitors, in contrast to her soft and pretty cousins like Paris, Rome and Barcelona - a saucy Katharine Hepburn to a come-hither Lana Turner.


Carlyle Discloses 6.27% Harsco Stake
LEAD: The Carlyle Group L.P., a Washington investment firm, said that it had acquired 6.27 percent of the Harsco Corporation and that it believed the pipe-fitting and metals concern, based in Camp Hill, Pa., was ''a potentially attractive acquisition candidate.''

Weicker Sees Possible Run For Governor
LEAD: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s last address to Connecticut, the state he represented in the Senate for 18 years, was a concession speech here in Town Hall on the cold afternoon of Nov. 9, 1988.
As his supporters stood stunned and his wife, Claudia, held back tears, Mr.
Weicker spoke of ''no excuses, no regrets, no griping, no comebacks.

Bruce Lee Albert has been named a partner and also executive vice president and director of account services at Lord Einstein O'Neill &amp; Partners.


Holiday Inn Deal Completed by Bass
LEAD: Bass P.L.C. completed its acquisition of Holiday Inns Inc. for $2.2 billion and said the motel chain's headquarters would be moved to Atlanta from Memphis.

Review/Theater;   Bogosian Illuminates Life in the City
LEAD: It's not news that Eric Bogosian is a great talent, a chameleon actor and penetrating social observer whose one-man shows have staked out their own mean streets in the crowded 1980's theatrical territory inhabited by Lily Tomlin, Spalding Gray, Whoopi Goldberg and so many others, from stand-up comedians to sit-down performance artists.

Judge Rules Noriega Trial Must Proceed
LEAD: A Federal district judge declared today that Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega must stand trial on drug-trafficking charges.
In so doing, the judge rejected defense lawyers' arguments that United States courts have no jurisdiction over the fallen Panamanian leader.

Coffee Prices Rise on Fear Of a Dock Strike in Brazil
LEAD: Prices of coffee futures rose yesterday on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid mounting concern about supply exacerbated by the threat of a dock workers' strike next week in Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer.


Kansas State Surges to Upset Missouri by 65-58
LEAD: Steve Henson and Jean Derouillere led an 18-2 run late in the second half tonight that carried Kansas State to a 65-58 victory over top-ranked Missouri.


Review/Music;   High-Energy Mendelssohn On the Organ
LEAD: Anthony Newman's immense physical talent for playing keyboard instruments is certainly basic to his prolific ventures in the music business.
On Sunday afternoon at Holy Trinity Church, Mr.
Newman roared through six Mendelssohn organ sonatas and three Preludes and Fugues as if the effort were barely worth mentioning.


Review/Film;   Coming of Age as a Gypsy With a Turkey for a Friend
LEAD: One of the roles in Emir Kusturica's ''Time of the Gypsies'' is played by a turkey, and the word role is not used lightly.
The turkey actually plays a part.
For a time, he is the pet and companion of Perhan (Davor Dujmovic), the oafish, naive and highly sensitive gypsy boy who is this coming-of-age film's hero; after that, the turkey winds up in a pot.


Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East Germany Agrees to Pay Reparations to the Jewish Victims of the Nazis
LEAD: East Germany, which has long refused to accept responsibility for the crimes of the Nazis against the Jews, has for the first time agreed to pay reparations to Jewish victims, the World Jewish Congress said yesterday.


Bishop Repeated Church Teaching to Governor;   Under Another Rubric
LEAD: To the Editor:


New Head of Danaher From Black &amp; Decker
LEAD: The Danaher Corporation, a Washington-based industrial company built by the Rales brothers, has chosen George M. Sherman, a top executive with the Black &amp; Decker Corporation, to be president and chief executive.

To My Social Security Critics . . .
LEAD: Two criticisms of my proposal to reduce Social Security tax rates are in general circulation.

LEAD:

Review/Art;   Caravaggio: A Tale of Two Lutes
LEAD: ''A CARAVAGGIO REDISCOVERED: The Lute Player,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an exhibition modest only in size.
It includes paintings of the first rank, paintings that have not been on view in years and paintings that have been unjustly ignored.
It juxtaposes these works with related prints, musical scores and instruments to give a vivid sense of the cultural milieu of the late 16th century, in which Caravaggio was fortunate enough to find himself.


Upheaval in the East: Diplomacy;   Baker Meets in Moscow On Arms and Afghans
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d opened talks today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, by setting out a variety of arms control initiatives, as well as a new American proposal for solving the Afghan conflict.

LEAD: Presiden tBush will nominate Adm.
Frank B. Kelso 2d to be the new Chief of Naval Operations, the White House announced Wednesday in San Francisco, where the President was traveling.
Admiral Kelso, now commander in chief of the Navy's Atlantic Command and supreme Allied commander for the Atlantic, would succeed Adm.

Islanders Frustrate Flyers
LEAD: When the 5-5 tie between the Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers was finished in the Spectrum tonight, the New York players and coaches were talking about the goal judge, and the reporters were firing slap-shot-like questions in his direction.

12 Held in Fake Train Ticket Scheme
LEAD: Instead of buying their monthly railroad commuter tickets the old-fashioned way, at the ticket window in a train station, about two dozen Metro-North commuters gave their money to someone they knew - someone with a photocopying machine, the authorities said yesterday.
A very good photocopying machine.


Loss of Balloons Hinders Drug Vigil
LEAD: A $7 million radar balloon that was lost after breaking free from its tether and the grounding of two others have left a gap in the efforts to prevent drugs from being flown into this country from Mexico.

Senate, 92 to 4, Wants U.S. Data On Crimes That Spring From Hate
LEAD: The Senate approved legislation today that would require the Federal Government to collect statistics on crimes motivated by prejudice based on race, ethnicity, religion or sexual orientation.


Chronicle
LEAD: STANLEY BREZENOFF, the former First Deputy Mayor of New York City, will continue to work on health-care policy when he joins the Commonwealth Fund as a senior program adviser on Feb. 20.
Before taking the Deputy Mayor's job, Mr.
Brezenoff, 52, served as the president of the city's Health and Hospitals


Gotti Jury Deliberates a Third Day Without a Verdict in Assault Case
LEAD: The jury in the John Gotti assault and conspiracy trial in Manhattan deliberated for a third day yesterday without reaching a verdict.


Profit Declines at Colgate
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 50.7 percent and its 1989 earnings slipped 11.9 percent from 1988, when the company profited from the sale of its Kendall health-care subsidiary.


Maria Gambarelli Fenton, 89, A Metropolitan Opera Ballerina
LEAD: Maria Gambarelli Fenton, who was prima ballerina of the Metropolitan Opera Ballet and headed the bills that opened the Capital and Roxy theaters and Radio City Music Hall, died after a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday at Huntington Hospital in Huntington, L.I.
She was 89 years old.


Monroe Last of '73 Title Knicks To Be Elected to Hall of Fame
LEAD: Earl (the Pearl) Monroe, who worked his magic on the pro basketball courts for 13 seasons, was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame yesterday along with Elvin Hayes, Dave Bing and the late Neil Johnston.

Knicks Hold Off Warriors' Late Rally
LEAD: With Patrick Ewing already saddled with two fouls and the Golden State Warriors ahead of the Knicks, 27-26, with 1 minute 39 seconds left in the opening quarter last night, Coach Stu Jackson of the Knicks decided there was no substitute for good substitutes.


Justin Acquisition Sought by Choctaw
LEAD: Choctaw Securities L.P., an investment partnership based in Kansas City, Mo., said it would ''seek to negotiate a mutually agreeable acquisition'' with the management of Justin Industries.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Choctaw said it had held discussions with financing sources for a possible bid.


Sequestering a Jury: The Chances a Judge Takes
LEAD: When the judge at the John Gotti assault trial decided to sequester the jurors for the length of the trial, he took a calculated risk.


Bearish Mood Is Overtaking Stock Investors, Study Says
LEAD: Investor sentiment has reached its most pessimistic level since June 1982, just before the start of the 1980's bull market, according to a weekly study that is closely watched by Wall Street.

The Details Come Out In Latest Infiniti Spots
LEAD: The latest television commercials from Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos for Nissan's Infiniti open with - no surprise - scenes of nature.
But then come the car and hard statistics - 278 horsepower, a 4.5-liter engine - satisfying dealers who have been screaming for details since the Zen-like campaign made its debut last fall.


Sweden Gets Inflation Plan
LEAD: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson said today that Sweden's economy was ''falling apart'' and that his Government would resign unless Parliament banned strikes and put into effect his plan for a two-year freeze on wages and prices.

LEAD:
James Moody's Jazz


Soldier String Quartet
LEAD: The Soldier String Quartet - a string quartet that plays with amplification and a percussionist - is to perform music by Dave Soldier and Elliott Sharp, and transcriptions of songs by the blues singer Muddy Waters and the soul singer James Brown tonight at 7 and 9 at Pyramid, 101 Avenue A, at Sixth Street.


Grand Met May Sell Alpo Pet Foods Unit
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate, said today that it was exploring the possibility of selling its Alpo Pet Foods Inc. division.


Occidental's Notes
LEAD: As part of its continuing debt restructuring, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation this week announced plans to redeem about $550 million of its outstanding 10 percent senior notes due in 1991 at a price of 100.
The notes were issued March 1986, and the company said the interest payment due on March 15, 1990, would be paid in the usual manner to registered note holders of record on March 1.


At the Bar
LEAD: Along Court Street in Brooklyn, in the high-rise rookeries where trial lawyers congregate, there are 65 years' worth of Izzy Halpern stories.


Major Oil Spills In the Past Year
LEAD:
March 24, 1989: Tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound, Alaska, spilling 10.92 million gallons of crude oil.
June 23, 1989: Tanker World Prodigy ran aground at mouth of Narragansett Bay off Newport, R.I., spilling 280,000 gallons of heating oil.
June 23, 1989: Tug-driven barge collided with cargo vessel in the Houston Ship Channel near La Porte, Tex., spilling 250,000 gallons of crude.


Market Place;   First Interstate Looks for Capital
LEAD: THE old line used to be that a banker would lend any amount of money, so long as the borrower could prove he did not need it.
Now it is the bank that needs the money, and the question is whether stock buyers will provide it.


Restaurants
LEAD: Manhattan still awaits a great Thai restaurant.
There are a dozen or so places around town that turn out a striking dish or two - and there are some solid family-run places in Brooklyn and Queens -yet no place has captured in a big way the delicacy and diversity of this underrated cuisine.
If pressed to recommend Thai food, I usually mention the Los Angeles import Tommy Tang's on Greenwich Street.

Nature's Forces Unleashed, in Miniature
LEAD: Odd things are happening at the World Financial Center.
Tornado clouds are rising, pendulums are wildly twitching, electronic flowers are blooming, and voices and faces are being distorted beyond recognition.


Ferranti Unit Deal Set With Thomson
LEAD: Thomson S.A. of France said it would pay about $57 million for half of Ferranti P.L.C.'s sonar business in trying to become Europe's leading military electronics contractor through ventures and acquisitions.
Under the agreement, Ferranti will transfer its sonar operations to a new company of which Thomson will own 50 percent.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages on Tues-day about the trainer Shug McGaughey referred incorrectly to a record he had hoped to attain on Nov. 6.
He could not have become the first trainer to win three cup races in a day; D. Wayne Lukas has already done so.


Top Savings Bailout Official Said to Consider Resigning
LEAD: Daniel P. Kearney, the president and chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation's Oversight Board, has threatened to resign the position he has held for only a few weeks because of differences with the Treasury Department, Government officials said today.


Where Love Can Bloom
LEAD: Given the freedom, funds and felicitous companionship, one could get an exhilarating head start on St.
Valentine's Day (which is Wednesday) this weekend.
One possible scenario could begin late on Friday afternoon.


Westchester Panel Votes to Avoid Layoffs
LEAD: The Westchester Legislature's budget committee agreed today to avoid layoffs of more than 400 county employees by restoring $14.5 million to the 1990 county budget.

New York Times Company Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
LEAD: The New York Times Company yesterday reported a loss of $19 million in the fourth quarter, compared with net income of $50.4 million, or 64 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988.


A Gravity Boost to Goal: Jupiter '95
LEAD: Completing the first leg of a long interplanetary journey, the Galileo spacecraftwill swing by Venus early tomorrow in a maneuver using the planet's gravity to get a boost in velocity and a change in trajectory so it can reach its ultimate target, Jupiter, in 1995.


End to Bush Observer Team's Role In Nicaraguan Vote Raises Debate
LEAD: A decision to disband an official American delegation that was to observe the Nicaraguan elections has intensified a political battle shaping up over the fairness of the campaign.


Jane Yockel, Arts Administrator, 63
LEAD: Jane Yockel, an arts administrator known for her support of avant-garde dance, theater and music, died of a heart attack on Jan. 31.
She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

S.&amp;P. Downgrades Sears On $5.6 Billion of Securities
LEAD: The slower-than-expected recovery in Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company's retailing operations has resulted in the downgrading of about $5.6 billion in the corporation's securities, the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.


Upheaval in the East;   Hard Feelings for Communist Faithful
LEAD: Anatoly S. Pankov, a Communist candidate in local legislative elections next month, is not elated about the announcement on Wednesday that his party is willing to give up its 70-year monopoly on power.
It is not that he views the decision as a threat to his election.
But he says he is afraid that the step comes too late to save the party from further decline, and possibly open division.

Apple Suit Delay
LEAD: The closely watched computer copyright lawsuit filed by Apple Computer Inc. against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company may be delayed by the departure of the judge presiding over the case.
Federal District Judge William W. Schwarzer in San Francisco said he will take a five-year leave to direct the Federal Judicial Center in Washington.


Bergen County Official Won't Seek Re-election
LEAD: The first Bergen County Executive, William D. McDowell, announced today that he would not seek re-election.


Lebanese Weigh Intervention in Christian Enclave
LEAD: President Elias Hrawi conferred with aides on a possible military intervention in the war-torn Christian enclave today as sporadic clashes and sharp political disagreement kept tension high between rival Christian factions.


Chronicle
LEAD: A new team of defense lawyers for LEONA HELMSLEY said yesterday they had uncovered ''shocking new evidence'' that would prove her innocent of evading about $750,000 in New York State income taxes.
Already sentenced to four years in prison for Federal income tax fraud, Mrs.
Helmsley, 69, has rejected an offer from state prosecutors to plead guilty.


Oil Tanker in Pacific Spills 300,000 Gallons Off Coast

Review/Art;   Good Humor and Doom From Robert Moskowitz
LEAD: The Robert Moskowitz retrospective opening tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art begins with the collage-paintings of 1961-63 that made Mr.
Moskowitz one of the bright young stars of the New York art scene.
The painted surfaces are thin.
The dominant color is a yellow ocher.
There is a nerviness and freedom in the feeling for materials.

Rabid Raccoons Are on Way
LEAD: Raccoons carrying the deadly rabies virus have been found dangerously close to the New York border, prompting state officials to issue a rabies warning.
Rabid raccoons are threatening the state's Southern Tier, portions of the mid-Hudson Valley and New York City, the officials said, and raccoon rabies is expected to enter New York State from Pennsylvania this spring.

TV Weekend;   Docudrama That's Based On a Drama
LEAD: Not all docudramas are based on best-selling books.
Tonight's ''Great Performances'' presentation, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, is offering a BBC revival of Terence Rattigan's ''Winslow Boy.'' With names changed, the play is based on a case that riveted England's attention in 1908.
The play, produced in London in 1946, was the first major success for Rattigan, who went on to write ''The Browning Version,'' ''The Deep Blue Sea'' and ''Separate Tables.

Theus Lifts Magic Over Sixers
Reggie Theus scored Orlando's last 8 points, including an 18-footer turnaround jumper with one second left last night that gave the Orlando Magic a 101-99 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.
Theus missed 10 of his first 12 shots but sparked Orlando with 13 points in the fourth quarter and finished with 17.

Flower, at 120 Million Years, Is Oldest
LEAD: A tiny fossilized plant, barely one inch tall and resembling today's black pepper plant, has been identified by scientists at Yale University as the oldest known flower.
It lived 120 million years ago and its flower was probably a drab green or beige - hardly the thing to inspire nosegays for dinosaurs.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 495 money market mutual funds increased $2.73 billion, to $387.39 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 150 institutional funds increased by $401.9 million, to $92.11 billion.
The assets of the 244 general-purpose funds were up by $1.02 billion, to $130.87 billion.

It did wipe out some deductions, like sales tax.

And differing state laws across the country may mean you have to keep the same detailed records as before.

Cars With Blaring Radios Become a New York City Nuisance;   Get All the Noisemakers
LEAD: To the Editor I read ''Ban the Boom,'' your Jan. 31 editorial on banning ''boom'' cars, with interest.
I have lived on East 34th Street for the last nine years and am familiar with boom cars, boom fire engines, boom police cars, boom garbage trucks and all the other boomers that are so much a part of life in New York


Producer Prices Post 1.8% Jump
LEAD: Reflecting December's exceptionally harsh weather, producer prices soared 1.8 percent in January, the biggest rise in more than 15 years, the Labor Department reported today.

Review/Dance;   A Richard Tanner Premiere by the City Ballet
LEAD: The only premiere of the New York City Ballet's winter season is Richard Tanner's ''Prague Symphony'' to Mozart, which was presented Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

Soviet Consumers Face Cutback In Meat as Feed Grain Runs Out
LEAD: Dispirited Soviet consumers face a cutback in meat production because the country has run out of grain to feed its cattle, the Government's chief food official says in remarks published today.

Leaving Trenton, Cooperman Still Seeks Answers
LEAD: New Jersey's Education Commissioner, Dr.
Saul Cooperman, leaves office at the end of June, content that changes he has engineered have eased the state's teacher shortage, toughened tests for basic skills and allowed the state to take over troubled districts to try to improve education in them.

Callers Besiege CBS Over Rooney
LEAD: CBS was deluged with telephone calls yesterday, some from people supporting Andy Rooney, others praising the network's three-month suspension of the ''60 Minutes'' commentator.
Network spokesmen would not say exactly how many calls had been received.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1990
LEAD:
The Economy


Francis Bowditch, 77, Dean and Headmaster
LEAD: E. Francis Bowditch, dean of students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1951 to 1956 and later headmaster of the New Lincoln School in Manhattan, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday in Boca Grande, Fla.
He was 77 years old and had homes in Boca Grande and Madison, Conn.


Happy Occasions Give Rise To Gifts for the Neediest Cases
LEAD: Celebrating an occasion of personal joy seems to bring out the charitable instinct in many people.
Births, engagements, weddings, significant birthdays and anniversaries have all been cited with gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.


Devils, in Fits and Starts, Rally Against Capitals
LEAD: The Devils rallied from a two-goal deficit in the third period tonight and defeated the Capitals, 5-3, here in a game with more stoppages than a busy city street during rush hour.

Anchor Shortage
LEAD: Dan Rather and Peter Jennings went to Moscow this week, but Tom Brokaw stayed home.


Bond Sale Is Postponed By Nabisco
LEAD: In another indication of the weakness in the market for ''junk bonds,'' RJR Nabisco Inc., whose $4 billion in securities dominate the high-yield market, has postponed a $1.25 billion junk bond offering.


Bridge
LEAD: It is common to end a deal with the sad realization that a very strong hand was not quite strong enough.
But the converse is rare.
Have you ever had a very weak hand that proves to be not quite weak enough?


Toyota's Re-entry Into the Mini-van Market
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a mini-van here today, the Previa, which features some unusual solutions to technical problems that have vexed such designers for more than a decade.


Apple Names Head of Europe Unit
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had promoted Soren Olsson to president of Apple Computer Europe Inc.


Georg Borgstrom, 77, Authority on Hunger
LEAD: Georg Arne Borgstrom, a scientist, geographer and ecologist who was an authority on hunger, died Wednesday in Goteborg, Sweden.
He was 77 years old and had lived in Goteborg since 1988.


Walk-In Doctors' Offices: Care for Those in a Hurry
LEAD: Storefront doctors' offices, where patients can be treated without appointments for all but the most serious medical problems, are thriving in many New York City neighborhoods.

Grand Canyon Out Of Triple Crown
LEAD: Grand Canyon, the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 5, will be sidelined for four months and miss the Triple Crown races because of a pulled muscle in his left front leg, the trainer D. Wayne Lukas said today in a written statement.

Upheaval in the East;   To the West, Parties Applaud, Warily
LEAD: Struggling to adjust to events in Eastern Europe, Western Europe's leading Communist parties have seen themselves forced to applaud the crisis convulsing international Communism to preserve some credibility before their own democratic electorates.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, a theater review on Sunday about the Manhattan Punch Line's sixth annual festival of one-act comedies appeared with an incomplete paragraph.
It should have read: ''Under the clockwork direction and choreography of Jason McConnell Buzas, the cast -Randy Danson, Liz Larsen, Ryan Hilliard and Chris Welles in the title role - turns 'Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread' into a vintage skit worthy of a 'Forbidden Off Broadway.


Continental Route
LEAD: An administrative law judge recommended Thursday that Continental Airlines be awarded a daily Houston-to-Tokyo route.
The recommendation needs Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner's approval.
Continental, based in Houston, has proposed providing daily service between Houston and Tokyo via Honolulu.

No Camps Without Agreement, Owners Say
LEAD: Negotiators for the owners of the 26 major league baseball clubs studiously avoided the word ''lockout'' today as they reaffirmed that they would not open spring training camps until they had a new labor agreement with the players.


Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Czechs Hear Soviets Promise Partial Troop Pullout Soon
LEAD: The Soviet Union will begin withdrawing some troops from Czechoslovakia this month and considers ''realistic'' a Czechoslovak demand that a substantial part of its forces be out by May 30, a Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister told the Czechoslovak press agency today.

Review/Film;   Out of a Coma, Still Dapper and Disarming
LEAD: In ''Hard to Kill,'' Steven Seagal, the latest and suavest inheritor of the Charles Bronson-Chuck Norris-Bruce Lee action-film mantle, comes out of a seven-year coma looking a lot better than most people would look going in.
The tanned, trim, very carefully groomed Mr.
Seagal, who sports a sleek ponytail and favors starched white shirts even though they often wind up with bloodstains, is significantly more dapper than the Los Angeles police detective he is supposed to be.

Marine Bank Posts $119.9 Million Loss From Bad Loans
LEAD: Marine Midland Banks Inc. yesterday announced a loss of $119.9 million in the fourth quarter because of problems with commercial real estate loans in the United States.


Moses Training For '92 Games
LEAD: Seventeen months after his last race, Edwin Moses said today that he intended to return to competition this year and continue running through the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain.


Washington Talk;   Hearings On the Hill: Inquisition Or Inquiry?
LEAD: Witnesses appearing in the marbled and mahogany hearing rooms on Capitol Hill can be forgiven a bit of confusion over whether they have been invited to an inquiry or to an inquisition.


Peter Malatesta, 57, Aide to Spiro Agnew
LEAD: Peter J. Malatesta, a restaurateur and aide to former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, died of pancreatic cancer on Thursday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.
He was 57 years old.


The Perfect Rose
LEAD: The traditional Valentine is the red rose.
One can say it all, but a dozen are always welcome.


Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian Parliament Calls Soviet Annexation Unlawful
LEAD: The Lithuanian parliament has approved a resolution declaring Lithuania's 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union ''unlawful and invalid'' and seeking talks with Moscow on independence.


Atomic Workers' Suit Cleared by U.S. Judge
LEAD: A Federal judge has cleared the way for trial of a decade-old suit by former Nevada Test Site workers and their survivors who contend that the workers contracted cancer and other diseases from nuclear weapons testing.


Braniff Will Sell Gates at Orlando
LEAD: Braniff Inc. agreed to sell its three passenger gates at Orlando International Airport to Chicago-based Midway Airlines Inc. for $2.25 million, a Braniff spokeswoman said.
Braniff, which is seeking Chapter 11 protection for the second time in a decade, will ask permission to conclude the sale at a hearing on Feb.


Chevron in Sale
LEAD: The Chevron Corporation, the San Francisco-based oil company, said it would sell its operations in Freeport, the Bahamas, to the Venezuelan state-owned oil company for about $100 million.
As part of the transaction, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. will acquire an inactive 500,000-barrel-a-day refinery, which was shut in 1985.

Douglas Long, Newspaper Executive, 65
LEAD: Douglas Long, chairman of The Sunday Correspondent, a British weekly newspaper, and co-founder of the daily Independent, died of liver cancer on Wednesday.
He was 65 years old.
Mr.
Long was deputy managing director of the Mirror Group of newspapers, whose flagship is The Daily Mirror, and in 1980 was made deputy chief executive of the group.


Missed Catch Is More Prized and Elusive
LEAD: Lawyers offered varied explanations for John Gotti's most recent acquittal, ranging from the psyches of jurors to the myth-making of the media to the tawdriness of the case against him.
Like all instant analyses, they made an outcome jurors wrestled over for four days seem all but inevitable.

Patents;   Bill Seeks To Protect Gene Work
LEAD: Imagine that a brewer has developed a low-alcohol beer with all the weight and flavor of a dark German lager.
The crucial ingredient is a novel strain of yeast that he has spent years breeding and has patented.
But just as sales are picking up, a French company begins importing a perfect imitation.


Tyson at 220 For Title Fight
LEAD: Mike Tyson weighed in at 220 pounds today for his heavyweight title defense against James (Buster) Douglas, who weighed 231 1/2.


John H. Poelker, Ex-St. Louis Mayor, 76
LEAD: John H. Poelker, an accountant who served one term as Mayor after 10 years as comptroller, died today after a long struggle against cancer.
He was 76 years old.


U.S. Jury Clears A Former Mayor In Bribery Case
LEAD: Former Mayor James E. Dyer of Danbury, who had been accused of shaking down developers, was acquitted today of all but one charge in his Federal corruption trial.


James Ryan Dies at 74; Ex-A.T.&amp;T. Executive
LEAD: James Vincent Ryan, a former assistant vice president of public relations for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J.
He was 74 years old and lived in Summit.


Iran Reaffirms Rushdie Death Threat
LEAD: Iran's supreme religious leader said today that a decree calling for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie, issued by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini a year ago, remained in force.


Slain American Found At Inca Ruins in Peru
LEAD: An American man was found shot to death amid ancient stone ruins in the Andean city of Cuzco, Peru's tourism center and once the capital of the Incas, the police said today.

Review/Pop;   Anything Goes as the B-52's Give a Shindig on Stage
LEAD: Silliness and optimism became amiably subversive when the B-52's performed on Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall in the second of three sold-out concerts.
The B-52's turn eccentricities and campy inside jokes into public revelry, sharing the possibility of pleasure in dangerous times. ''Do anything you want,'' Fred Schneider exhorted in ''Dance This Mess


Late Goal by Turgeon Frustrates Rangers
LEAD: The seconds couldn't tick off the clock fast enough for Mike Richter, the Rangers' goalie, as he stood in his crease, the game about to expire but the puck again entering his zone.

Icahn on T.W.A. Woe: 'We're at Crossroads'
LEAD: When Carl C. Icahn won control of Trans World Airlines in August 1985 he donned a pilot's uniform jacket in his office and shouted joyfully: ''We've got ourselves an airline!
We've got ourselves an airline!'' These days, Mr.
Icahn sounds far less jubilant as he tries to determine the course of a carrier whose fortunes have fallen considerably in the last year.


News Summary
LEAD: International
3-8
A U.S plan for deeper troop cuts in Europe would be acceptable to President Gorbachev, but only if it left both countries with equal troop levels, said Secretary Baker, who met with the Soviet leader.
Mr.
Baker also suggested that Washington might be prepared to accept a reunified Germany that would not necessarily be a full member in NATO.


Prices of Treasury Securities Soar
LEAD: Treasury securities prices soared yesterday as investors rushed to lock in yields, which have been tumbling since the conclusion of this week's refunding auctions.
Dealers said the same high yields that led to the successful sale of $30 billion of Treasury notes and bonds attracted investors to the secondary market in these issues.

Brown Chooses Top Police Assistant
LEAD: A 48-year-old police commander, whose reputation as a management expert helped propel his rapid rise within the New York City Police Department in the last six years, was appointed as First Deputy Police Commissioner yesterday, the department's second highest post.


Wanted: Education Chief With Open Ears
LEAD: New Jersey's new Governor, Jim Florio, wants an education commissioner who will involve more voices in policy making, aides say.


Review/Music;   Previn Fill In for Ozawa With the Boston
LEAD: The Boston Symphony concerts Wednesday and Thursday nights at Carnegie Hall were originally to have been conducted by Seiji Ozawa, and to have offered a rather more interesting program than usual -Haydn's ''London'' Symphony, Yo-Yo Ma in Shostakovich's Cello Concerto No. 2 and, at the very end, Rossini's ''Semiramide''


Betsy J. Gootrad Becomes Bride
LEAD: The marriage of Betsy Jane Gootrad to Dr.
David Michael Kasper took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.
The Rev.
F.
Forrester Church performed the ceremony.
The bride, 33 years old, is a daughter of Harold Gootrad of Paris and Helen Gootrad of New York.
A graduate of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., she graduated cum laude from Harvard University and is a managing director of Fomon &amp; Gootrad Holdings, money managers in New York.


Bankruptcy Can Be a Fate Worse Than Liquidation;   Rehabilitation the Goal
LEAD: To the Editor:


GOTTI NOT GUILTY ON ALL 6 CHARGES IN ASSAULT TRIAL
LEAD: John Gotti, who has been described as an icon of the underworld and the nation's top Mafia boss, was pronounced not guilty of assault and conspiracy charges in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday.

Y.&amp;R. Pleads Guilty in Bribe Case
LEAD: Young &amp; Rubicam Inc., one of the world's largest advertising agencies, pleaded guilty yesterday and agreed to pay a $500,000 fine to settle the Federal Government's charge that starting in 1981 it had engaged in a conspiracy to bribe foreign officials to obtain and hold the Jamaican Government's tourism account.


More Wheat for China
LEAD: China has been authorized to buy an additional one million metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department announced on Thursday.
Under Secretary Richard T. Crowder said the wheat would be available to China under the department's Export Enhancement Program, which allows private exporters to sell American commodities at reduced prices and then collect Government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses.


New Romanian Unity Council Holds Its First Meeting


Baltimore Hospital to Start Drug Tests on Its Physicians
LEAD: For the first time, a hospital will conduct random drug and alcohol tests on all doctors who deal directly with patients.


Mortgage Rates Rise
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.21 percent, up from 10.17 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.46 percent this week, up from 8.45 percent the week before.


Bond Fails to Remove Breweries' Receiver
LEAD: Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., the flagship company of the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond, failed today to persuade a court to free its Australian breweries from receivership.

Fire Halts Thousands on IRT
LEAD: A fire burned track ties on the West Side IRT line and delayed 10,000 people yesterday afternoon.
The fire, at 72d Street and Broadway, was reported at 3:50 P.M., after debris on the southbound express track ignited, a spokesman for the Transit Authority, Termaine Garden, said.
The No. 1, 3 and 9 lines halted for 35 minutes.


Elizabeth Bryan Patten, Civic Leader, 82
LEAD: Elizabeth Bryan Patten, a Chattanooga philanthropist and civic leader, died Thursday at Memorial Hospital in Chattanooga.
She was 82 years old.


Big Cocaine Seizure in Mexico
LEAD: The authorities have seized nearly 4,000 pounds of cocaine from a drug ring that was run out of a Mexico City prison with the support of five corrupt police officers, including two members of the country's special anti-narcotics force, the Attorney General's Office said today.


Ancient Roman Silver to Be Sold
LEAD: Fourteen lavishly decorated vessels, said to be from the fourth to the fifth centuries and described as the largest and finest collection of ancient Roman silver ever uncovered, are being sold through Sotheby's.
The presale estimate for the collection is $70 million.

Looking at Legends New and Old
LEAD: With the sun shining brightly on a typical Florida day, basketball's top players arrived here today as the National Basketball Association's All-Star weekend began.


Cold Pushes Up Prices


Coffee Rises to 5-Month High On Concern Over Supplies
LEAD: Coffee futures prices surged yesterday to their highest levels in five months on New York's Coffee, Sugar &amp; Cocoa Exchange, fueled by rumors of canceled Mexican coffee shipments and other supply concerns.

Del Shannon, a 60's Songwriter, Dies at Home in Apparent Suicide
LEAD: Del Shannon, who wrote and sang the hit, ''Runaway'' in 1961, was found dead in his home, apparently from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head, the authorities said today.
He was 50 years old.


Sports People: TENNIS;   An Honor for Evert
LEAD: President Bush yesterday awarded the Flo Hyman Award for excellence in sports to Chris Evert, the recently retired tennis pro, calling her ''the role model for our nation's young women.''


Crazy Eddie Arrest Order
LEAD: A Federal district judge yesterday morning ordered the arrest of Eddie Antar, the founder of Crazy Eddie Inc., after Mr.
Antar failed to make a court appearance in a civil case and also disregarded an order to return $52 million that the Government contends is illegal profits.


Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Coach Overthrown
LEAD: When Drake University plays Wichita State today, Eddie Fields, an assistant coach, will be coaching Drake.
That's because Tom Abatemarco was removed as head coach Wednesday after the players said they were upset over his ''inhuman treatment'' and would no longer play or practice for him.
Abatemarco was reassigned to unspecified duties in the athletic department.


Shirley Verrett to Open Lincoln Center Series
LEAD: The soprano Shirley Verrett is to be the first guest in the spring series of Lincoln Center Offstage evenings, at 6 P.M. on Thursday at Paul Hall at the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street.
The program consists of an hourlong discussion between a moderator and the performer.
An informal wine-and-cheese reception follows.


Lord Maclean, 73, Aide to Queen; Organized 1981 Royal Wedding
LEAD: Lord Maclean, the former chief official of Queen Elizabeth II's household and organizer of the 1981 wedding of the Prince of Wales, died on Thursday, his family announced today.
He was 73 years old.


Quarantine: Sometimes a Duty
LEAD: When to employ a quarantine, the isolation or detention of individuals determined to be an infectious danger to others, is not a new dilemma in public health -especially not in the city of Typhoid Mary.
Yet the recent media hullabaloo and protest circus over Mayor David Dinkins's appointment of Woodrow Myers as New York City Health Commissioner badly confused this issue.


Elegantly Triumphant, Gotti Greets Admirers
LEAD: He left the courthouse through the judge's entrance, smiling and dapper like a triumphant politician, and the press and the crowd of admirers were waiting, as always, to pay homage to this man with the aura of invincibility.


Upheaval in the East: The Germans;   EAST BERLIN'S RUIN PREDICTED IN BONN
LEAD: A senior adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that East Germany might become insolvent in a few days.
But spokesmen for the Governments of East and West Germany rejected the statement, as did bankers and diplomats.

LEAD: Golfers at the Turtle Cove Golf Complex in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx teeing off in shirtsleeves yesterday as the temperature reached 63 degrees to break the record of 60 degrees set in 1949. (NYT/Eddie Hausner)

HOLIDAY ON MONDAY
LEAD:
Lincoln's Brithday will be celebrated Monday. Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Government offices: Federal and state open. City closed.
Post Office: Regular service.
Banks: Option to close.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation: No pick-up, recycling collection or street cleaning.


NAMIBIANS ADOPT NEW CONSTITUTION
LEAD: Namibia's Parliament voted for a liberal democratic constitution today and removed the last barrier to independence after 70 years of South African rule.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is prepared to accept President Bush's proposal for deeper troop cuts in Europe, but only if the plan leaves both countries with equal levels, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said this morning.

Florida Airport in Race With Growth
LEAD: The ponds, palm trees and other oasis-like amenities of Orlando International Airport are under siege.
Thousands of construction workers, hundreds of trucks with tons of dirt and concrete, and 45,000 passengers pour in and out of the airport every day.


Kodak Recycling
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company announced it would begin recycling its Fling, Stretch and Weekend disposable cameras.
The company said the program is intended to reduce solid waste.
A New York public affairs research organization said last month that the cameras were among the worst examples of overpackaged and nonrecyclable consumer products.


Corrections
LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday about First Interstate Bancorp misidentified a Texas money manager.
He is Shad Rowe.


Fed Decision Is Disclosed On Easing Interest Rates
LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their December meeting on a further easing of their high-interest-rate policies because of the sluggish economy, according to minutes released today.


Disney Bans Commercials At Showings of Its Films
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company is giving theatergoers a bonus - no commercials with its movies.
That may please some moviegoers, but cinema advertising executives and theater owners are unhappy.


Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   Hungarians and Vatican Restore Diplomatic Ties
LEAD: After a rupture of four decades, the Vatican formally re-established diplomatic relations with Hungary today, and immediately began talking about doing the same before long with other Eastern-bloc nations.


In Today's Housing Market, Is It Better to Buy or Rent?
LEAD: The decision to own or to rent a home has traditionally been based on three elements: cost, personal preference and investment.
But the recent decline in house and apartment prices has made a such an investment less of a sure thing and has helped to convert many potential buyers into renters, if only temporarily.

Robert W. Kistner, 72, Gynecologist, Is Dead
LEAD: Dr.
Robert W. Kistner, a Harvard Medical School professor who specialized in the treatment of endometriosis, a condition of the uterus that can cause infertility in women, was found dead Tuesday at his home at the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club in Wellington, Fla., where he lived in retirement.
He was 72 years old.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: No wonder RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI hasn't declared his intentions about running for Governor of New York.
The latest Marist College poll, a highly regarded statewide poll, released yesterday, shows GOV.
MARIO M. CUOMO running ahead of Mr.
Giuliani by 60 percent to 26 percent.
Mr.
Cuomo was given a favorable rating by 64 percent of the 639 registered voters in the poll.


The Smart Way to Close Bases
LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's tentative proposal to shut or scale down dozens more military bases caused predictable howls in Congress.
Some members warned of economic catastrophe.
Others said Mr.
Cheney was picking on Democrats.
Nonsense, he replied, I'm just saving money.
But he may also have been needling members who aim to cut weapons he wants to keep.

LEAD: The College Football Association said yesterday that it had agreed to smaller television contracts with ABC and ESPN that reflected the University of Notrereame's deciconoto drop out of the agreements.

Tomorrow night she will be host to the National Literacy Honors, a program that recognizes reading tutors and their successful pupils.

LEAD: After a furious fight and by a narrow margin, Congress sustained President Bush's veto of a bill giving Chinese students in America a statutory right to stay.
Mr.
Bush had warned Congress that if it insisted on the bill, Beijing would retaliate by cutting off future student exchanges.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said its experimental electric car had attracted great interest and that it expects recommendations within three months from a team studying the feasibility of producing the vehicle.

LEAD: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland has asked 17 nations to let Warsaw suspend its debt repayments this year and freeze its $40 billion debt, the Government said today.


Unisys Aide Is Sentenced
LEAD: A former official of the Unisys Corporation was sentenced today to a year in prison for conspiring to make illegal campaign donations and obstructing the F.B.I.'s investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud.


Omens for South Africa
LEAD: Final touches have been put on the new constitution.
South-west Africa will become independent Namibia on March 21, the first day of spring, completing the formal decolonization of Africa.

David Stivender, 56, Chorus Master of Met Opera
LEAD: David Stivender, the chorus master of the Metropolitan Opera since 1973 and a member of the company's conducting staff since 1978, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at Prresbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh.
He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Italian Bank for East Bloc
LEAD: The Italian Cabinet approved a plan today to establish a financing company to promote joint ventures in Eastern Europe.
The company, Simest S.p.A., will operate like a merchant bank.
It will take minority stakes in joint ventures and participate in other industrial and commercial collaborations, mainly with small and medium-sized companies.


Mandela Meets With Anti-Apartheid Coalition
LEAD: Anti-apartheid campaigners spent several hours today meeting with the black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela on developments in the anti-apartheid movement.

Review/Dance;   French Baroque Synthesis Of Dance, Music and Dress
LEAD: Music and dance were allied in France during the 17th and 18th centuries.
Theatrical spectacles combined singing, dancing and poetry, and instrumental pieces were often based upon dance forms.
People could both listen to minuets in concert halls and dance them in ballrooms.
This union of the arts was emphasized in ''French Baroque: Dance and Music for the Dance,'' which the Vineyard Theater presented Tuesday night at the Dimson

She was injured when she fell on skis in St.
Moritz, Switzerland, on Wednesday.
She will have another examination

COLLEGE BASKETBALL
Buzzer Shot Gives Yale a Victory
Casey Cammann scored on a pass from Ed Peterson as the buzzer sounded to give Yale a hard-fought 67-65 overtime victory last night over Cornell in an Ivy League game in New Haven.
Cornell had forged a 35-27 halftime lead, in part because of 12 first-half points from Steve Johnson, a guard.

Sea Containers Plans Buyback
LEAD: Sea Containers Ltd. said its board had decided to recommend to shareholders a recapitalization plan worth as much as $490 million.
Sea Containers, a Bermuda company that operates ferries in the English Channel, said the plan called for the company and certain subsidiaries to buy up to seven million common shares at $70 each in cash.


Religion Notes
LEAD: Romania and Repentance The head of the World Council of Churches has conceded that the group failed to take a public stand against Nicolae Ceausescu when he was the Romanian dictator.


Whirlpool Closing Kentucky Factory
LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation will close its Mount Sterling, Ky., dishwasher plant by March 1991 and lay off most of the factory's 650 workers.
The appliance company said the plant's production would be shifted to its Findlay, Ohio, factory, which already makes dishwashers.


Three Korean Parties Merge, Setting Off Student Protests
LEAD: The governing party and two opposition groups completed a merger today that gives them a huge majority in Parliament, and students responded with protests, firebombs and rocks.

LEAD: Looking gaunt and speaking in a hoarse voice, a politician viewed as among the most likely to become the next Prime Minister of Japan is reminding audiences that newspapers were all but writing his obituary last year.

Backloading: Not So Benign
LEAD: Buy now, pay later.
That's the premise behind ''backloading,'' the practice that aides to Mayor David Dinkins of New York say they're considering.
With the city facing the one-two punch of a $1 billion deficit and expiring labor contracts, City Hall may try to save money up front by delaying wage increases.

LEAD: With promises of a speedier refund, the Internal Revenue Service is encouraging taxpayers to file their returns electronically this year, and it expects two million to do so through 9,000 authorized private firms.

LEAD: A judge cleared the way today for Joseph J. Hazelwood's lawyers to seek to blame Coast Guard negligence rather than the captain of the Exxon Valdez for the nation's largest oil spill.

LEAD: When the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth-Harold Prince musical ''Merrily We Roll Along'' opened on Broadway in November 1981, it was blasted by the critics and closed after 16 performances.

West, a Republican from Spokane, sent a note to GINGER MARSHALL, who was watching from the gallery.

The Owners Are Being Ingrates
LEAD: In 1969, baseball was doomed, and I was sent to cover the story.
This was my first spring training, and, possibly, my last, and maybe baseball's last, too.
The grand old game - 100 years old as a profession then - was on its last legs.
To many, the crack of the bat in the batting cage sounded like the pounding of nails in a coffin.

LEAD: The stock market ended a strong week on a subdued but positive note yesterday.

Corrections
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about an antitrust ruling against the American Medical Association for its boycott of chiropractors described the Federal appeals court's opinion incompletely in some copies.
The opinion, by the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, said the A.M.A. had economic motives but was acting mostly out of concern about scientific methods in patient care.


Survey of U.S. Jewish Leaders Finds Overwhelming Support for Israeli-P.L.O. Talks
LEAD: Officials of American Jewish organizations, although highly distrustful of the Palestine Liberation Organization, say that Israel should talk to the P.L.O., a national survey has found.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Improving Your Skiing
LEAD:
Ski resorts these days are offering a variety of classes for skiers of every skill including beginners, as well as instruction in particular techniques.
Make arrangements in advance with the resort's ski school to enroll in a class.
And, unless you are a beginner, look for a school that arranges for a ''ski down,'' in which an instructor watches you ski before placing you in a class.


A Feisty Chief Shakes Up the Smithsonian
LEAD: Five years and four months after Robert McCormick Adams succeeded S. Dillon Ripley as secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, the gigantic national storehouse and research and educational center is guided by bold new ideas and unconventional leadership.
But, as the institution changes, it is beset with internal discord.


Islanders Rally in Overtime
LEAD: Norman Wood, a real estate man from Manchester, Mass., has had two season tickets for Bruins hockey games for more than 20 years.
They are downstairs in one corner of Boston Garden, right behind an advertising sign that says ''The Right One.''

LEAD: LENINISM, a doctrine with roots in the 19th century that was a scourge of most of the 20th, has finally begun to lose its hold over the Soviet Union on the eve of the 21st.


Holbrook Adams Engaged to Wed S. P. Hodgkins
LEAD: Mrs.
David B. Findlay Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Holbrook Adams to Stephen P. Hodgkins, a son of Dorothy Hodgkins of Punta Gorda, Fla., and Richard B. Hodgkins of Wilton, Me.
The prospective bride is also a daughter of the late Peter R. Adams.
A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Cathleen Kegelman, an associate buyer for Brooks Brothers, and Douglas Allen Reynolds, an associate at Solomon Brothers, both in New York, were married yesterday at St.
Catharine's Church in Spring Lake, N.J.
The Rev.
Joseph Slinger performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.


Support Group For Organ Recipients
LEAD: ''A New Life Beckons Organ Recipients'' (Jan. 21) told the stories of four transplant recipients whose lives were turned around because they were able to receive an organ transplant.
It was an article full of joy and hope.
There are hundreds of others who have been given a second chance at life.
The list grows daily.


Television Sets Worth a Hearing
LEAD: Sound has been television's stepchild, and it has been treated badly.
It has been battered and bruised in poor equipment and has long suffered neglect at the hands of video manufacturers who regarded sound as secondary.

George Goetz of Piscataway, N.J., to Stephen William Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
William D. Miller of Bethesda, Md., and Canberra, Australia, took place yesterday at the Takoma Park (Md.) Presbyterian Church.

George Taylor performed the ceremony.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary in some copies on Jan. 27, reprinted in all copies on Jan. 28, about the social critic Lewis Mumford, misidentified a historian who reviewed one of his works.
The reviewer was Geoffrey Bruun.
It also misidentified Mumford's most important mentor.
He was Sir Patrick Geddes, a Scottish sociologist and regional planner.


L.I. Relatives Seek Answers On Missing Servicemen's Fate
LEAD: Although it has been 17 years since Long Island's Matejov family got word that 21-year-old Joseph had been killed in an Air Force mission over Laos, Mary Matejov says she knows that her son survived the crash and that the United States Government knowingly lied to her about his status.


A LITTLE BIT CAN MEAN A LOT
LEAD: It has been conventional wisdom that upping the number of digital bits in the decoder circuits of a CD player improves its sound.
While CD players were originally designed for 16 bits, companies like Yamaha and Denon proclaimed the superiority of CD players using 18 or even 20 bits.
Those extra bits did indeed offer advantages, even though it was rarely understood that the ebulliently advertised claims in this regard needed careful qualification.


Japan Needs America, Too
LEAD: To the Editor:


That 'New Breed' Of Volunteers
LEAD: The recent article ''A New Breed of Volunteers Alters Ways of Helping Others'' captured the spirit of the ''new breed,'' people who work from 9 to 5 and still make time in their busy schedules to help others early in the morning, evenings and weekends, or during lunch hours, as well as retirees who are giving their time and expertise.


A Treatise Against Drug Use
Any film that features a fictional rap group called ''The Say No Rappers,'' whose antidrug lyrics include the lines ''Big Sister is the white girl/ Her name is cocaine,'' can't begin to reach the teen-age audience it is aimed at.
Kids are smarter and savvier than that, and it's hard to imagine they will find much truth in ''The White Girl.'' The film is so sincere, blunt and awkward it resembles a 94-minute-long public service message about the dangers of drugs.
Written, directed, produced and distributed by Tony Brown, the host of ''Tony Brown's Journal'' on public television, it tells of a black college student named Kim, a judge's daughter, who battles a cocaine problem.


Tough Get Going
LEAD: Sounding as if she had just had a halftime pep talk from a football coach, Leona Helmsley seemed eager to take the offensive last week as she prepared to defend herself against the next round of tax evasion charges.
Mrs.
Helmsley, who is appealing her Federal conviction, not only said she was innocent of those counts and the state charges she still faces, but also implied that she might be due a tax refund.

Munich
LEAD: To the Editor: On a recent visit to Munich, I visited the German Museum of Hunting and Fishing on Neuhauser Strasse.
I found the entire museum fascinating, but one exhibit particularly impressed me.
On the second floor was a large, low table filled with stuffed animals.
In addition to a written identification of these animals, a Braille plate beside each one bore its name.

As the President of the United States that year, Herbert Hoover was being paid $75,000.

To Czechs, Benes Symbolized Resistance;   Masaryk's Presentiment
LEAD: To the Editor:


THE SEARCH FOR THE BEGINNING OF TIME
LEAD: ANY SPACECRAFT THAT inspires allusions to Alice of Wonderland cannot be meant for some ordinary excursion through the heavens.
The Hubble Space Telescope is, indeed, not just any spacecraft.
Scheduled for launching this spring, after five years of delays, the spacecraft and its exquisitely polished 94 1/2-inch-wide telescopic mirror should enable astronomers to see farther and 10 times more clearly than they have before, out tantalizingly close to the edge of the universe and toward the very beginning of time.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it.
The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left.
I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking.

LEAD:
INTERNATIONAL
The Rush Toward a Single Mark
East and West Germany are hurtling toward monetary union.
Not even the opposition of West Germany's central Bundesbank or East Germany's elections March 18 appear likely to block a speedy agreement.
On Tuesday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany called for immediate talks; the very next day, his Cabinet set up a unity committee.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it.
The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left.
I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking.

SATURDAY NIGHT
LEAD: SATURDAY NIGHT IS different from any other night.
On Saturday night, people get together, go dancing, bowling, drinking, out to dinner, get drunk, get killed, kill other people, go out on dates, visit friends, go to parties, listen to music, sleep, gamble, watch television, go cruising, and sometimes fall in love - just as they do every other night of the week.

Ship Safety
LEAD: To the Editor: The Oct. 29 Travel section contained two articles, ''How Safe Are Cruise Ships?'' and ''Under Full Sail From Monte Carlo to Italy's Coast'' on Windstar Sail Cruises' Wind Star.
Surprisingly, the two articles could be linked.
As a former ship's physician with years of experience on several noteworthy vessels, it became apparent to me that a ship's safety is not only related to the knowledge and experience of the crew in handling the physical hazards that may occur but also to the size and competence of the ship's medical staff.

No Commentator
LEAD: As things stood last week, the next 780 minutes of ''60 Minutes'' will include no minutes with Andy Rooney.

RESULTS
LEAD: Tennis
McEnroe Upset by Mayotte: Tim Mayotte joined Ivan Lendl in the final of the Milan indoor tournament in Italy by stunning John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-4, in their semifinal match last night.
McEnroe struggled with an erratic serve and was unable to cope with Mayotte's aggressive play.
After the match, McEnroe hinted that he had an injury to his left arm but declined to elaborate, saying he did not want to seem to be making an excuse for his defeat.

PASTIMES: Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Prune grapevines.
Limb up large shade trees to allow more light into the garden.
Check rose canes for wind or ice damage.
Cut off the faded flowers of amaryllis, but allow the leaves to remain and grow to renew the bulb.
Check cactuses for mealybugs; control promptly if these insects are found.

AFTER 60 YEARS, A TRIANGLE IS ROUNDED OFF
LEAD: I am not sure whether the most remarkable thing about the recent competition to find a building to complete the Federal Triangle was the design that won, the design that lost, or the fact that the competition was held at all.
For this was like few architectural competitions in our time or any other: all entrants were required to produce a design in the spirit of the neo-classical architecture of the rest of the Federal Triangle, the vast complex of Federal offices between Pennsylvania Avenue, Constitution Avenue and 15th Street that was built in the late 1920's and early 1930's.

AIDS CASES IN U.S. ROSE 9% IN 1989
LEAD: The number of new AIDS cases in the United States rose 9 percent last year, the smallest increase since the Centers for Disease Control started reporting AIDS cases in 1981.
But the number of new cases grew faster among heterosexuals, newborns, women and Southerners, health officials say.

Design;   TARTAN TOUCHES
LEAD: Few fabrics carry with them as much folklore as the tartan.
Scottish plaids have been used as coats of arms, articles of clothing and patterns that decorate everything from mugs to jewelry boxes.The earliest tartans were thought to have been woven by the Celts before the year 1000.
Indeed, these plaids were so much a part of the Scottish culture that between 1746 and 1782, the British Parliament banned their wearing by anyone except the military, in an attempt to break up Scottish clans.

Identity crisis, the perennial puzzlement of the newcomer in the city, is the issue poignantly and melodramatically at hand in Richard V. Irizarry's ''Ariano,'' now playing at the estimable Puerto Rican Traveling Theater.


Taxes Give the Democrats One More Identity Problem
LEAD: WHEN Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposed cutting the Social Security tax, some party consultants seized on the idea as a brilliant political weapon.
Here was a Democratic tax cut for the 1990's that was fairer than the Republican tax cuts of the 1980's.
At the same time, the proposal revealed two facts of Republican fiscal policy: that cuts in the progressive income tax had effectively been paid for by increases in the regressive payroll tax, and that the proceeds were being spent like any other revenues rather than being socked away.

NEW YORK
Government offices: Federal and state open. City closed.

LEAD: THE Board of Legislators seemed to solve one problem while compounding another last week when it approved the construction of an $18.9 million sludge-drying plant in the Ludlow Park section of Yonkers.
The action came in time for the county to avoid Federal fines for ocean dumping of toxic wastes.

Another shows Lech Walesa and asks: How many Poles does it take to change the world?

A LIFETIME OF CONFLICT
LEAD: July 18, 1918 - Mandela is born at Qunu, a small town in the Xhosa-speaking region of Transkei, the son of a Tembu tribal leader. 1938 - Mandela enters Fort Hare College.
Two years later, he is expelled for participation in a student strike and moves to Johannesburg. 1941 - Mandela completes work for his bachelors' degree by correspondence and studies law at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg.

A Turn in the Drug War?
In what experts hope is a turning point, the crime rate in and around Washington, D.C., is growing more slowly, and the number of suspects testing positive for cocaine use has dropped in recent months.

Poland Applies Shock Treatment to Revive Its Economy
LEAD: Poland's crash economic plan is intended, in short, to jump-start the nation's jalopy-like economy.
But critics ranging from free-market economists to doctrinaire Communist leaders fear that the plan's high-voltage jolt can cause the rusting, brittle economy to explode before it heaves forward.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Moves by Carnation
LEAD: Citing a desire to bring its roster of advertising agencies into line with those of its corporate parent, Nestle S.A., the Carnation Company has taken three accounts, worth $12 million to $15 million in billings, from Ogilvy &amp; Mather in Los Angeles.
Advertising for Carnation's Contadina Fresh refrigerated pasta and sauces, and for its infant nutritional products, will go to McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles.


Debate Flares on U.S. Role at a World's Fair
LEAD: Congress has triggered a debate between cost-conscious lawmakers, who say private sponsors should pay for an American pavilion at the 1992 World's Fair in Spain, and others who worry about whether corporate sponsorship is appropriate for a project that will represent the United States.


Trading in Arab Bank
LEAD: The Arab Banking Corporation, the Arab world's largest bank, said today that it would become the first Persian Gulf-based concern to offer its shares to foreign investors on the open market.
It said it planned a $250 million public share offering in the first half of 1990.
The bank's president, Abdullah Saudi, said the Government said it would allow foreigners outside the six-member Gulf Cooperation Council to trade the bank's shares on the island's stock exchange, making it the first Gulf market to do so.

He was 63 years old and lived in Sanibel, Fla., and previously was a longtime resident of New Canaan and Weston, Conn.

Lincoln's Birthday Today
LEAD: Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Government offices: Federal and state open. City closed.
Post office: Regular service.
Banks: Option to close.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation: No pick-up, recycling collection or street cleaning.
Schools: Closed.
Financial Markets: Open.

Bridge
LEAD: Alvin Roth has been called ''the greatest theoretician in the history of the game.'' The Roth-Stone system was seminal in the development of bidding theory and introduced the unusual no-trump, the negative double and other significant ideas.
At 75 he is as creative as ever; his book on ''Modern Roth'' will be published in the spring.

Mayor several weeks ago over the telephone.
They will be married in Washington.

LEAD: WOULD a severely creased strip of vintage baseball cards that last sold for $15,000 in 1972 be worth $2 million today?
Probably not in the real world, but you can't blame a fellow for dreaming.
