Like the Party, East Europe's Official Communist Press Is in Deep Trouble
LEAD: All over Eastern Europe, the formerly all-powerful ''official press'' is in even bigger trouble than the Communist parties in whose name it has been speaking for 40 years.


Jean Cattier, 88, Dies; Led Bank Consortium
LEAD: Jean Cattier, retired chairman of the European American Bank, a European bank consortium that he helped found in 1968, died of respiratory failure on Saturday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I.
He was 88 years old.
Mr.
Cattier was a native of Brussels who came to this country in 1926.
He was a partner in the investment banking house of White, Weld &amp; Company for more than 40 years, rising to executive committee chairman and retiring in 1973.


Ruth Levin Schlein Weds
LEAD: Ruth Levin Schlein and Sidney Hill were married yesterday in Mr.
Hill's apartment in Manhattan by Rabbi James Prosnit.
Mrs.
Hill is the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs.
Oscar Levin.
Mr.
Hill, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs.
Lazarus Hill, is a founder of the Berry-Hill Galleries in New York.
The bride's first husband died, as did Mr.


Changes in Crafts
LEAD: ''By Hammer and Hand: New York Trades Transformed, 1788-1842,'' an exhibition on how a growing New York affected the lives and work of craftsmen, will be on view through June 11 at the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street.
Paintings, prints, tools and other items that illustrate changes in woodworking, printing, silversmithing, shoemaking and tailoring are included.


Trade Surplus Puts Bonn Ahead of Japan
LEAD: West Germany has announced a record trade surplus for last year, putting Europe's dominant economic power ahead of Japan for the first time since the 1970's.


It's Westminster Today As the Warmups End
LEAD: There were 14 specialty shows at nine sites in the metropolitan area yesterday, but they all were but a prelude to Westminster, the country's most prestigious dog show, which opens a two-day run this morning at Madison Square Garden.

A Chicago Exhibition on Lincoln's America
LEAD: ''A House Divided: America in the Age of Lincoln,'' an exhibition that has just opened at the Chicago Historical Society, is more than a show of bland manuscripts and evenhanded statements about the Civil War.
The 600 rare documents and artifacts on view, together with a pointed narrative, have been arranged to make a case for the idea that it was slavery more than secession that led to the conflict.


6 Said to Die in Salvador Air Force Raid
LEAD: At least six people were killed today, five of them children, when the Salvadoran Air Force bombed a settlement of former Salvadoran refugees, witnesses said.


A Tribute to Fitzgerald With Heart and Soul
LEAD: The acclaim that has been accumulating around Ella Fitzgerald for more than half a century will reach a peak of sorts this evening when her colleagues from all areas of the music world pay tribute to her at Avery Fisher Hall in a benefit concert for the American Heart Association.

LEAD: GERALDINE A. FERRARO fell into a political vacuum after her unsuccessful run for vice president in 1984 and the subsequent legal potholes of her husband, JOHN A. ZACCARO, and her son, JOHN A. JR.

Broadcast in South Africa
LEAD: South African television, which focuses on Government leaders and largely ignores their black opponents, provided viewers with a stunning sight tonight, broadcasting the release of Nelson Mandela and his emphatic speech before a huge rally on the steps of Cape Town City Hall.


Eleanore Gassenheimer, WQXR Executive, 78
LEAD: Eleanore Gassenheimer, who under her professional name of Pat Hurley was public relations director of radio station WQXR for 30 years until her retirement in 1973, died after a long illness on Friday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I.
She was 78 years old and lived in West Islip, L.I.


Indian Troops Kill 3 at Kashmir Cease-Fire Line
LEAD: The leader of Pakistan-controlled Kashmir said today that Indian soldiers killed at least three protesters as they tried to cross a military control line, setting off an exchange of fire with Pakistani troops.

LEAD: Buster Douglas's knockout of Mike Tyson might be the biggest upset in boxing history, but Tyson's defeat was not the first time a seemingly invincible heavyweight champion had lost to a heavy underdog.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL
A3-17
Nelson Mandela is a free man.
After 27 years, he walked out of prison and then promptly urged his supporters at home and abroad to increase their pressure against the white Government in Pretoria.

Israel's Rules Block Some Soviet Jews
LEAD: Israeli legislators called on the Interior Ministry today to change its regulations requiring new immigrants from the Soviet Union to prove they are Jewish, saying the current rules humiliate the immigrants and give the impression that they are unwelcome in Israel.

LEAD: SECRETARIAT, the 1973 Triple Crown winner who is beginning a posthumous career as shill, is going to have to sell a lot of cereal before he'll be a patch on Dan Patch.


In Virginia, a Challenger to Warner Is Sought
LEAD: Virginia Democratic leaders say they have no candidate to oppose the state's Republican Senator, John W. Warner, after they spurned the offer of a supporter of the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. to run as a Democrat.


Ms. Urdang Wed To L. D. Ziegler
LEAD: Beth Ellen Urdang and Dr.
Lawrence David Ziegler were married yesterday at the Regency Hotel in New York by Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman.
The bride is a daughter of A. Albert Urdang of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Eleanor S. Urdang.
The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs.

BRIEFS
LEAD: Andover Bancorp, Andover, Mass., and First Essex Bancorp said they had agreed to a merger in a tax-free stock exchange.
Each of the 4.1 million outstanding Andover common shares will remain outstanding and represent one share of the new company.
Each of the six million outstanding First Essex shares will be converted into 0.526 share of the combined company.

LEAD: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs plunged by 32 last week, dropping below 900 for the first time this year, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.

Company News;   Sizeler Property
LEAD: Sizeler Property Investors Inc. said that through last Friday it had been tendered 2.2 million shares of Property Trust of America, or 54.1 percent, in its $11.59-a-share bid.
Sizeler said it extended its offer for 2.9 million sahres of Property Trust until March 9.
The offer was extended pending an appeals court decision on whether the takeover could be completed between the two real estate investment trusts.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages on Feb. 8 about Robert Phelps, a basketball player at Nazareth High School in Brooklyn, misidentified the school's basketball coach.
He is Ted Gustus.


Jewish Group Faces Reorganization
LEAD: The American Jewish Committee, widely regarded as the dean of Jewish organizations in the United States, plans a major restructuring that it hopes will give the group a sharper focus and reduce its costs.

Pruning Prune Day, and Others
LEAD: Things started out innocently enough back in 1918, when Congress designated Mother's Day.
The Congressional penchant for commemoratives has since lurched out of control.
National Prune Day, Tap Dance Day and Patient Account Management Day now compete with Dairy Goat Awareness Week for the national spotlight.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 6 about Panamanian banks and money laundering referred incorrectly to the relationship of the Dadeland Bank of Florida to a senior Panamanian offical and accusations of money laundering.
Guillermo (Billy) Ford, Second Vice President of Panama, is not an owner of Dadeland.
No Federal or state authorities have accused Dadeland of improper ties to the Medellin drug cartel.

LEAD: Housing completions fell 12.8 percent in December from a month earlier, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.3 million units, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: BOWIE K. KUHN, the former Commissioner of Baseball, surfaced yesterday, sort of.
After it was reported that he was hiding in Florida following the bankruptcy of his Manhattan law firm, Myerson &amp; Kuhn, he issued a statement through his lawyer in Manhattan.
He is in Florida, he reported, although he didn't say exactly where.

LEAD: Iraq's Oil Ministry has begun production at its southern Suba oilfield with an initial output of 20,000 barrels a day, the official Iraqi News Agency said today.

He's right.

N.H.L.
Thibaudeau Helps Leafs Triumph
Gilles Thibaudeau's power-play goal with 6 minutes 45 seconds remaining in the third period last night broke a 3-3 tie as the Toronto Maple Leafs beat the visiting Los Angeles Kings, 5-3.
Al Iafrate and Gary Leeman each scored twice for Toronto, which got four of its five goals on power plays and killed off the Kings' seven power plays.

Company News;   Grand Met Plans Shift at Retail Unit
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food and liquor company, said it would reorganize its British retail operations by forming two separate companies to manage its pubs and restaurants.
The new pub company will run the Chef and Brewer, Clifton Inns and Berni operations, while the restaurant company will handle Old Orleans, Pastificio, Pizzaland and Perfect Pizza businesses.


After 3 Decades, Mandela Measures Up to Legend
LEAD: When Nelson Mandela emerged from more than a quarter of a century in jail on Sunday, he told the crowd that gathered to hail him here that he had left behind ''long and lonely years'' of deprivation.
He did not mention that he had also left his reading glasses and the text of the speech he had written for the occasion.

LEAD: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had lost $222 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a profit of $56 million, or 97 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1988.


Pilotless Flights to Explore the Ozone Hole
LEAD: SCIENTISTS at Harvard University are building a pilotless airplane for research flights through the ozone hole in the upper atmosphere over Antarctica.

LEAD: The jail that opened Sunday for Nelson Mandela began to free a nation even as it freed a man.
After 27 years, and with the whole world watching, South Africa saw a half-mythical prisoner recalled to political life.
Mr.
Mandela rose impressively to a remarkable occasion.
Calmly and without bitterness, he displayed the measured dignity the old Romans described as gravitas.

He was 71 years old and lived in Venice, Fla.

China-Soviet Ventures
LEAD: China and the Soviet Union are discussing possible joint projects in the mining of Chinese copper, aluminum and tungsten, The China Daily said on Sunday.
The newspaper said Soviet technical experts had recently visited some sites.
One possible joint project involves a large copper mine in northeastern China.

Air France Strike Set
LEAD: Air France's pilots' union today called on its members to strike for 48 hours next weekend to protest deteriorating working conditions and a continuing loss in purchasing power, a union statement said.
The statement came as a two-day strike by flight navigators and mechanics at France's three main airlines - Air France, Air Inter and UTA - was drawing to a close.


Savings Bond Sales Up
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $826 million in January, up 39 percent from December, the Treasury Department reported last week.
January's sales, which were 2 percent higher than those of January 1989, brought the total value of bonds held by the public to a record $118.2 billion.
Savings bonds are earning interest at a rate of 6.98 percent when held five years or longer.


Voyager to Snap First Family Portrait of Planets Tonight
LEAD: A FAMILY portrait of the Sun's planets, except for Mercury and Pluto, will be taken tonight by the Voyager 1 spacecraft.
Nothing like it has ever been tried.

Bridge
LEAD: A team event that is sometimes played in Europe but is very rare on this side of the Atlantic requires each member of a team to play with each of the others in turn.
Probably the only American example is the Betty Kaplan Teams, which was played on Saturday at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan.


Sports People: Hockey;   Diduck Hospitalized
LEAD: Gerald Diduck, an Islander defenseman, entered North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., Monday, for treatment of a virus, the club announced.
Mark Aldridge, the Islander trainer, said Diduck was being tested for possible blood poisoning.
He is not expected to play tonight when the Islanders face the Calgary Flames at Nassau Coliseum.

Company News;   U.S. Investor Owns 9.2% of Blue Arrow
LEAD: A large United States investor has reportedly agreed to buy 9.2 percent of Blue Arrow P.L.C. for $96.7 million, becoming the biggest shareholder of the British company, whose chief asset is the temporary employment agency Manpower Inc.


Clues on Aging
LEAD: Researchers in the United States and Japan say they believe they have found a link between the aging of human cells and a specific chromosome.
The findings, which were reported in the Feb. 9 issue of the journal Science, may have relevance not only to the understanding of aging but also to the study of cancer.


In Slovenia, Link to Rest of Nation Weakens
LEAD: Less than a month ago, the Communists of Slovenia pulled out of a national party congress and became a loose thread that is now unraveling Communist cohesion across the country.
A few days ago they shocked their comrades further by announcing they were no longer Communists.


Perrier Recall: How Damaging Is It?
LEAD: Over more than a decade, Perrier convinced Americans that its French spring water was chic enough to be worth $29 a gallon when consumed in small bottles in restaurants.
But over just two days, Perrier has seen its marketing efforts of endangered by a swell of bad publicity.

Critic's Notebook;   Why Andy Rooney Had to Go, Guilty or Not
LEAD: The case of Andy Rooney is like a multi-vehicle crash that brings traffic to a stop.
Unfettered comment ran smack into minority sensibilities; the public relations needs of a network collided with the prerogatives of one of its most popular performers; a news organization's obligation to openness came up against the medium's role as a binder of society.


A Generation Writing in English Is Broadening the Fiction of India
LEAD: In a burst of innovation, a new generation of young, iconoclastic and cosmopolitan writers is rapidly expanding India's literary horizons in novels and short stories.
Writing in English, these authors are able to present their disarmingly intimate and often unconventional images of India to readers beyond their nation's borders.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the British trial of seven people charged with wrongdoing in the 1986 Guinness P.L.C. takeover of the Distillers Company misidentified a defendant, Roger Seelig.
He is a former corporate finance director at the investment banking firm of Morgan Grenfell in London.

Platinum and Gold Increase On Fear Over South Africa
LEAD: Platinum futures prices jumped yesterday after Nelson Mandela endorsed anti-apartheid violence and nationalization of South Africa's mining industry, sending a shudder of fear about supplies through the precious metals markets.


Dollar Posts Modest Gains As the Mark Remains Off
LEAD: The dollar ended narrowly higher yesterday against most major currencies in quiet trading.


Ecogen May Place Itself on the Block
LEAD: Ecogen Inc. said it was considering the sale of all or part of the company because of a shortage of cash for developing and commercializing its biopesticides.
To conserve cash in the short term, it said it would temporarily suspend production of one of its biofungicide products, limit field trials and cut certain spending.


Black South Africans in New York Area Are Upbeat but Cautious
LEAD: Black South Africans in the New York area said in interviews yesterday that the release of Nelson Mandela improved the prospects for negotiations between the Pretoria Government and South Africans opposing apartheid.

LEAD: If a modern Rip Van Winkle had been asleep only a few months, he would still wake up astonished.

New Jersey Turnpike Plan Dwindles Despite $2 Billion in Debt
LEAD: Five years ago the New Jersey Turnpike Authority issued $2 billion in bonds to finance the widening of 35 miles of the state's most important road.
Today much of the project has been abandoned, none of it is complete, and the authority is seeking large toll increases to pay the cost of the borrowed money it is still deciding how to spend.


G.M. Financing Unit to Buy Anchor Mortgage Business
LEAD: The GMAC Mortgage Corporation said today that it had completed an agreement to buy the Residential Funding Corporation, a mortgage-servicing subsidary of the Anchor Savings Bank, Hewlett, L.I., for approximately $62 million.


'Junk Bond' Prices Fall On Worry Over Drexel
LEAD: The prices of ''junk bonds'' skidded sharply again yesterday as investors reacted nervously to news that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., long the backbone of those markets, was scrambling to raise much-needed capital from outside sources.
Some bonds fell in morning trading by as much as five points, or $50 for every $1,000 face amount, but most ended the day off only one to two points, dealers said.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Strategy For Benson &amp; Hedges
LEAD: DISPUTING the accuracy of recent reports in the advertising trade press, a top Philip Morris marketing executive says the company is not repositioning Benson &amp; Hedges cigarettes as a brand for blue-collar smokers.
Instead, the nation's largest tobacco company will try to maintain its edge with the current customers who like the cigarettes' image of style and affluence.


Economic Scene;   Global Warming: Look or Leap?
LEAD: FOR George Bush the candidate, global warming was hot stuff - not as critical to the nation's future, perhaps, as ending prison furloughs for murderers, but near the top of the list of issues that mattered to the quiche and Volvo crowd.


Co-op Manager In Queens Faces City Tax Inquiry
LEAD: Queens authorities are investigating accusations that a once prominent real-estate company has fraudulently failed to pay New York City property taxes and other fees for many of the 80 cooperative apartment buildings it manages in the borough.


Review/Art;   From Lopsidedness to Limpidity: A Rethought and Renewed Tate
LEAD: Some of the happiest people in London at this moment are the staff members of the Tate Gallery.
After yearlong preparation, day-by-day collegial debate and a very short period in which the museum was closed, a renewed, readjusted and rethought Tate Gallery was opened to the public on Jan. 25.


Eating Well
LEAD: FEEDING children is never easy.
When both parents work, it's a double challenge.
Time and energy are in short supply at the end of most work days.
Mom and dad generally have little inclination to cook and little mental stamina to bargain with picky young eaters over what's being served.

Life Jackets Result in Search
LEAD: The Coast Guard is searching 2,500 square miles of ocean and questioning the operators of marinas on the United States' Atlantic and Pacific coasts to determine the origin of 13 life jackets that have washed up on a beach at Martha's Vineyard, a spokesman said today.
Seven jackets were discovered Sunday and the others Monday.

He was 83 years old.

The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   Key Events for drexel Burnham Lambert
LEAD:
1976: The Drexel Burnham Group Inc., a brokerage firm, agrees to merge with Lambert Brussels Witter, a subsidiary of Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, Belgium's second-largest holding company, creating Drexel Brunham Lambert Group and its brokerage subsidiary.
The merger gives Groupe Bruxelles Lambert approximately a 28 percent stake in the new company.

The Second Baddest Dude
LEAD: rrIron Mike Tyson, beaten decisively but clinging to a technicality, had claimed that the heavyweight title was still his.
Some say, paraphrasing Jimmy Swaggart, that Don King made him do it.
Others had spoken about big money from future fights being jeopardized, or that it was simply a refusal to face reality.


The Editorial Notebook;   The Death Dilemma
LEAD: Two years ago in Oregon, a boy named Adam Jacoby Howard was dying of leukemia.
A bone marrow transplant might have helped but that would have cost $100,000 -money his family, on welfare, didn't have and money the state was not prepared to fork over.
Earlier in the year the legislature had voted to stop organ transplants for welfare recipients and devote the funds to prenatal care instead.

Excerpts From the Speech by Mandela in Soweto
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Nelson Mandela's speech here today: His Pride in Soweto . . .
As proud as I am to be part of the Soweto community, I have been greatly disturbed by the statistics of crime, what I have read in the newspapers.
Although I understand the deprivations our people suffer, I must make it clear that the level of crime in our township is unhealthy and must be eliminated as a matter of urgency.

I.B.M. Expands Memory Chips
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had begun pilot production of computer memory chips that store 16 million bits of data, four times the capacity of today's most advanced memory chips.


Moscow Accepts U.S. Advantage Of 30,000 Soldiers Across Europe
LEAD: The Soviet Union abandoned its demand for equal American and Soviet troop levels in Europe today and accepted President Bush's proposal that the United States be allowed to maintain a 30,000-soldier advantage.

Paramount Oil, Monticello in Link
LEAD: The Paramount Petroleum Company and the Monticello Acquisition Corporation said they had agreed in principle to merge their oil and gas operations effective July 1.
William E. Simon, former Secretary of the Treasury, and Alvin V. Shoemaker, former chairman of the board of the First Boston Corporation, are heading the new entity.

The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   The Fed Nightmare
LEAD: For years, E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has warned anyone who would listen that Wall Street firms have as much potential to disrupt the financial system as commercial banks do - if not more.
Thanks to their rapid growth in the 1980's, securities firms today - like banks -have billions of dollars of financial obligations.


Big Cocaine Dealer in Capital Sentenced to Two Life Terms
LEAD: A Federal district judge today sentenced Rayful Edmond, one of Washington's biggest cocaine dealers, to two terms of life in prison without possibility of parole.


Rostropovich Is Home at Last With Just a Touch of America
LEAD: Mstislav Rostropovich spoke to his compatriots in his own land and language tonight for the first time in 16 years.
What he said to them with the two great Russian symphonies and the encores he conducted was that life is tragic, and the march from tragedy to redemption tortuous.

What's in a Name
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Cricket Tour Is Cut Short
LEAD: In a move described as a gesture toward the ''recent dramatic political developments in South Africa,'' the South African cricket authorities today cut short a tour by an English cricket team that has provoked widespread anger and violent protests among blacks and others who support an international sports boycott of their country.


Chronicle
LEAD: There was another lesson on the environment yesterday.
In Washington, DANIEL REICHER, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a leading environmental group, reported to work as a staff member of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, only to be told in the afternoon that he had no job.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.B.A.
Bird's Free-Throw Streak Ends
Larry Bird's string of consecutive free throws ended last night in Houston at 71, but he scored 38 points and grabbed 14 rebounds to lead the Boston Celtics to a 107-94 victory over the Rockets.
Bird missed a free throw with 4 minutes 17 seconds left in the third quarter, ending his streak seven short of the league record.


Trottier's 500th Proves Insufficient
LEAD: The cheering became louder and louder and reached a deafening point when the bench emptied in celebration in a scene reminiscent of the Stanley Cup years for the Islanders.


Doctorow Wins Book Critics' Award
LEAD: E. L. Doctorow's ''Billy Bathgate'' won the fiction category in the 1989 National Book Critics Circle awards announced on Monday.


Education Commissioner Confounds His Critics
LEAD: There was no great expectation that Thomas Sobol would challenge the status quo when he became New York State's 11th Commissioner of Education in 1987.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
LEAD: *
Barnum Communications Inc., a New York health-care marketing and communications agency, has changed its name to Barnum &amp; Souza Inc.


Eulogy to John Doe, a Symbol of 'All Hurts'
LEAD: It came time yesterday to eulogize the homeless man killed last month on a subway platform at Columbus Circle, and still no one knew his name.


Hard-Working Smoker Opens Pack at Bottom
LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: An explanatory insertion and a headline on Monday with the transcript of an address by Nelson Mandela mistranslated a word of a Xhosa chant used at anti-apartheid gatherings.
The word, ''mayibuye,'' is translated ''let it come back'' - a reference to African land and, by implication, political power.


How Japan Can Reduce Its Huge Trade Surplus
LEAD: To the Editor:


Offer of Leniency for Kidnapper Seeks Return of a Missing Girl, 2
LEAD: When 2-year old Aliza May Bush wandered out of her mother's apartment Feb. 2 and disappeared, the only trace found of her was a small pink mitten at the edge of the driveway.


A Big Chicago Realty Firm Stops Paying Some Bills
LEAD: One of the nation's largest real estate firms said today that many of its commercial properties were so troubled financially that it had no choice but to stop paying certain bills.


Mashed Potatoes, A Garlicky Tang
LEAD: EVERYONE likes mashed potatoes; they are ''comfort food,'' pleasing to children and adults alike, haute cuisine buffs as well as fast food addicts.
And nothing complements mashed potatoes like gravy -be it the natural juices from a veal roast, thickened pan drippings from a roast turkey, or, as in my menu today, vegetable sauce made for a meat loaf.


Real Estate;   A Manhattan Warehouse Is Salvaged
LEAD: A MAJOR success story in New York City's efforts to retain manufacturing jobs and put dilapidated buildings back on the tax rolls involves a husband-and-wife team of Israeli film makers turned jewelry entrepreneurs, a Dutch bank, Federal grants and an old liquor warehouse in Greenwich Village.


De Klerk, Mandela - and Bush
LEAD: For decades, we have been told that South Africa's racial conflict is at the stage of five minutes to midnight.
For decades, the nation's future has been discussed in grisly scenarios: revolutionary upheaval, enduring white domination, racial partition and Lebanon-style chaos.


Texas Journal;   On Geographic Names And Cleaning Them Up
LEAD: The State of Texas is trying to clean up its map, eliminating the racist names of landmarks and neighborhoods, names have brought embarrassment and protest in recent months.

INTERNATIONAL
A3-15
A framework for unifying Germany has been agreed upon by the four World War II Allies at the end of an East-West conference in Ottawa.
Although difficult issues remain, a reunified Germany could be a reality by the end of the year.

Support for Airline Deregulation
LEAD: After an extensive study of airline competition, the Transportation Department has found no cause for alarm in the shrinking number of major airlines in the decade since the industry was deregulated.

LEAD: A company that respects the public's growing concerns for human health and the environment serves society and itself.
A company that appears to treat them casually risks a heavy loss in public trust.
Perrier seems to have grasped this point; Exxon has not.


Vienna to Extend Social Benefits To Jewish Victims of the Nazi Era
LEAD: Austria has concluded agreements to pay nearly $200 million in benefits to Jews who suffered there during the Nazi era, officials in New York said yesterday.

On the Ethiopian Front, Rebel Confidence Rises
LEAD: On the peak of this stone-laden mountain, a wiry guerrilla fighter ducks and weaves along a waist-high trench.
Through binoculars he peers at the enemy trenches of the Ethiopian army, an ocher ribbon carved around the hill several hundred yards in front.


Crime Writers Examine the Mystery of Popularity
LEAD: ''I hate it when people start mystery discussions by saying, 'You're probably wondering why I brought you all together in this room,' '' said Otto Penzler, the moderator of ''An Evening of Crime.'' ''They think that nobody ever thought of it before.
Like people who write stories as mystery parodies.


Free Choice: When Too Much Is Too Much
LEAD: AMERICANS can choose from more than 25,000 items on their supermarket shelves, tune in as many as 53 television stations, buy any of 11,092 magazines or periodicals, and be solicited by tens of thousands of special-interest and public-interest groups.
It's freedom of choice, the American way.
But an increasing number of sociologists and other experts are beginning to believe that the marketplace may have outsmarted itself.

LEAD: A North Carolina woman subpoened before a federal grand jury investigating allegations that Mayor Marion S. Barry used illegal drugs was jailed today for refusing to testify after she was granted immunity.

Three Robbery Suspects Slain
LEAD: Undercover police officers who had been investigating a number of restaurant robberies shot and killed three suspects and wounded a fourth outside a McDonald's restaurant here early Monday.
None of the nine police officers were hurt.
The suspects had tied up a manager, who was alone, and forced her to give them the combination to the safe.

The Trocks, as the dancers are familiarly known, took obvious delight in tearing passion to tatters.

Review/Television;   A Folklorist Who Insisted on Black Pride
LEAD: One of the highlights of public television's current Black History Month schedule is tonight's ''American Playhouse'' presentation of ''Zora Is My Name!'' That defiant exclamation point is significant.
Zora Neale Hurston, the black writer and folklorist, was a fierce advocate of black pride back in the 1930's and 40's, long before the nation was being pointedly told that black is beautiful.

U.S. Corporations Disdainful of Research

Intel: Supplier Rising As a Big Competitor
LEAD: The Intel Corporation, once just a supplier of chips to computer makers, is increasingly becoming their competitor, making everything from personal computers to supercomputers.
Some of Intel's customers are grumbling, but industry analysts say the diversification makes sense for a company that already makes the most complicated and important part in a computer.


TOP PRETORIA AIDE SEES END TO RULE BY WHITE PARTY
LEAD: A top aide to President F. W. de Klerk said today that the South African Government expected that the National Party, bastion of white supremacy for 40 years, was ''unlikely'' to remain in control of the Government for much longer than the next five years.
He predicted that toward the end of this period, the white House of Assembly would approve a new constitution based on universal suffrage.

LEAD: The Atlanta Hawks traded the forward Antoine Carr and the guard Sedric Toney to the Sacramento Kings today for Kenny Smith, a guard, and Mike Williams, a rookie forward.

LEAD: Although Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that a bankruptcy filing by the firm would be framed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, a provision intended to give a company time to reorganize, specialists in the field said there was little chance the firm would survive.

LEAD: Defying an emergency decree and a ban on demonstrations, thousands of people rallied Tuesday in the capital of Soviet Tadzhikistan, Soviet television reported early today, saying that as many as 37 people had died since rioting began there late Sunday night.

About New York;   Stars Are Born? Booking Cowgirls And Jokeaholics
LEAD: rrSteven Scott Productions, which books acts for everything from Super Bowl parties to cable-television quiz shows to automobile dealerships, advertised in Back Stage that it was again holding auditions for ''unique and unusual acts.'' So what's ''unique and unusual?'' It varies.
Past auditioners have included a woman who recites poetry to salt and pepper shakers; a man who jumps into rolls of toilet tissue and then wraps himself like a mummy within 10 seconds, and a pantomimist who imitates a monkey eating a banana.

Fatal Burglary on Long Island
LEAD: A man was shot to death and his son injured in an apparent burglary, the police said today.
A man broke into the rear of the Grauer family house in Hewlett at 9:30 P.M.
Monday, the police said.
The intruder opened the master bedroom door, apparently thinking no one was home, and was confronted by Stewart and Susan Grauer.


Pan Am Debt Pact
LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation said that its airline unit had negotiated the extension of $64 million in obligations and interest payments to manufactures, lessors and other creditors, giving the troubled carrier at least until Feb. 28 to pay its bills.
Pan Am said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the negotiations were completed last month.

Radiation Exposure Seen as Posing Risk For Airplane Crews
LEAD: Pilots and flight attendants on many airline routes are exposed to more radiation than most workers in nuclear power plants, new Government studies show.
In power plants the Government imposes extensive safety requirements, including education, monitoring and procedures to minimize dose, but no such limits are applied for the flight crews.

Let's Not Get Carried Away With Reality
LEAD: There I was out to dinner with two heavyweight New Yorkers, extremely nice, literate people to whom I was wholeheartedly defending Shirley MacLaine.
That's right, Shirley MacLaine.
Mind you, I was making no defense of her claim to past lives; that far I can't go.
But as to her benign, maybe even salutary emphasis on yoga and meditation, her jam-packed new-age seminars, her books and videos (yes, I've even rented one), in that I could certainly see no evil intent beyond a little spiritual hustling.

A Novelist at the Crossroads of Soviet Society
LEAD: As the son of a diplomat, the Soviet writer Victor Erofeyev spent part of his boyhood in Paris.
It was there, strolling on the Champs-Elysees, enjoying the sun and the style, that he first felt torn between East and West. ''I felt I had two homes,'' he said, ''Paris and the Soviet Union.''


Perrier Says Employees Failed to Change Filters
LEAD: The contamination of Perrier sparkling water was caused when company employees failed to replace charcoal filters that screen out benzene, a chemical impurity in the natural gas present in the company's famous spring in southern France, Perrier officials said yesterday.

LEAD: If your partner overbids, landing you in an overly optimistic game contract, you can expect to fail by a trick or two, perhaps doubled.
Then, according to your temperament, you can grumble, or glower, or go quietly on to the next hand.

New Vintage Publisher
LEAD: Jane Friedman was named to the new position of publisher of Vintage Books yesterday, effective next Tuesday.
She will retain her positions as publisher of Random House Audio Books and senior vice president of Alfred A. Knopf.
In her new capacity she will report to Sonny Mehta, president of Knopf.
Martin Asher, the vice president and editor in chief of Vintage, will become senior vice president.


Bertelsmann Is Considering Buying Technical Publisher
LEAD: Bertelsmann A.G., the West German media giant that owns the Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group Inc., wants to expand its publishing base in the United States by acquiring a company that specializes in educational, scientific and technical books, a senior company official said yesterday.


Texaco Tree Plan
LEAD: Texaco Inc., one of the nation's oil giants, announced a $1 million program to plant trees this spring to start private-sector involvement in President Bush's ''America the Beautiful'' program.
James W. Kinnear, Texaco's president, said the money would be shared by Denver, Houston and New Orleans, where the company has extensive operations.


Ballard Ruled Unable To Control Own Care
LEAD: A district court judge in Toronto ruled yesterday that Harold Ballard, the hospitalized owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, was mentally incompetent to make decisions about his health care.
But the court battle over control of his medical care and his property is continuing.


P.S.C. Releases Phone Audit
LEAD: The New York State Public Service Commission released a staff audit yesterday that found that the New York Telephone Company had paid excessive charges to the purchasing division of its parent company, the Nynex Corporation, for the removal of phone equipment.
The audit said the Nynex purchasing division had overcharged New York Telephone by as much as $28 million.


British Air's Profits Up
LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. reported today that its profits jumped 39 percent in its third quarter, partly because of traffic growth, lower pension contributions and aircraft sales.
The carrier said earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled $78 million, compared with $56 million in the corresponding period a year ago.


Home Improvement
LEAD: AN easy way to enhance the appearance of a bathroom is to replace a shower curtain with a glass or plastic shower door.
Hinged doors are available for virtually all bathtub and shower stall shapes and installations.
Sliding doors, described here, are designed to fit rectangular tubs or stalls between two end walls.

U.S.-Korea Trade Plan
LEAD: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and South Korea's Minister of Trade and Industry, Han Seung Soo, signed an agreement Tuesday to create a joint committee on commercial cooperation intended to expand trade and reduce friction.
The committee will develop opportunities for cooperation in trade and investment, and exchange technical information and data on mutually beneficial development projects.

Close to Home
LEAD: BY now I will know if this week's mail included two envelopes addressed in rather peculiar scrawls.
But, of course, it did.
The scrawls were peculiar because the senders tried to disguise their handwriting, and the envelopes opened on valentines.
They were either funny or in a foreign language.
One of last year's offerings was of a puppy wearing a flowered hat, and read: De muchos besos y abrazos Este Valentin esta lleno Para alguien muy especial


Oil Blown Ashore in California, Aiding Cleanup
LEAD: Stormy weather during the night appeared today to have blown ashore most of the oil remaining from last week's tanker accident off Huntington Beach, a development that was seen as a mixed blessing.


Review/Theater;   Anorexic Cookbook Author Invents a Play
LEAD: N. Richard Nash's ''Come as You Are'' is a potluck dramatic stew centering on a cookbook author with an anorexic past.
This might be called a case of overcompensation - or artistic bulimia - although, as one later learns, the cook does not eat her own food.


Perrier Widens Recall After New Finding
LEAD: Source Perrier announced today that it was withdrawing every bottle of its sparkling mineral water throughout the world after traces of benzene, a toxic chemical, were reported in bottles tested in Denmark and the Netherlands.


Market Place;   Drexel's Strength: A Numbers Game
LEAD: AS Drexel Burnham Lambert tumbled, it was able to assert that it was a financially strong firm.
To back up that claim, it could even point to Federal standards it was more than complying with.
Now, Drexel's ability to conform to regulatory standards is raising questions about whether those safeguards are so full of holes that investors can easily be misled.


An Eating Club at Princeton Starts Vote to Admit Women
LEAD: Undergraduates at the oldest of the 13 private eating clubs at Princeton University are starting to break a 111-year tradition of all-male membership.

Komatsu to Buy 2 Carbide Plants
LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation said it intends to sell two polysilicon plants to the Komatsu Electronic Metals Company of Tokyo.
The plants in Moses Lake and Washougal, Wash., employ a total of 270 people and had 1988 sales of about $35 million.
Terms of the impending sale were not disclosed under an agreement between the companies, said Harvey Cobert, a spokesman for Union Carbide, which is based in Danbury,

LEAD: Eddie Hatcher, one of two militant American Indians who in 1988 held hostages in the offices of The Robesonian, a local newspaper, agreed to plead guilty today in exchange for an 18-year state prison sentence.

LEAD:
N.B.A.
Catledge Helps Magic Beat Bulls
Terry Catledge scored 7 of his 34 points in overtime last night and the Orlando Magic rallied from a 14-point second-half deficit to defeat the visiting Chicago Bulls, 135-129.
After Matt Guokas, the Orlando coach, was ejected for protesting a technical assessed to Nick Anderson, the Magic battled back and tied the game at 118-all on Otis Smith's off-balance jumper with 28 seconds left in regulation.


Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Albanian-Serb Tension Touches All in Kosovo
LEAD: The Albanians gather in a haze of cigarette smoke in the university coffee shop, complaining about the ruling Serbs.
A few blocks away, in a little restaurant named for the tomb of an epic Slavic poet of resistance to the Ottomans, Serbs grumble about the majority Albanians.


St. John's Defeats Seton Hall
LEAD: Boo Harvey stepped over the time line tonight and made history, as St.
John's defeated Seton hall in overtime, 90-81.


Japan Trade Surplus Cut
LEAD: Surging imports pushed Japan's trade surplus down 90 percent in January, but the gap with the United States showed less dramatic improvement.


Washington Basks in al Fresco Fantasies
LEAD: The brisk winds of February only hint of the coming spring, but inside the Mayflower Hotel here an ode to outdoor living is on display.
Eighteen designers and 18 prominent Washingtonians have teamed up to create vignettes that celebrate the promise of summer entertaining and dining.

LEAD: The concert of the Riverside Symphony in the Miller Theater at Columbia University on Sunday afternoon was a chatty affair.
It began with remarks by Peter Smith, the dean of Columbia's School of the Arts, introducing the program, for which printed notes were also provided.
After the first work the audience heard a taped interview with the composer of the second, Oliver Knussen, by the orchestra's music director and conductor, George Rothman.

LEAD: When Ronald Reagan appears in a Federal courtroom on Friday, he is likely to be asked point-blank the fundamental questions about his role in the Iran-contra affair, which have gone unanswered for three years.

Train Hits Car, Killing Driver
LEAD: A commuter train bound from New York City to Bay Head, N.J., struck a car at a crossing in Holmdel, N.J., last evening, killing the car's driver, the police said.
None of the 475 passengers aboard the N.J.
Transit train were injured, but a dozen southbound trains were delayed up to two hours and three northbound trains up to an hour, said Sgt.

Fewer Jobless in Britain
LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell by 23,200 people in January, to a provisional 5.7 percent of the work force, the Government said today.
The seasonally adjusted figures showed unemployment at its lowest since October 1980, the year after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher came to power.
The improvement in the unemployment number was tempered, however, by data showing that December's annual rate of increase in average earnings was 9.25 percent, the same as November's.

Review/Art;   An 18-Year Journey Through Rauschenberg's Development
LEAD: Robert Rauschenberg's art is so diverse that sometimes it is easy to lose sight of his achievement.
He once turned his bed, red quilt and all, into a painting that now hangs in the Museum of Modern Art.
He has made ''combines,'' as he calls his painting-sculpture hybrids, using such unlikely items as a stuffed eagle or a stuffed goat with a car tire around its middle.


Corrections
LEAD: The caption of a picture by The Associated Press on Monday about a clash in Cape Town between marauding youths and the police referred incorrectly to the youths.
Nothing was known of political involvement by the youths; there was no evidence that they supported the African National Congress, despite the presence of crowds nearby celebrating the release of Nelson Mandela from prison.


Lemieux Sidelined
LEAD: Mario Lemieux of the Penguins, whose 46-game point scoring streak ended Wednesday night, won't be practicing or playing for a while.
He was examined yesterday in Pittsburgh by Dr.
Charles Burke, an orthopedic surgeon and the Penguins' team physician, who prescribed additional therapy, rest and traction.

Village Voice Publisher
LEAD: Michael B. Ellerin has been named publisher of The Village Voice, the paper's owner announced yesterday.
Mr.
Ellerin has been the weekly newspaper's classified advertising director.
He succeeds Sally J. Cohen, who was publisher for 15 months.
David Schneiderman, president of the VV Publishing Corporation, said she was leaving for personal reasons.

Serbian-Albanian Conflict Reverberating Across Yugoslavia
LEAD: Yugoslavs looking at television some nights ago came across an amazing sight, a political rally in Titograd where speakers were drowned out by an audience shooting hundreds of guns into the air.


Changing Tactics, Miners Will Vote on Pact
LEAD: The United Mine Workers said today that it would let its 1,700 striking members vote next Monday on a contract with the Pittston Coal Group rather than wait for a final court ruling on $64 million in fines against the union.


Whittle Says Channel One Is on Target
LEAD: Channel One, the daily news service for schoolchildren that has provoked intense criticism because it will include commercials, has signed up more than 2,500 schools and $200 million worth of advertising, Christopher Whittle, the chairman of Whittle Communications, said yesterday.


Commonwealth Edison Offering
LEAD: The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago priced a two-part issue of first mortgage bonds totaling $350 million yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The 'Creative Hessians' Are Coming
LEAD: SOME call them ''creative Hessians'' - the seasoned freelance advertising writers and art directors who, for fees of up to $1,000 a day, fill in for temporarily absent creative staff members at ad agencies or help the agencies revive moribund ad campaigns.

Canada's Banks Increase Rates
LEAD: Canada's largest banks raised their prime lending rate three-quarters of a percentage point today, to 14.25 percent, the highest level since 1982.

Mandela Sees Basis for Talks on Power Sharing
LEAD: Nelson Mandela said today that his private discussions with the Government had already laid a foundation for negotiations on power sharing between blacks and whites and that he wanted the talks to start as soon as possible.


Nets Lose Track of Players as Skid Hits 12
LEAD: When the second half started tonight, the Nets had only four players on the court.
Charles Shackleford, the starting power forward, was in the locker room with an upset stomach, and the Net bench had forgotten to replace him in the lineup.

The Reilly-Sununu War
LEAD: It's no secret that John Sununu and William Reilly clash on environmental issues, but it's also no scandal.
Disagreement between the White House chief of staff and the head of the Environmental Protection Agency provides a constructive way to help President Bush make policy.


Review/Art;   Peace, Purity and Energy In Still Lifes by Morandi
LEAD: The exhibition of 16 still lifes by Giorgio Morandi (1890-1964) at the Philippe Daverio Gallery comes at an ideal moment.
Against the backdrop of a contemporary art scene in which money, bombast and irony have reigned for a decade, Morandi's example of abstemiousness and monklike dedication to the humblest of tasks is another reminder that art need not be big and brash to make its mark, nor must it be entirely made over from one season to the next, like the latest couture collections.


ADVANCE REPORTED IN LEUKEMIA TESTS
LEAD: Researchers have produced a mouse that suffers from a form of human leukemia, giving scientists a new way to test therapies for treatment of the disease.

Review/Music;   Los Angeles Piano Quartet
LEAD: The Los Angeles Piano Quartet was founded in 1977 and consists of players who also teach as far afield as Santa Barbara and Tucson.
The group appeared Thursday night at the 92d Street Y for a concert that was notable for a novelty but disappointing in more conventional repertory.

Henry Utell, 85, Dies; Founded Hotel Service
LEAD: Henry Utell, the founder and former president of Utell International, a hotel telephone reservation system, died Sunday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center after a short illness.
He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

First Chicago Hoax in Paper
LEAD: A newspaper article on a potential takeover deal supposedly based on comments made by the president of the First Chicago Corporation was a hoax, the bank said today.


Profits Fall At Ford And G.M.
LEAD: The nation's two biggest auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, posted significant declines in earnings for the fourth quarter and the year, reflecting the softness in auto sales and their costly incentive programs for buyers.
Ford's results also reflect the sale of the company's Rouge Steel subsidiary in the fourth quarter.

LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation, the nation's largest maker of medium and heavy trucks, today reported a loss of $18 million in its first quarter.
It attributed the difficulty to lower demand for its products and higher production costs.
Navistar said the net loss for the three months ended Jan.

Approval of Extra Money For Savings Rescue Is Near
LEAD: The agency that oversees the bailout of the savings and loan industry is close to approving a plan that will permit the additional borrowing of more than $40 billion from the Treasury Department this year.
The new money is needed to cover the interim costs of taking over and selling off insolvent institutions.


Mayor Barry Indicted on Charges Of Possessing Cocaine and Lying
LEAD: A Federal grand jury indicted Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today on five misdemeanor counts of possessing cocaine and three felony counts of lying about being involved with drugs.

New York Man Is Arrested In 43-Year-Old Miami Killing
LEAD: A New York man was arrested today in the slaying 43 years ago of a Miami police officer who was shot while on patrol outside a football game.
The suspect, Leroy Strachan, 61 years old, of 207 W. 123d St., was arrested after he was brought to the 6th Precinct by a Miami police detective, said Sgt.
Mary Wrensen, a spokeswoman for the New York City Police Department.


DEALS
LEAD:
BASEBALL
KANSAS CITY (AL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Loggins, outfielder, on a one-year contract.
CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Luis Quinones, infielder, to a one-year contract.
HOUSTON (NL) - Agreed to terms with Joaquin Andujar, pitcher, and Andujar Cedeno, shortstop, on one-year contracts.


Neiman Marcus
LEAD: The Neiman Marcus Group Inc. said it had long-term plans to open a 140,000-square-foot Neiman Marcus store at the Long Island Galleria, a shopping mall being developed in Westbury, L.I., by Westfield Inc.
The store will be the Dallas-based retailer's second in the New York area and 24th location in the nation.

LEAD: To the uninitiated, the blues is the blues - a simple form of music performed in a simple style.
But aficionados know there's more to the blues than 12 bars, 3 chords and ''my baby left me.''

LEAD: As Communism collapsed in country after country in Eastern Europe last fall, it became clear that what all of them wanted was to join the Western cultural, political and economic traditions from which they had been cut off for 40 years.

LEAD: Jack Newcombe, a novelist, a journalist and the author of books about sports figures, died Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital.
He was 66 years old.

Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 497 money market mutual funds declined by $374.1 million, to $387.11 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 152 institutional funds decreased by $768.7 million, to $91.42 billion.
The assets of the 244 general-purpose funds rose $351.5 billion, to $131.22 billion.

A's McGwire Signs One-Year Contract
LEAD: Mark McGwire, the slugging first baseman for the Oakland Athletics, signed a one-year contract for $1.5 million yesterday and averted today's scheduled arbitration hearing.
The 26-year-old McGwire, who earned $455,000 in 1989, was asking $1.72 million, with the A's offering $1 million.

LEAD: Ansett Airlines has ordered 10 Airbus Industrie A321 aircraft for delivery between 1995 and 1999, the General Electric Company said Wednesday.

Late Buying Gives Dow Gain of 25.23
LEAD: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday, helped by a late spurt of futures-related ''buy'' programs.
As arbitragers sold futures and bought stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 25.23 points, to 2,649.55.


How the First Ladies Dressed for the Ball
LEAD: Edith Wilson's inaugural dress was black velvet and had an eight-foot train studded with sequins.
Nancy Reagan's was covered with rhinestones and crystal beads and had one bare shoulder.
Grace Coolidge is represented by a short red-velvet ''flapper'' design.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Consumer's World page on Jan. 20 about finding a retirement home in Florida misstated Florida property tax rules.
Under the homestead exemption, the first $25,000 of the assessed value of a primary residence is not taxed.
There is no additional $5,000 exemption for owners who are 65 or older.

Review/Film;   Following Heidi Through Love and War
LEAD: ''So!
Who has a song for us?'' Peter asks Heidi and her schoolgirl chums in a scene from ''Courage Mountain.'' ''We can't have a campfire without a song or a poem!'' Will anyone be surprised to find Charlie Sheen playing cheerleader here in the role of Heidi's stalwart swain?
They should be.
Both the actor and the film seem to have taken a step backward in time, back to the days when adventure films for young audiences did not involve dance competitions, video games or the kinds of personal triumphs that lead to unanticipated fame.


Big Jump In Starts Of Housing
LEAD: Housing starts jumped a record 29.6 percent last month as builders took advantage of the warmest January on record, the Government reported today, but analysts said the industry could not sustain the pace.

LEAD: Craig Stadler has gone without a victory on the PGA Tour since the 1984 Byron Nelson Classic, but none of his near-misses over the last several years were as agonizing to watch as his putting debacle at last week's Hawaiian Open in Honolulu.


Phoenix Mayor Moves On
LEAD: Mayor Terry Goddard resigned today to seek the Democratic Party's gubernatorial nomination to fill the post being vacated by Gov.
Rose Mofford.
Mr.
Goddard, a son of former Gov.
Sam Goddard, was elected to his first term as mayor in 1983.
He won re-election three times, most recently in October against the chairman of the state Republican Party, Burton Kruglick.


Shevardnadze Calls for Meeting This Year on German Unification
LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union called today on the 35 nations taking part in an East-West conference on security in Europe to begin working on a meeting later this year to prepare for German unification.

New Eruption in Alaska
LEAD: The Redoubt Volcano erupted again today with a cloud of ash six miles high, causing flight restrictions and forcing the evacuation of an oil terminal.
The volcano, 150 miles southwest of Anchorage, was dormant for 25 years until it erupted two months ago.


President's In-Flight Show: New Pique Toward the Press
LEAD: In an extraordinary display of Presidential pique, George Bush accosted reporters aboard Air Force One today to let them know he was mad about news reports on his penchant for secrecy and wasn't going to take it anymore.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced nine powerful work stations whose design and pricing indicate that the nation's largest computer maker is breaking with its traditions.


New England Bank Pact to Sell Loans
LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation signed an agreement to sell about $1 billion of the loan portfolio of its communications lending group to the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
The loans were being sold at par value.
The loans will be acquired by Canadian Imperial in a three-step financing process.


AIDS Expert Warns of Hazards in Research
LEAD: A leading AIDS researcher warned in a paper being published today that certain experiments with the AIDS virus could result in new, more deadly strains of the virus.
Although such strains have not been produced, the concern is that they might be.


Negotiators Exchange Outlooks on Talks
LEAD: The baseball negotiations took a strange turn yesterday, the day the owners' spring training lockout officially began.
Fay Vincent, the commissioner, and Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, reversed positions in their assessment of the status of the talks.


Asian-American Is Named To Head a Major Campus
LEAD: Chang-Lin Tien was named today as chancellor for the University of California's prestigious Berkeley campus.

Review/Opera;   Domingo and Verrett in 'Samson et Dalila'
LEAD: No sensible person has ever made great claims for ''Samson et Dalila'' as a great work of art.
Its musical and dramatic weaknesses are so obvious that the wonder is how Saint-Saens's once-popular opera could possibly continue to interest a modern audience.
Like most inferior operas, it requires the tenderest treatment if it is to succeed.

Keyes Beech, 76, Correspondent In Asia for Five Decades, Is Dead
LEAD: Keyes Beech, who for many years was a foreign correspondent in Asia and won a Pulitzer Prize in 1951 for his reporting on the Korean War, died yesterday of emphysema at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington.
He was 76 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

Review/Photography;   Photography's First 150 years, Seen Through a Trusted Eye
LEAD: THOSE who had hoped that the observance of photography's first 150 years would occasion a re-evaluation of the medium's place in the world (and in the world of art) can take heart. ''Photography Until Now,'' the Museum of Modern Art's slightly tardy survey of the last century and a half of picture making, is an original, discerning and sometimes surprising show that challenges the public understanding of what the art of photography really is.

Review/Dance;   Balanchine and Mendelssohn
LEAD: It has been said that George Balanchine was drawn to the creation of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' by the music of Felix Mendelssohn.
Balanchine eventually used the composer's overture and incidental music to the Shakespeare play and other, more obscure Mendelssohn scores for his ballet.
Balanchine's first act follows the Shakespeare play with fidelity.


The Citadel Rejects a Woman
LEAD: The first woman to apply for admission to the corps of cadets at the Citadel has been rejected.
The Justice Department recently ordered Virginia Military Institute, the nation's only other state-supported military academy, to admit women or face a lawsuit.
Virginia has challenged the order.
Since the Citadel was founded 148 years ago, no woman has been admitted to the 2,000-member corps of cadets.

Review/Pop;   A World Dancing as It Dies
LEAD: In ''Rhythm of Life,'' the most powerful cut on Hugh Harris's recent debut album, ''Words for Our Years,'' the 24-year-old English singer and songwriter accomplishes something that many pop figures have run aground while attempting.
Stringing together images of disaster and ecstasy - of houses burning, of making love ''by the light of the bombs'' - he creates a richly charged vision of the world in all its turbulence, dancing and dying at the same time.

Holiday on Monday
LEAD: Washington's Birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Government offices: Closed.
Post office: Express mail and special delivery only.
Service at main post office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Closed.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended
Sanitation: No pick-up, recycling collection or street cleaning.

Restaurants
LEAD: New York City's relatively paltry selection of quality restaurants on the waterfront has been substantially enhanced with the recent arrival of the Hudson River Club, a handsome and comfortable dining room facing New York Harbor with the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island off in the distance.
The food can be as inspiring as the setting.


Prudential Venture Set on Real Estate
LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company of America and Jones Lang Wooten will begin a $2 billion program to buy property around the world.
The Prudential Global Real Estate Investment Program is intended to help companies acquire a real estate portfolio spread among leading cities in several countries.
Plans are to invest in prime real estate assets over five years.

Lessons in Capitalism - From Poland
LEAD: You're unemployed.
What kind of help do you want from your Government?
How about unemployment insurance that starts high but falls over time?
The benefits would remain high if you enrolled in a training program but drop to zero if you refused legitimate job offers.


Review/Theater;   Tyrannical As Ever, 'Margarida' Returns
LEAD: In the 12 years since Miss Margarida held her first class in New York City, demanding blind obedience to her tyrannical rule, dictators have fallen and a dissident playwright has become president of his country.
After cataclysmic historical events, seeing Estelle Parsons in ''Miss Margarida's Way'' in 1990 is like encountering an obstreperous figure from the past, a black sheep returning for a family gathering.

Dollar Is Generally Higher But No Strong Trend Is Seen
LEAD: The dollar advanced against all leading currencies except the Canadian dollar yesterday, although there was little news to provide direction in the foreign exchange markets.


Anderson Enjoys A Happy Return
LEAD: Kenny Anderson, the top scorer in New York State high school basketball history, came home to play last night for the first time since entering Georgia Tech, and proved he is still one of New York's finest.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
Companies


Penney's Profits Drop 15.6%
LEAD: Fourth-quarter profits at the J. C. Penney Company fell 15.6 percent, mainly because the sale of its New York headquarters had inflated 1988 earnings, the big retailer reported today.


Appeals Court Frees Inmate on Hunger Strike
LEAD: A prisoner who had been on a hunger strike for nearly a year to protest his conviction on drug charges has been freed by order of the Michigan Court of Appeals.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.H.L.
North Stars Extend Kings' Slump
Mike Gartner posted his second three-goal game of the season and Jon Casey made 37 saves last night as the Minnesota North Stars handed the Los Angeles Kings their fifth successive defeat, 6-3.
The victory was the second in eight games for the North Stars and their 21st home victory, tying them with Montreal for most in the league.


Hanson to Buy a Stake in Peabody
LEAD: Hanson P.L.C., the British-based investment concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 45 percent stake in the Peabody Holding Company, the largest coal producer in the United States, for about $504 million.
The share Hanson is buying is now held jointly by three companies: the Boeing Company, Bechtel Investments Inc.


Understanding America's Diversity
LEAD: Does New York State's education curriculum adequately reflect the rich complexity of American society?
No, says State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol.
He wants to develop a new multicultural curriculum to increase student awareness of the history and culture of America's ethnic and racial groups and ''other peoples throughout the world.

LEAD: The prospect of a rapid economic union of West and East Germany is sending jitters through European and other bond markets, pushing interest rates higher.

Industrial Equity Sues Cummins
LEAD: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., the New Zealand-controlled company that owns 14.9 percent of the Cummins Engine Company, filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing Cummins of securities fraud and charging that its chairman and five inside directors breached their shareholder duties.


Shifts in Travel Group At American Express
LEAD: The American Express Company announced yesterday that R. Craig Hoenshell had been appointed the new president of its Traveler's Cheque Group USA.


Dismissals By Drexel Seen Today
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the fallen Wall Street firm, will dismiss thousands of its employees today, Drexel executives said yesterday.


Bush Says Bill Ignores His Powers
LEAD: Signing a bill today to allocate $9.8 billion in funds for the State Department next year, President Bush said he did not consider several of its provisions binding, including language that would require him to inform Congress of any sensitive diplomatic missions.


Vast New Airport Is Proposed for Chicago
LEAD: Mayor Richard M. Daley has proposed building a new airport on the Southeast Side that would be larger than O'Hare International Airport, one of the busiest in the world.

Ralston Venture
LEAD: The Ralston Purina Company. said its international division had formed a joint venture with a Hungarian farm cooperative to produce livestock and poultry formula feeds in Hungary.
St.
Louis-based Ralston said it believes the deal with Agro-Industrial Union of Hajdusag is the first between an American company and an Eastern European farm cooperative.


I.R.A. INVESTMENTS
LEAD: Even with changes in the tax laws, Inidividual Retirement Accounts remain one of the best investments for later years.
While contributions may not be deductible for some, taxes on all the earnings are deferred until the holder retires.
A world of caution comes from bank analysts, who note that a growing number of institutions are adding charges to I.R.A.


Miners Cheered by Contract's Terms
LEAD: About 2,000 miners and their wives gave Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers of America, an emotional standing ovation here today, leaving little doubt how they feel about the contract he negotiated and the prospect of going back to work after 10 months of walking picket lines and living on $225-a-week strike pay.


Corrections
LEAD: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''Speaking Parts'' misidentified the theater where it is playing.
It is the Quad Cinema, on 13th Street west of Fifth Avenue, not the Bleecker Street Cinema.


Hercules Outlines Divestiture Plans
LEAD: Hercules Inc., the chemicals and plastics producer, expects to receive more than $300 million from planned divestitures, its chairman, David S. Hollingsworth said. ''We've announced plans to sell the electronics and printing products business,'' he said, adding that the company is ''actively exploring divestitures'' of its Simmonds Precision Products Inc.


76ers Get By With 4 Overtime Points, 100-96
LEAD: Rick Mahorn and Johnny Dawkins had two free throws apiece - the only points in the extra period - as the Philadelphia 76ers won with the lowest-scoring overtime period in National Basketball Association history tonight, 100-96, over the Seattle SuperSonics.


Spring Exercise for Five Mets
LEAD: On the day they were supposed to report for the start of spring training, five pitchers on the Mets tossed baseballs on a Little League field and played half-court basketball on a playground three miles from their training complex, which was locked and empty.

Bankers Hesitant on Drexel Sales
LEAD: Senior executives with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street firm that collapsed earlier this week, held high-level meetings yesterday with a number of banking officials who have been balking at settling sales of securities by Drexel in the last few days, people who were briefed on the talks said.


Upheaval in the East;   Private Farmers in Bulgaria Will Get More Land to Till
LEAD: The government has agreed to end restrictions on private farming by lifting curbs on how much land individuals can till, the official press agency reported today.


No. 2 Police Official to Move From L.I. to New York City
LEAD: New York City's new No. 2 police official, First Deputy Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, who lives in Garden City, L.I., will move into New York to comply with city policy and the philosophy of Mayor David N. Dinkins, city officials said yesterday.


EXILED OPPOSITION TO SEND A PANEL TO MEET DE KLERK
LEAD: The governing body of the African National Congress said today that it would send a delegation to South Africa ''as soon as possible'' to meet with President F. W. de Klerk in an attempt to remove obstacles to opening talks with Pretoria.


U.S. Seizes Franklin Savings Association
LEAD: Federal regulators today took control of the Franklin Savings Association, a large and unorthodox savings institution based in Ottawa, Kan., with $11.4 billion in assets and close ties to Wall Street.
It is now the largest savings unit in Government hands.

Coast Guard Assailed On Oil Spill Readiness
LEAD: A California Congressman has accused the Coast Guard of overstating its readiness to deal with oil spills like the one that fouled the Pacific Coast south of Los Angeles last week.


British Inflation at 7.7%
LEAD: Britain's inflation rate was unchanged in January at an annual 7.7 percent for the third consecutive month.
Financial markets had been expecting a lower figure after economists had predicted that the pace of rises in the retail price index, Britain's main measure of inflation, would fall to 7.5 percent.

Guatemala Bus Crash Kills 12
LEAD: Twelve Guatemalan refugees were killed and five seriously injured when a bus collided head on with a gas tanker near the Mexican town of Chetumal, about 900 miles southeast of Mexico City, the police said today.


Pressure Building for Mayor Barry to Resign After Indictment
LEAD: The indictment of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. on drug and perjury charges on Thursday has intensified pressure, from friends as well as enemies, for his resignation.

LEAD: The holders of the controlling stake in The St.

Willard Thorp, 90, Princeton Professor; Headed U.S. Studies
LEAD: Dr.
Willard Thorp, a literary historian, an editor and a critic who taught at Princeton University for more than 40 years before retiring in 1967, died of cardiac arrest on Thursday at the Merwick Nursing Home in Princeton, N.J.
He was 90 years old and lived in Princeton.


Vuitton Family Plans To Buy 95% of Lanvin
LEAD: An investment group led by the Vuitton family said today that it planned to buy 95 percent of Lanvin, the 100-year-old Paris fashion house that also makes Arpege and My Sin perfumes.

Prison for Pit Bull's Owner
LEAD: The owner of a pit bull that fatally mauled a 2-year-old child who wandered within reach of the chained dog was sentenced in Santa Clara County Superior Court today to 3 years 8 months in prison.
The 39-year-old defendant, Michael Patrick Berry, was convicted in December of involuntary manslaughter and three lesser charges in the death of the child, James Soto.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.H.L.
Sabres Win After 5-Goal Rally
Playing at home, the Buffalo Sabres scored five consecutive goals for a come-from-behind 5-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens last night.
Pierre Turgeon scored the game-tying goal 1 minute 16 seconds into the third period, then assisted on what proved to be the game-winner, scored five minutes later by Dave Snuggerud.


Fire Kills 2 Who Saved Their Children
LEAD: A mother and father died in a fire early yesterday morning in Brooklyn after the mother desperately squeezed their four children under a window gate that had been illegally wired shut, fire officials said.


Fiat and Poland In Car Agreement
LEAD: Fiat S.p.A., Italy's auto giant, said it had signed a preliminary agreement to produce a midsize car in Poland.
Fiat won the agreement after nearly three years of talks and competition with Japan's Daihatsu Motor Company.
The value of the deal was not disclosed.

LEAD: The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation cut the price on two of its models to spur sales.

Patents;   Preventing Kidnapping Of Babies in Hospitals
LEAD: Clifford Wheeless Jr., an obstetrician/ gynecologist in Baltimore, has patented a device to prevent the kidnapping of newborn infants. ''There have been a number of babies stolen out of hospitals and nurseries,'' Dr.
Wheeless said.
The invention is similar to the anti-shoplifting magnetic tags attached to clothing displayed in stores.

LEAD: Industrial production took its biggest plunge in nearly four years last month, the Government said today, but analysts cited temporary factors for the 1.2 percent drop and said output should resume growth at a sluggish pace.

LEAD: Executives at the General Motors Corporation are making plans to shift an undisclosed amount of the company's $35 billion in pension-fund assets into ''junk bonds,'' said people in the market who have been told about the move.

LEAD: When the two Miami police detectives seized Leroy Strachan on a Manhattan street on Thursday, he told them that he had expected it, that it was only a matter of time before they would catch up with him, they said.
He was wanted for the murder of a police officer in Miami 43 years ago.

Patents;   A WAtch to Ease Jet Lag
LEAD: Ross E. Mitchell, an inventor in Newtonville, Mass., obtained a patent this week for a watch to help travelers fight jet lag by making time fly.
Mr.
Mitchell noted that travelers arriving in a different time zone normally switched to the new time in an abrupt and disorienting way.
His new watch is designed to smooth this transition by spreading the adjustment over the flight.

LEAD: Rioting in Soviet Central Asia spread today to the Soviet Republic of Uzbekistan as Muslims clashed with ethnic Armenians in Samarkand, Radio Moscow reported.

LEAD: Since his ejection from the Australian Open last month, mum has pretty much been the word on court for John McEnroe, who is in Toronto for the Skydome World Tennis event this week.

LEAD: President Bush faces a quandary in Nicaragua.

Faxing as a Way to a Faster Refund
LEAD: Instatax Inc. of San Diego has developed a system that enables taxpayers to fax their prepared tax returns to the company, which then transmits the returns to the Internal Revenue Service.
The service costs $29.95 plus faxing and mailing costs.
Generally, refunds on returns filed electronically are received within two weeks.

LEAD: The second toxic chemical leak in two weeks at a plant considered among the most modern in the nation forced the authorities on Thursday to order 15,000 residents here to remain indoors.

Peace Before Power
LEAD: The principle is settled.
West Germany will absorb East Germany, probably this year.
Bonn's December elections will be for a Reichskanzler, not just leader of the Federal Republic but of all Germany.
Whether East Germans participate remains to be decided.
But they will have a big influence.
The electorate will know it is choosing the government for a united country.

Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about Henry A. Kissinger's resignation from the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board described the board's activities incorrectly.
It meets formally about every two months, and consultants and staff members meet at other times.
The item also referred incorrectly to John Tower's nomination to the board.
