DEALS
LEAD:
Baseball


2 Public Relations Styles Clash in Battle of Trumps
LEAD: One is a mild-mannered man who once had a client bring a live elephant to the steps of City Hall, but who has since more often relied on his skills as a conciliator to build a large public relations firm and a reputation as a man you need to know in New York City.


Rail Link to Airport
LEAD: To the Editor:


Coping: With Photographic Red Eye
LEAD: Of all the things that can go wrong in a snapshot, few are more disconcerting than the phenomenon of red eye.
It leaves friends and family looking like ghouls, their eyes glowing an unearthly shade of crimson.
While over the last 10 years camera manufacturers have eliminated virtually all the other plagues that can ruin photographs, red eye has remained an all-too-common flaw.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the bombing of a refugee settlement in El Salvador misidentified the group that confirmed reports of the attack.
It was the Salvadoran Red Cross, not the International Committee of the Red Cross.


What's Blocking the Thrift Bailout?
LEAD: The meter keeps ticking on the savings-and-loan crisis.
Insolvent thrifts are piling up losses at a rate of $6 million a day.
Or maybe it's $14 million.
Or even $20 million.
It's hard to pin down a firm number.
It's even harder to pin down who's running the rescue effort.


Corrections
LEAD: Articles between Jan. 26, 1986, and last Saturday about John Gotti, whom law enforcement officials call the leader of the Gambino crime family, referred incorrectly to the Queens club that is said to be his headquarters.
Despite frequent references to the ''Bergen Hunt and Fish Club'' in court papers, a sign recently posted at the club calls it the Bergin Hunt and Fish Social Club.


Southwestern Bell to End Test of Data 'Gateway' Offer
LEAD: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said yesterday that it plans to end its test offering of a ''public information gateway'' that allows computer users to tap into a variety of data bases by dialing one number from a telephone line.


The Editorial Notebook;   Soviet Subs in Sweden
LEAD: Every year, Soviet submarines penetrate deep into the territorial waters of neutral Sweden, gathering intelligence and testing Swedish defenses.
Sweden keeps hoping that Moscow's leaders, who surely cannot intend these gross violations, will bring their navy under control.


H.R.A. Dismisses Priest in Inquiry
LEAD: The Rev.
John Mario, a priest whose credentials have been questioned in recent weeks, was dismissed yesterday as an official with the New York City Human Resources Administration.


Bridge
LEAD: Few players realize that there are considerable opportunities for effective deceptive plays in the trump suit.
There is, for example, a whole family of doubleton tenaces: jack-nine, queen-ten, king-jack and ace-queen.
In each case it is sometimes productive to play the higher honor unnecessarily, and lead the declarer down a tempting path.


Reagan Testifies in the Poindexter Case
LEAD: More than three years after the Iran-contra affair put his Administration under a cloud, former President Ronald Reagan answered questions under oath today about his role in it, testifying in a locked Federal courtroom for five hours.

Beliefs
LEAD: After three decades of sustained interfaith dialogue among America's Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews, the borders of most religious groups are largely undefended, and no one is massing troops along them.
Compared with the bitter Catholic-Protestant conflicts of, say, the 1950's, today's occasional quarrels look more like customs disputes than full-scale belligerency.

Sentencing Criminals: A Formula for Fairness
LEAD: Under a new philosophy of prison sentencing that is spreading across the country, California's judicial system appears to have largely eliminated racial bias in determining which convicts go to prison and for how long, a study by the Rand Corporation has reported.


Upheaval in the East;   Shakeup in Poland's Media
LEAD: One-third of the managers and directors of state radio and television have been replaced and the pro-Solidarity broadcast chief plans a full reorganization this spring, the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported today.
Most of the new management people are former television journalists and directors ousted when martial law was imposed in December 1981.


Choreography Winners
LEAD: Four winners have been announced in the Boston International Choreography Competition sponsored by the Boston Ballet.
Rick McCullough was awarded the gold medal and a cash prize of $3,000 for ''Others Because . . .,'' set to Prokofiev's first violin concerto.
Bonnie Scheibman won the silver medal and $2,000 for ''Moon Roses,'' set to music by Bruce Novack.

Holiday on Monday
LEAD:
Washington's Birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Government offices: Closed.
Post office: Express mail and special delivery only.
Service at main post office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Closed.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended
Sanitation: No pick-up, recycling collection or street cleaning.

Herrick B. Young, 86, Ex-College President
LEAD: Herrick B. Young, a former college president who was an authority on international education, died of pneumonia on Thursday at Sibley Hospital in Washington., He was 86 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: Over the objections of the state, a sheriff, fed up with months of overcrowding at the county jail here, has commandeered a National Guard armory and says he will temporarily house prisoners there ''to keep the peace.''


Harlem Woman, 66, Dies After Robbery
LEAD: A Harlem grandmother who feared staying alone at night suffered a fatal heart attack early yesterday, minutes after she opened the door to two masked gunmen who ransacked the apartment and fled, the police said.
Detectives investigating the robbery are treating it as a murder case.

The Earthy Bounty of Umbria
LEAD: UMBRIA, the small, green, hilly, landlocked region of central Italy, is best known in the rest of the world for the Spoleto Festival, the cathedral of Orvieto and St.
Francis of Assisi.
In Italy it is loved for its natural beauty and quiet civility but most of all for being a good place to eat.
Its fruity green olive oil is arguably the finest the country produces.


Review/Music;   Greg Osby's Saxophone Improvisations
LEAD: In the last several years, the young saxophonist Greg Osby has emerged as a distinct, important figure on the alto saxophone, making appearances on his own moody, funk-influenced recordings as well as with the composers Andrew Hill and Steve Coleman and the drummers Cecil Brooks and Jack DeJohnette.


$1 a Pound and Nutritious? Squid
LEAD: AT a dollar a pound, which is what it is selling for in Chinatown these days, squid must be the cheapest seafood you can buy.
It is also extremely nutritious, being low in fat and calories and high in protein.

LEAD: Roger Keizerstein's warning that financially advantaged youngsters will have more difficulty establishing independent households because many will not be able to afford comparable lifestyles and will thus choose to remain in the comforts of the parental nest is based on a simplistic formulation of a complex problem.

The Intricate Patterning of Batik
LEAD: IN a small rice-farming village south of Jogjakarta, Indonesia, a 19-year-old woman crouched in the doorway of her bamboo house, using the last rays of sunlight to see as she applied molten wax to a piece of cotton fabric.
The woman, Miss Setyawati, was creating a work of batik, Indonesia's national handcraft.

Boxing: Same Old Stories, New Twists
LEAD: When Don Skene was a boxing reporter for The New York Herald Tribune, his sense of perspective was so broad he never entered a fight club without saying, ''Things were never like this when we fought on barges.'' Unfortunately, the late Mr.
Skene was wrong.
Nothing ever changes in boxing.
New faces populate the same old stories.

LEAD: A new system for de-icing the the wings of airplanes and the rotors of helicopters has been invented by Leonard Haslim, a program manager at NASA's Ames Research Center in Mountain View, Calif.

WRIGHT'S HEIRS BUILD SOME BRIDGES TO THE REAL WORLD
LEAD: Olgivanna Lloyd Wright, the widow of Frank Lloyd Wright, died in March 1985, and for more than three years after that, her bedroom in the Wright residence at Taliesin West remained empty.
There was no surprise to the fact that the room was left like a shrine: Taliesin, which is owned by the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation and functions as part tourist attraction, part architecture school, part Wright archive and part ongoing architectural practice, has always had an oddly worshipful, almost cultlike quality to it.


NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Augusta, Me.;   Mobile-Home Ban Outlawed
LEAD: A STATE law effective with the new year that forbids the outlawing of mobile-home parks has enraged many municipal leaders who resent Augusta's dabbling in what they consider to be town issues.

LEAD: Lebanon's embattled Christian militia coalition, vowing to fight on despite losing main strongholds in East Beirut, mounted an attack today against an army base north of here where 500 troops loyal to Gen.
Michel Aoun have been holding out.

Mortimer Edelstein, Lawyer, 85
LEAD: Mortimer Edelstein, a lawyer who was assistant general counsel to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey before he became a partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Wharton &amp; Garrison, died on Thursday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla., where he had retired in 1977.
He was 85 years old.


Paris Couture: Living Up to the Legend
LEAD: THE PARIS COUTURE IS THE OLYMPIAD of fashion design.
In this biannual arena in which a chosen few compete, a couturier has free reign to create whatever vision he has in mind.
Money is no object, and the most magnificent materials, accessories and artisans are at his fingertips.
The news media of the world are there to cover the results, and, in turn, the publicity helps sell large quantities of more affordable products bearing the couturier's label.


POSTINGS: An A.I.A. Guest;   The Prince on Architecture
LEAD: The Prince of Wales, who has been sharply critical of some of the newer examples of modern architecture and urban planning in England, will share his ideas with 600 of this nation's leading architects on Thursday during a visit to Washington.


Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
LEAD: The whole idea of a lockout is absurd.
We faithful fans, numbed by winter, have been looking forward to the new season.
And who's responsible for the high salaries, anyway?
Certainly not the players.
The owners have backed themselves into a corner and are now resorting to very unpleasant methods to get themselves out of it.


Now, to Negotiate The Contours of Apartheid's End
LEAD: THE old man who walked out of the prison farm near Cape Town a week ago was proof even to South Africa's critics that President F. W. de Klerk was serious about changing the universally despised system of apartheid.
The unconditional release of Nelson Mandela, now 71 years old, was more than a concession to the world, for it set in motion a process that the Government hopes will produce a new constitution giving the black majority long overdue political rights without jeopardizing the interests of the white minority.


Upheaval in the East: Has Castro Caught the Bug?;   Cubans Outline Plan to 'Perfect' Communist Rule
LEAD: Cuba's Communist Party leadership today announced what it described as plans for deep reforms in the country's political system.
But its statement made it clear that Cuba was not abandoning one-party Communist rule.


If You're Thinking of Living in: Fort Lee
LEAD: THE name George Washington brings grimaces to the faces of many Fort Lee residents.
But it's not the Father of the Country - who laid out a fort on the site in 1776 - they have a grudge against; it's the bridge named for him, the one that was opened in 1931 to connect New Jersey with Manhattan.


Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
LEAD: Owners collude to hold free-agent costs down, or they engage in cutthroat bidding wars that lead to absurdly inflated contracts for journeymen players.
Neither the owners nor the players seem to recognize any common interest with the fans.
Get the fans to walk away, and one fine day the whole enterprise will collapse like a house of bubble-gum baseball cards.

Riding the 'Junk' Whirlwind
LEAD: Despite the swift demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the ''junk bond'' market seems certain to survive, money managers, analysts and traders said.

Japanese Composers Delve Into the Past for Their Future
LEAD: Orchestral music in Japan has a history at least as old as jazz in America.
Although the musical language of many Japanese composers remains rooted in an internationalist style (especially the ''color-field'' style so prevalent here and in Europe since the 60's, best exemplified by composers such as Witold Lutoslawski or Gyorgy Ligeti), it is being molded with confidence into a more typically ''Japanese'' character.

Before long, their fun and games are aimed toward kinky sex.
Years later, in a hot tub, where the prince is playing with his little boat, they have a spat over mutual infidelities, and Vi tosses fried chicken nuggets at Artie.

Canada
LEAD: To the Editor: Here is a warning of entrapment at the Canadian border for all American tourists.


Long Shot Earns Spot On Pro Basketball Team
LEAD: AT first glance, Greg Grant would appear to have no business playing in the National Basketball Association.
He is 5 feet 7 inches tall and weighs 145 pounds.
Five years ago, he was a college dropout selling fish in his hometown.
He then returned to school and became a standout player at Trenton State College, hardly a collegiate basketball power.

Mr.
Baker wrote the article with Chris Chase.

Marx, Subverted
LEAD: Karl Marx must be cringing in his grave.
The draft platform of the Soviet Union's Communist Party that was published last week contains an economic bombshell: approval of private ownership of private capital.
This proposed surrender of the party's economic dictatorship is every bit as radical as the document's proposed surrender of the party's 70-year political dictatorship.

Budget Impasse Comes to an End
LEAD: THE struggle over the county's 1990 budget ended last week as the Board of Legislators averted eliminating more than 400 jobs while indicating that it would take a more assertive role in drawing up future budgets.


Black History: A Bridge Between Two Americas
LEAD: IN the mid-70's, when I was a college freshman and black studies was flourishing on college campuses across America, I took a black history course in which, as expected, there was a roomful of fellow blacks.
What was unexpected was one white student among the bunch.

Secretive Nicaraguan Voters Leave Election Hard to Call
LEAD: After a decade of war, economic crisis and political polarization, Nicaraguans will vote in eight days in this country's first free and broadly contested democratic election.
But because most voters, wary of such freedom, remain deeply reluctant to discuss their personal views, even the best-informed specialists say they are at a loss to predict who will win.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
Golf
Forsman Takes Lead: Blustery winds were so severe that Dan Forsman needed only a par 72 to rally and take the third-round lead yesterday in the Shearson Lehman Hutton Open tournament at La Jolla, Calif.
With winds gusting more than 40 miles and hour, and occasionally accompanied by a drizzly rain, Forsman outlasted other struggling contenders to establish a two-stroke margin at 203, 13 under par on the South course at Torrey Pines.


Caring's Dollar Value
LEAD: While the responsibility of management is to increase shareholder value, that does not preclude a corporation from engaging in socially responsible activities.
Indeed, such activities may prove to increase shareholder value.


Fear of Directors
LEAD: To the Editor:


The King of Conflict of Interest
LEAD: For nearly two years now, Don King and Mike Tyson have emerged as the Siamese twins of boxing.
Siamese twins joined at the money clip.
One is seldom seen in public without the other.
And last Tuesday, as King apologized meekly and weakly for having protested that James (Buster) Douglas didn't deserve to be the new heavyweight champion because of a long count, the promoter kept using the word ''we,'' meaning himself and the dethroned champion who was sitting nearby.


I.R.S. INVESTIGATING FOREIGN COMPANIES FOR TAX CHEATING
LEAD: Bolstered by new auditing powers, Federal tax officials are investigating many American subsidiaries of Japanese companies on the suspicion that they have underpaid corporate income taxes by billions of dollars.


Boerum Hill
LEAD: To the Editor:


P.S. 135
LEAD: To the Editor:


Plan to Incinerate Tainted Missouri Soil Is Opposed
LEAD: Times Beach has been a ghost town since dioxin was discovered in the soil seven years ago and the Federal Government bought up all 801 homes and businesses and moved the residents out.


S.R.O. in Moscow
LEAD: Mstislav Rostropovich had his audience all but dancing in the aisles last week when he returned to the Soviet Union for the first time in 16 years and gave a concert of other Russians' greatest hits.
Mr.
Rostropovich, who was forced out of the Soviet Union in 1974 after his career hit a dead end over his support for Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, drew curtain call after curtain call on the conclusion of a program at the Moscow Conservatory that included symphonies by Tchaikovsky and Shostakovich.


A Loss For the Theater
LEAD: When Dennis McIntyre died on Feb. 1 (of cancer, at the age of 47), obituaries were brief and, for many, his name was unfamiliar.
Sadly, his death will not inspire Broadway eulogies, but his life says something revealing about the plight of the playwright.
He was a fine playwright with the potential to be a major one, but more than many of his peers he had difficulty getting his work produced.


Don't Forget Baseball's Young Fans
LEAD: Why should I care about Major League baseball?
After eight years as a judge in criminal and juvenile court, why would I have special concerns about the 1990 season and the disputes between the players and owners?


Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
LEAD: Whether or not I attend any games or watch any on television, I'm going to have to pay for the monetary fiasco, just as I'm going to help pay for the savings and loan scandals.
So I say ''a pox on all their houses'': players, owners, television (networks and stations), sponsors and all the rest.


A Bookstore Where Books Are Heard
LEAD: AT the Little Professor Book Center in Niantic, fledgling writers meet to talk about writing, established authors give readings and children attend story hours.
The activities represent what a bookstore should offer, said Robert Rue, who, with his wife, Connie, owns the store.


Reviews/Music;   A New Old-Instruments Ensemble
LEAD: The Classical Band, New York's first major attempt to create a period-instruments orchestra, is in the midst of its inaugural season.
Wednesday evening's all-Beethoven concert at Carnegie Hall, the ensemble's first under a conductor other than its founder, Trevor Pinnock, had its palpable charms.
But it also suggested that the orchestra is still very much feeling its way.

LEAD:
CLASSICAL
Lloyd: Symphony No. 5
BBC Philharmonic conducted by George Lloyd. Albany TROY-022; CD and cassette.
Much of George Lloyd's music is autobiographical, or at least reflective of world events during his lifetime.
His Fifth Symphony (there are apparently 11 to date) was written in Switzerland while the composer was slowly recovering from serious wartime injuries.

Trial Shows a Strong Valdez Crew With Some Flaws
LEAD: When the Exxon Valdez left the port of Valdez one night last March, her crew included a timid helmsman, a second mate who may have had mental problems and a captain with a history of drinking, according to testimony at the trial here of Capt.
Joseph J. Hazelwood.


CAN HE SAVE THE ELEPHANTS?
LEAD: The burning of the elephant tusks taken from poachers was a marvelous symbolic gesture.
However, as I recall, the ivory burned was worth approximately $3 million.
It seems to me it would have been wiser for the Government to sell the ivory and use the income for elephant-protection services.
STEVEN T.

Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: When Arthur Conan Doyle had Sherlock Holmes comment that chess is the mark of a scheming mind, he was dead right.
The black pieces are neither heavier nor possessed of any more force than the white ones, so if they are to win, they have to be sneakier.

LIFE IN THE EXECUTIVE SUITE AFTER DREXEL
LEAD: With the demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a collective sigh of relief is sweeping the board rooms of corporate America.
The collapse of the Wall Street firm, which created the popular ''junk bond,'' is seen as the most convincing evidence yet that the financial fuel for corporate raiders and hostile takeovers is drying up.


Keeping the State's Black History Alive
LEAD: A WEALTH of Connecticut's black history remains locked inside trunks, bureaus and attics in homes across the state, says George Bellinger, president of the Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society in New Haven.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about efforts to stop emigration from Israel characterized Mordechai Glick incorrectly.
He is a member of the Organization to Stop Emigration From Israel but is not its head.
The caption also misidentified the setting.
It was Mr.
Glick's home, not his office.


Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: The phrase ''Do good, make good'' seems like a good motto to live by, but when found on a curious set of aluminum tokens, it's a reminder of a turbulent period of American prison reform.
Prisoners at Auburn and Sing Sing prisons in New York used the tokens when morale and discipline were at an all-time high.

An American Sendup Of the British Royals
LEAD: IN ''Rumors in the Palace,'' Enid Rudd's two-character sendup of royal tradition, British style, the oversexed future king (Arthur) and his frigid teen-age princess (Vivian, or Vi) play, teasingly, with plastic water guns.
Before long, their fun and games are aimed toward kinky sex.
Years later, in a hot tub, where the prince is playing with his little boat, they have a spat over mutual infidelities, and Vi tosses fried chicken nuggets at Artie.

LEAD: The Islanders still hold first place in the Patrick Division.

Campus Life: Princeton;   Trying to Erase Their Image As Drinking Clubs
LEAD: Princeton University's 13 private eating clubs provide meals to about 75 percent of the upperclassmen and, until recently, alcohol to hundreds of underclassmen, many of them under age.
But if last weekend's club initiation parties are a guide, new rules on alcohol use are turning these campus social centers into bastions of sobriety.


The Quest for Synthetic Blood
LEAD: The long search for synthetic blood for use in transfusions is becoming a neck-and-neck race between companies working on ''white bloods'' and those working on ''reds.'' The goal is to find a substance that is easy to use and free from contaminants like hepatitis or the AIDS virus.

The Executive Computer;   I.B.M. Jumps Into Work Stations, With Both Feet
LEAD: The announcement last week of a new line of powerful work stations by the International Business Machines Corporation has again focused attention on the microprocessor technology called RISC and the operating system called Unix.
While they have been around for years, RISC chips and Unix are widely viewed as the next major steps in the evolution of high-performance business computers.

Corrections
LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on Sept. 10 misstated the policy of Trans World Airlines on bereavement fares.
The one-third refund for an airline ticket to a family member's funeral applies only to full fares, not to discounts.
The Times queried T.W.A. in October after receiving a reader complaint; T.W.A.

LEAD: I realize tiat Danny Aiello's head must be swimming after playing supporting parts in such deathless masterpieces as ''Harlem Nights'' and ''Fort Apache, the Bronx,'' so it's no surprise he failed to mention that he played a leading role in my play ''Gemini.'' It's my recollection that he was with us for nearly three years, Off, and, eventually, on Broadway in the late 1970's.


Jean Wallace, 66, Screen Actress Known for 1940's and 50's Roles
LEAD: Jean Wallace, a screen actress who had feature parts in a dozen Hollywood productions and was married to two stars, Franchot Tone and Cornel Wilde, died of a gastrointestinal hemorrhage Wednesday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif.
She was 66 years old.


Acquiring Art to Show in Public Spaces
LEAD: TOM MORAN, the visual arts coordinator at the State Council on the Arts, oversees the implementation of the Arts Inclusion Act, which provides for the purchase of art for public spaces in state government buildings.
Since joining the council in 1982, he has coordinated more than 50 projects that are enlivening the plazas, lobbies and grounds of new and renovated structures built by the state.

LEAD: To the editor: My wife and I love snorkeling and skin diving but a series of hip replacement operations has made climbing ladders into dive boats a real struggle for her, especially in choppy water.

A NEW LOOK AT WHAT'S IN A NAME
LEAD: Words like Romanticism, Classicism and Serialism, the common coin of musical commentary, can become so worn from continual handling that they lose all value.
They take on a mystical fogginess, emphasized by Germanic capitalization, that makes them impressively abstract but worthless as tools for thought.

LEAD: THREE distinct facets of the world of American glass, past and present, are on exhibit here at the Hudson River Museum. ''Persians,'' a series of sculptural blown-glass assemblages by Dale Chihuly, a leading artist in his field, is the dramatic centerpiece of three shows that will run through March 18.

Barry, who entered a drug and alcohol clinic in Florida last month after his arrest on cocaine possession charges, was indicted last week on five misdemeanor drug charges and three felony counts of perjury.

Pastimes;   Stamps
LEAD: On Feb. 20, 1962, at 3:30 P.M.
Eastern Standard Time, John Glenn became the first American to orbit Earth.
At the same hour on the same day, the United States released a stamp that had been designed and printed in secret and distributed to 305 post offices.


In China, Loving Lady Chatterley
LEAD: For the better part of 25 years, I felt discontented with teaching in America.
This is not a country that reads much, or believes that the little it is required to read has anything to do with the world of banks, cars and missile silos.
We are practical to a fault, clean mental machines, so Thoreau, Whitman and Mark Twain go in one ear and pass out the other, frequently without impediment, loss of speed or any notable effect.


The Selling of Western Water Rights
LEAD: Last September, the City Council of Aurora, Colo., approved a $1.25 million purchase of agricultural water rights in the South Platte river basin.
Eager to secure more water for its rapidly growing population, this municipality east of Denver joined numerous others throughout the West by turning to what it sees as the only vast pool remaining: irrigation water.


Style Makers;   Berdie Stein, Frame Designer
LEAD: An almost universal reaction to ''My Frame,'' which was conceived by Berdie Stein, is ''How come no one thought of it before?'' But no one did and that's why children's art was, until last year, usually stuck on refrigerator doors or taped on walls.
And that's how the company ''My Art'' was born.

LEAD: Nepal has put the police and the military on alert and detained hundreds of people in an effort to crush plans to begin a pro-democracy campaign on Sunday.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump's marriage is not the only one of his important relationships that is not working out these days.
His rapport with the ''junk bond'' market - whose contribution to his success arguably approaches that of his estranged wife, Ivana - has become equally rocky.

LEAD: Dominance isn't given up very easily at the Daytona 500.
Like a driver in the 10-car conga lines that roll down the backstretch in a bumper-to-bumper draft, if you want to cut in near the front, you could be bucking the turbulence a long time.

LEAD: IT IS MIDAFTERNOON IN A SLEEK ANNEX TO the Sony Corporation's headquarters in Tokyo, and Norio Ohga and Michael P. (Mickey) Schulhof are sitting in a plush screening room reserved for the company's top executives.
For weeks, Sony's engineers have been trying to get this unlikely team - a former opera singer who is Sony's president and chief executive, and a former physicist who is vice chairman of the Sony Corporation of America - on the same continent at the same time.

The recent grand opening of Sebastiano's represents an imperceptible change.

Business Diary: February 11-16
LEAD:
COMPANIES
Drexel: Driven From the Market It Created
Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday amid ironies heaped as high as its clients' - and now its own -debts.
The brokerage house has been driven from a ''junk bond'' market it created.
A firm whose executives insisted they were investing in America, not just making quick profits, failed in part because they put too little money in the business and took too much out for themselves, bankruptcy filings indicate.


A May Wedding For Miss D'Amico
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
John F. D'Amico of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Jean D'Amico to T. Kendrick Sharp Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Sharp of Atlanta and Asheville, N.C.
A May wedding is planned.


Salvadoran Military Accepts Responsibility for Bombing
LEAD: El Salvador's military accepted responsibility today for the bombing of a refugee site last Sunday that killed at least five civilians.

LEAD: The young soprano Angelina Reaux, like her obvious role model Teresa Stratas, is a singer with unusually strong dramatic instincts and the will to transcend the image of opera singer as a delicate hothouse flower.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Up-to-the-Minute Scores From the Revolution in the East Bloc
LEAD: THE SPRING OF 1990 holds the promise of momentous transformations as the nations of Eastern Europe hold elections in their quest for democracy, and as a disengaged Soviet Union strives to forge ahead with change amid an explosion of internal conflicts.
Marc D. Charney and Anne Zusy of The Week in Review compiled a country-by-country look at where things stand in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.


The Sahara
LEAD: To the Editor: I seriously question the propriety of featuring the article by Erik Sandberg-Diment (''Across the Sahara by Car,'' Dec. 31).
As adults, the Sandberg-Diments have every right to risk their lives by traveling through that unpredictable and hostile environment.
I am appalled, however, that they were accompanied by their children, especially a 7-year-old.


Dining: ON THEIR OWN
LEAD: The designer Bill Blass perks up when the subject comes up.
A popular man about town wherever he is, Blass dreams of dining alone. ''In New York, it would be in bed; in the country, on a card table set in front of the fire,'' he muses. ''If it's diet, it would be Lean Cuisine.
Indulgence?'' - a big smile here - ''Ben &amp; Jerry's ice cream!

LEAD: LOMBOK.
It sounds like a planet on ''Star Trek.'' The island is not really in outer space, but, as I showed my son on the globe, it was literally on the other side of the world, some 10,000 miles away in Indonesia.

LEAD: AT a dollar a pound, which is what it is selling for in Chinatown these days, squid must be the cheapest seafood you can buy.
It is also extremely nutritious, being low in fat and calories and high in protein.

LEAD: Dramatic changes in medical practice have shattered the profession, leaving many doctors deeply demoralized.

Marinas Yield Unpaid Taxes
LEAD: STATE revenue agents billed 328 boat owners more than $400,000 in unpaid state taxes after a sweep of marinas along Long Island Sound, the State Department of Revenue Services said last week.

Turning Left or Right? Please Use the Signal
LEAD: I applaud Irving Kamil's article dealing with drivers who fail to use directional signals (''Turning Without Telling,'' Opinion page, Jan. 7).
While our area is so much better than California in this regard, one can't help but be appalled by the lack of courtesy this shows.


Organizer Bans Liquor At Antidrug Fund Raiser
LEAD: PEOPLE don't need liquor to have a good time.
That is the message of an alcohol-free dinner dance scheduled for March 3 in Shelton.

LEAD: The owners are wallowing in jillions in profits but are unsatisfied and want another jillion or three, and they are unwilling to share even a fraction of a jillion more with the players - when it is to see the players that we pay our contributions to those huge profits.
MARGERY REIFLER DUNN $


Outdoors;   Hookless Lures Still Catch Notice
LEAD: Once recognized only by those who collected, studied or actually made or used them, fish decoys - lures without hooks - are swimming into public view.


Europe's Grand Classics of Skiing;   In a French Vale, A Pair of Towns Keep Traditions
LEAD: PERHAPS the biggest attraction for American skiers in the Alps is that generally the resorts there - unlike the Northeast and the Rockies - were not created for skiing.
They are essentially villages that were always there, amid magnificent mountain terrain on which winter sports were easily grafted.


Crack Addiction Is Forcing Prostitutes Onto the Streets
LEAD: YOUNG, old, black, white or Hispanic, Long Island's new types of prostitutes share several common bonds.
They are almost all addicted to crack; they are for the most part freelance entrepreneurs who work without pimps, and they are part of what is believed to be the greatest number of women ever to ply the sex trade on the


WHAT'S DOING IN: Orlando
LEAD: If Orlando had not existed before Walt Disney World, those who built the central Florida entertainment empire would probably have had to invent the city.
With 32,000 workers and more than 23 million annual visitors, Disney World relies on Orlando and surrounding communities to house its employees and administer the airport that is the gateway to its three theme parks: the Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center and Disney-MGM


CAN HE SAVE THE ELEPHANTS?
LEAD: Thank God for a brilliant, violent bruiser like Richard Leakey, who stands squarely on the side of the animals and fairness (''Can He Save the Elephants?'' by Jane Perlez, Jan. 7).
I heard him speak at the Explorers Annual Dinner and at the Friends of Conservation fund-raising luncheon last year.
His approach is so blunt and unforgiving and determined that he may serve as the catalyst for many who are anguished over the destruction of elephants and rhinos but feel helpless.


POSTINGS: West Side Landmark;   Rebuilding a Stable
LEAD: The Claremont Riding Academy, a fixture on the Upper West Side for nearly a century - it stables 100 horses and serves almost 50,000 riders a year - has been rescued from the knacker and will undergo an extensive rehabilitation with the help of the city's Industrial Development Agency.

Review/Theater;   Management-Labor Conflict, in 'Special Interests'
LEAD: It's been more than 50 years since plays dedicated to the glory of the labor movement flourished.

LEAD: A year ago, Winnie Mandela was held in disgrace by the anti-apartheid movement for condoning what was widely described as bullying and brutality by her young bodyguards.

Correction
LEAD: The Fast Forward column last Sunday misidentified the winner of the 1941 Academy Award for best supporting actress.
She was Mary Astor.


In Pupil 'Tracks,' Many See a Means Of Resegregation
LEAD: THE battles over voting rights, school integration and public accommodations have long been more or less settled, but some blacks in the South say they now face subtler forms of discrimination.
In education, they say, it shows up in public school ''tracking'' systems, and the issue was at the heart of black protests here last week.


Hanging Wall Cabinets
LEAD: HANGING wall cabinets, even an individual cabinet, can be a tricky task for amateurs.
But by planning the job beforehand, using the proper tools and fasteners and having at least one helper, a good job can be done without too much trouble.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:
THE MAN WHO TRIED TO BURN NEW YORK, by Nat Brandt. (Berkley, $3.95.) In one of the more obscure incidents of the Civil War, a band of renegade Confederate soldiers tried to burn New York City in retaliation for what General Sherman did to Atlanta.
In 1986 our reviewer, Patrick Clinton, said Nat Brandt's rendition of the trial of one of the conspirators ''is full of surprising perplexities, and the descriptions of his gradual descent into drunkenness and despair and of his death as the last Confederate to be hanged for spying are memorable reading.


Mongolia to Remove Its Last Stalin Statue
LEAD: Mongolia's Communist Government has decided to remove the last statue of Stalin from the capital, signaling another concession to democratic demands, an official newspaper said today.


Triumph Opened Doors
LEAD: THE so-called miracle victory of the 1980 United States Olympic hockey team at Lake Placid wound up being, quite literally, an icebreaker in terms of the sport's visibility at home and the new stature American hockey attained with the National Hockey League.
Suddenly hockey gained viability as a career for aspiring athletes who might otherwise have looked to other sports as their launching pads.


Cope Takes Flag at Daytona
LEAD: Derrike Cope got into stock-car racing when his baseball career ended with what he called a complete blowout of his right knee.
Another blowout today, this one in Dale Earnhardt's right rear tire with about a mile to go, gave Cope the victory in the Daytona 500, the sport's biggest race.

William C.W. James, Lawyer, 70
LEAD: William C. W. James, a former board chairman of the Salmagundi Club, the oldest professional artists' club in the United States, died Saturday in Fishguard, Wales, where he had retired in 1987 after working in New York.
He was 70 years old.


FLORENCE MAMOU MARRIES
LEAD: Florence Mamou, a student at New York University, was married yesterday in Paris to Jean Madar, the founder and president of Jean Philippe Fragrances, a cosmetics and perfume company in New York City.
Rabbi Alan Goldman, the Chief Rabbi of Paris, performed the ceremony at Temple Rue de la Victoire.


Merger Worries Utilities in New England
LEAD: A likely merger between New England's largest electric utility and the New Hampshire power company that built the Seabrook nuclear plant is troubling the utility industry in the region.

Prices Fall in Tea Glut
LEAD: The price of tea has fallen to its lowest level in more than five months because a glut of poor-quality tea has swamped the market, traders said last week.
But they said the fall could be short-lived, because better teas are expected soon at London's tea auction and world consumption is expected to remain strong, particularly in India.


8 Fraternities and Sororities Announce an End to Hazing
LEAD: Leaders of eight national black fraternities and sororities announced an agreement on Saturday to eliminate hazing by banning the pledging process.


Couple Is Acquitted in Death Of Son in Religious Healing
LEAD: A Christian Scientist couple who tried to heal their ailing 15-month-old son through prayer instead of medical care, have been acquitted on charges of involuntary manslaughter and child endangerment.

China Acts to Reduce Economic Discontent
LEAD: Apparently alarmed that economic difficulties might touch off unrest, China's leaders have considerably eased economic controls and returned in part to the economic policies that preceded the violent crackdown last June, Chinese officials and foreign diplomats say.

LEAD: A member of the Lithuanian Communist Party's ruling politburo predicted today that the republic would pull out of the Soviet Union this year.

Soviet Visitors Tour Space Center As It Readies Spy Satellite Mission
LEAD: Soviet lawmakers toured the Kennedy Space Center today as the space agency readied the shuttle Atlantis for launching with a secret satellite that will reportedly spy on the Soviet Union.


Crimes of Hate
LEAD: Add Mr. and Mrs.
Wilfred Phillip and James Zappalorti to the list of bias-crime victims in New York.
The Phillips, a black couple, recently bought a house in a predominantly white Brooklyn neighborhood.
A week later, the house burned in what investigators say was a case of racially motivated arson.


Wanderkin Wins With Late Charge
LEAD: Wanderkin, the 7-year-old New York-bred gelding who had been looking past his prime lately, scored his first stakes victory in 16 months when he ran down Iron Courage to win the $100,000 Fort Lauderdale Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

LEAD: The police battled with thousands of students and political militants demonstrating for democracy in central Katmandu today, and at least four people were killed in clashes in the Nepalese countryside.

Estimate of Cancer Peril In Air Travel Is Raised
LEAD: The risk of fatal cancer from radiation in airliners is 17 times greater than reported last week in a Government study, the Department of Transportation has acknowledged after other scientists found errors.

LEAD: When the makers of Very Fine juice went looking for a new advertising agency last fall, the company put together a list of six top Madison Avenue names and one agency that some of the contenders had never heard of: Mullen Advertising.


Party Is On; Town Isn't Invited
LEAD: A party to celebrate the incorporation of this suburb of about 58,000 between Seattle and Tacoma will be held outside the municipal boundaries, embarrassed organizers have learned.
Only after arranging the party for Feb. 28 at a bowling alley did planners learn it was not in the town as approved by voters a year ago.

Ethiopia's P.O.W.'s
In the last year, rebels have seized about 55,000 prisoners in Ethiopia's long civil war.

LEAD: Sky Television, Rupert Murdoch's satellite programming service in Britain, had operating losses of about $129 million in its first year.

Options in Cross-Country Gear
LEAD: SIMPLICITY.
Cross-country skiing's astonishing growth has sent old-time downhill skiers back into the woods and has introduced the joys of winter to neophytes because it is a simple sport.
Devotees have been telling everyone that if you can walk, you can cross-country ski.

LEAD: rrA tennis player who was annoyed that his eyeglasses slipped during play has designed a strapless device to hold eyewear in place.


Review/Television;   In 'Montana,' Big Sky Upstages Ranchers
LEAD: An old saw about failed Broadway musicals warns that the score is crucial because you can't hum the scenery.
Larry McMurtry's ''Montana'' runs into a similar problem.
The made-for-cable movie, being shown on Ted Turner's TNT tonight at 8 and 10, was filmed largely in Bozeman, Mont., and is filled with some splendid vistas of Big Sky country.


Mongolian Protesters Demand That New Party's Congress Be Televised Delegates adopted a charter that urges changes in Mongolia's political and economic systems and an end to the Communist power monopoly, but pledges to work within the Constitution, a source said. (Reuters)

LEAD: Twenty years ago this month, New York City imposed its paradigmatic consumer protection law.
Bess Myerson was consumer affairs commissioner then, followed briefly by Betty Furness.
Those were the golden days of the consumer movement.

LEAD: Using a borrowed computer and working out of the study of his house on Chicago's North Side, Gabriel Nicolescou this week finished the second issue of Democratic Romania, a 12-page newsletter that carries translations of American news reports on Romania.

Bidding for the Best and the Poorest
LEAD: Do major colleges and universities conspire to set the price of tuition and financial aid?
The Justice Department's antitrust division has been exploring that question for months, looking at the practices of about 60 institutions.

Washington's Birthday Today
LEAD:
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Government offices: Closed.
Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only.
Service at main post office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Closed.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation: No pickup, recycling collection or street cleaning.

In Pretoria: Last Throes of Marxism?
LEAD: The winds of change battering Marxism around the world have hit the South African Communist Party, which has endured by making itself synonymous in many blacks' minds with the struggle of the majority to free itself of domination by the nation's white minority.

LEAD: Virginia F. Coleman, a partner in the law firm of Ropes &amp; Grayin Boston, was married there yesterday to Mervin M. Wilf, who is of counsel to the Boston law firm of Hale &amp; Dorr.
Rabbi Beverly Lerner officiated at the Harvard Club, assisted by the Rev.
Margaret Gunness, an Episcopal priest.
The bride, 45 years old, is keeping her name.


Sihanouk to See Cambodian Premier
LEAD: Prime Minister Hun Sen plans to meet this month with Prince Norodom Sihanouk and renew a proposal that the Prince break with the Khmer Rouge guerrillas and return to Cambodia as the country's President and Commander in Chief, Cambodian officials said today.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp misidentified the news agency providing the report.
It was Reuters, not The Associated Press.


How Johnson Controls Guarded Its Big Secret
LEAD: After a secretive campaign to throw its leading competitor off track, Johnson Controls Inc. has introduced what it maintains is the next generation of computerized systems to control heating, security and other functions in buildings.


Missouri Eyeing No. 1 Again
LEAD: Doug Smith scored 23 points, including the winning 3-point play with 40 seconds left, as Missouri held off Oklahoma, 92-90, today and put itself in position to regain the No. 1 ranking in the Associated Press poll.


Chronicle
LEAD: With no sign of jet lag, MARY McFADDEN was back in her office after her seventh trip to India in three years.
She is designing the costumes for ''Zooni,'' an Indian epic that chronicles the fall of Kashmir in the 16th century, to the Mogul Empire.

the Roman Catholic Bishop
of Londonderry.

Colorado Meet Lures Disabled Skiers
LEAD: KIRK PARKHURST sits in a custom-molded plastic seat, with a suspension system of springs and shock absorbers attached to a single ski under him.
With his arms, Parkhurst holds short poles with outrigger skis on the ends.
He wears a crash helmet to protect his head as he races at speeds up to 60 miles an hour.


Reviews/Music;   Quartet Offers an Account Of a Schubert Rarity
LEAD: Prosperity is often the artistic undoing of small chamber ensembles.
The ability to fill increasing numbers of seats places them in halls that maximize income while dwarfing the original intentions of chamber music.
Music by the few for the many seldom works.


Sharon Resigns From Israeli Government, Vowing to Run for Prime Minister


Reviews/Music;   Up From the Delta, Blues And Its Home-Grown Roots
LEAD: Friday night's Mississippi blues show at the Triplex Theater, presented by the World Music Institute, might as well have been a seminar on how music adapts to the changing world.
Otha Turner opened the concert playing a reed fife that probably sounded just fine on the west coast of Africa a few centuries ago; he sang Little Walter's ''My Babe,'' a Chicago blues tune from the mid-1950's, and played a hymn.

The Startling Spring of 1990
LEAD: It has been a long winter indeed since Soviet tanks crushed Prague Spring in 1968.
Now, throughout Eastern Europe, from the Urals to the Elbe and from the Black Sea to the Baltic, elections are promised early this year.
With independent, democratic and reform parties blossoming, that means an astonishing 144 million people will realize a once-impossible dream.

Some Point to Massachusetts as Extreme of Regulation
LEAD: In 49 states, grumbling private doctors are consoled by the fact that the regulation could be worse: they could be practicing in Massachusetts.
In the name of controlling costs and improving access to medical care, that state has led the nation in enacting strict laws to govern doctors' practices and limit their fees.

LEAD: A kind word is in order on President's Day for those white Anglo-Saxon Protestants known as the Founding Fathers.

Indeed, the word ''debunk'' was first employed by W.

LEAD: New York City, which is having trouble moving homeless families out of welfare hotels, may be unable to fulfill a pledge to stop using the hotels by June, municipal officials say.

Bridge
LEAD: One unusual development in national championships in recent years has been the growth of morning knockout team games.
Many players, particularly those who have traveled considerable distances to attend, are eager to play serious bridge for 10 hours a day instead of the usual seven.
And the morning knockout gives them what they want.

Argentina to Cut Taxes
LEAD: In an attempt to forestall frantic price markups as Argentina experiences its second bout of hyperinflation in seven months, the Peronist Government announced measures today to curtail state spending and cut taxes on imported food.
Among other measures, Economy Minister Antonio Erman Gonzalez said President Carlos Saul Menem's salary would be cut 20 percent and set as the top wage for Federal employees.

Golf

Gasoline Spills in Barge Crash
LEAD: A barge loaded with 30,000 barrels of gasoline caught fire when it collided with another barge in the Intracoastal Waterway, the Coast Guard said today.
No one was injured and the fire was extinguished late Sunday night, a Coast Guard spokesman said.
The waterway was closed as a precaution because of an undetermined amount of gasoline in the water and the possibility of further fire.

Oil Rig Count Increases
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs increased for the first time this year when it rose by 19 rigs last week to 918, officials of Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The firm said the number of working rigs was well above the 766 recorded at this time last year.
In the previous week, the rig count dropped by 32, to 899, after several weeks of decline.

Bulls Hold Off the Rockets

Houston had a chance to tie the score with a 3-point field goal with 14 seconds left, but Buck Johnson's shot went off the rim.(AP)

Review/Television;   Children of a Previous War
LEAD: ''No Father, No Mother, No Uncle Sam'' describes the children born of black American soldiers and white British mothers during World War II.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Sunrise, Sunset
Q. How are the times of sunset and sunrise determined?
A.
Sunset and sunrise have exactly the same definition: the time when the apparent uppermost ray of the Sun is on the astronomical horizon.
If it is the first ray, it is sunrise and if it is the last ray, it is sunset.


Study Hints Of Harm In Heart Operations
LEAD: PRELIMINARY results of an international study show that coronary bypass surgery produces subtle, long-lasting impairment of mental performance in nearly one in five people who undergo the operation, researchers say.

Scientists Report Producing Genetically Engineered Trees
LEAD: Scientists reported today that they had developed the world's first genetically engineered trees: poplars designed to be grown on large plantations for energy production.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: BLACK sea bass is one of my favorite local fishes.
The plump little fellows with semifirm, mild-flavored white flesh usually range from 1 1/2 to 3 pounds but have been seen as big as 5 pounds.
According to historical accounts, sea bass were so prolific around New York Harbor in the first half of the 19th century that commercial fishermen rarely had to venture beyond Sandy Hook, N.J., for their daily catch.

Underdogs, Favorites and California
LEAD: Repeatedly, California's Presidential primary has been secondary.
The state contains 1 of every 10 Americans and yet, time after time, the race for one party's nomination or the other has been settled before the first Tuesday in June, when California voters cast their primary ballots.


Weary Of J.F.K.? This Field Hopes So
LEAD: Bradley International Airport, New England's perpetual No. 2 airfield after Logan International in Boston, has never escaped the fact that for most travelers Connecticut is a place to be flown over and looked down upon on the way to somewhere else.


$250 Million Issue From G.E. Credit
LEAD: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering $250 million in 8.70 percnt notes due 2003 through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.


Platinum and Copper Rise On Concern About Supply
LEAD: Platinum futures prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting strong demand for the metal amid uncertainty about inflation, stock prices and South Africa.


Teams Scramble for Home Ice
LEAD: College hockey's regular-season schedules end this weekend in three of the four Division I leagues, and the teams will be scrambling for final positions that determine playoff sites.
Since home teams win two-thirds of the time in playoffs, there is reason to scramble.


Officials Say Revising U.S. Clean Air Law Would Weaken It
LEAD: The New York City region's air will remain unhealthy if changes in the Clean Air Act under discussion by the White House and the Senate become law, government officials in the Northeast and private environmental groups contend.


Industry's Growing Romance With Diamonds
LEAD: Materials scientists are making rapid progress in simplifying the arduous task of manufacturing diamonds.
As a result, diamond coatings could become commonplace in the 1990's on everything from industrial drills to scratch-resistant sunglasses and, perhaps as soon as the end of the decade, in a range of high-performance microchips.


Soviet Legislators Urge A Tight Grip on Rallies
LEAD: The Soviet Parliament urged a crackdown today on illegal demonstrations scheduled for Sunday and said the authorities should tightly control legal rallies, the Tass press agency said.


'Great to Be a Bishop': Thomas Vose Daily
LEAD: When it came time for Bishop Thomas V. Daily to sum up the spirit he hopes will guide his actions as the newly appointed leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, he reached into his pocket and pulled out the familiar prayer attributed to St.
Francis of Assisi, ''Lord, make me an instrument of your peace.

Ms.
Zahn has left her job as a co-anchor of ''World News This Morning'' on ABC-TV, which she joined in


Supreme Court Roundup;   Justices Limit Parent's Rights in Child Abuse Case
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that a parent who is under a court's supervision for previously abusing a child must obey a court order to produce the child or disclose his whereabouts, even if the disclosure is incriminating.


Bernard C. Kovach, Executive, 55
LEAD: Bernard C. Kovach, president and chief executive officer of Bill Communications, publishers of business magazines, died of a heart attack on Saturday while vacationing with his family in Plymouth, Vt.
He was 55 years old and lived in Plandome, L.I.


Freshman Steps In and Seton Hall Snaps Losing Streak
LEAD: Marco Lokar of Seton Hall sank more field goals in the game against Pittsburgh tonight than he had made all season.
He almost scored more points as well.


Court Warns Buyers Of Child Sex Items
LEAD: People who buy child pornography magazines and videotapes in New York State are breaking the law, the state's highest court warned today.

LEAD: The new head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, Bishop Thomas V. Daily, said yesterday that he would bar Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo from speaking in parishes in the diocese because of the Governor's support for abortion rights.

LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo and the Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Mel Miller, were at a reception last December, doing what politicians usually do at such events -gossiping about other politicians.

LEAD: Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company, the Wall Street securities firm, took a big step toward increasing its investment banking presence in Tokyo yesterday, announcing that it had recruited Ken Saito, a top deal maker at Sumitomo Bank, to head its mergers and acquisitions department in Japan.

LEAD: The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday in moderate trading, as the British pound took center stage, reaching a 10-month high against the dollar in the United States and abroad.

Brazil's Cooling Alternative To All That Coffee? Fruit Juice
LEAD: Both the tempo and temperature are feverish here with the approach of Carnaval on Feb. 24.
Ninety-degree evenings are charged with the beat of dancing feet and drums tapping out this year's samba routines and rhythms.
By day, the beaches are flowered with gaily hued umbrellas, towels, surfers, students and tourists.

At the Nation's Table
LEAD: IT emerges from the oven with its syrupy batter of cinnamon, sugar and egg white dripping over the side of the plate.
It is dense, more like a German coffee cake than a traditional pancake.
And it is anything but flat, rising six inches or so above the base of the frying pan in which it is baked.

LEAD: The Soviet Union's primary intelligence service, the K.G.B., has not slackened its espionage and other actions against the United States under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but it has become less ''blatant and flat-footed'' at what it does, the senior American intelligence official said today.

Mr.
Hoving died on Nov. 27 at the age of 91.

LEAD: The Governor of Puerto Rico today announced a plan to sell the Government-owned telephone company and use the proceeds to create two ''perpetual funds'' of $1 billion each, one for secondary education and the other to improve the island's public services like its drinking water and sewage systems.

Bank Unit to Martin
LEAD: The Martin Agency, which won the Banc One Corporation account in December, picked up the account of the Columbus, Ohio, holding company's Texas operation, Bank One Texas N.A., on Friday.

Japan's Lead in Computer Research Grows
LEAD: In a sprawling laboratory complex here, Japanese researchers are working on an ambitious program that demonstrates how - and how quickly - Japan is widening its lead over the United States in certain crucial fields of electronics technology.
It also underlines the contrast in the way the two nations are pursuing a promising but costly frontier of industrial expertise.

Shell From Israeli Zone Kills 2 in Lebanon
LEAD: Two Nepalese soldiers serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon have been killed and six wounded by an artillery shell just north of the Israeli-designated security zone in southern Lebanon, officials of the force said today.

LEAD: An East German newspaper published an unusual interview today with the chief rabbi of Moscow, in which he expressed fears about rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union.


Waltrip Makes History
LEAD: Although he finished only 14th in the Daytona 500, the race at the Daytona International Speedway was an important benchmark for Darrel Waltrip.
Waltrip, a 43-year-old native of Franklin, Tenn., who is a three-time Winston Cup champion, earned $49,340 and that total was enough to make him the first man in motor sports history to surpass $10 million in career winnings, with a total of $10,036,481.

LEAD: The United States said today that Israeli soldiers continued to violate the rights of Palestinians in the occupied territories, causing ''avoidable deaths and injuries.'' He was 73 years old and lived in Cambridge.

No Sun in Lebanon
LEAD: New thinking opens long-shuttered windows elsewhere.
Peace is proclaimed in Europe.
Not in cheerless Lebanon.
The doleful headlines speak only of continued killing.
In East Beirut, two Christian armies have been fighting house to house, room to room, with no quarter given.
More than 500 lie dead, 2,000 are wounded, and once-pleasant neighborhoods are in ruins.


Employment Agency Accused of Bias
LEAD: New York State and City officials yesterday accused a major employment agency of discriminating against black applicants and people regarded as too old.


Nicaragua: The Sour-Grapes Brigade
LEAD: Implacable critics of the Sandinista Government are crying foul about next Sunday's elections in Nicaragua.
In the face of overwhelming, credible evidence that the campaign has been conducted fairly, their complaints sound suspiciously like efforts to discredit in advance an imminent Sandinista victory at the polls.

LEAD: A New York City Councilman, contending that David N. Dinkins is entitled to some privileges as mayor of the nation's largest city, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to permit the Mayor to fly first class at city expense, which current rules prohibit.

LEAD: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and the dominant force in economic policy making, told Congress today that the economy's ''weakest point may have passed'' and that the nation could expect ''moderate economic expansion'' this year.


Food Notes
LEAD: Knowing Nutrition A Gallup survey on diet and health has found that most Americans have a good idea about sensible eating.
Ninety-five percent said balance, moderation and variety were the keys to healthy eating, and 77 percent were familiar with the four basic food groups.

The Real Point of Barry's 'Sting'
LEAD: The indictment of the District of Columbia Mayor, Marion Barry, on perjury and drug charges may signal a new and controversial use for the oldest of ''stings.'' Since the lords of the Philistines directed Delilah to entice Samson so that they could ''prevail against him,'' beautiful women have been used to lure vulnerable men into sin, crime and corruption.

LEAD: There is convincing evidence that some species of frogs, toads and salamanders are rapidly declining in many parts of the world, a panel of experts concluded today.

Culture Chief Asks Use of Drug Plan Funds
LEAD: New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs proposed yesterday that all government money used for drug education in the city be given to her department for cultural and recreational programs for schoolchildren.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about New York City's labor negotiations misidentified a segment of the membership of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Local 237 negotiates on behalf of horseshoers, not blacksmiths.
Blacksmiths are represented by Local 5 of the International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sunday about AIDS in the Middle East misidentified the head of the World Health Organization's AIDS program.
He is Dr.
Jonathan Mann.


Wightman Cup Stopped
LEAD: The Wightman Cup, born in an age when British tennis was the world's best and American women were just learning to play the game, was pushed aside today, the victim of a decade of United States dominance.

LEAD: Coach Steve Tosches of Princeton last night received the Scotty M. Whitelaw Trophy as the Division I-AA coach of the year in the East.
Tosches, whose Tigers last season shared the Ivy League championship with Yale, has compiled a 19-10-1 record (14-7 in the Ivy League) over the last three seasons.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev conceded today that the two Germanys had a right to unity but stressed the Soviet Union's own ''inalienable right'' to insure that reunification does not lead to ''moral, political or economic damage'' for the Soviet Union.


Holyfield Spurns Deal
LEAD: Evander Holyfield yesterday turned down a $40 million, three-fight deal offered by Steve Wynn, owner of the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.
James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, and Holyfield, the No. 1 contender, have agreed to a title fight this year.
The package offered by Wynn included fights with George Foreman and Mike Tyson.

Miners' Contract Highlights
LEAD: United Mine Workers' summary of the contract they approved.
The U.M.W. has been on strike since April 5 in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky against the Pittston Coal Group.
Terms: Four years.
Wages: Top scale of $17.52 an hour in selected positions, a raise of $1.20 an hour.
Health benefits: 100 percent medical coverage for employees, pensioners and their families.


Britain, in Split With Europe, Eases Pretoria Ban
LEAD: Britain broke ranks with the other members of the European Community today and ended its ban on new investments in South Africa.


Interpublic Net Increases 17.6%
LEAD: The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday reported net income for the fourth quarter of 1989 of $27.4 million, or 81 cents a share, up 17.6 percent from $23.3 million, or 70 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1988.
Revenue rose 2.4 percent, to $380 million from $371.1 million.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas rose by 19, to 918, for the week ended today, Baker Hughes Inc. said.
The Houston oilfield services company said there were 766 operating rigs a year ago.
The weekly count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil and gas.

Lessons
LEAD: From the one-room schoolhouse to the monumental high schools that began to appear at the turn of the century, school architecture has signaled the way Americans think about education.


Expanded Review of Pentagon Cuts Planned
LEAD: The Bush Administration plans to expand a review of possible Pentagon cuts to include up to 12 expensive weapons systems, including two nuclear missiles, because of reduced Soviet-American tensions, a senior Defense Department official said today.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD: THe place was the women's locker room at the 92d Street Y where Soozy Goldfarb overheard two women discussing the Pan Am Building. ''Where is it?'' the first woman asked.
The second woman gave her the address. ''What does the building look like?'' ''It's mostly glass and metal,'' the second woman replied.


DEALS


Judge Is Asked to Delay Reagan Tape
LEAD: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter today asked a Federal judge to postpone the release of former President Ronald Reagan's videotaped testimony until after a jury is selected for the Iran-contra trial of the former national security adviser.


Japan's Status Quo;   Economic Interests Stifle the Outrage In the Electorate Caused by Scandals
LEAD: In the last year, Japan has experienced the downfall of two Prime Ministers, widespread outrage over the official and after-hours behavior of politicians, protests by women and other events suggesting that this most stable of nations was on the verge of great political change.


Toppling of Tyson: More Fallout
LEAD: James (Buster) Douglas's 10th-round knockout of Mike Tyson in Japan shocked the public and caught the boxing establishment off guard.
How unprepared for the Douglas era were the major-domos of the sport?


CHRONICLE
LEAD: Since his presidential campaign sank in scandal in 1987, GARY HART has been quietly practicing law in Denver.
Now he is writing a book about the Soviet Union, and he said yesterday he has had access to ''the entire leadership except Mr.
Gorbachev.'' He leaves today for Moscow, where he has been traveling nearly every month, 10 days each trip, for a year.


Sheeb Journal;   Africa's 30 Years' War: A Rebel Scouts for Allies
LEAD: Isaias Afwerki, a tall 44-year-old guerrilla dressed in jeans who has long commanded the rebels of Africa's longest war from stone bunkers shrouded in gray thorn trees, has recently emerged into the international world of well-tailored suits and burnished dining rooms.


Market Place;   Split Opinions On Global Marine
LEAD: TO judge by the stock market, there is life after bankruptcy for Global Marine Inc., the oil driller that came out of Chapter 11 proceedings less than a year ago.


WIDOW IN VERMONT WON'T LOSE HOUSE
LEAD: A negligence suit that had threatened an elderly widow with the loss of her home and life savings was settled out of court today, sparing the woman's possessions.


Brewers Sign Yount: $9.6 Million for 3 Years
LEAD: Robin Yount, the American League most valuable player last season, has finally agreed to terms with the Milwaukee Brewers on a three-year contract that will pay him $9.6 million.
The team announced in December that Yount had agreed to a contract but details were not complete.

A2-12
Germans have a ''right to unity,'' President Gorbachev conceded.
But he insisted that Moscow has the right to insure that reunification does not threaten the Soviet Union morally, politically or economically.

Helmut Kohl visited East Germany, plunging into the intense political campaign for East German elections now less than four weeks away.

LEAD: Cryptoclearance, the popular 6-year-old who has earned more than $3 million, and Summer Squall, one of the early Kentucky Derby favorites, both suffered ailments after recent morning workouts at Gulfstream Park, their trainers said today.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
COMPANIES
Drexel Burnham Lambert paid bonuses totaling hundreds of millions of dollars to executives shortly before its parent filed for bankruptcy, Wall Street executives said. [Page A1.]
First Boston has arranged to get money from several affiliates by selling some bridge loans.
Company executives said the move was intended to provide greater liquidity.


Book Notes
LEAD: Weidenfeld Galaxy Losses and disappointing sales led Ann Getty and George Weidenfeld to merge Weidenfeld &amp; Nicolson and Grove Press into a single house last year, and rumors still crop up that the merged house - Grove Weidenfeld - will be shut down.
But those rumors now surface much less often, and in the meantime the house has been signing important authors and selling reprint rights for respectable money.

Profit Reported By Honeywell
LEAD: Honeywell Inc. reported fourth-quarter net income today of $392 million, or $9.26 a share, on sales of $1.6 billion.
That was in contrast to a loss of $483 million in the period a year earlier, when sales totaled $1.58 billion.


Chevron Cut May Total 1,000 Jobs
LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said today that it would trim up to 1,000 jobs this year, or 12 percent of the payroll of its domestic exploration and production unit.
The oil giant also said it would sell more than $700 million worth of its domestic properties in the next two years.


For Philadelphians, New Way to Shop
LEAD: When a fancy new wine store opened here recently, it struck some Pennsylvanians as an event on the magnitude of the dismantling of the Berlin Wall.


Smoking's Cost to Society Is $52 Billion a Year, Federal Study Says
LEAD: Federal officials estimated today that that cigarette smoking costs the nation $52 billion in health expenses or time lost from work, about $221 per person, each year.


Eating Well
LEAD: ON the way to a slimmer self, most dieters reach a plateau where despite continued effort, extra pounds refuse to budge.


Henry X. O'Brien, Retired Justice, 86
LEAD: Henry X. O'Brien, former Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, died of cancer Saturday.
He was 86 years old. , Justice O'Brien served on the State Supreme Court for 21 years after 14 years as a trial judge in Allegheny County and five years as an Allegheny County assistant district attorney.

Report Blames Subway Bosses In Track Death
LEAD: A subway track worker was killed last November because his superiors failed to tell him that trains using the track that day would be going in both directions, and because no ''Insufficient Clearance'' signs had been posted, a New York State Labor Department investigator has concluded.

Review/Photography;   A Texas-Sized Show to Boggle the Eye
LEAD: It is a sight to make sore eyes: Houston's George R. Brown Convention Center filled with row upon row of photographs, some 3,500 in all.
There are 27 exhibitions in the hall, mounted on temporary Styrofoam walls.
Elsewhere, in museums, galleries and other exhibition spaces throughout the city, 60 more shows await photography enthusiasts.

Volkswagen Campaign
LEAD: Rolling Stone magazine has lent its ''Perception/Reality'' advertising campaign to Volkswagen.
In this execution, which appears in the March 8 issue of Rolling Stone, perception is the humble Beetle, and reality is Volkswagen's current line.
The One Club recently named the campaign, which was devised by Fallon McElligott, as the third-best campaign of the 1980's.

Rosewood to Sell Its Energy Group
LEAD: The Rosewood Corporation, whose financial group has been fighting for control of troubled First Executive Corporation, has decided to sell its energy exploration and production group, Rosewood Resources.

Review/Opera;   Mirella Freni as Puccini's Manon Lescaut, at Met
LEAD: Puccini's music is not known primarily for inscrutability, but in one respect he is one of opera's paradoxes.
Most of the soprano heroines he created are vulnerable little creatures who hold out their hearts to men and ask to have them broken.
Yet the voice required of these frail characters must be so robust and throbbingly intense that, used with proper intensity, it can quickly fray and end in tatters.


Perkin-Elmer Plan
LEAD: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation said it will conduct a ''Dutch auction'' self-tender offer Wednesday for up to 10 million shares of its common stock, or about 23 percent of the 43.5 million outstanding shares.
Under the procedure, the company said, each stockholder will be invited to tender shares at prices of $22 to $26 a share.

Smiley Gets Big Raise
LEAD: The Pittsburgh Pirate left-hander John Smiley won his arbitration case yesterday, giving the players a 4-3 edge over the Pirates in salary hearings.
Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, awarded Smiley a 1990 salary of $840,000, or more than triple his 1989 salary of $230,000.
The Pirates had offered $630,000.

Binks shares soared $10.75 today, to $43.75, in trading on the American Stock Exchange.

LEAD: National service, everybody's cause in Washington last year, finally comes to a vote in the Senate this week.
The bill contains something for everybody; unfortunately, it also contains something from almost every senator who had a thought on the issue, and also President Bush's ''thousand points of light.


The Joy of Daring
LEAD: At first we were going to tough out the Perrier crisis.
We figured the odds were pretty good.
Benzene was found in only a few bottles.


Michael Powell Is Dead at 84; Film Career Spanned 50 Years
LEAD: Michael Powell, a British film director, screenwriter and producer whose quirky and often disconcerting movies included ''The Red Shoes,'' ''The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp'' and ''Peeping Tom,'' died of prostate cancer on Monday at his home in Avening, Gloucestershire, England.
He was 84 years old.


Doctor Denies She Left Needle for Prego
LEAD: The doctor accused of leaving the needle that punctured Dr.
Veronica Prego's finger in 1983 testified yesterday that she had never left a needle on a patient's bed.


Timing Coffee Service to Suit the Taste
LEAD: THE fancier the restaurant, the later it serves the coffee, sometimes after the dessert.
In diners a mug is filled as soon as you are seated.


Surgery for Campanella
LEAD: Roy Campanella, the Hall of Fame catcher, who has been hospitalized since Dec. 30 with complications from diabetes, underwent surgery yesterday for the removal of gallstones.


Officer Is Questioned as a Suspect In Bombing Death of L.I. Detective
LEAD: A Nassau County police officer was questioned yesterday as a prime suspect in the death of an off-duty Suffolk County narcotics detective who was killed last week in a car bombing outside his home in North Patchogue, L.I., a law-enforcement official said.


Drugs Pit Baker vs. Third World at U.N.
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called on the General Assembly today to adopt a global program against drug traffickers.
But third-world speakers demanded that the United States and its industrialized allies curb demand for drugs and help poorer nations cut production.


24 Toll Takers Fall Ill at Triborough Bridge
LEAD: Twenty-four workers at Triborough Bridge tollbooths became ill over the last four days, and the city is monitoring the air near the booths.
No motorists are reported to have been affected.


Indian and Pakistani Troops Exchange Gunfire in Kashmir
LEAD: Pakistani and Indian troops exchanged fire for several hours today after a Pakistani soldier was wounded on the troubled Kashmir border, officers and a Western observer said.


Kaypro Corp. President Quits
LEAD: David Kay, the son of the founder of the Kaypro Corporation, has resigned as the company's president, less than a month after taking the job.


CML Gives Up List
LEAD: The corporate raider Irwin L. Jacobs said that CML Group Inc. had reversed its earlier decision and agreed to give him a list of the company's shareholders.
Mr.
Jacobs, who is based in Minneapolis, is seeking to remove CML's board and sell the company to the highest bidder.
Mr.
Jacobs filed suit to force the company to turn ove the list.


Real Estate;   Seven-Year Face Lift Is Completed
LEAD: THE enormous building at 120 Broadway that provoked protests 80 years ago and led to enactment of the first zoning laws in New York City - and indeed the nation - has been given a face lift that required seven years of intensive work.
Among the tasks in the just-completed renovation were the cleaning of the 50,000-square-foot facade of the 40-story structure and the replacement of many of its eroded terra cotta details.


Vanishing Species: The Local Hangout
LEAD: The Blue Moon Tavern looks like a dump.
Its weatherbeaten exterior, dating to the depths of the Great Depression, has been described as ''uniquely ordinary.'' A fern could never grow inside, nor would any of the tavern's regular patrons want it to.

Bridge
LEAD: Reprinting major works of bridge literature that have long been unavailable is a useful service to the game.
Granovetter Books has recently produced a new edition of ''Bridge is a Partnership Game'' by Alvin Roth and Tobias Stone, with a modern supplement.
This book, first published in 1958, is the best exposition of the Roth-Stone methods, which contributed much to modern bidding.

Refinery Blast Kills Two
LEAD: A truck loading liquefied petroleum gas into a storage tank caught fire and exploded at an Amoco refinery today, killing two people and injuring three others.
The accident occurred near the main storage area of the refinery, prompting the evacuation of nearby residents and closing streets in this northwestern Indiana community.
