LEAD: A highly regarded biologist nominated last week to be president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology backed out of the job yesterday, saying he could not bear to give up his research.


Rates Soar To Highest Since May
LEAD: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of both short- and long-term Treasury securities plunged.
Dealers largely blamed concern that rising interest rates overseas would further increase the cost of borrowing in the United States.

James River Sale

Q.Five years ago, I had a plumbing contractor ''rod'' the sewer line leading out to the street.
Since then, every time we have had much rain, water has backed up into the basement through the two sewer drains in the basement floor, even though there is a two-foot-high standpipe on each drain.

Frogs as Canaries
LEAD: It would make the beginning of a science fiction story.
A world congress of biologists meeting in Canterbury, England, last September found on comparing notes that frogs are disappearing from ponds, swamps, creeks and rain forests all over the world.
Are the vanishing amphibians signaling an invisible peril for humans, like canaries in a mine?

Sheriff Ashe, fed up with overcrowding at the county jail, commandeered the armory and moved 15 minimum-security prisoners there after citing a 17th-century Massachusetts law that he said allowed local authorities to compel National Guard assistance if they perceived a threat to public order.

Merchant Pacific Buys Barry Stake
LEAD: The Merchant Pacific Corporation, a private investment firm in Los Angeles, has acquired 8.4 percent of the R. G. Barry Corporation.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Merchant Pacific said it had bought 313,000 shares on the open market for an average of $9.25 each.
Barry's shares rose 12.5 cents each today, to $7.625, in trading on the American Stock Exchange, giving the company a current value of $28.2 million.

LEAD: The Israeli Government today criticized a State Department report accusing the military here of abusing Arab human rights, saying that the report failed to make clear that the army's actions were in response to Palestinian violence.

For Some Felons, Signals Replace Cells
LEAD: Steve L. is a convicted sex offender who came home from work near here one recent day at 3 P.M., as required under his probation.
At 4:09, he left his house for 17 minutes.
And the signal from a small radio transmitter attached to his ankle could no longer reach a monitoring box in the kitchen.

Market Place;   Can Macy Endure Price-Cutting?
LEAD: MORE than three years after its leveraged buyout, R. H. Macy &amp; Company is encountering doubts about its ability to survive if the current wave of price-cutting by major retailing chains continues.
Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it was considering cutting the rating on Macy's already low-rated ''junk bonds,'' sending the prices of the bonds down further and prompting an angry response from the company.

Why End Social Security to Save It?
LEAD: The huge and growing surpluses in the Social Security trust fund make Congress uncomfortable.
Some members don't like sitting on a large unclaimed pot of taxpayers' money.
Others are angered by the use of a regressive payroll tax to pay the Government's bills.


Personal Health
LEAD: Eating disorders, which afflict millions, threatening their health and sometimes their lives, are most successfully treated when detected in their early stages.
Yet, experts say, neither families nor physicians are sufficiently alert to the early signs of serious eating problems.


Review/Television;   When the Mystery, Not the Corpse, Is in Pieces
LEAD: If you are looking for a reason to contribute a bit more to public television during its approaching money-raising period, a comparison between tonight's episode of the engaging Hercule Poirot series on Channels 13 (at 8 P.M.) and 21 (at 9 P.M.) and the adaptations of stories by Agatha Christie and others on the Arts &amp; Entertainment cable channel may do the trick.

LEAD: Fifteen localities in the United States have been selected for a new initiative to curb alcohol and drug abuse, financed by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton, N.J.

United Way to Aid Smaller Agencies
LEAD: Under criticism for supporting only long-established charities, United Way of New York City expects to devote $70 million in the next five years to bolstering scores of small local agencies that help jobless youth, illiterate adults, AIDS patients, victims of domestic violence and the homeless.

International


Review/Music;   A Refreshing Side of Mahler, Based in Folk
LEAD: Mahler's songs are, for some, the half-formed embryos from which the later symphonic expanses were to grow.
Paradoxically, song forms, and the poetic texts that shape them, also rescued him from excess, imposing boundaries from without and restraining one of the most boundless of Romantic egos.
Mahler's songs tend to speak less extravagantly, with less heart-rending passion and at less length than the symphonies, but they may be more coherent in the process.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from an address by President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today to a joint meeting of Congress, as translated by an interpreter and provided by Federal News Service, a transcription company.
The last time they arrested me, on Oct. 27 of last year, I didn't know whether it was for two days or for two years.

Caring for the Homeless
An emerging group of doctors is confronting the staggering medical problems of the homeless and finding diverse ways to deliver care.


100 Jobs to Be Cut By Sterling Drug
LEAD: The Sterling Drug Company, a unit of the Eastman Kodak Company, said it was cutting about 100 jobs at its New York corporate headquarters.


Reviews/Music;   Californians Lead a Retreat Into the Past
LEAD: Europe - particularly Great Britain, West Germany and Austria -has enjoyed a considerable headstart on early-music players on the United States.
The question is not knowledge so much as skill.
Eighteenth-century oboes, flutes and strings are played similarly to the instruments taught currently in music conservatories, but their purity of sound comes at a price: mechanisms that are often less sophisticated, more awkward and consequently treacherous to manage.


Apple to Cut 400 Workers
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would reduce its work force by 400 people, or about 3 percent, as part of an effort to improve profitability.


Home Care Attendant Is Charged in Killing
LEAD: A 25-year-old home care attendant was arrested yesterday and charged with killing an 84-year-old woman in her Manhattan apartment on Valentine's Day and robbing her of bank books and certificates of deposit worth more than $300,000, the police said.

LEAD: At the United Nations, in the vast hall of the General Assembly, one delegate after another gets up and announces how much his country hates narcotics.

Arbitration List
LEAD: Here are the salaries and raises (or cuts) for players who filed for salary arbitration this year.
First figure is 1989 salary, second figure is 1990 salary and third figure is the amount of pay raise or cut the player will receive; (a) denotes raise figured on average annual value of old and/or new multiyear contract.


Turkish Killings Echo Across 75 Years to Create a Din in the Senate
LEAD: The Senate spent hours today locked in an unusual debate over honoring the countless Armenians who died early in the century at the hands of the Ottoman Turks, a debate that has pitted some of the Senate's most powerful figures against each other and unleashed a frenzy of lobbying.

LEAD: Because of the failure of a computer system at The Associated Press yesterday, the tables listing trading in Government agency bonds could not be processed and do not appear today.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury is investigating whether Pete Rose may owe taxes on income from cash earned at baseball card and memorabilia shows, a spokeswoman for Rose confirmed today.

LEAD: The Army told Congress today that the Bush Administration's plan to shrink the military might force the Army to dismiss some career officers ''as a last resort.''

LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that its wafer fabrication plant here had made the company's first computer memory chip capable of storing 16 million bits of information.

LEAD: Proposing yet another hurdle to the secession of Staten Island from New York City, the Dinkins administration is asking the State Legislature to require all voters in the city, not just those on Staten Island, to vote on the issue before it could be approved.

LEAD: After enjoying a sensational season that won him the National League comeback-player-of-the-year award, Lonnie Smith of the Atlanta Braves went on a calorie-comsuming spree that raised the weight on his 5-foot 7-inch frame from 190 to 225 1/2 pounds.

Knicks Trade Strickland to Spurs for Cheeks
LEAD: Rod Strickland, the unhappy Knick who had asked to be traded, got his wish last night.
In an exchange of guards that brought them a more experienced and less controversial player, the Knicks sent the 23-year-old Strickland to the San Antonio Spurs for the 33-year-old Maurice Cheeks.


William H. Nelson, Gay Advocate, 40
LEAD: William H. Nelson, president of the Dallas Gay Alliance from 1984 to 1987, died of complications from AIDS on Tuesday.
He was 40 years old.


Arnold Ostwald, 66, Lawyer in Manhattan
LEAD: Arnold Ostwald, a lawyer in Manhattan for almost 40 years, died on Monday in Eastham, Mass., after he and his seeing eye dog were struck by a car while out for a walk.
He was 66 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.


Ideas for the House, Ranch to Cape Cod
LEAD: THE far west end of 33d Street is an improbable site to construct a 1,990-square-foot, three-bedroom ranch house.
But one was completed there yesterday in the Jacob Javits Convention Center as an exhibit for the Greater New York Home and Apartment Show.


Results Plus
LEAD:
TENNIS
McEnroe and Gilbert Are Upset
Top-seeded John McEnroe and second-seeded Brad Gilbert were upset yesterday at the U.S.
Pro Indoor tournament in Philadelphia.
Richey Reneberg broke McEnroe's service three times in the third set to win, 6-7, 6-3, 6-3.
Paul Haarhuis won 12 of the last 15 points to beat Gilbert 7-6, 5-7, 6-4.

LEAD: VMS Realty Partners, the troubled real estate giant, said today that its chief executive of only four months, Jeffrey A. Park, would resign.
Joel A. Stone, who had been president before Mr.
Park joined the company will succeed Mr.
Park, VMS said.

LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Bank Funding Corporation priced through various securities dealers a three-part bond issue yesterday totaling $2.99 billion.

Norbert Schimmel, Collector, Dies; Specialist in Antiquities Was 85
LEAD: Norbert Schimmel, a collector of antiquities who gave an important group of ancient Egyptian reliefs to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1985, died of pneumonia on Friday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla.
He was 85 years old, and had lived for many years in Great Neck, L.I.


Tools for Carvers and Cabinetmakers
LEAD: ''SPECIALTY woodworking tools are no longer available over the counter,'' said a co-owner of the Garrett Wade Company in Manhattan. ''If you go into a hardware store to find a tool, there's very little selection left.
What used to be a hardware store is now a houseware store.''


Review/Theater;   A Sexual Cover-Up in 'New Anatomies'
LEAD: Isabelle Eberhardt drowned in the desert, the victim of a freak flood.
This was a bizarre end to a brief, fascinating life.
She was a European who transformed herself into an Arab; in the guise of a man, she traveled through the Sahara and lived with with the natives under her adopted name, Si Mahmoud.


Money-Fund Yields Mixed
LEAD: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds dipped slightly and taxable funds were virtually unchanged.


Review/Ballet;   Martins's 'Black and White'
LEAD: Peter Martins's ''Black and White,'' which the New York City Ballet presented for the first time this season on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, takes its title from the colors of its simple costumes.
It is a ballet of mischievous music and sobersided choreography.

LEAD: Eliot Feld has just changed the name of his company from the Feld Ballet to Feld Ballets NY.
The idea was to give the troupe ''a New York identity,'' the management reports, although the new plural has not been explained.


Congress Assails Air Force Over Accounting
LEAD: A Congressional audit charges that the Air Force has understated by tens of billions of dollars the costs of its weapons systems in data provided to the executive and legislative branches of Government as well as to its own financial managers.

Drexel Offers Explanation For Bonuses
LEAD: As many creditors reacted with dismay to the news that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had paid perhaps as much as $350 million in bonuses to executives in the weeks before it collapsed, the firm's chief executive, Frederick H. Joseph, made a telephone conference call yesterday to assure some creditors that the firm had done nothing untoward.


Loss at Westwood One
LEAD: Westwood One Inc. reported on Tuesday that it lost more than $4 million in the fourth quarter on sharply higher revenues and operating income.
The company, which owns two radio networks and several radio stations, attributed the loss to the heavy cost of recent investments, including the acquisition of a radio station here.

The company named Donald T. Shire senior vice president for human resources and administration.

Southern Blooms In Northern Climes
LEAD: The first chores of spring begin in late February.
Now is the time to have gasoline-powered lawn mowers serviced, to have their blades sharpened or replaced and to check their spark plugs and oil filters.
The ornamental grasses and perennials left standing over the winter should be cut back now.
Many deciduous shrubs, like the taller kinds of cotoneaster, can be pruned now, when the structure of their branches is plain enough to see.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Jan. 19 about Barbara Piasecka Johnson's proposed purchase of the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, referred imprecisely to her inheritance.
Mrs.
Johnson inherited $350 million from her husband, J. Seward Johnson; according to a recent calculation by Johnson &amp; Johnson, that was about 11 percent of the total Johnson fortune.


Patrick H. McMahon Dead at 84; Burned Sailor Saved by Kennedy
LEAD: Patrick Henry McMahon, the wounded sailor whom Lieut. (j.g.) John F. Kennedy towed to safety on his back after PT-109 was splintered by a Japanese destroyer 47 years ago, died Sunday at a convalescent home in nearby Encinitas.
He was 84 years old.


Florida Players Free
LEAD: The four University of Florida players suspended last Oct. 16 after they admitted betting on college and pro games will not be prosecuted and will be eligible to play next year, the university said yesterday.

LEAD: Instead of taking the trading route to reduce their overabundance of defensemen, the Devils chose the New York State Thruway route to Utica to help solve the problem, sending Craig Wolanin, their biggest defender, to their minor league team in the upstate city.

49% Stake to Cost Fiat $104.8 Million
LEAD: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian automobile giant, will pay $104.8 million for 49 percent of a new unit that will make and distribute Maserati cars, De Tomaso Industries said.
Under the deal, Fiat will also assume $23.1 million in deferred severance pay obligations.
The deal was announced in December, but no price had been set.

LEAD: Dorothy Avery Slesinger, a teacher and co-founder of one of the first coeducational summer camps on the East Coast, died of pneumonia on Saturday at New York Hospital.
She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Jamaica to FCB/Leber
LEAD: The Jamaica Tourist Board awarded its advertising account yesterday to FCB/Leber Katz Partners.
The previous agency, Young &amp; Rubicam, lost the account when the United States Government charged it with conspiring to bribe Jamaican officials to win the account, which bills about $6 million.
Young &amp; Rubicam has pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to bribe officials.


U.N. Drug Plan Puts Stress on Reducing Demand
LEAD: he United Nations today approved a new anti-narcotics plan that stresses the need to reduce demand in the industrialized consuming countries and to compensate poor drug-producing countries for losses suffered by curbing the trade.

Our Towns;   Under the Wheel Of Bureaucracy, License to Shriek
LEAD: Teresa Bednar remembered people screaming, fire alarms clanging and flames flicking from the ceiling.
She also recalled customers who looked as if they would rather have fried than flee.


Frank Ross, 85; Producer of Films Made 'The Robe'
LEAD: Frank Ross, a film producer whose credits included ''Of Mice and Men'' and the first wide-screen movie, ''The Robe,'' died of complications after brain surgery on Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.
He was 85 years old. ''The Robe,'' a biblical epic that took Mr.
Ross 10 years to bring to the screen, had its premiere in 1953 and was the first film produced by the


Caller ID Won't Screen the Pesky Sales Pitch
LEAD: To the Editor:


Harold Leland Goodwin, Author, 75
LEAD: Harold Leland Goodwin, an author who wrote science-adventure books for children and books about space exploration, died of cardiac arrest at his home on Sunday.
He was 75 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the postponement of a space shuttle launching, partly because of the commander's illness, included an erroneous comment from NASA about the rarity of such an occurrence.
It was at least the second time - not the first - that a manned space flight had been postponed because of a health problem.

LEAD: President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d suggested today that it was time for the Israeli Government to stop hesitating about putting its own peace plan into effect, and to make the necessary compromises to open negotiations with the Egyptians and Palestinians.

Notebook;   Red Ransom's Return Overshadows Donn
LEAD: The Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park on Saturday is the season's first Grade I race outside California, but not the most compelling race on the card.
More excitement surrounds the fifth race, a $24,000 seven-furlong allowance event marking the return of Red Ransom.


CNBC to Chiat/Day
LEAD: The Consumer News and Business Channel, or CNBC, has switched its advertising account from Lord Einstein O'Neill &amp; Partners to Chiat/ Day/Mojo in New York.
Lord Einstein had the account since June.
Michael Eskridge, the president of CNBC, a joint venture of NBC and the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, L.I., said CNBC wanted to work with a bigger operation.

The Reagan Tape;   REAGAN TESTIFIES HE DID NOT ORDER ANY ILLEGAL ACTS
LEAD: In a videotaped deposition made public today, former President Ronald Reagan repeatedly denied that he ever instructed his subordinates to violate the law during the Iran-contra affair.
Mr.
Reagan said he never knew about the full extent of his aides' involvement in covert efforts to help the Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: ''We are being asked to accept a pig in a poke under unreasonably short time constraints, and that pig smells awfully bad.''
- Doug Baily, Attorney General of Alaska, on a possible plea bargain in the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

New York Can't Go It Alone in the Fight to Control Acid Rain
LEAD: To the Editor:


Cabaret to a Different Drummer
LEAD: WHEN Michael Moriarty takes the stage of the Ballroom to perform his new nightclub act, one of the first things he does is explain that his show is ''jazz cabaret,'' not cabaret per se.
The actor and singer's disclaimer prefaces a quirky, fascinating show that breaks down the distinctions between music-making and acting.


Chronicle
LEAD: STEPHEN RUBIN, the new president of Doubleday publishers, has named ANN GODOFF to be executive editor and MARLY RUSOFF as executive director of publicity.
The appointments follow that of SUSAN MOLDOW as editor in chief earlier this month.
Mr.
Rubin has a mandate to put an end to Doubleday's losses, which totaled several million dollars last year.


Bass Group Cuts Its Enterra Stake
LEAD: An investment group led by members of the Bass family of Fort Worth has lowered its stake in the Enterra Corporation to 3.2 percent from 7.2 percent.
In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group gave no reason for the sale of the shares.
The group had acquired its Enterra shares in exchange for its holdings in CRC Evans Pipeline International Inc., which merged with the Houston-based energy-services company in


Margaret Craske Is Dead at 97; Directed Met Opera Ballet School
LEAD: Margaret Craske, a leading ballet teacher in England and the United States, died on Sunday at Grand Strand General Hospital in Myrtle Beach, S.C.
She was 97 years old.
A pupil of Enrico Cecchetti, the great Italian ballet pedagogue, Miss Craske danced for a short time with the Diaghilev Ballets Russes and toured with Ninette de Valois, founder of the Royal Ballet, in a small group that performed in English variety theaters during the 1920's.


Review/Graphic Design;   If It's Commercial, Is It Really Art?
LEAD: ONE of the most significant developments in 20th-century artistic life has been the widening of the arena that constitutes art.
Where painting and sculpture once prevailed in splendid isolation, a raft of art forms now commands equal attention from galleries and museums: architecture, film, performance, photography, video and, most anomalously, graphic design.


Eastman Kodak
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced an electronic film-editing system that is intended to take the place of the razor blade in professional photography labs.
The system is the company's latest entry in the developing field of hybrid electronic photography.
The Premier image enhancement system begins and ends with a regular film image.


Fire Hazard Brings Recall of Spray Confetti
LEAD: The Consumer Product Safety Commission today recalled more than a million cans of spray string confetti because the propellants are flammable.

UAL to Give Unions Data for Possible Bid
LEAD: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that its board had authorized the release of financial information to United's unions but that it had not received a new buyout proposal from them.


Eastern Air In Pact With Its Creditors
LEAD: After nearly a year of negotiations, Eastern Airlines reached an agreement in principle yesterday with its unsecured creditors on a plan to bring the carrier out of bankruptcy within several months.

Details' Editor Is Dismissed by Newhouse
LEAD: When Annie Flanders found out two years ago that S. I. Newhouse was buying the magazine that she had founded, she marched in and informed him that she had been fired from every job she had ever had.
This week, Ms.
Flanders, editor in chief and founder of the offbeat fashion magazine Details, was dismissed again.

Ex-Wedtech Head Sentenced
LEAD: The former president of the Wedtech Corporation, whose testimony helped convict former Congressman Mario Biaggi, was sentenced yesterday to five months in prison for his role in the corruption scandal.
The former executive of the defunct South Bronx military contractor, Anthony Guariglia, pleaded guilty in 1987 to bribe charges and cooperated with prosecutors.

LEAD: Westview Press of Boulder, Colo. a leading publisher of scholarly books, has been acquired by SCS Communications Inc. of New York.

LEAD: *
Country Lake Foods Inc., St.
Paul, said it was delaying its acquisition of Superior-Dairy Fresh Milk Co., Minneapolis, because the U.S.

Top Service Corp. Post To Longtime Supporter
LEAD: When L. William Heiligbrodt was chairman of the Texas Commerce Bank, he lent money to a start-up Houston company whose plan was to buy funeral homes and cemeteries.
He has remained associated with the company, now known as Service Corporation International, and has just been named its president and chief operating officer.


Chronicle
LEAD: Members of Solidarity and staff members of Poland's National Assembly have ended a two-week stay in Washington, where they learned about the American legislative system.
HENRYK WUJEC, a member of the Sejm, the lower house of the National Assembly, and Secretary of the Citizens' Committee of Solidarity, led the 10-member delegation.

Piniella Eager to Put Pinstripes Behind
LEAD: He is trying to make the best of it, but the days have seemed to pass like months for Lou Piniella.
Some days, he visits relatives.
Others, he spends the afternoon fishing.
Mostly, he waits.
It has been like this since the first week of February, when Piniella and his family arrived at their beach home in Reddington Shores, Fla., and waited for baseball to begin.


VIETNAMESE FORCE HELPING CAMBODIA, DIPLOMATS ASSERT
LEAD: Several thousand Vietnamese troops and military advisers returned to Cambodia last fall after a much-publicized withdrawal and are helping the Cambodian Government to defend two strategic cities from guerrilla attack, two senior Eastern European diplomats say.


Late Rally Sends Prices Soaring
LEAD: A late rally sent prices of Treasury securities soaring and yields tumbling yesterday.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about Cuban-Americans' hopes for an end of Fidel Castro's rule omitted a word from remarks by a Miami banker, Bernardo Benes.
He said ''half'' in his comment: ''I know for a fact that if Castro goes tomorrow, the day after tomorrow retail stores in Miami are going be selling goods to five million additional people, which is half the population of Cuba.


Carnation Shifts Shops, Plans Interpublic Moves
LEAD: Two weeks after assigning the consumer advertising account for its infant nutritional products to McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles, the Carnation Company has taken the professional advertising for the products away from McCann Healthcare Advertising.
Carnation, a subsidiary of Nestle S.A., has moved that portion of the account to M.E.D.

Outdoors;   All Aboard! Skiers Chug to the Hills
LEAD: EARLY on a Saturday morning in 1935, Grand Central Station was crowded with 447 skiers preparing to board a train to Pittsfield, Mass., to test their skills on a hilly pasture in the Berkshires.
At the Art Deco station in Pittsfield, the eager skiers clamored out of the train as the thousands of locals who had gathered for the occasion watched.

Pierce Leads Surge by Bucks
Ricky Pierce scored 33 points and the Bucks used a late 20-3 surge to end Dallas's winning streak at five games in Milwuakee last night.
Brad Lohaus added 18 points and Greg Anderson and Jay Humphries 16 apiece for the Bucks.
Roy Tarpley scored 26 points to tie a season high and Rolando Blackman and Derek Harper added 18 apiece for Dallas, which also had won 12 of its last 14 games.(AP)

LEAD: Arguably the most important goal for Israel today, and one shared by Americans, is the prompt resettlement of as many Soviet Jews as possible in Israel.

Economic Scene;   German Options On Money Union
LEAD: CHANCELLOR HELMUT KOHL means to use his country's powerful currency as the catalyst for uniting East and West Germany.
A cardinal aim of Mr.
Kohl's plan for rapid monetary union is to check the emigration of Eastern workers to the West.
Far more than 400,000 East Germans have moved into West Germany, and the exodus is continuing at a rate of about 2,000 a week.

LEAD: The stock of the Union Carbide Corporation rose $1.25 yesterday, to $23.75, on rumors of a possible sale of one or more divisions, or a possible joint venture, analysts said.
Union Carbide's Linde division, which manufactures gases, and the Ucar Carbon Company unit are two of the divisions most frequently cited by traders as being possibly up for sale.

Victor Lasky, 72, Whose Writings Focused on Fighting Communists
LEAD: Victor Lasky, a columnist and author whose outspoken anti-Communist views were the main focus of his writing and lecturing, died of abdominal cancer yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington.

At the Bar
LEAD: Is there a constitutionally protected right to flog a dead horse?
How about a live one?
Do the owners of the late great Secretariat have the same rights as the heirs of Babe Ruth?
Are Roy Rogers and Trigger or Christie Brinkley and Easy Goer equal under the law?
They are questions that have horse owners, horse artists and at least a few horse lawyers talking.

LEAD: As music listening and performing have moved from the religious to the secular, the rituals surrounding the practice of music have grown increasingly distant from their roots in momentous ceremonies based on life and death or the changing seasons.

Topics of The Times;   Mock Spring, Gentle Winter
LEAD: Spring of a sort has burst into the Bronx.
Under the glass roofs of the Enid Haupt Conservatory at the Botanical Gardens, clumps of crimson tulips sway in the indoor breezes, stiff hyacinths give off their soft perfumes and golden narcissus hang over a little pond looking down - as the first Narcissus did - at their own reflections in the water.

Review/Film;   Crazy Quilt Of Family, Shakespeare And Farce
LEAD: Failure has its gradations, just as success does.
There are films that fail at doing nothing more elaborate than occupying their viewers' attention for an hour or two, and there are others that fail on a much higher plane.
John Boorman's ''Where the Heart Is,'' incorporating elements of Shakespeare, Impressionist painting, magic, fashion and family psychology into a wildly imaginative, thoroughly incoherent mix, has an undeniable grandeur and nobility even in the midst of its broadest lapses of sense, taste and style.

Open Positions on Short Sales Are Up 5.1% on Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose by 26.6 million shares, or 5.1 percent, in the four-week period ended Feb. 15.
Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

Wolves Trade Johnson
LEAD: Steve Johnson, who feuded with Minnesota from the time he was picked by the Timberwolves in the expansion draft, was traded last night to Seattle for Brad Sellers.


Corrections
LEAD: A front-page article on Feb. 15 about contraceptives misstated the National Right to Life Committee's position on their development.
It opposes work that might lead to abortion-inducing drugs, but neither supports nor opposes contraception.


Restaurants
LEAD: After four recent visits to La Cote Basque, still one of New York City's most sumptuous dining spots, I came away with several lingering memories.
One is of an awestruck young couple (my guess was high school prom age) trying to act so worldly as they struggled with the all-French menu and puzzled over the surfeit of silverware.


U.S.-Registered Tanker Explodes in Persian Gulf    The Surf City was one of 11 Kuwaiti tankers reflagged by the United States in 1987 to protect them from Iranian attacks during Gulf crossings. (Reuters)


Reducing Hall of Fame Guesswork
LEAD: Nothing invites an impassioned debate more rapidly than discussing various sports Halls of Fame and who is voted into them.
Add the aspect of racism, as Jim Brown did last week in Ohio, and you have an issue that hits the raw nerve of sports.

A Lutanist And a Tenor Collaborate Sporadically
LEAD: Before a concert in Maryland the other day, the British tenor Nigel Rogers and the American lutanist Paul O'Dette took a moment to guess at the number of works they had performed since they began touring together in 1980. ''It must be at least 500,'' Mr.
Rogers estimated.
Mr.
O'Dette added that because circumstances dictated that they offer a different program at virtually every concert, they have prepared 120 works for their current tour.


Nearly 2 Years Later, Pennzoil Fills Position
LEAD: The Pennzoil Company yesterday named James L. Pate its chief operating officer, filling a vacant post in its top management.

INSIDE
LEAD:
Federal Court Strikes Down Flag Protection Law
In the first court test of a 1989 law barring desecration of the American flag, a judge declared it unconstitutional.
An expected Government appeal could bring the issue before the Supreme Court by May.
Page A10.
Greenspan Reassurances
The Federal Reserve chairman said a January price surge was not likely to continue, suggesting the Fed would not tighten credit soon.


Douglas Makes Deal for Two Fights
LEAD: James (Buster) Douglas would make $25 million to fight Evander Holyfield and could get $35 million for a rematch with Mike Tyson under a deal with Steve Wynn, the promoter Bob Arum said today.

Honda vs. Subaru
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company, which makes the Acura Legend car, said it was seeking to block a trademark for the name of a Subaru car, the Legacy.
Honda, which filed a complaint with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, said that it was not challenging use of the Legacy name, but that it did not want a trademark granted for the Legacy.


Bank of New England Loss Worse Than Expected in '89
LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation said today that its 1989 losses of $1.11 billion were worse than expected.
It said it was studying whether loan-loss provisions should have been bigger earlier in the year.


Bond Tables Are Incomplete
LEAD: The tables listing trading in Treasury bills, bonds and notes on page D12 and in Government agency bonds on page D15 do not contain a column listing the change in the bid price from the previous day.


Late Selloff Pushes Dow 8.79 Points Lower
LEAD: Stocks fell broadly yesterday, depressed by late selling, and after being nearly 30 points higher than its opening level about 2 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average finished 8.79 points lower, at 2,574.77.


Tektronix to Cut 600 Employees
LEAD: Tektronix Inc. said it would lay off 600 employees by late May because an anticipated sales increase had not materialized.
Most of the layoffs will occur in the test and measurement group, the electronics company said.
The group manufactures various products, including Tektronix's original product line, oscilloscopes.

Corrections
LEAD: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to a stock deal between the Advanced Telecommunications Corporation and the Metromedia Company.
Advanced has agreed to repurchase 1,954,500 shares of its common stock from Metromedia at $13 a share, for a total of $25.4 million.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Whitman Corp. May Sell Unit
LEAD: The Whitman Corporation, the consumer goods and services conglomerate, said it was considering restructuring its operations and selling one of its four main businesses.


A Looser Leash on Football Talent
LEAD: The National Football League has grudgingly yielded to reality and fairness by announcing it will let college juniors enter its rookie draft - if they renounce their college eligibility.
That leaves the league well short of where it needs to be, but at least the direction is progressive.

Zoellick are asked to talk about him, they sound a little like the brainwashed servicemen in ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' who uniformly refer to their sergeant as ''the kindest, bravest, warmest, most wonderful human being I've ever known in my life.''

LEAD: CARLY SIMON added a Grammy Award to her Oscar and Golden Globe Award for her song ''Let the River Run,'' from the movie ''Working Girl.'' The song, she said, was ''an anthem for New York.'' Federal Jurors Rule For Transit officers In Decoy Unit Arrest
LEAD: A Federal civil jury yesterday rejected a man's contention that he had been wrongfully arrested by a transit police decoy unit in a chain snatching in a Brooklyn subway station three years ago.
The man was acquitted of the chain-snatching charge.

Book Fair
LEAD: Rare, vintage and just plain old books by the thousands will be for sale this weekend at Public School 3 in Greenwich Village during the 11th annual Antiquarian Book Fair.
Novels, science fiction, mysteries, biographies, art books and nonfiction of every description, as well as prints, postcards, comic books, baseball cards, autographs and almost anything else that has found its way onto a printed page, will be sold at the school by more than 70 dealers.

Converting a Mill;   Condos in 19th-Century Structures
LEAD: In 1844, when Robert Beattie, an Irish immigrant, built a brownstone carpet mill on the banks of the Passaic River in Little Falls, N.J., he brought jobs, the railroad and residents to the tiny community.
Now, a century and a half later, Mr.
Beattie's mill is stimulating new growth for the town.


Pan Am's Planes
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had a $210 million order from the Pan Am Corporation for 10 Jetstream Super 31 aircraft and 10 Jetstream 41 aircraft, with options on another 20 planes.
Deliveries of the Jetstream 41 are scheduled to begin in February 1993 and will be completed by the end of that year.


East Germans Deny a Report That Ex-Spymaster Has Fled
LEAD: East German officials today disputed a report that the country's former spymaster, Markus Wolf, fled East Germany for the Soviet Union, saying he was only on vacation and was not under investigation for illegal arms deals.


Nepal and India Move Close to Ending Dispute
LEAD: After a bitter yearlong standoff, India and Nepal appeared today to have agreed on a formula for settling their trade and transit disputes.

7 Copters Face Off in Medfly Dispute
LEAD: A raging dispute over pesticide safety took to the skies early today when a Pasadena police helicopter intercepted a phalanx of six helicopters chartered by the state and tried to order them to halt their aerial spraying of the insecticide malathion.


Nicaragua Vote Monitors Confident
LEAD: After months of preparation for national elections here on Sunday, international observers who will oversee the vote say they believe it will be virtually impossible for the Sandinista Front or its opponents to cheat without being detected.


Mr. Havel's Profound Paradox
LEAD: ''You can help us most of all,'' Vaclav Havel told Congress Wednesday, ''if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy.'' The Czech President, who embodies his country's emergence from Soviet domination, called this remark paradoxical.
Maybe, but it also expresses a profound truth and suggests a wise course of action for the


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 497 money market mutual funds increased by $3.57 billion, to $390.68 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 152 institutional funds rose $1.25 billion, to $92.67 billion.
The assets of the 244 general-purpose funds rose $1.33 billion, to $132.55 billion.

LEAD: The Secretary of Health and Human Services today urged athletes and sports organizations to turn aside the ''blood money'' of tobacco company sponsorships.


Litton Contract
LEAD: Litton Industries said it had won a $614.2 million Navy contract to build three Aegis guided-missile destroyers.
Litton's Ingalls Shipbuilding division in Pascagoula, Miss., already holds a contract to build three of the ships.
In addition to the six Aegis destroyers, Ingalls is building seven Ticonderoga-class Aegis guided-missile cruisers and three more Wasp-class amphibious assault ships.

Religion Notes
LEAD: Plea on Soviet Clash The clash between Christian Armenians and Muslim Azerbaijanis in the Soviet Union has provoked an unusual joint statement from representatives of the Armenian and Muslim communities in Los Angeles.
Religious leaders from the two groups warned in early February against interpreting the Soviet conflict as one ''based on religious differences.

With Peace Talks Near, Cambodia Reports Victory
LEAD: With a new round of peace talks starting here on Monday, the Cambodian Government has achieved its first victory in a counteroffensive against opposition forces in northwestern Cambodia.


Pakistan Open to U.S. Plan on Afghans, Aide Says
LEAD: Pakistan has abandoned its support for a military solution in Afghanistan and has told the Bush Administration that it is not opposed to an American proposal that the Afghan President, Najibullah, remain in power during negotiations for a political settlement, a senior Pakistani official says.

Review/Dance;   A 'Toreador' With Danish Roots
LEAD: The relationship between cause and effect can be a strange one.
What if two Spanish dancers named Mariano and Dolores had not performed in Copenhagen in 1840?
The world would have been bereft of a sparkling, lighthearted production presented by the Cleveland Ballet that grew out of that visit.

Spy Planes Begin Flight From Legend to Museum
LEAD: After more than 25 years of stratospheric snooping, the world's fastest and highest-flying planes have begun making their final flights this week -to museums across the country.


Shares in Pfizer Are Down Again
LEAD: The shares of Pfizer Inc., which have fallen recently because of problems with heart valves it makes, fell another $3 yesterday, to $56.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Pfizer was the most active issue yesterday, with more than 3.9 million shares traded.
Pfizer reiterated that it had adequate reserves and insurance to cover claims involving the valves, some of which have fracutured.


Corrections Corrections Corrections
LEAD: A listing with the Personal Health column on Thursday, about sources of help for eating disorders, misstated addresses or telephone numbers for three organizations.
The American Anorexia/Bulimia Association is at 418 East 76th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; (212) 734-1114.
The National Anorexic Aid Society's number is (614) 436-1112.

Baseball Bargainers Will Continue Talking
LEAD: Baseball's labor negotiators met for about three hours yesterday and made minute progress.
The talks proceeded well enough to prompt the sides to meet today, the first Saturday session in the three months of negotiations.
But neither their words nor their schedule signaled that a settlement was in sight.


Ronald B. Monroe, Administrator, 50
LEAD: Ronald B. Monroe, an administrator with the Conservation Company, a public-policy consulting concern, and Seedco, a community development and human services organization, died of AIDS on Wednesday at University Hospital.
He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.


What Mr. Reagan Remembers
LEAD: Nobody expected Ronald Reagan to shed much new light on the Iran-contra affair.
But the former President's recorded testimony was even more vague and dismaying than anticipated.
Yet he survived with the same mixture of affability and innocence that saw him through the gravest blunders of his incumbency.


Japanese Buy Farm Team
LEAD: The Suntory International Corporation, an American subsidiary of Suntory Ltd., has bought the minor league Birmingham Barons baseball team, a spokesman for the Japanese brewery said today.

LEAD: The three major television networks and Cable News Network have agreed to create a single Election Day poll of voters after they have voted that would provide the same information at the same time to each organization, two senior network officials who asked not to be identified said yesterday.


16-Year Term for Drunken Driver
LEAD: Larry Mahoney was sentenced today to 16 years in prison for causing the deaths of 27 people in a collision between his pickup truck and a school bus carrying a church group, the worst drunken-driving accident in the nation's history.

The Olympus Infinity Zoom 200 is made by the Olympus Corporation, which is owned by the Olympus Optical Company of Tokyo.

Utility Escapes Fine in Handling of A-Plant Waste
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that it would cite the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, but not fine it, for the mishandling of radioactive waste at its Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear plant.


India Crash Revives French Dispute Over Safety of Airbus Jet
LEAD: The crash of an Airbus A320 jet that killed 97 people in India last week has reignited a dispute in France over whether the computerized, highly advanced aircraft is too complicated to fly.
The French pilots union is urging that the airliner be grounded in France.


Fitzwater v. Lawyers
LEAD: Anyone who disapproves of lawyers has a friend in the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, who said today, ''Lawyers certainly deserve all the criticism they can get.''

Laws Banning Sale of Car Rental Insurance Are Questioned
LEAD: Now that laws to prevent car rental companies from selling separate collision insurance coverage are in place in New York and Illinois, other states are considering similar bans.
But questions are being raised about how well the laws serve the consumer.


'Rumors' to Close Today
LEAD: ''Rumors,'' a comedy by Neil Simon, will close after this evening's performance at the Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street.
The play, directed by Gene Saks, will have run for 531 regular performances and 12 previews.


California Saving Unit Is Seized
LEAD: In the most striking indication yet of how the woes of the ''junk bond'' market have spread to the savings and loan industry, the Government today seized the Imperial Savings and Loan Association, one of California's largest savings institutions.


Habib Sabet Is Dead; An Iranian Altruist And Industrialist, 86
LEAD: Habib Sabet, one of Iran's major industrialists, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.
He was 86 years old and lived in Paris.


Patents;   A New Surgical Glove To Block Infection
LEAD: A heart surgeon at Pennsylvania State University's College of Medicine has invented a surgical glove that he said reduces the chance of being exposed to blood contaminated by the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis.


Investment Banker Proposed as Actuary
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins and the chairman of the Municipal Labor Committee, Stanley Hill, yesterday recommended Robert C. North Jr. to become chief actuary of the New York City pension systems, one of the largest pools of retirement funds in the country.

LEAD: Democratic leaders said today that Congress might consider trying to cut income taxes on ''upper-middle-class'' families but raising taxes on the richest Americans.


David Greenstone, 52, U. of Chicago Professor
LEAD: J. David Greenstone, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago and an author, died of cancer on Wednesday at Bernard Mitchell Hosiptal in Chicago.
He was 52 years old and lived in Chicago.

LEAD: The devout of the Russian hard-liners gathered in a sports arena here tonight to condemn President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for his attempts to liberalize and Westernize Soviet society, and to celebrate being Russian nationalists when many consider such attitudes chauvinist.


Sides Confer in Prego Case Amid Signs of a Settlement
LEAD: The case of Dr.
Veronica Prego, who contends she contracted AIDS from a contaminated syringe needle in a Brooklyn hospital, was interrupted yesterday afternoon as the opposing sides conferred in the judge's chambers for two hours amid signs that a settlement would soon be announced.


C. Rodgers Burgin, Retired Banker, 90
LEAD: C. Rodgers Burgin, a retired banker, died of pneumonia Thursday at Milton Hospital in Massachusetts.
He was 90 years old and lived in Milton.


U.S. Issues End Volatile Day Unchanged
LEAD: Treasury securities prices were essentially unchanged yesterday, but the closing quotes masked volatile price moves here and overseas.
One Treasury securities dealer likened the day's action to ''a football being kicked between players in Japan and West Germany with us as spectators.''


Board of Elections Seeks Fines in Races For School Boards
LEAD: Acting unusually aggressively, the New York City Board of Elections began civil action yesterday against 109 community school board candidates and 19 candidate committees for failing to file financial reports after school board elections last May.

LEAD: Al MacInnis, the Calgary Flames defenseman who was voted the most valuable player of the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring, was found not guilty of assault today.

LEAD: The Jets continued their tilt toward young coaches with no pro experience yesterday when they signed Ed Donatell, a 33-year-old defensive backs coach from California State-Fullerton.


Britain's 5th-Warmest Winter
LEAD: Daffodils are blooming and fruit trees are budding as Britain enjoys the warmest February since the American Revolution and the fifth-warmest winter since records began in 1659.
Today's high of 65 degrees Fahrenheit tied a record for the date, and the coldest temperature all winter was 37 degrees on New Year's Day.


Dinkins Seeking Advice on Ethics Of Cable Talks
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins has asked an ethics panel to advise him on participating in deliberations over cable television franchises because his son owns stock in a company with an interest in a franchise in Queens.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections Corrections Corrections
LEAD: An obituary on Thursday about William W. Bartley 3d, a research fellow and former professor, misidentified a survivor, Elvina Bartley.
She is his mother, not his wife.

LEAD: Stung by objections to a proposed settlement of criminal charges against the Exxon Corporation in the Alaska oil spill, the Justice Department today defended itself against charges by state officials that the deal would let the company avoid paying the full cleanup costs.


Mikolaj W. Balicki, Hospital Founder, 97
LEAD: Mikolaj W. Balicki, a former judge in Poland and a founder of a childrens' hospital in Cracow, died of heart failure on Wednesday at his daughter's home in Montclair, N.J.
He was 97 years old.


Former Justice Minister Acquitted in Geneva
LEAD: A former Swiss Justice Minister was acquitted today of charges of divulging official secrets in a case involving the suspected laundering of profits from the drug trade.


Baker Presses Israel to Open Peace Talks
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Foreign Minister Moshe Arens today that it was time for Israel to accept his compromise formula for opening talks between Israelis and Palestinians, Administration officials said.


Grand Met in Talks On Breweries' Sale
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food, liquor and retailing giant, confirmed it was negotiating to sell its brewing operations to Elders IXL Ltd. of Australia.
A Grand Met spokesman, Bill Bullard, said Grand Met was also negotiating with another potential buyer, whom he refused to identify.

Mortgage Rates Mixed
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.31 percent, up from 10.10 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.44 percent this week, down from 8.48 percent the week before.

Old World Faces in the New
LEAD: For more than three months now, television screens have been filled with faces Americans rarely saw before, those of ordinary Czechoslovaks, East Germans, Hungarians, Bulgarians and the citizens of half a dozen Soviet republics.
As these peoples emerge from the gloom of official obscurity, Americans feel a jolt of recognition: they look remarkably like people we know.

LEAD: Stock prices retreated again yesterday, pulled down by worries about interest rates and another exceptionally steep decline in the Tokyo stock market.

LEAD: Korea's militarized North-South frontier remains dangerous even at the end of the cold war that prompted it.
Pyongyang is still armed to the teeth, rigid and unpredictable.
What has changed is the ability of South Korea, after years of stunning growth, to help pay for its own defense.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Reading Cognac Labels
LEAD:
Cognac, the brandy made in the Charentes region in western France, is often sold with confusing names and initials on the label; the French Government regulates some but not all of them.
Almost all bottled Cognacs are blended from barrels of Cognac made in different years, and the letters on a label indicate the age of the youngest Cognac allowed in the blend.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL
Hunter Beats John Jay for Title
John Jay College, the Cinderella team of the CUNY basketball tournament, the team that upset the host and favorite, the College of Staten Island, in the semifinals, lost to Hunter College by 103-80 last night in the title game.
Secundino Velez, a sophomore guard from Puerto Rico, scored a game-high 31 points to lead Hunter to its first CUNY championship since 1970.

LEAD: Bank robberies in New York City have risen sharply in the last few months, and the suddenness and sharpness of the increase has bank executives and law enforcement officials baffled.


Jose Napoleon Duarte, Salvadoran Leader In Decade of War and Anguish, Dies at 64
LEAD: Jose Napoleon Duarte, the former President of El Salvador who oversaw a shaky experiment in centrist civilian government after nearly a century of military rule, died yesterday at his home in San Salvador, his doctor said.
He was 64 years old and had been diagnosed in May 1988 as having advanced liver cancer.


Germans Are Said to Weigh A Dual Rate on Currency
LEAD: In an effort to balance political expediency and economic wisdom, the West German Government is considering using more than one exchange rate in a monetary union with East Germany, Government officials said today.

LEAD: Ronald Reagan's videotaped testimony endangers a central defense contention in the upcoming trial of John M. Poindexter that the former President authorized Mr.
Poindexter's actions in the Iran-contra affair, several criminal lawyers said today.

LEAD: The delivery men arrive at the end of the business day, and an hour or two later, after they have hauled the heavy boxes into the house and begun installing your new washing machine or bolting together your new wall unit, a defect becomes obvious: a dent, a broken piece of trim, a missing shelf, or something else that is not right with a major purchase.


'Miss Margarida' Closing
LEAD: ''Miss Margarida's Way,'' a revival of the 1977 one-woman play starring Estelle Parsons, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street.
The show, written and directed by Roberto Athayde, will have run for 11 regular performances and 8 previews.

LEAD: Meyer Blinder, a founder of a large penny-stock brokerage, and four associates were indicted today in Las Vegas on Federal racketeering and securities fraud charges.

LEAD: When Andrew Dice Clay called himself ''the most vulgar, vicious comic ever to walk the face of the earth,'' as he did on stage Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, he left out two other adjectives: juvenile and calculating.

LEAD: In what is regarded as a pivotal victory for the prosecution, a judge ruled yesterday that incriminating statements by five of the six defendants in the Central Park rape case could be admitted as evidence.

LEAD: Officials at the Kennedy Space Center said today that they were cautiously optimistic about launching the space shuttle Atlantis and its secret payload early Sunday.
They said they expected a break in the bad weather that has been mainly responsible for delaying the craft's military mission.

LEAD: In what is thought to mark the first time that an entire educational campus was put on the auction block because of bankruptcy, Bishop College, once the largest black college in the Western United States, was sold this morning after years of scandal and financial distress.

LEAD: Renault, the state-owned automotive group that is France's biggest industrial concern, and Volvo, Sweden's leading industrial company, announced a far-reaching alliance today, under which each will own large shares of the other.

Corrections Corrections Corrections
LEAD: A subheading yesterday on an article about counseling of AIDS patients in New York referred incorrectly to the state's position on care in hospitals and nursing homes run by the Roman Catholic Church.
While the church opposes counseling AIDS patients on a number of matters, like sex safety practices, the state has not proposed forcing church-run institutions to counsel patients to ignore church doctrine.

D.&amp;H. Extension To March 23 Set
LEAD: The Interstate Commerce Commission extended an order allowing three regional railroads to continue operating until March 23 on the Delaware &amp; Hudson Railway tracks.
The order, which was initially scheduled to expire today, allows the New York, Susquehanna &amp; Western Railway, the Lackawanna Valley Railroad and the North Shore Railroad to use the tracks.

LEAD: ''Sweeney Todd,'' the York Theater production of Stephen Sondheim's 1979 musical with book by Hugh Wheeler, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Circle in the Square Theater, 254 West 50th Street.

Exploring a New Berlin
LEAD: BERLIN, it now seems likely, is to become once more the capital of the Germans.
In principle, that should make the city whole again, a megalopolis of three million people free to reclaim its place among the great centers of European culture and industry.
But it is hard to imagine how the return of the capital will do more than add one more Berlin to the bewildering set already shaped by a tortuous history.


Sampras Reaches Final
LEAD: For 18-year-old Pete Sampras, a draw that became progressively unkind to superstars and inspirational to newcomers allowed him to use a big serve and cool nerves to reach his first career final at the Ebel Pro Indoor tournament.
Already the youngest player entered in the event, today he became the youngest finalist since the tournament's inception 29 years ago.

Tangled roots perplex her ways,

WHEN BRITISH JUSTICE FAILED
LEAD: Court No. 2 of the somber Old Bailey Courthouse in London was packed to capacity last Oct. 19.
Ranks of wigged lawyers squeezed into the jury box.
A hundred reporters crowded the back benches; the public gallery was overflowing - but the courtroom was deathly silent.
As the Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord Lane, finished his summing up, his voice, quiet and restrained, carried to the back of the courtroom: ''These appeals are allowed and the convictions are quashed.


Flight Smoking Ban at Hand
LEAD: A Federal law that bans smoking on virtually all domestic airline flights takes effect Sunday.
Under the law, smoking will be allowed only on flights of six hours or more - that is, on some trips between Hawaii or Alaska and the 48 contiguous states.

Kabobs and Breads of Lucknow
LEAD: KABOBI-SHARABI is an old Urdu (the language of Moguls in India) expression.
Literally it means one who loves grilled meat (kabob) with wine (sharab).
In a broader sense it is ascribed to anyone who appreciates good living and delights in gastronomic pleasures.
Ask any kabobi-sharabi for the best in the world for kabobs and he will invariably point to Lucknow, the capital of Northern Province and the home of the great

LEAD: Unions, in recent years, have initiated strikes that have been costly to them, but owners of baseball's 26 teams appear to be losing their own lockout.

LEAD: Malcolm Forbes, chairman and editor in chief of Forbes magazine and one of the country's most flamboyant multimillionaires whose enthusiastic pursuits included yachting, motorcycling and ballooning, died yesterday of a heart attack in his sleep at his home in Far Hills, N.J.
He was 70 years old.

LEAD:
MAO TSE-TUNG AND HIS CHINA
By Albert Marrin.

Tokyo Teeters, But New York Holds Firm
LEAD: In October 1987 and again two years later, Wall Street started panics that spread around the world, only to be slowed and eventually halted in Tokyo.
Each time, the Japanese stock market slipped a little but soon rallied, to the great relief of traders everywhere.

Borrowing Trouble II
LEAD: The man who took television to new lows has reached one himself.
Morton Downey Jr., whose syndicated Morton Downey Jr.
Show was generally considered the prototype of ''shock television,'' filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition in Federal Court in New Jersey last week.
Mr.
Downey listed assets of more than $6.8 million and liabilities of about $2.4 million, but he apparently is having cash-flow problems.

He is a past chairman and a longtime member of the commission, not its founder.

Vincent Teresa, 61; Mafia Aide Became Informer and Author
LEAD: Vincent Teresa, a colorful, obese New England crime figure of the 1950's and 60's who became a Federal informer and later was a co-author of two books about his underworld experiences, died of kidney failure Wednesday in Seattle, The Associated Press reported.
He was 61 years old.

LEAD: Hilary Foretich, the 7-year-old girl at the heart of the country's best-known custody battle, went on a 15,000-mile odyssey in 30 months in hiding with her grandparents, traveling from Washington to Plymouth in western England to Christchurch, New Zealand, where her father located her a few days ago.

YEARNING FOR AN IRON HAND
LEAD: Bill Keller's account of Russian nationalism brought to memory tales of the Russian past on which I was weaned (''Russian Nationalists: Yearning for an Iron Hand,'' Jan. 28).
My Russian-born father would tell us about the events of the 1905 pogrom, when Cossacks broke into his home.
My grandmother hid him in a wardrobe closet and covered him with blankets to save him from the drunken attackers, who beat her furiously, with cries of ''Kill the Yids and save Mother Russia.


Soccer Leagues Merge
LEAD: The American Soccer League and the Western Soccer League have been merged into the American Professional Soccer League for marketing and business purposes.


Looking Good Under Pressure
LEAD: WHere are women in the world whose mascara never smudges.
Their lipstick never blurs, their noses never shine, their hair never droops or sags.
Or maybe it does, but we never see it.
The point is this: They don't spend hours planted before the mirror, fussing, primping and retouching their makeup.

LEAD: Walking through London's Eaton or Belgrave Squares, it seems as though life hasn't changed since these residential neighborhoods were orignally built in the early years of the 19th century.
The rows of terraced houses look as they always have on the outside, but inside many of the buildings have been completely renovated to function efficiently in the 20th century.

LEAD: THREADING electrical cable behind walls to extend existing circuits or to add new ones is seldom easy.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD: ''When my purpose tends to men, I always see burdened wretches, I have only the feeling of ridiculous objects.
Never [so]  in front of women, where I always find a way to isolate a few elements that satisfy the painter in me.'' So wrote Edouard Vuillard (1868-1940), a Parisian painter who never married, stayed home with maman and his sister and painted them repeatedly at their daily work as seamstresses.

Let Business Be Responsible
LEAD: To the Editor:


Food;   Homecoming
LEAD: When I was a small child in Chicago, my mother began what became a repeated chant: we must return one day to gu xiang, ''the village of our ancestors.'' She became more urgent with time as she began to fear she would be too old to make the journey.
And when China opened to travelers in 1978, my mother's determination grew.

LEAD: FIRST, one Roman Catholic bishop warned Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo of New York that he was in serious danger of going to hell, and the Archbishop of New York didn't disagree.
Now, the new bishop of Brooklyn has said that Mr.
Cuomo had better watch what he says in his home borough.


Quick, Wholesome Recipes With Lentils
LEAD: NOW that increased consumption of complex carbohydrates and fiber is recommended for a wholesome diet, lentils should be on the shopping list.
These tiny members of the legume family are delicious, versatile and easy to prepare.
Unlike most dried beans, they do not require presoaking.

During the 1980's, modems opened up a world of information, including electronic mail, computer data bases and services ranging from airline reservations to stock trading.

LEAD: THE Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry signed into law last summer was not just a simple matter of covering the depositors' losses.
To recoup what it can, the Government is obliged to sell off billions of dollars in foreclosed property it inherited from hundreds of insolvent thrifts.

Q and A
LEAD:
Caribbean Golf
Q.
We have chartered a yacht to sail in the Caribbean to celebrate our mother's 60th birthday.
The only way we could convince my brothers that this would be fun was to promise golf along the way.
Where can I get information on golf courses in the Leeward Islands and the Windward Islands?


Tunnel Vision
LEAD: Culturally speaking, it still has the ring of a contradiction in terms: a Los Angeles subway.
Nonetheless, ground was broken for the city's Metro Rail system more than three years ago.
And work on the first 4.4 miles - M.O.S. 1, or minimum operable segment - proceeds on schedule; Angelenos can anticipate underground travel beginning in the fall of 1993.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:
BORROWED TIME: An AIDS Memoir, by Paul Monette. (Avon, $8.95.) A poet chronicles the final year and a half of his lover's life, as his body succumbed step by step to AIDS. ''Fired with the knowledge that his own immune system was compromised, Mr.
Monette has etched a magnificent monument to his lover's bravery, their commitment to each other and the plague of hatred and ignorance they had to endure,'' William M.


Review/Music;   New Schnittke Quartet
LEAD: The Alban Berg Quartet brought Alfred Schnittke's newest string quartet (his fourth) to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon.
It is a piece that lives for its slow movements, of which there are three.


Outdoors;   Proposal for Salmon Fishery
LEAD: A proposal to use surplus brood stock of Atlantic salmon to provide a put-and-take sport fishery for the species in a section of the Merrimack River in New Hampshire has distressed many of those who have for years been laboring to restore spawning runs of those highly prized food and game fish to the rivers of New England.


Currency;   No Bottom Yet for the Yen
LEAD: Expect more skirmishes this week in the so-far losing battle to boost the swooning yen.
There was some hope last week that the yen would strengthen, given the victory on Sunday of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in Japan's national elections and the expectation that the Bank of Japan would soon raise its discount rate.

Some Small Joys On New Disks Of Italian Operas
LEAD: At hand are the five newest major-label recordings of mainstream Verdi and Rossini operas, and there is no use in delaying the report that all five are unsatisfying.
A grand old maestro with offbeat casting, dedicated restudying of scores through critical editions, a defiant stand in favor of ''traditional'' interpretation, superstar casting - nothing seems to work.

He also paid tribute to ''the endless heroes of youth . . .
You, the young lions have energized our entire struggle.'' Mr.
Mandela has become the living symbol of the struggle for black liberation.

Mexico's Dismal Debt Deal
LEAD: The jury is now in on the 1989 debt restructuring agreement between Mexico and the international financial community.
Unfortunately, the deal is a bad one for Mexico.
The agreement, signed on Feb. 4, falls far short of the country's needs, has not and will not produce the desired effects, and leaves the nation in a woefully weak position for future negotiations.

Warner released the film, which is rated R, on Feb. 8 at the price of $24.98, meaning that the studio thinks it should sell better than it rents.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a capsule listing of issues in medicine last Sunday, with a front-page article about doctors, misstated the percentage of black and Hispanic doctors for 1988.
Black doctors made up 3.3 percent of the profession; Hispanic doctors made up 4.7 percent.

Elegant, Practical Finnish Decorative Arts
LEAD: FINLAND is probably the only country in the world where the designers of mundane objects can achieve stardom.
The Finnish custom of lionizing artists started in 1900 when a team of architects and designers headed by Eliel Saarinen astonished the world with their realization of the national pavilion at the Paris World's Fair, an elaborate, shingled building in the National Romantic style.

Theyhave integrity.
And they are sexy.
Terms usually invoked to decribe friends, lovers, and sometimes, politicians, are the ones that crop up most when the topic turns to work clothes.
Mention any one of those familiar and functional items, ranging from T-shirts to overalls to fishermen's caps, and the conversation takes on a high tone with a sentimental edge.

The Executive Computer;   Can the Old Processing Technology Beat Back a Challenge?
LEAD: Some hot new processors still rely on Complex Instruction Set Computing.
THE Series 6000 work stations introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation earlier this month clearly demonstrate the fundamental speed advantages of the technology called Reduced Instruction Set Computing.
The RISC machines use a type of simplified processor chip that yields performance once found only among computers costing 10 to 100 times as much.

Galloping Gamay
LEAD: Sonoma-Cutrer, a prominent California winery, uses one grape and makes only one wine from it: chardonnay.
In this respect, Sonoma-Cutrer is unusual.
Many wineries make only one wine, but they use a number of grapes to do it.
For example, a Bordeaux chateau like Lafite-Rothschild makes only one wine, the world-famous red that bears its name, but it may use three, four or even five different grapes, in varying proportions.

Threading Fish Tape
LEAD: THREADING electrical cable behind walls to extend existing circuits or to add new ones is seldom easy.
But stiff, tempered-steel tape called fish tape is the tool designed for the job and professional electricians rely on it.
Fish tape is also used to route cable through conduit.


Abstraction Returns to Haunt Photography
LEAD: After a hiatus of more than 30 years, the specter of abstraction once again haunts the art of photography.
But today's version of abstract photography has little in common with the Abstract Expressionist style and high seriousness of work from the 1950's by Aaron Siskind, Minor White and others.
Instead, it seems suffused with a sense of belatedness and loss, as well as an acute awareness that abstraction functions as a sign of the realm of the spiritual.

Review/Theater;   'Burner's Frolic' Continues Fuller's Cycle
LEAD: With ''Burner's Frolic,'' the fourth in Charles Fuller's continuing cycle of plays about black Americans in the second half of the 19th century, one has a clearer picture of the playwright's ambitious intention.
Through a series of episodes, seemingly tangential in the sweep of American history, the playwright is scrutinizing the economic entrapment of people forced to weigh their pragmatic needs against their desire for complete emancipation and integration.

Question Box
LEAD:
The Gashouse Gang
Q.
During the 1930's, the St.
Louis Cardinals were referred to as The Gashouse Gang.
How did they acquire the nickname?
A.
There is more than one version of where the term for the scrappy Cardinal teams of the mid-30's came from, but the common thread is that it originated in New York City sometime in 1934 and that it mirrored the ragtag crowd of thugs, rowdies and misfits from the Gashouse District on the East Side of Manhattan, the area around 14th Street in which large gas tanks were housed.

Balls Recalled
LEAD: CALL it a safety-minded humanitarian gesture or a clever marketing ploy, but a leading manufacturer has stopped producing traditional baseballs for the youth market, issued a recall for those in circulation and called for other manufacturers to follow suit.
The company, Worth Inc., says it will replace any of its balls bearing a youth league stamp with a model it claims will virtually eliminate serious impact injuries among often inept, accident-prone young players without sacrificing so much as a single extra-base hit or short hop of performance.

This one, though, is better than most, primarily because it's loaded with estimable talent.

Reviews/Music;   Sadness and Serenity in an Evening of a Cappella Songs
LEAD: Chanticleer's evening of a cappella music at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday seemed more than anything an act of mourning.
All the component parts were constant in this otherwise far-flung program - sorrow, fear, resignation, hope.
These 12 male singers from San Francisco began with a Gregorian setting of the medieval hymn ''Ave Maris Stella,'' went on to Josquin's ''Missa Ave Maris Stella'' and then to a young Gyorgy Ligeti's versions of Central European folk songs.

Reviews/Music;   Mel Lewis Group Plays On Without Him

Review/Music;   Mozart to Mystical Messiaen From the Omega Ensemble
LEAD: There were neither novelties nor surprises among the works played by the Omega Ensemble on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

LEAD: At the end of ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' three young people of 1957, all with dreams of theatrical or literary glory, stand on a roof in New York City to spot Sputnik, a symbol of their high hopes, as it streaks across a starry sky.
Nine years after its failure on Broadway, ''Merrily'' continues to follow its own alluring, elusive trajectory through the musical theater.

LEAD: In baseball, history handcuffs certain batters and pitchers.

Digital to Offer Failure-Proof Unit

Fault-tolerant computers generally have several processors and special software that insures that data are not lost in the event of a failure.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
MARKETS
Japan's Government and the Tokyo Stock Exchange sought to calm investors amid the largest stock decline since the crash of October 1987.
The Bank of Japan offered short-term loans to banks to make sure the market had enough cash to operate.
The Finance Ministry bought bonds to push long-term interest rates lower.

Predators Influence Growth Of Snails
LEAD: COMMON freshwater snails hunted by crayfish grow larger, reproduce later in life and live longer than snails not exposed to the predator, researchers have found.


Israel Letting 16 Arab Colleges Reopen
LEAD: The Israeli military authorities announced today that they were allowing 16 community colleges in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to reopen.

Ambitious Effort Aims to Find Gravity Waves
LEAD: SCIENTISTS plan to embark on their most ambitious effort yet to find and exploit one of the most elusive of the predicted phenomena of nature: gravitational waves.
As long ago as 1915, Albert Einstein predicted in his general theory of relativity that the violent birth and death of stars in the universe would give off gravitational waves, bathing the earth in a unique kind of radiation.

Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Gorbachev Sees Havel and Agrees To Speed Withdrawal of Troops
LEAD: The Czechoslovak President, Vaclav Havel, and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, agreed today on a faster timetable for the Soviet troop withdrawal from Czechoslovakia as well as on an end to cold war intelligence cooperation directed against Western nations.


Bank Robbery Suspects Held
LEAD: Two men who lived near each other in Brooklyn were arrested yesterday and charged with two dozen bank robberies, Federal agents said.
The two knew each other but did not work together, the F.B.I. said.
Joseph Butler, 32 years old, of 300 Bushwick Avenue in the Williamsburg section, was accused of robbing 18 banks on a team that created diversions while a gunman held up tellers.

African Elder Trims One-Party Stand
LEAD: Julius K. Nyerere, a leading advocate and practitioner of one-party rule in Africa for the 25 years that he led this country before his retirement, has recently opened the door, if only gingerly, to a multiparty system in Tanzania.


Shortchanged by the Census?
LEAD: Why does the Census Bureau refuse to acknowledge that counting New York City is not like counting Salina, Kan.?
Because it is apparently playing politics: someone in Washington doesn't want an accurate count in largely Democratic urban areas.


Rig Count Drops Again
LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas continued to decline last week, falling by 21, to 897, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
But the count so far this year remains 19 percent above last year's 757, said Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist with Baker Hughes.
Mr.
Kerridge said the rig count generally declines in the first quarter and is expected to bottom out in March or April.


Grove Weidenfeld Says It Will Offer Itself for Sale
LEAD: Grove Weidenfeld, the book publishing company started in 1985 by Ann Getty and Lord Weidenfeld, will be offered for sale today, it was announced yesterday.
The decision was reportedly made by Mrs.
Getty, who is the financial backer of the money-losing company, and her advisers.

LEAD: Prices of precious metals plunged yesterday on extensive selling sparked by another sharp drop in share values in Japan.

Simmons said he would solicit proxies to remove the plan.

Dollar Up Broadly, Reaching 8-Month Highs Against Yen
LEAD: The dollar climbed broadly yesterday in foreign exchange trading, reaching its highest levels in eight months against the Japanese yen despite reported efforts by monetary authorities in Japan and the United States to curb its advance.

Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger
LEAD: By last winter, when she came to The Times for a brief visit, she had dwindled to a tiny sparrow.
But her eyes still flashed with curiosity, and curiosity is a word that tells much about the long and happy life of Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger.


Our Towns;   Basketball Guard Wins for Being Just Like the Rest
LEAD: Two days before Christmas in 1988, a car carrying Chris Samele and four other Torrington High School students skidded on an icy road, spun out of control and struck a guardrail.
Two students walked away unscathed, but Chris and two others were thrown out the back window.
Shawn Collins was killed.
Dawn Storrs was injured.

The Morning After in Nicaragua
LEAD: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's remarkable victory in Nicaragua is far from complete.
Her Sandinista opponents are still entrenched in power.
Her own supporters are deeply divided.
Her country's economy is a mess.
She'll need generous help, especially from Washington.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column of Business Day on Friday about the increasing use of sophisticated market research in motion picture advertising misstated the role of Seiniger Advertising for ''The Hunt for Red October.'' The agency was responsible for the creative work for the print advertising; it did not do the research for the advertising.

Pro Bono
LEAD: *
To attract younger volunteers, the American Red Cross introduced a television commercial yesterday in which the performers Carly Simon, Randy Travis, Branford Marsalis and Paul Shaffer do volunteer work to the music of the Rolling Stones' ''Gimme Shelter.'' The campaign was developed by the J. Walter Thompson Company in cooperation with the Ad Council.
