LEAD: Bernard G. Nemeroff, a lawyer and owner of the Dellwood Country Club in New City, N.Y., died of lung cancer on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach.
He was 82 years old and had lived in retirement in Miami Beach since 1979.

LEAD: Source Perrier S.A. said today that it would reintroduce its sparkling mineral water worldwide with new labels showing the contents were bottled after the contamination incident 10 days ago that forced a huge withdrawal of its products.

LEAD: A DC-10 was cruising 33,000 feet over the Amazon rain forest recently when a short, stocky man in blue jeans and a polo shirt barged into the cockpit. ''Hi, I'm Fernando Mesquita,'' the man announced, stretching out a hand to the startled pilots. ''See any fires down there?''

LEAD: An Ontario Supreme Court justice has ordered Olympia &amp; York Developments Ltd., which is owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto, to open its financial books.

Henry Fairlie, British-Born Writer On American Politics, Dies at 66
LEAD: Henry Fairlie, an expatriate British author and journalist who wrote about the American political scene, died of heart failure Sunday at George Washington University Medical Center in Washington.
He was 66 years old and lived in Washington.

South Africa's Defense Minister said he had halted all activities of a covert unit accused of killing apartheid foes, pending a judicial inquiry.

Large corporations are encouraging employees to step off the fast track, convincing many that they can find rewards in lateral mobility.

Cuomo and Florio Criticize Bush on Lack of Money for Education
LEAD: The Democratic governors of New York and New Jersey, both of whom face major budget problems at home, criticized the Bush Administration today for failing to commit Federal dollars to the education goals established on Sunday by the White House and the nation's governors.


Penobscot Journal;   Good Will Is Great, But Can It Fix a Road?
LEAD: No one in this bayside town of 1,200 people charges that local government has squandered money or even that property taxes are too high.
But on March 6, when townspeople gather for the annual town meeting, they will consider a petition to abolish property taxes.

JWP to Acquire Neeco for Stock
LEAD: JWP Inc., a supplier of water and maintenance services based in Purchase, N.Y., agreed to acquire Neeco Inc., a reseller of desktop computer systems based in Canton, Mass.
JWP said the transaction, which it valued at about $100 million, would be accomplished through an exchange of 0.523 share of JWP common for each


Jackson Says He Won't Run For Mayor of Washington
LEAD: After months of political pondering, the Rev.
Jesse Jackson announced today that he would not run in this year's race for mayor of the nation's capital.


Tribute to Helicopter Pilot Killed Chasing a Drug Suspect


IDEC Japan Link
LEAD: The IDEC Pharmaceuticals Corporation, a privately held biotechnology company based in La Jolla, Calif., entered an agreement with the Institute of Immunology Company of Tokyo under which IDEC will receive up to $23 million for product rights and equity from the Japanese biotechnology company.
Institute of Immunology, which is also privately held, will receive rights in Japan and certain Asian countries to develop IDEC therapeutic and diagnostic products and about 20 percent of IDEC's preferred stock.


Review/Music;   Merkin Program of Works by Baltic Composers
LEAD: In his programming for the New York University Chamber Music Society, Gregory Haimovsky, the group's artistic director, seems to be taking a stand on the separatist tensions that have lately been erupting in the Soviet republics.
As a follow-up to last season's Year in Russian Music series, he is now leading his ensemble through the Year in Eastern European Music.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about a plan to sell Puerto Rico's government-owned telephone company misidentified the head of the Puerto Rican Federation of Labor.
He is Federico Torres Montalvo.


Turnover in Nicaragua;   Nicaraguan Decade: War, Ruin and Turnabout
LEAD: 1978: Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, editor of the newspaper La Prensa, is shot to death on a Managua street by unidentified assassins, intensifying discontent that undermines the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza Debayle.


Explorers to Tackle Everest of Cave Systems
LEAD: BENEATH the Huautla plateau in the Mexican state of Oaxaca, the limestone is like Swiss cheese.
Water percolating down through the rock has carved out a complex network of tunnels, caverns and subterranean rivers, creating what is probably the world's deepest cave system, and presenting a challenge to adventurous speleologists.

A.T.P. Executive Switches Courts
LEAD: Hamilton Jordan's days are numbered as the chief executive officer of the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour, but he is not complaining.
Jordan, who has come under verbal attack lately by John McEnroe and Ivan Lendl, confirmed that he was vacating his position and would move into a role as chairman of the board as soon as an appropriate successor is found.


Corrections
LEAD: The Business Scene column yesterday misstated the reason Saks Fifth Avenue was put up for sale.
The action is part of a strategy by Saks's owner, B.A.T.
Industries P.L.C., to defend itself from a takeover.
It is not because of any bankruptcy filing.

On Secession: Too Little and Too Soon
LEAD: After irresponsibly encouraging Staten Island's ill-considered rush toward secession from New York City, Gov.
Mario Cuomo is now trying to calm things down.
He's pushing for a measure that would give the State Legislature final say over the borough's fate.
That's an improvement over the faulty measure he signed in December, which lets Staten Island act unilaterally.


Upheaval in the East;   Yugoslavs Are Bullish On a Stock Exchange
LEAD: The Belgrade stock exchange, the first of its kind in Communist-ruled Yugoslavia, reopened today after a break of almost half a century.


Southmark Is Sued by Unit
LEAD: The San Jacinto Savings and Loan Association has filed a $1.4 billion claim against its parent, the Southmark Corporation, saying Southmark had forced it to make bad loans.


CSX in Move To Free Cars
LEAD: To relieve a national shortage of grain-carrying rail cars, the CSX Corporation of Richmond said Friday that effective April 1 it would give shippers less time to load and unload cars.


Millrose Loses Sponsor
LEAD: The North American indoor track and field season had enough problems, with fewer meets this year, a paucity of records and declining attendance.
Now, the Panasonic Company has decided not to renew its sponsorship of the Millrose Games, leaving the country's most prestigious indoor track and field meet without vital financial assistance.


Nets Have Bowie Plan
LEAD: Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager, said yesterday that he hoped to sign Sam Bowie to a long-term contract before the season ends.
Bowie, the Nets' 7-1 center, will be a restricted free agent when his five-year contract expires.
The 28-year-old Bowie has expressed dissatisfaction that the Nets have yet to begin serious negotiations.


W. D. Manshel, 66; Magazine Publisher Was an Ambassador
LEAD: Warren D. Manshel, an investment banker and publisher who was Ambassador to Denmark under President Carter, died of heart failure on Sunday at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., where he was being treated for cancer.
He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Conrail Buyback
LEAD: Conrail said it had bought back 22.32 million of its shares - about one-third of its outstanding common stock - at $49 a share, or a total of more than $1 billion.
Under a previously announced ''Dutch auction,'' Conrail invited each shareholder to tender shares at a price between $43 and $53.
Conrail earlier announced it would repurchase the shares delivered at or below $49.

LEAD: Unable to enforce rules that prohibit people from sleeping on subway benches, the New York City Transit Authority is trying a new tack: removing the benches altogether.


Wal-Mart Net Jumps By 31.8%
LEAD: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. continued its rapid growth in the fourth quarter, with profits rising by 31.8 percent to $425.9 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with $323.2 million, or 57 cents in the year-ago period.
Sales in the quarter rose by 24.6 percent to $8.1 billion.

LEAD: Working conditions in the cramped regional mail center here are bad, postal officials concede.
The roof leaks, sorting is done on several levels and employees have only a third of the space they require.
In summer tents are put up.

President-elect Violeta Chamorro has begun preliminary talks with the defeated Sandinista Government on the first democratic transfer of power in Nicaraguan history.
The talks were called positive.

Harken Withdraws Offer for Tesoro
LEAD: The Harken Energy Corporation withdrew its offer to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation for $11.75 a share, or about $190 million, in cash.
Harken's chairman, Alan G. Quasha, said in a letter to Tesoro's chairman, Dr.
Richard V. West Jr., that Harken had concluded the San Antonio-based oil refining and marketing company's board was not interested in maximizing shareholder value.

Samuel R. Mozes Is Dead at 66; A Former New York City Planner
LEAD: Samuel R. Mozes, a city planner for more than a quarter-century and a figure in international Jewish affairs, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at his home in East Hampton, L.I.
He was 66 years old.


Hoare Govett Plan
LEAD: The securities house Hoare Govett Ltd. plans to offer its employees a 51 percent stake in the company when its owner, the Security Pacific Bancorporation, cuts its holding to 49 percent starting in mid-1990, a Hoare Govett spokeswoman said.


Leaked Ulster Document Suggests Divisions in 2 Protestant Parties
LEAD: A long-secret document outlining concessions that the two main Protestant parties in Northern Ireland are willing to make to break a political impasse in the British province was disclosed today in an Irish newspaper.


How Bases Came to Be In Democratic Districts
LEAD: To the Editor:


GORBACHEV FORCES BILL ON PRESIDENCY PAST LEGISLATURE
LEAD: Under fierce prodding from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Supreme Soviet gave initial approval today to his proposal to secure greater executive powers through the institution of a popularly elected presidency.


Trade Deficit Shrank in '89
LEAD: The United States trade deficit increased slightly in the fourth quarter of 1989 but narrowed to $113.2 billion for all of last year, its lowest level since 1984, the Government reported today.


The Kimbell Decides Its Building Is a Treasure to Be Cherished
LEAD: The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, responding to an outpouring of criticism of the additions it planned to its celebrated building by the architect Louis I. Kahn, announced yesterday that it had postponed the new structures indefinitely.


Eastern Requests Cash From Escrow
LEAD: Eastern Airlines said that with the support of its unsecured creditors, the carrier had asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan on Monday to release $60 million from an escrow account.
The account holds $557 million from sales of aircraft, routes and airport gates by the carrier since it filed for protection from its creditors on March 9 under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.


A $194.04 Million Offering Is Made by New York State
LEAD: New York State yesterday priced a $194.04 million issue of general obligation bonds and awarded the financing to a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Market.

WINE TALK
LEAD: ITALIAN wine prices have been going up, just like French, Spanish and American wine prices.
Even so, I would venture to say that there are more good Italian wines for under $20 than there are from any other country.
Moreover, more than a few of the lower-priced Italian wines are better than wines priced three times as high.


Kremlin Says It Found Secret Soviet-Nazi Pact
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Ministry has acknowledged that it has found copies of a secret Soviet-Nazi agreement that allotted parts of Eastern Europe to the Soviet Union.

Warsaw Fights for Role In German Unity Talks
LEAD: Increasingly worried that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has not renounced all claims to Polish territory, Poland is making a concerted diplomatic drive for a place at any international talks on German unification.

Eating Well
LEAD: FOOD manufacturers seem to have a penchant for taking nutritious foods and processing them to the point where they are no longer wholesome.
Potatoes are a good example.
In its purest form, a medium 5-ounce potato provides only 155 calories and is virtually free of fat and sodium.
Potatoes are also good sources of complex carbohydrates, fiber and vitamin B6, and excellent sources of vitamin


Guy Caesar Bauman, Met Art Historian, 38
LEAD: Guy Caesar Bauman, an art historian and assistant curator in the European paintings department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died of AIDS at his home on Sunday.
He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Jan. 29 about the efforts of Lewis du Pont Smith, an heir to the du Pont fortune, to regain control of his inheritance misidentified the publisher of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.
It is the American Psychiatric Association, not the American Medical Association.


New Pantheon Head Named Amid Resignation Protest
LEAD: Amid a growing portest from authors, Random House Inc. appointed Fred Jordan as vice president and publisher of Pantheon Books yesterday, effective March 15.


Review/Television;   Halting Time's Ravages So Art May Endure
LEAD: The ravages inflicted by time, nature and man on some of the world's most treasured monuments and works of art have received belated and somewhat panicky attention in recent years.
If you've wondered what is going on behind the scaffoldings and tarpulins that keep tourists from seeing what they came to see, tune into ''The Future of the Past.


Nicaraguan Envoys Resign Themselves To Sandinista Loss
LEAD: Sadness and perplexity hung over the Nicaraguan Embassy today, as diplomats and staffers resigned themselves to their imminent departure from Washington as a result of the Sandinista election defeat.


Tolls Gov. Florio Can Support
LEAD: Former Gov.
Thomas Kean of New Jersey did commuters no favor in December by blocking a proposed $1 toll increase on bridges and tunnels run by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
They are vital to the region's economic health and badly need maintenance, and the region's airports can no longer subsidize them.


Dollar Up Against the Yen Despite Bank Intervention
LEAD: The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen yesterday, reaching an eight-month high despite intervention by central banks.
It closed mixed against other currencies.


G.M. College Donations
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would donate about $35 million to colleges and universities in 1990.
Eighty percent of G.M.'s donations support science and engineering activities, while the rest goes to various business education programs, the company said.
G.M. has donated roughly the same amount to universities for each of the last five years, according to the company.


N.F.L. Lengthens Its Season To Fit New TV Arrangement
LEAD: To accommodate a huge new television deal, the National Football League will change its longstanding format of playing 16 consecutive weeks in the regular season.


Nets' Road Slump at 16 After Loss to Pacers
LEAD: Reggie Miller and Chuck Person each scored 25 points tonight as the Indiana Pacers handed the Nets their 16th straight road loss, 118-113.


No Old-Timers Voted Into the Hall of Fame
LEAD: For the second time in three years, the veterans committee has failed to add any old-timers to the Baseball Hall of Fame, shutting out for at least one more year such former players as Phil Rizzuto, Nellie Fox and Richie Ashburn.


EXXON IS INDICTED BY U.S. GRAND JURY IN SPILL AT VALDEZ
LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Anchorage today indicted the Exxon Corporation and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts stemming from the Alaskan oil spill, after negotiations between the Justice Department and the company on a settlement of the case broke down. .


New York to Add Lawyers For Surge in Youth Crimes
LEAD: New York City plans to double its staff of lawyers assigned to prosecute juveniles because of an enormous surge in Family Court cases as well as crimes, city lawyers told a City Council hearing yesterday.


Education;   School Turns Losers Into Winners
LEAD: Young Aaron Cann, a teen-age dropout from high school, was a tall, husky neighborhood bully who had lots of money.
With plenty of crack to sell and many customers, he had a lucrative business.


Victory Over TB Seen as Thwarted by Budget Unit
LEAD: Tuberculosis can be eliminated from the United States relatively cheaply and quickly, but the White House budget office has failed to ask for the small sum necessary, Federal health officials say.


Poland Resumes Full Diplomatic Ties With Israel
LEAD: Israel and Poland resumed full diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break.
Poland was the third Warsaw Pact country to renew relations with Israel in the last six months.


Why Teen-Agers Dress the Way They Do
LEAD: To the Editor:


47 KILLED IN INDIA AS 8 STATES VOTE
LEAD: At least 47 people were killed and 200 wounded by bombs, factional battles or the police today in voting for legislatures in eight Indian states, news agencies reported.

Adage Inc., Billerica, Mass., a computer graphics company, said its holders had approved the acquisition of the company by General Business Investment Corp., West Chester, Pa.


Education;   Bush Criticized on Schools
LEAD: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said today that President Bush was failing to back up his oratory about educational excellence with Federal money and the Administration's proposed 2 percent spending increase for schools was ''meager'' and ''tepid.''

LEAD: Because of a malfunction in The Times's newsroom computers, the Company Index is missing from this edition.
The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers.

New York Area Tour Shows Panel Havoc of AIDS
LEAD: Members of a Federal AIDS commission who toured New York City and northern New Jersey said yesterday that they had found the severity of the epidemic worse than they had feared.


Queens Raid Finds Counterfeit $18 Million
LEAD: Federal agents said yesterday that they had seized a printing press and more than $18 million in counterfeit money in an apartment at 1683 Cypress Avenue in Glendale, Queens.


Once Again, Oklahoma Trounces a Top-Ranked Team
LEAD: It's not clear what Kansas did to make Oklahoma angry, or what the Jayhawks took that belonged to the Sooners, but Oklahoma pounded the top-ranked Jayhawks tonight as if they had stolen something in administering a lopsided defeat.


Economic Scene;   So Long, Marlboro Man
LEAD: THE latest figures on death and destruction from tobacco, released last week by the Department of Health and Human Services, hold few surprises.
The $52 billion financial toll estimated for 1985 looks downright conservative next to the $65 billion calculation made five years ago by the Congressional Office of Technology


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
LEAD: Sue Parento has joined Young &amp; Rubicam as senior vice president and associate creative director.


Noodles for Soviets
LEAD: The Samyang Food Company of South Korea hopes to export its ramen fast-food noodles to the Soviet Union by April, the company said today.
The company plans to test the market with a shipment of $20,000 worth of noodle packages.
South Korea has no formal diplomatic relations with Moscow but has been trying to improve ties recently.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We can talk openly about sex, violence, war, condoms and deviant behavior on television, in the newspaper and on the floor of the Congress.
Yet we cannot seem to talk honestly and openly about whether we need more or less taxes, more or less spending, or what, if anything, we should do about the rising cost of entitlements.


Joint Venture Expected For Display Screens
LEAD: Several electronics companies are discussing the formation of a venture to develop and produce display screens for use in laptop computers, military gear and television sets, an official involved in the venture said today.


A Darwinian Creation of Software
LEAD: A fledgling science that creates software whose behavior mimics that of living creatures is beginning to provide scientists with a new class of software tools with significant commercial potential.


The Sauce Is Tangy, The Joking Tasteless
LEAD: Christopher Carroll has heard all the jokes already, thank you.
About how this is a spicy story.
A hot controversy.
A messy situation that drips with drama.


Tokyo Stock Market: Island No Longer
LEAD: The turbulence in the Tokyo financial markets in the last week has shown that the influence of one nation's market on another's, a process that has been dubbed globalization, is in some ways more powerful but works in more subtle ways than had been thought.
It has also provided a vivid lesson of how much Japan's financial markets, now the world's largest, have changed in the last two years because of the easing of financial regulations and the rise of


Chronicle


Mitchell Set to Move a Clean Air Bill to Senate Floor
LEAD: As bargaining on clean air legislation continued out of the public eye, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, insisted today that he would bring legislation back to the floor Thursday, with or without an agreement with the Bush Administration.


Ritter and Macchiarola Quitting Covenant House
LEAD: The Rev.
Bruce Ritter, who has been battling allegations of financial and sexual misconduct for three months, resigned last night as the head of Covenant House, which he built from two apartments in lower Manhattan into apartments in lower Manhattan into a network of 17 centers serving 25,000 youths.


Bridge
LEAD: Each year three Charity Games are played throughout North America, and each generates close to $70,000 for the American Contract Bridge League's Charity Foundation.
The same deals are played in every club, and the players receive an analysis sheet with an expert prediction of the likely course of bidding and play.


Turnpike Sidesteps Confrontation And Votes to Keep Present Tolls
LEAD: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority voted yesterday not to raise tolls this year, sidestepping a threatened showdown with Gov.
Jim Florio.


France Is to Pay 80% of Cost of Abortion Pill
LEAD: The French Government announced today that it would subsidize the cost of using a pill that induces abortion, known as RU 486, after 34,000 abortions were carried out free of charge with the method in the last 21 months.


Celtic Pact for Shaw
LEAD: The Boston Celtics announced yesterday they had reached agreement on a multiyear contract with the guard Brian Shaw beginning next season.


Catholic Group Urges Sweeping Change in Church
LEAD: A group of Roman Catholics from Chicago is seeking 100,000 signatures on an appeal for major changes in the Catholic Church.
They would include the ordination of women and married people to the priesthood, widespread consultation with believers in developing church teaching about sexuality and the participation of priests and lay people in the selection of bishops.

Nova Scotia Prices 9 1/4% Debentures
LEAD: The Province of Nova Scotia yesterday priced $300 million in 9 1/4 percent debentures due in 2020 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


Critic's Notebook;   Rock Music of Eastern Europe: So Western, So Familiar, So Old
LEAD: My visitor was a Hungarian rock musician, in Manhattan for a short time, who had dropped by to tell me about his band.
Soft-spoken, amiable and fairly fluent in English, he was Attila Grandpierre, the main ''howler'' of a group called Vagtazo Halottkemek, the Galloping Coroners.


Benjamin F. Schwartz, Navy Prosecutor, 80
LEAD: Benjamin F. Schwartz, a prosecutor with the Navy, died of heart failure on Sunday.
He was 80 years old.

Disease Control Center Says AIDS Shouldn't Bar U.S. Entry
LEAD: The Centers for Disease Control has recommended that AIDS and all other contagious diseases except tuberculosis be removed from a list of illnesses that is used to bar people from entering the United States, Federal officials said.


Looking to '92
LEAD: At the National Governors' Association dinner here on Monday, the Rev.
Jesse Jackson worked the crowd and chatted with other guests about his decision not to run for mayor of Washington.
He talked about concentrating on winning statehood for the District of Columbia and improving the moral tenor of the scarred capital.


At Prague Colleges, Marxism Withers Away
LEAD: Sitting in his half-emptied office, Prof.
Zdenek Safar mulls over his future.
For most of the last two decades, the 42-year-old instructor has taught Marxist-Leninist philosophy.


Medflies and Malathion
LEAD: The city fathers of Pasadena, Calif., sent up their police helicopter last Thursday night.
Its task was to ticket some helicopters engaged by the state to spray the dreaded Mediterranean fruit fly.
The bust was observed, of course, by a fleet of television helicopters.
It's hard not to wonder if the fight between the fly and its foes hasn't lost touch with the ground.


Shuttle Workers Load Fuel for New Liftoff Effort
LEAD: After taking a 48-hour break in hopes of better weather and luck, mission controllers prepared today for another attempt to launch the space shuttle Atlantis.

Producer Talks of Rooney's Return Soon
LEAD: The executive producer of ''60 Minutes'' yesterday attributed a recent drop in the program's ratings in large part to the suspension of Andy Rooney and, in a memo posted at the CBS Broadcast Center, told staff members that the commentator ''will soon be coming back.''


Sandinista Leaders, Facing Defeat, Didn't Argue, Carter Says
LEAD: When Sandinista leaders discovered on Sunday evening that they were losing their country's first free and broadly contested national elections, they made no attempt to keep power or dispute the results, former President Jimmy Carter said today.

A Florida Hotel Where a Rabbi Opens The Restaurant and Kosher Prevails
LEAD: ALONG with requests for water or more rolls, patrons at the lobby restaurant in the Hyatt Orlando hotel here often ask for something more: a rabbi.


Rust Succeeds Berry As Coach of Patriots
LEAD: Rod Rust, who spent 14 seasons as a National Football League assistant, became the second oldest head coach in the league yesterday, taking over the New England Patriots a day after the team dismissed Raymond Berry.


The Easily Handled Phyllo Pastry Challenges Its Puffy Rival
LEAD: A ONCE-IN-A-GENERATION change has been taking place in restaurant kitchens across the country with little notice.
Phyllo, the flaky, thin pastry of the Middle East, has slowly but most certainly been replacing the finicky puff pastry that classical chefs both adore and curse.


Cornell Gunter, 53, Member of Coasters
LEAD: Cornell Gunter, the lead singer of the Coasters, the doo-wop group whose hit recordings in the late 1950's included ''Yakety Yak'' and ''Charlie Brown,'' was shot dead here in his car on Monday, the police said today.
He was 53 years old.


BOEING WINS PLEA ON SEVERENCE PAY
LEAD: Unanimously rejecting the Justice Department's interpretation of a Federal ethics law, the Supreme Court ruled today that Congress has not barred private employers from giving lump-sum severance payments to employees about to enter Government sevece.

She replaces Donald W. Lohin, who is leaving the company.


Parcel Bomb Wounds Leading Spanish Judge
LEAD: A parcel bomb severely wounded the president of Madrid's High Court today, the police said.


Lenders Say Managua Has a Long Road Back
LEAD: Despite a newly proclaimed eagerness by the Bush Administration and the World Bank to breathe new life into Nicaragua's economy, economists predict that the rebuilding will take years after more than a decade of war and a United States-sponsored trade embargo.

Reviews/Music;   Arleen Auger Song Recital Stays an All-German Affair
LEAD: Arleen Auger's recital of German lieder at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening showed intelligence even in its choice of encores.
Evidently counting on the fact that few in the audience would leave (few did), Miss Auger parceled out a set of songs by Richard Strauss one at a time with spoken introductions and translations, nicely rounding out a program comprising Schubert, Wolf and Strauss in the first half and Schoenberg and

LEAD: Tickets to Met home games will go on sale at 9 A.M. tomorrow at Shea Stadium and at all Ticketron outlets as well as through the Ticketron phone charge service.


Market Place;   Investors Return to Stock Funds
LEAD: Despite a choppy stock market in February, investors resumed their purchases of stock mutual funds at a rapid rate, fund managers said yesterday.
Investors had moved out of such funds in January for the first time in seven months.

Centaur Settles Part of Legal Fight
LEAD: Centaur Partners said it and National Intergroup had settled half of a legal fight between the two parties in Delaware State Court.
Under the agreement, disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, National Intergroup has allowed Centaur to solicit consents from the company's shareholders to force the election of a majority of the board at the company's next annual meeting, without starting the company's anti-takeover plan.


Gasoline Prices Plummet As Ample Supply Is Seen
LEAD: Prices of gasoline futures plunged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in a selloff linked to perceptions of ample near-term supplies.
Other petroleum futures also retreated.

Now Batting in Birmingham
LEAD: Major league baseball's stodgy owners are advised to note what's happening in minor-league Birmingham, Ala.
The Japanese are coming.
Suntory International, the American subsidiary of the largest privately owned company in Japan, is buying the Birmingham Barons, the hottest team in the Southern League.

U.S. to Aid Negotiations On Contra Repatriation
LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that they would try to arrange negotiations between the Nicaraguan guerrillas and the new President-elect of Nicaragua so that the contras could disband and return home as soon as possible.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD:
AFTER FEBRUARY
When winter winds prevail
and rain comes down to soak us,
And all our dreamings fail,
And life slips out of focus.
What I would give to have
The chutzpah of the crocus!
DORIS KLEIN

LEAD: Federal health officials recommended yesterday for the first time that all Americans, not just those with high cholesterol levels, reduce the fat content of their diets to lower their risk of heart disease.

The Spare-No-Cost Wedding Regains Popularity in China
LEAD: After lavishing cigarettes and wine upon his wedding guests, Quan Xinguo hugged his new wife and chortled with delight over the sumptuousness of the nuptial celebrations.
After all, they had cost nearly $6,000, or more than six years' wages.


Education;   Cold War Test Questions: Pretending Won't Do
LEAD: State education officials hastily decided today to scrap outdated questions about Eastern Europe on a sixth-grade social studies test instead of asking pupils, as test administrators had planned, to pretend that the cold war was still being waged.


Panel Questions Credibility Of Nuclear Health Checks
LEAD: A special panel has concluded that the program for monitoring the health of workers in the nuclear weapons industry should be moved from the Department of Energy to another Federal agency because the program's credibility has been damaged.


Study Weighs Race as Death Penalty Factor
LEAD: The death penalty is more likely to be the sentence when a white is killed than when a black is killed, a Congressional report said Monday.


Reviews/Dance;   Cool Passion From Robbins And City Ballet
LEAD: ''Other Dances,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, is Jerome Robbins at his most sophisticated.
An extended pas de deux set to Chopin piano pieces, the ballet has the music's teasing folk accents but is essentially a dance of stylized abandon and cool passion, founded in the classical ballet technique, for two playful and dreaming lovers.


25 Are Hurt as Storm Floods Welsh Village
LEAD: Raging seas, whipped up by a storm that has killed 51 people in Europe, surged through a shattered sea wall and swamped homes in this coastal village today.


Pungent Wisdom From A Kitchen Olympian
LEAD: MIDWINTER rain fell in a contemplative pitter-patter on the stucco hacienda tucked in the hills.
A calico cat sat rigid as a sphinx on the back stoop of the ranch, glaring at the heavy wooden door.
But a guest standing inside saw only miles of vineyards, parched from a dry season, turning their pruned tips toward the sky.

LEAD: A clean, efficient and low-maintenance home heating system of the future may run on coal.

LEAD: Tired of being confused with the bus company it sold off in 1987, the Greyhound Corporation changed its name yesterday to the Greyhound Dial Corporation.

LEAD: New Forum, the mass citizens' movement that played the leading role in the overthrow of Communist rule last autumn, has fallen from elation into dejection now that its victory appears complete.

Offer for Pop Radio
LEAD: The Heritage Media Corporation, which already owns about 57 percent of the common shares of the Pop Radio Corporation, said Monday that it had offered to acquire the rest for $20.50 a share.
Pop Radio said the Kaufmann Fund and Pop Radio's president, Robert F. Hussey, and chairman, Robert K. Gray, who own 437,766 Pop common shares, or 12.2 percent, had granted Heritage proxies to vote their shares in favor of the new proposal.


New No-Fat Dessert Gets a Taste Test
LEAD: THE ice cream of 19th-century America was so rich in butterfat that it was considered too sinful to eat on the Lord's day, especially if doused with sauce or syrup.
According to the Ice Screamers, an association of ice cream historians in Philadelphia, an enterprising soda jerk coined the term ''sundae'' as a code word, to save would-be sinners the embarrassment of actually articulating their desire for the forbidden treat.


Fed Chairman Criticizes Social Security Tax Cut
LEAD: As lawmakers continued to grapple for a response to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes, Alan Greenspan, who as chairman of the Federal Reserve is the Government's most influential economic policy maker, said today that Mr.
Moynihan had properly diagnosed a crippling national problem but had prescribed the wrong medicine.


After 10 Years, Queen Gives Up Hotel Scepter
LEAD: Leona Helmsley loved her image as the queen of the hotel chain she runs.
And she fiercely guarded it.
When one advertising executive proposed an ad that featured the arm of a model reaching for a towel in a Helmsley hotel, she scrapped the idea. ''The only arm in these ads is going to be mine,'' she told the executive.


DIVISIONS HARDEN IN LEBANESE FIGHT
LEAD: After a month of bitter fighting between rival factions, Lebanon's 300-square-mile Christian enclave has been partitioned into war zones, further splintering this divided country.


Orchestra of Nice Cancels
LEAD: The Nice Philharmonic Orchestra has canceled its 1990 North American tour because a French Government subsidy needed to cover costs was eliminated.
The tour was to have included a concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, March 25.
The Carnegie Hall Subscription Office will mail refunds to subscribers.
Information: 247-7800.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a rise of almost 9.2 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-February.

Restaurant Gunfire Kills 2
LEAD: A man shot and killed one person and critically wounded another in a downtown restaurant early this morning and then was himself shot to death by the police.
The Police Chief, Don Millhouse, said the gunman had begun firing after ''some kind of an argument started, we don't know what about.'' The Chief said the names of those shot would not be disclosed until relatives were notified.

LEAD: In a move intended to raise cash for its automotive operations, the Chrysler Corporation today confirmed plans to sell and lease back the sprawling technology center it is building in a Detroit suburb.


Cox Broadcasting Post
LEAD: Nicholas D. Trigony has been named president of the broadcasting division of Cox Enterprises Inc. of Atlanta.
The 49-year-old Mr.
Trigony will succeed Stanley G. Mouse, who is 68, when he retires on Wednesday, Cox Enterprises said.
Mr.
Trigony is executive vice president for the division, which is responsible for Cox's seven television stations, five AM radio stations and seven FM outlets as well as Telerep, a national television sales representation concern.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McCall's to Revamp Over Next 6 Months
LEAD: Beginning with the April issue, readers of McCall's will be able to watch the magazine reshape itself during the next six months.
The redesign will feature a cover that the publisher says is less cluttered.
There will also be more emphasis on home fashion and furnishings.
The redesign is an attempt to separate the women's service magazine from its six primary competitors.

LEAD: A group of shareholders of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation has settled a dispute over the use of $86 million in Occidental funds to build an art museum for Armand Hammer, the company's chairman and chief executive.
Another group, however, said it would oppose the proposed settlement when the class action lawsuit comes up for approval in Delaware Chancery Court on April 4.

LEAD: In an unprecedented move, an American university and a South African university are starting a joint program aimed at training black, Indian and mixed-race South Africans for business management posts in the racially divided nation.

LEAD: A Mount Vernon man has been charged with murder and arson in the weekend fire that killed a man here and left 20 people homeless, the police said today.
The arson, they said, apparently was prompted by an argument involving a woman, a former companion.

Jessica B. Harris with characteristic acerbity.

LEAD: Raymond Griffin, a 5-year-old boy who the police said was given 10 ounces of whisky at a party at his house and told to ''drink it like a man,'' was in a coma today and reported to have irreversible brain damage.
Anthony Jimerson of Fort Worth, a 21-year-old guest at the party, was arrested on charges of injury to a child.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: THE term chopped beefsteak may sound like menu jargon for hamburger, but the recipe here is really much more than just run-of-the-mill burgers with melted cheese.
For one, it begins with about one-and-a-half pounds of beef cut from the round.
This is slightly more expensive than regular hamburger from chuck, but far superior.

Review/Music;   Love and Fidelity in Mozart's Harem
LEAD: Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera's repertory on Monday evening, is typical of his later works in that seriousness and comedy are so intertwined that it is pointless to wonder where the one leaves off and the other begins.
Even in this lighthearted singspiel about the attempted abduction of an English woman from a Turkish harem there are sober undercurrents.

LEAD: Lufthansa, the West German airline, said it was in talks to buy a small stake in Interflug, East Germany's state carrier.

Changes in Japanese Cabinet Set Off a Debate
LEAD: Toshiki Kaifu was formally re-elected Prime Minister on Tuesday and was immediately plunged into disputes over the composition of his Cabinet, including the ouster of the ruling party's most prominent woman.


Honda Export Plan
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company plans to export a United States-made Accord station wagon to Europe, Honda's chief executive, Tadashi Kume, said.
Honda will begin making the Accord wagon at its assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, later this year for the 1991 model year.
Honda's Marysville plant now makes the Civic and Accord models.

LEAD: The Northrop Corporation pleaded guilty today to failing to conduct tests and to pay a $17 million fine, one of the largest penalties ever imposed on a military contractor.

LEAD: Senator Juan Ponce Enrile, the former Defense Minister who helped install President Corazon C. Aquino in the 1986 election and revolt that toppled the Marcos dictatorship, was arrested today in connection with a coup attempt that nearly overthrew the Aquino Government in early December.

LEAD: William Earl Buckler, a specialist in Victorian literature and a former dean of New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Sciences, died of cancer on Sunday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.

LEAD: In a decision that will help many of the nation's biggest companies fend off hostile takeovers, a three-judge panel of the Delaware Supreme Court ruled yesterday that corporations have a right to decide their own future rather than sell to the highest bidder.


About Education
LEAD: Advocates of children's television are poised to open an offensive in Congress next month against the network deregulation put in place by President Reagan.
They hope to reverse a trend - the shrinking time given to children's programs and the growing time given to commercials beamed at children.
After a decade of defeat, they are optimistic about their chances of victory.

Review/Music;   A Russian Opera And a Work By Weill
LEAD: How much of Dmitri Shostakovich resides in ''Rothschild's Violin'' is something we shall never really know or perhaps need to.
The one-act opera after Chekhov's story was left incomplete by Shostakovich's pupil Benjamin Fleischmann before he marched off to die in defense of Leningrad during 1941.
The Juilliard Opera Center made ''Rothschild's Violin'' part of its double bill at the school on Friday night, joining it with Kurt Weill's hybrid stage work of 1933, ''The Seven Deadly Sins.


Grateful Havel Honors Soviet Foes of Invasion
LEAD: In a display of care for the embattled tradition of dissent in the Soviet Union, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia met today with the few Soviet citizens who criticized the Kremlin's invasion of Czechoslovakia 22 years ago and suffered beatings and exile as a result.


United Brands
LEAD: The United Brands Company announced it would change its name to Chiquita Brands International Inc., effective March 20.
The change is intended to increase the Cincinnati-based company's recognition, but will not alter its business strategy, said Keith E. Lindner, president and chief operating officer.
